Site is located on the southwest corner of Warren and Dudley Streets in Brookline, south of Route 9, near the Brookline Reservoir.

Site is 0.7 miles from the Brookline Hills MBTA stop on the Green Line, D Branch.

entrancePasses.description: No entrance passes required.
entrancePasses.title: No Entrance Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Summer: Warm temperatures, average high temperature around 80 degrees Fahrenheit, often with humidity. July and August bring the hottest temperatures.
Fall: Cooler temperatures, mean temperatures between 45 and 65 degrees Fahrenheit, sometimes rainy. Peak fall foliage is in mid-October.
Winter: Cold, with snow, average low temperature around 25 degrees Fahrenheit. 
Spring: Cold to cool temperatures, average mean temperatures between 40 and 60 degrees Fahrenheit.
properties.name: Frederick Law Olmsted
properties.description: Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903) is recognized as the founder of American landscape architecture and the nation's foremost parkmaker. Olmsted moved his home to suburban Boston in 1883 and established the world's first full-scale professional office for the practice of landscape design. During the next century, his sons and successors perpetuated Olmsted's design ideals, philosophy, and influence.

images.altText: Fairsted
images.title: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
images.caption: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site

properties.fullName: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter the site, and reservations are not required. However, you may wish to confirm visiting hours prior to your arrival by contacting the rector at 215-389-1513.
entranceFees.title: Gloria Dei Church fee

properties.directionsInfo: The Gloria Dei Church is accessed from Christian Street in South Philadelphia. As in any city, use your street smarts and do not leave any valuables visible in your car. Several SEPTA bus routes serve the vicinity of the site.  Visit the website for more information.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
properties.name: Gloria Dei Church
properties.description: Before Pennsylvania there was New Sweden. Discover this last historic link to a forgotten past. Visit the church's pastoral surroundings and its burial ground of patriots and ordinary citizens alike.

images.altText: A color photo of the Gloria Dei Church steeple during a sunset in Philadelphia.
images.title: Steeple of the Gloira Dei Church
images.caption: The Church building at Gloria Dei 'Old Swedes' has been in use since 1700, making it the oldest church building in Pennsylvania and the second oldest in the United States.  The steeple was completed in 1703.

images.altText: A color photo of the Gloria Dei Church yard showing tombstones with the church in the background.
images.title: Gloria Dei Chuch yard
images.caption: Gloria Dei Church was designated as a National Historical Site in 1942. The Gloria Dei congregation owns and maintains the church and the related buildings, its ministry and the grounds.

images.altText: A color photo of the interior of Gloria Dei Church showing the pulpit and a stained glass window.
images.title: Interior of the Gloria Dei Church
images.caption: Situated above the pulpit is the only stained glass window in the church building.  Created in the mid 1800's, the window is the earliest example of American stained glass among the 3600 windows in the Philadelphia region.

images.altText: A 19th century photograph of the Gloria Dei Church, with the cemetery in the foreground.
images.title: The Gloria Dei Church c.1850
images.caption: This 1850's photograph shows a bird's-eye view of the Gloria Dei Church, with the cemetery in the foreground, with the masts of ships visible in the background.

images.altText: A color photo of a model tall ship hanging inside Gloria Die Church.
images.title: Model of a ship hanging inside Gloria Dei Church
images.caption: Hanging from the ceiling of Gloria Dei are models of the two ships that brought the first Swedish colonists to North America in 1638, the "Kalmar Nyckel" and the "Fogel Gryp."

properties.fullName: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: All tours of the John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site are free of charge.
entranceFees.title: None

properties.directionsInfo:
By Subway: Take Green line ("C" -Cleveland Circle) trolley to Coolidge Corner stop. Walk four blocks north on Harvard Street, turn right on Beals Street and continue to number 83.

By Car:  From Exit 18 (I-90 E) or Exit 20 (1-90 W) follow the Allston/Brighton exit ramp, merge onto Cambridge Street and go one mile. At the fourth light, turn left on Harvard Street and proceed about one mile. Turn left on Beals Street and go to number 83. Limited Street Parking available.
properties.weatherInfo: Typical New England Weather: Warm, humid summers and cold winters. Any available outdoor programs take place rain or shine.
properties.name: John Fitzgerald Kennedy
properties.description: As a boy, JFK’s parents never expected he would grow up to be president. Yet in his birthplace home he learned values that inspired a life in public service. His mother, Rose Kennedy, recreated her family’s first home to share her memories of those early years with visitors. We commemorate not only his early life, but the ideas and principles he left behind.

images.altText: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
images.title: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
images.caption: Photograph of the birthplace of John F. Kennedy on Beals st. in Brookline, MA

properties.fullName: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site is a fee free site. This includes all tours and special events.
entranceFees.title: Fee Information

properties.directionsInfo: Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters NHS is located in a residential section of Cambridge, MA. There is very little public parking in the area and onsite parking is limited to vehicles with handicapped parking permits. However, the site is a short walk from Harvard Square, where there are paid parking lots and a station for the MBTA Red Line and numerous bus routes. The use of public transportation to the site is highly recommended. Follow the link for detailed instructions.
properties.weatherInfo: New England weather is highly variable. Temperatures in the winter can be very cold with high snowfall. Fall and spring are generally pleasant. Summer temperatures are generally mild, with periods of heat and humidity. However, the house is air conditioned and heated for collection care and the comfort of the visitor.
properties.name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters
properties.description: Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site preserves the home of Henry W. Longfellow, one of the world’s foremost 19th century poets. The house also served as headquarters for General George Washington during the Siege of Boston, July 1775 - April 1776. In addition to its rich history, the site offers unique opportunities to explore 19th century literature and arts.

images.altText: house covered with new fallen snow
images.title: Winter at Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
images.caption: New fallen snow blankets the historic mansion.

images.altText: mansion highlighted by the changing colors of fall
images.title: Longfellow House-Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
images.caption: Thousands tour the historic headquarters of George Washington and home of Henry Longfellow each summer.

images.altText: garden back dropped by house
images.title: Longfellow Family Garden
images.caption: The Longfellow Family Garden provides a peaceful getaway in the heart of Cambridge.

images.altText: large crowd on the east lawn listening to singers perfom
images.title: Summer Festival Concert
images.caption: Each year is highlighted by the Summer Festival on the house's east lawn.

images.altText: children interacting with puppet
images.title: Fun for All Ages
images.caption: Special events create fun for all ages.

images.altText: reenactors in front of house
images.title: The General Finds His Park
images.caption: You never know who you might find!

images.altText: pink flower in garden
images.title: Longfellow Family Garden
images.caption: Vibrant colors abound throughout the year in the Longfellow Family Garden.

properties.fullName: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate 95 North, take Exit 23 - State Offices. Take a left at the light to the bottom of Orms Street. At light, right onto Charles Street; continue straight through one light, then quick left into memorial parking lot.

From Interstate 95 South, take Exit 23 - Charles Street. Take first left onto Ashburton Street and continue straight through three lights. After the third light, take a quick left into the memorial parking lot.
properties.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures range from 56-83F. Fall temperatures range from 30-70F. Winter temperatures range from 20-45F. Spring temperatures range from 30-70F.
properties.name: Roger Williams
properties.description: Roger Williams National Memorial commemorates the life of the founder of Rhode Island and a champion of the ideal of religious freedom. Williams, banished from Massachusetts for his beliefs, founded Providence in 1636. This colony served as a refuge where all could come to worship as their conscience dictated without interference from the state.

images.altText: Native garden in the foreground with the visitor center in the back.
images.title: Native American Garden and Visitor Center
images.caption: The visitor center also features a Native American Garden.

images.altText: A colonial kitchen garden with grenery growing.
images.title: Colonial kitchen garden
images.caption: Come learn about history in our colonial kitchen garden.

images.altText: View of the park in early spring.

images.caption: View of the park in early spring.

images.altText: Historic marker in the snow.

entranceFees.description: Entrance and all events are free.
entranceFees.title: Women's Rights Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: From the New York State Thruway (I-90) take exit 41 (Route 414). Turn right onto Route 414 South after exiting the tollbooth. Follow Route 414 South for approximately four miles. At the intersections of Route 414 and Routes 5 & 20, turn left onto Route 5 & 20 East. Follow for approximately one and a half miles into the Village of Seneca Falls. The Visitor Center is on the left at 136 Fall Street, Seneca Falls, NY 13148.
properties.weatherInfo: In the winter, temperatures range from 0-40 degrees with an average of 10 inches of snow per month. Summer temperatures range from 60-85 degrees with high humidity.
properties.name: Women's Rights
properties.description: Women’s Rights National Historical Park tells the story of the first Women’s Rights Convention held in Seneca Falls, NY on July 19-20,1848.  It is a story of struggles for civil rights, human rights, and equality, global struggles that continue today.  The efforts of women’s rights leaders, abolitionists, and other 19th century reformers remind us that all people must be accepted as equals.

images.altText: The Wesleyan Chapel in summer
images.title: Wesleyan Chapel
images.caption: The Wesleyan Chapel, site of the first Women's Rights Convention

images.altText: Front of Women's Rights National Historical Park Visitor Center
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitors can come to learn about the largest social movement in history, the women's rights movement.

images.altText: The Elizabeth Cady Stanton House with a tree and National Park Service sign in the front yard
images.title: Elizabeth Cady Stanton House
images.caption: Take a ranger led tour in the home where Elizabeth Cady Stanton led the women's rights movement and raised 7 children

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to visit Tupelo National Battlefield. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: No entrance fee

properties.directionsInfo: Tupelo National Battlefield (NB) is a one-acre monument located on Main Street, Tupelo, Mississippi. Main Street in Tupelo is also known as Highway 6 and Highway 278. Tupelo NB sits on the south side of Main Street on the west side of Tupelo. Exit off the Natchez Trace Parkway onto Highway 6 (near Milepost 260), head east, into Tupelo. Travel one mile east and find Tupelo NB on the right side of Main Street. There is limited parking available adjacent to the monument.
properties.weatherInfo: Mississippi is classified as a humid subtropical climate, the weather ranges from mild winters to hot summers with high humidity between May and September. Average high temperatures reach into the high 80's in summer, and into the high 40's in winter. Check local forecasts to plan your trip.
properties.name: Tupelo
properties.description: In July, 1864, Union forces, including men from the United States Colored Troops, marched into Tupelo, Mississippi.  Disorganized Confederate soldiers fought fiercely but could not overpower the federal troops.  Neither side could claim a clear victory, but Union troops had succeeded in their main goal:  keeping the Confederates away from Union railroads in Tennessee.

images.altText: The monument with a cannon
images.title: Tupelo National Battlefield Monument
images.caption: In July, 1864, Union forces, including men from the United States Colored Troops, marched into Tupelo, Mississippi.  Disorganized Confederate soldiers fought fiercely but could not overpower the federal troops.  Neither side could claim a clear victory,

Brice's Cross Roads National Battlefield Site is free.

The Mississippi’s Last Stands Visitor and Interpretive Center is open 9 a.m. -5 p.m. Tuesday-Saturday. Admission is $5 for adults and $2 for children under 12 years old. Group rates are available.

properties.directionsInfo: Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site can be found 15 miles north of Tupelo, Mississippi. Exit U.S. Highway 45 onto Mississippi 370, in Baldwyn, Mississippi. The battlefield is located 6 miles west of Baldwyn, on Mississippi 370. Visitors may also consider visiting the Mississippi's Final Stands Interpretive Center in Baldwyn. Exit U.S. Highway 45 at Mississippi 370 and turn east. Take the first right off of Highway 370 to the interpretive center.
properties.weatherInfo: Mississippi is classified as a humid subtropical climate, the weather ranges from mild winters to hot summers with high humidity between May and September. Average high temperatures reach into the high 80's in summer, and into the high 40's in winter. Check local forecasts to plan your trip.
properties.name: Brices Cross Roads
properties.description: The Confederate victory at Brices Cross Roads was a significant victory for Major General Nathan Bedford Forrest, but its long term effect on the war proved costly for the Confederates. Brices Cross Roads is an excellent example of winning the battle, but losing the war.

images.altText: The monument with cannons on each side
images.title: Brices Crossroads Monument
images.caption: The Confederate victory at Brices Cross Roads was a significant victory for Major General Nathan Bedford Forrest, but its long term effect on the war proved costly for the Confederates. Brices Cross Roads is an excellent example of winning the battle, bu

entrancePasses.description: This annual pass covers entrance fees at national parks and national wildlife refuges and standard amenity day use fees at national forests and grasslands, and at lands and waters managed by the Bureau of Land Management, the Bureau of Reclamation, and the Army Corps of Engineers. It admits the pass owner and their accompanying passengers, or three (3) adults. The Annual Pass costs $80.00

This pass will get the cardholder plus 3 additional persons age 16 and older entry to Fort Christiansvaern. Applicants must provide documentation of permanent disability and residency or citizenship.

properties.weatherInfo: Welcome to the tropics!
properties.name: Christiansted
properties.description: No place in the Caribbean still demonstrates the architectural, economic, and political influence of Europe like Christiansted National Historic Site. Come wander through 18th century buildings in one the Caribbean's few urban parks. It is a unique experience that you will never forget.

images.altText: Ca. 1815 painting of activity at the wharf in Christiansted, St. Croix.
images.title: Commerce and the Christiansted Wharf
images.caption: The Christiansted wharf was a cosmopolitan port throughout the 18th and 19th centuries.

images.altText: Drawing of Alexander Hamilton, age 18
images.title: Young Alexander Hamilton
images.caption: Alexander Hamilton spent his youth on St. Croix, from 1765 until 1772. This drawing was made shortly after he left the island.

properties.weatherInfo: Kansas has a temperate but continental climate, with great extremes between summer and winter temperatures but few long periods of extreme hot or cold.
properties.name: Brown v. Board of Education
properties.description: The story of Brown v. Board of Education, which ended legal segregation in public schools, is one of hope and courage. When the people agreed to be plaintiffs in the case, they never knew they would change history. The people who make up this story were ordinary people. They were teachers, secretaries, welders, ministers and students who simply wanted to be treated equally.

images.altText: Monroe School and park visitor center
images.title: Monroe Elementary School
images.caption: Monroe Elementary School, was one of the four segregated elementary schools for African American children in Topeka

properties.description: Alexander Hamilton created the tools for the success of the United States. From his humble beginnings as an orphan on the Caribbean island of Nevis, he became George Washington's right-hand man. Come visit Hamilton Grange and find out more about this controversial founder and the country home that he built on his Harlem estate.

properties.name: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace
properties.description: This is the boyhood home of the first U.S. president to be born in New York City. Raised in a townhouse at 28 E. 20th St., Theodore Roosevelt would grow up to be our 26th President and become immortalized on Mount Rushmore. However, he started life as a sickly yet bright boy who exercised to improve his health and began a lifelong passion for the "strenuous life."

images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace Exterior
images.caption: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace Exterior

GPS

Plane

properties.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in East Tennessee, but temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer and Winter ranges can be extreme. The President's Homestead is not climate controlled and may be closed at times during excessive highs or lows in the summer and winter.
properties.name: Andrew Johnson
properties.description: Andrew Johnson's complex presidency (1865-69) illustrates the Constitution at work following the Civil War. As the President and Congress disagreed on Reconstruction methods, the Constitution served as their guide on balance of powers, vetoes, and impeachment. In the end, it evolved as a living document with pivotal amendments on freedom, citizenship, and voting rights - topics still vital today.

properties.directionsInfo:
General Grant National Memorial is located in Riverside Park, on the upper west-side of Manhattan. 

The entrance to the mausoleum is between north-bound and south-bound Riverside Drive, near the intersection of West 122nd Street. The visitor center is located to the west, across south-bound Riverside Drive.

Street parking is available, but can be very hard to find. The area is well-served with both Bus and Subway, by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York (http://www.mta.info/).

properties.name: General Grant
properties.description: The final resting place of President Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia, is the largest mausoleum in North America. It testifies to a people’s gratitude for the man who ended the bloodiest conflict in American history as Commanding General of the Union Army and then, as President of the United States, strove to heal a nation after a civil war and make rights for all citizens a reality.

images.altText: Mausoleum and flags in sunny weather
images.title: Mausoleum
images.caption: The Mausoleum is the final resting place for Ulysses S Grant and his wife Julia D. Grant.

images.altText: Two red stone sarcophagi are in a crypt. A bust of General Sherman can be seen in the distance.
images.title: The Sarcophagi of Ulysses and Julia Grant
images.caption: Two sarcophagi, made of granite from Wisconsin, house the remains of Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia. Bronze busts of key union generals (like William T. Sherman seen here) occupy the  niches in the lower crypt.

images.altText: A circular dome is held up by carvings of allegorical figures.
images.title: The Upper Dome of the Mausoleum
images.caption: The dome of the memorial stretches 150 feet into the sky. On its four corners are four allegorical sculptures, executed by J. Massey Rhind.

images.altText: A neoclassic pavilion sits on the hillside, surrounded by trees with the Hudson River below.
images.title: The Overlook Pavillion, above the Visitor Center
images.caption: The Overlook Pavilion is great place to check out the scenery. Beneath the overlook is the park's visitor center.

images.altText: A black wrought-iron fence surrounds two trees. The enclosure is located directly behind the tomb.
images.title: Site of the Temporary Tomb
images.caption: This enclosure marks the location of the temporary vault where Grant was initially interred. His remains were in the temporary vault for 12 years, from 1885-1897.

images.altText: West Point Cadets in formal uniforms carrying three flags in front of the mausoleum
images.title: U S Military Academy at West Point Colorguard
images.caption: Visit the site on the Birthday Ceremony for U.S. Grant

Walk several blocks. Make a left onto Provost, heading north. Provost becomes S. Third Ave. Continue north on S. Third Avenue to the stop sign on the right at the Salvation Army. Make a right at stop sign onto S. Columbus. Saint Paul's will be on your right. Walk from the subway to the site should be about 15 minutes, approximately 2/3 of a mile.

properties.name: Saint Paul's Church
properties.description: Since 1665, Saint Paul's Church played a vital role in the colonial life of Eastchester, 20 miles north of New York City. Townspeople voted at the nearby Village Green; local militia drilled outside its doors. But the American Revolution changed everything. American, British and Hessian troops tore down the old wooden meetinghouse for firewood and used the unfinished stone chapel as a hospital.

images.altText: Rebecca Turner gravesite
images.title: Rebecca Turner gravesite
images.caption: A former enslaved person, Rebecca Turner attended the church and is buried in the cemetery. A local elementary school is named after her.

images.altText: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site
images.title: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site
images.caption: The church was originally a wooden meetinghouse. This stone structure was still unfinished when US, British and Hessian troops used it for a hospital during the Revolution.

images.altText: Encampment volley
images.title: Encampment volley
images.caption: History is a blast, especially when costumed Revolutionary War interpreters visit the site during a special event.

images.altText: Local students gather inside Saint Paul's Church
images.title: Local students gather inside Saint Paul's Church
images.caption: In 2015, local students visited the site to honor Rebecca and Benjamin Turner, two former members of Saint Paul's Church. Local schools have been named after the couple.

images.altText: The restored church pews
images.title: The restored church pews
images.caption: The pews have been rebuilt to resemble what was here when the stone church was first opened.

properties.fullName: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site

It is highly recommended that all visitors use mass transit when traveling to Federal Hall.

properties.name: Federal Hall
properties.description: Here on Wall Street, George Washington took the oath of office as our first President, and this site was home to the first Congress, Supreme Court, and Executive Branch offices. The current structure, a Customs House, later served as part of the US Sub-Treasury. Now, the building serves as a museum and memorial to our first President and the beginnings of the United States of America.

images.title: Federal Hall Interior

properties.directionsInfo: Castle Clinton is located in historic Battery Park. It is only directly accessible by foot, bicycle, or wheelchair. You cannot drive directly to the site. Local parking is nearly impossible to find and expensive. All public transportation options are located outside of Battery Park.

properties.weatherInfo:
Castle Clinton National Monument has a variety of weather. New York City has hot summers and cold winters. Spring can have heavy rains and Autumn can be cool. 
http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?CityName=New+York&state=NY&site=OKX&lat=40.7198&lon=-73.993#.Vqj8OvkrJlZ
properties.name: Castle Clinton
properties.description: Located at the southern tip of Manhattan Island, Castle Clinton stands where New York City began, and represents not only the city’s growth, but the growth of a nation. Initially intended to prevent a British invasion in 1812, the fortification has transformed over the years to welcome theatergoers, immigrants, sightseers, and now, millions of visitors to New York Harbor.

images.altText: Castle Clinton NM Entrance
images.title: Castle Clinton National Monument
images.caption: Castle Clinton stands where New York City began.

entranceFees.description: Entry to Ulysses S. Grant National Historic Site is free.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee for Visitor Center or Historic House

properties.directionsInfo: Ulysses S. Grant is located in south St. Louis County on Grant Road, near Gravois Road to the south. Watson Road is to the north, I-270 is to the west, and Laclede Station Road is to the east.
properties.weatherInfo: St. Louis weather can be uncomfortable and occasionally severe, so please plan your visit accordingly. High heat and humidity, severe thunderstorms, snow and ice, and extreme cold are all possible depending upon the season. For an update of inclement weather conditions which may affect your visit, call (314)842-1867 and follow the instructions to connect to the inclement weather report.
properties.name: Ulysses S Grant
properties.description: Ulysses S. Grant is known as the victorious Civil War general who saved the Union and the 18th President of the United States. He first met Julia Dent, his future wife, at her family home, named White Haven. From 1854 to 1859 the Dents, Grants and an enslaved African-American workforce lived on the property.

images.altText: View of house with fence. Autumn colored leaves on trees
images.title: White Haven in Autumn
images.caption: White Haven is picturesque in all seasons, but in the fall the trees are especially beautiful.

images.altText: view of house from side and back. The house has several additions. Stone summer kitchen on right
images.title: White Haven
images.caption: Behind the house is stone summer kitchen.

images.altText: To the left is the ice house and to right is chicken house.
images.title: Outbuildings
images.caption: Ice house and chicken house behind the main house.

images.altText: Saddles in tack room
images.title: Tack Room
images.caption: The historic stable tack room.

images.altText: boy looking at touchscreen in museum
images.title: Museum Exhibits
images.caption: The interactive museum is located in the historic stable.

images.altText: Historic green house with snow on ground
images.title: Winter at White Haven
images.caption: Visiting the park in the winter can be beautiful and peaceful.

images.altText: View of house from front with budding tree branch in foreground that is also covered in ice.
images.title: White Haven in Early Spring
images.caption: Snowfall in early spring.

properties.name: Clara Barton
properties.description: Clara Barton dedicated her life and energies to help others in times of need - both home and abroad, in peacetime as well as during military emergencies. Glen Echo was her home the last 15 years of her life and the structure illustrates her dedication and concern for those less fortunate than herself.

images.altText: two and half story wooden frame house with double porch and stone corner posts.
images.title: Clara Barton National Historic Site Front View
images.caption: Clara Barton National Historic Site

images.altText: side view of Clara Barton's house with Red Cross flag and American Flag.

images.title: Front Parlor
images.caption: Front Parlor, Clara Barton's favorite chair in front of flags.

images.altText: large potbelly stove in center hallway with open view to third floor

properties.directionsInfo: The Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site is located at 532 N. 7th Street, Philadelphia, PA 19123. It sits in an urban area served by Interstates 95 and 676. On- street parking is usually available near the site. The site is also easily accessible by public transportation. See the directions web page for more information.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
properties.name: Edgar Allan Poe
properties.description: Described as horrifying, mystifying, and brilliant, Poe’s writing has engaged readers all over the globe. The six years Edgar Allan Poe lived in Philadelphia were his happiest and most productive. Yet Poe also struggled with bad luck, personal demons and his wife’s illness. In Poe’s humble home, reflect on the human spirit surmounting crushing obstacles, and celebrate Poe’s astonishing creativity.

images.altText: Color photo of a rectangular three story brick home with rows of windows on each floor.
images.title: Poe House, exterior
images.caption: Edgar Allan Poe lived in Philadelphia for six years, but he resided at this home for about a year, 1843-1844.

images.altText: Color photo of the parlor in the Poe House showing illustrations of furniture on the walls.
images.title: Parlor
images.caption: Wall mounted illustrations show how the room may have been furnished when Edgar Allan Poe lived in the house.

images.altText: Color photo of the basement with brick floor, false chimney, and wooden staircase.
images.title: Basement
images.caption: Is this where Poe got his inspiration for The Black Cat?  Descend to the basement and decide for yourself.

images.altText: Color photo showing a large raven statue with wings outspread on a metal plinth.
images.title: Raven statue
images.caption: Stand in the shadow of the raven statue in the yard.

images.altText: A small red-carpeted room with faux marble table, red upholstered chairs and sofa, and red curtains.
images.title: The Reading Room
images.caption: The reading room at the Edgar Allan Poe National Historical Site is furnished according to Poe's essay "The Philosophy of Furniture."

properties.fullName: Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site

properties.directionsInfo: Site administrative offices are located at 15 State Street.  However, Ranger programs begin at either the Robert Gould Shaw Memorial on Beacon Street, or at the Museum of African American History at 46 Joy Street on Beacon Hill.

entrancePasses.description: There are no entrance passes for this site.  Ranger guided walking tours are free of charge.  Our partner, the Museum of African American History charges an admission fee.
entrancePasses.title: There are no entrance passes for this site.

properties.weatherInfo: Boston African American National Historic Site is located in downtown Boston which can see extreme cold in the winter months, as well as extreme heat and humidity throughout the summer months.  Walking tours may be cancelled during severe heat and/or weather events.
properties.name: Boston African American
properties.description: Centered on the north slope of Beacon Hill, the African American community of 19th century Boston led the city and the nation in the fight against slavery and injustice. These remarkable men and women, together with their allies, were leaders in Abolition Movement, the Underground Railroad, the Civil War, and the early struggle for equal rights and education.

images.altText: View from the pulpit at the African Meeting House
images.title: The African Meeting House
images.caption: The African Meeting House served as the religious, educational, and political center of Boston's 19th century African American community.

images.altText: A yellow wooden house on Beacon Hill
images.title: The William Cooper Nell House
images.caption: This is the home of education activist, abolitionist, and historian William Cooper Nell.

images.altText: A large bronze statue showing a man on horseback and soldiers walking alongside him
images.title: The Robert Gould Shaw Memorial
images.caption: The Robert Gould Shaw Memorial honors Colonel Shaw and the Massachusetts 54th, the first African American regiment from the North to fight in the Civil War.

images.altText: A close up image of flowers laid at the feet of the soldiers on the Shaw Memorial
images.title: Flowers at the Shaw Memorial
images.caption: Flowers laid at the feet of the soldiers on the Robert Gould Shaw Memorial.

images.altText: The entrance door into a red brick townhouse on Beacon Hill
images.title: The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House
images.caption: Lewis and Harriet Hayden used their home as an Underground Railroad safe house to shelter those running away from slavery.

addresses.line2: Boston African American National Historical Site
Boston African American National Historical Site

properties.fullName: Boston African American National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to Nicodemus National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Park Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Nicodemus National Historic Site is located in northwestern Kansas on Highway 24 between Hill City and Stockton.
properties.weatherInfo:
Northwest Kansas has a four season climate typified by long, hot summers, cold winters, short spring and fall seasons, and nearly constant breeze. Humidity is relatively low compared to the eastern portion of the state.

Afternoon thunderstorms with lightning, hail, and gusty winds frequently occur during the spring and summer. Tornados are possible but are less common in Kansas than they are in several other states. In the event of a tornado seek shelter immediately. Winter snow accumulation is usually l
properties.name: Nicodemus
properties.description: Formerly enslaved African Americans left Kentucky in organized colonies at the end of the of post-Civil War Reconstruction period to experience freedom in the "promised land" of Kansas. Nicodemus represents the involvement of African Americans in the westward expansion and settlement of the Great Plains. It is the oldest and only remaining Black settlement west of the Mississippi River.

images.altText: District #1 Schoolhouse
images.title: District #1 Schoolhouse
images.caption: Nicodemus was the first school district in Graham County, Kansas. They first met in dugouts, and then in a frame building. The current building was built in the early 1900's after a fire destroyed the previous one.

images.altText: The First Baptist Church
images.title: The First Baptist Church
images.caption: Church seen through a field of prairie grass.

images.altText: Township Hall building
images.title: Township Hall
images.caption: The Township Hall on a beautiful Spring day.

images.altText: Nicodemus African Methodist Episcopal building
images.title: Nicodemus African Methodist Episcopal
images.caption: Nicodemus African Methodist Episcopal

images.altText: Nicodemus Descendants outside Visitor Center
images.title: Nicodemus Descendants
images.caption: Nicodemus Descendants outisde the park Visitor Center

properties.directionsInfo: From Route 128, take exit 25A, Route 114 East to Salem. Follow Route 114 into Salem where it will become North Street, then Summer Street (pass the Witch House on the right). Turn left onto Norman Street and then stay straight through the traffic light onto Derby Street (note: Route 114 will turn right at this corner toward Marblehead). Follow Derby Street throught the traffic light straight past the Beverly Cooperative Bank to the next intersection.
properties.weatherInfo: Hot, humid summers. Cold, snowy winters.
properties.name: Salem Maritime
properties.description: Established on March 17, 1938 as the first National Historic Site in the United States, Salem Maritime National Historic Site consists of nine acres of land and twelve historic structures along the Salem waterfront, as well as a downtown visitor center. Located in the urban setting of Salem, the park preserves and interprets over 600 years of New England's maritime history and global connections.

images.altText: Park Waterfront & Vessel Friendship of Salem
images.title: Park Waterfront & Vessel Friendship of Salem
images.caption: Park Waterfront & Vessel Friendship of Salem

addresses.line1: 2 New Liberty Street - Salem Armory Visitor Center

properties.directionsInfo: The First Ladies National Historic Site is located in downtown Canton, Ohio. Free parking is available behind the Saxton House or at our gated lot on the corner of Market Avenue South and 3rd Street SW. Please begin your visit at the education center at 205 Market Avenue South.
properties.weatherInfo:
The weather at First Ladies National Historic Site is typical of Northeastern Ohio: four distinct seasons. 

Spring's rain and warming temperatures bring new leaves on trees and blooming wildflowers.

Summer temperatures range from 49 to 95 degrees F and can be humid. 

Fall temperatures can range from low 70s during the day to freezing during the night. Fallcolor peaks mid-October.

Winter weather conditions can rapidly change. Temperatures vary from mid-30s to below zero.
properties.name: First Ladies
properties.description: First Ladies National Historic Site consists of two properties in downtown Canton, Ohio - the home of First Lady Ida Saxton-McKinley and a small visitor center with an exhibit and film. Come learn about how the position of First Lady has evolved over time to include a public role.

images.altText: a front view of the Ida Saxton McKinley House
images.title: First Ladies National Historic Site
images.caption: This was the longtime residence of William and Ida McKinley.

images.altText: A piano in the Saxton McKinley Home
images.title: Saxton McKinley House Piano
images.caption: Ida Saxton's original piano is just one of many items belonging to President McKinley and First Lady Ida McKinley.

images.altText: Close up view of home entrance.
images.title: Saxton McKinley Home
images.caption: The Saxton McKinley Home is significant as the only residence with direct historical ties to President William McKinley remaining in his hometown of Canton.

entranceFees.description:
Everyone touring the Truman home, including children, must have a ticket.  Tickets for children 15 years old or younger are free.

Once bona fide educational groups may make reservations for tours. All other tickets are issued same day, first come, first served.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo: The Visitor Center is located at the intersection of Truman Road and Main Street, in Historic Fire Station No.1. From the north or south, take I-435 to Truman Road (State Hwy 12), exit 60. Travel east on Truman Road three miles; you'll pass the Truman Home at Delaware Street. From the east or west, take I-70 to the Noland Road exit (12). Travel north on Noland Road four miles to Truman Road. Turn west on Truman Road and travel two blocks. The Truman Home is five blocks to the west of the visitor center.

entrancePasses.description: For those with a permanent disability. Must provide proof of disability.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description:
For Fourth graders and their families.

Visit www.everykidinapark.gov to print a paper pass, to be exchanged for a plastic pass at a site that carries them. Harry S Truman currently carried these.
entrancePasses.title: Every Kid in a Park Pass

entrancePasses.description: For active members of the Military and their families. Proof required.
entrancePasses.title: Active Military Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Located on the western edge of Missouri, the park enjoys each of the four seasons. Early spring brings frequent and rapid fluctuations in weather. The summer season has warm days, periods of high heat and humidity, and mild nights. The fall season is normally mild with sunny days and cool nights. Winters can be cold. The January low averages 21 degrees. The area receives a yearly average of 37 inches of rain per year and around 18 inches of snow.
properties.name: Harry S Truman
properties.description: President Harry S Truman took America from its traditional isolationism into the age of international involvement. Despite his power, he never forgot where he came from. Today, visitors can experience the surroundings Truman knew as a young man of modest ambition through his political career and final years as a former president.

images.altText: The Truman home near sunset.
images.title: The Truman Home
images.caption: Although Harry Truman was a 20th century president, his home was from the Victorian era.

images.altText: The Truman Farm Home sits behind Autumn trees.
images.title: The Truman Farm Home
images.caption: From when he was 22 until he was 33 years old, Harry Truman lived on his grandmother's farm.

images.altText: The Noland home sits across the street from the Truman home.
images.title: The Noland Home
images.caption: Harry Truman's cousins, the Nolands, lived right across the street from him.

images.altText: The Frank Wallace home where Bess Truman's brother lived.
images.title: The Frank Wallace Home
images.caption: Bess Truman's brother, Frank, and his wife Natalie, lived in this small bungalow right behind the Truman home.

images.altText: The George Wallace home with the Truman home in the background.
images.title: The George Wallace Home
images.caption: Bess Truman's brother, George, and his wife, May, lived right behind the Truman home.

properties.fullName: Harry S Truman National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: All activities and tours are free.
entranceFees.title: Free

properties.directionsInfo: Take I-90 (NY Thruway) to Exit 33 (Verona-Rome). Turn Right onto Rt. 365 E. Follow Rt. 365, veering left as Rt. 365 merges with Rt 69 at the fork in the road. This will take you over an arterial bridge into the City of Rome. Fort Stanwix NM will be across Erie Blvd. on the right side of James Street.

entrancePasses.description: All activities and tours are free.
entrancePasses.title: No Pass Required for Entrance

properties.weatherInfo: The Park lies within a temperate zone and experiences four full seasons. Summer can become very hot and humid. Snow is common as late as May and as early as October. The fort area can become muddy in all seasons. With most activities outdoors, good closed-toe walking shoes and low heels are advised. Air conditioning and heating is limited to park visitor center most times in the year. Water and extra layers of clothing in all seasons are always recommended!
properties.name: Fort Stanwix
properties.description: For centuries, the Oneida Carrying Place, a six mile portage connecting the Mohawk River and Wood Creek, served as a vital link for those traveling by water from the ocean to the Great Lakes. When Europeans arrived, nations fought for control of the carry, the homelands of the Six Nations Confederacy, and the rich resources of North America. In this struggle, Fort Stanwix would play a vital role.

images.altText: A park ranger directs a group of children thorugh the fort.
images.title: Which Adventure Will You Choose?
images.caption: From ranger tours, to walking trails, to exploring history, there's plenty to do at Fort Stanwix!

images.altText: Children dance, jump, and skip on the parade ground of reconstructed Fort Stanwix.
images.title: Celebrate the Park! Fort Stanwix at 40 & the NPS Centennial!
images.caption: The park is gearing up for the National Park Service Centennial. Find out what's going on and what's already been done!

images.altText: Small boxes in rows contain small artifacts, including broken pipes and glass bottles.
images.title: Objects From the Past: Museum Collection
images.caption: Learn more about the objects in the park's museum collection.

images.altText: A woman digs in a carefully excavated hole.
images.title: Uncovering the Past at Fort Stanwix
images.caption: What evidence of the past has been found at Fort Stanwix? Stop through to find out!

images.altText: Soldiers stand in a neat row holding their muskets.
images.title: Fort Stanwix: History Happened Here!
images.caption: Discover the vital role that Fort Stanwix/Schuyler, the fort that "never surrendered" played in the American Revolution.

phoneNumbers.description: Due to the site's limited hours, visitors are advised to phone the Independence Visitor Center at the above number.  Rangers at the visitor center (open 7 days a week) can answer questions and provide information about the Thaddeus Kosciuszko National Memorial

emailAddresses.description: Use the email for information about the site.

entranceFees.description: Admission is free.
entranceFees.title: None

properties.directionsInfo: The Thaddeus Kosciuszko National Memorial is located at 301 Pine Street in Philadelphia. It is within walking distance of Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell Center. Parking is quite limited near the site.  The site is easily accessible by public transportation.  See the park's web page for directions.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
properties.name: Thaddeus Kosciuszko
properties.description: Visit the house where wounded Polish freedom fighter Thaddeus Kosciuszko lived and hear how this brilliant military engineer designed successful fortifications during the American Revolution. See the room where he received notable visitors such as Chief Little Turtle and Thomas Jefferson.

images.altText: Color photo showing a three story brick rowhouse on a corner lot.
images.title: Kosciuszko House, exterior
images.caption: The Thaddeus Kosciuszko house is a national memorial to an international champion of human rights.

images.altText: Color photo of the bedroom with a orange upholstered sofa and a bed in the small room.
images.title: Bedroom
images.caption: Learn about Kosciuszko's role in the American Revolution as well as his defeat against the Russians in his native Poland.

images.altText: Black and white photo, circa 1960, showing a three story brick rowhouse situated on a corner lot.
images.title: Kosciuszko House, ca. 1960
images.caption: The home where Thaddeus Kosciuszko once lived fell into disrepair.  The site became a National Memorial in 1972.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees to the park.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-71 north; Take Exit 2 (Reading Road and Eden Park Drive). Stay in right lane; turn left at first stoplight onto Dorchester Avenue, and go to the top of the hill. Turn right on Auburn Avenue and go 1 ½ blocks to the site. Park will be on the right.

From I-71S, take Exit 3 (Taft Road). Follow Taft Road westbound.  Go 0.75 mile to Auburn Avenue. Turn left and go 0.5 mile to the site. Park will be on the left.

entrancePasses.description: The park no longer sells the America the Beautiful National Parks & Federal Recreation Lands Pass. However, you can go online to purchase select passes and to order select passes at https://store.usgs.gov/pass/index.html
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful passes

properties.weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 48 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 77 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just under 40". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of less than 12"
properties.name: William Howard Taft
properties.description: High atop one of Cincinnati's most prominent hilltops stands the two-story Greek Revival house where William Howard Taft was born and grew up. Hard work, a good education, and an interest in civic duty are attributes that made the Taft family outstanding leaders over the years. The environment that shaped Taft's character and philosophy  is highlighted  on a visit to the site.

images.altText: A cardboard cutout of Taft against the wall
images.title: William Howard Taft cutout
images.caption: A William Howard Taft cardboard cutout in the education center

images.altText: The Taft house and visitor center
images.title: Park Photo
images.caption: The Taft House and Education Center as seen from Auburn Ave.

images.altText: The Taft House
images.title: Park Wallpaper with Centennial logo
images.caption: The William Howard Taft NHS wallpaper

images.altText: Animatronic robot sitting near a car display by creek
images.title: Charlie Taft III Display
images.caption: Animatronic Charlie Taft III robot inside of the Taft Education Center

images.altText: Portrait of Taft on a wall near a fireplace
images.title: Inside of the Taft House
images.caption: A portrait of William Howard Taft hangs in the foreground of a portrait of his father

properties.fullName: William Howard Taft National Historic Site

entranceFees.description:
Visitors 16 years and above are $10/person. There is no charge for parking. The entrance fee allows each visitor to take a guided tour of the Garfield Home. 

Visitors 15 and under are free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Youth ages 15 and under are FREE!
entranceFees.title: Youth 15 and under

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate 90 - exit at Route 306 and head north to Route 20. East on Route 20 about 1.5 miles. Site is on north side of Mentor Avenue.

From Route 2 - exit at Route 306 and head south to Route 20. East on Route 20 about 1.5 miles. Site is on the north side of Mentor Avenue.
properties.weatherInfo: Winter tends to be cold with snow and ice from January - early March. Summers are comfortable, but can be humid and reach into the 90's. There is a 100 yard walk between the Visitor Center and Garfield home; visitors are advised to check weather conditions prior to their visit.
properties.name: James A Garfield
properties.description: A front porch can serve many purposes. For some, a place to enjoy the breeze on a warm summer night. For others, a perch from which to keep eyes on what's happening in their neighborhood. In 1880, James Garfield used his front porch as a platform to greet thousands of well-wishers during his presidential campaign. Today, the porch serves as a gateway to the story of the Garfield family.

images.altText: Carriage House entrance from the south
images.title: Carriage House
images.caption: The Carriage House, built in 1894, was repurposed by the National Park Service to become a modern visitor center. It was part of a $12.5 million restoration in the 1990's.

images.altText: A view of the memorial library addition through the trees.
images.title: Library addition, north side
images.caption: Mrs. Garfield constructed a beautiful addition to the Garfield home following the President's assassination in 1881. These 9 rooms contain the first Presidential Memorial Library,  including the a fireproof vault which once contained Garfield's papers.

images.altText: Front porch of Garfield home showing red front door
images.title: The Front Porch, Garfield Home
images.caption: The front porch of James Garfield's home was the scene of the first front porch campaign. The presidential candidate gave patriotic speeches and met with thousands of people who came to which him well during the summer and fall of 1880.

images.altText: Visitor Center main entrance off the parking lot.
images.title: Visitor Center, Main Entrance

properties.name: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural
properties.description: As president, Theodore Roosevelt created protections for ordinary citizens, began regulation of big business, and made the US a major force in international affairs. Yet one of the most important presidencies in America's history nearly didn't happen. See the place where a brief, emotional, and improvised ceremony in Buffalo, NY brought TR into office, and forever altered the nation.

images.altText: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural Site
images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural Site
images.caption: This home in Buffalo, NY, is where Theodore Roosevelt took the oath of office as President on September 14, 1901.

properties.fullName: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: The Great Egg Harbor River is fee free. For details and information, visit, http://www.rivers.gov/rivers/great-egg-harbor.php.

properties.directionsInfo: Estell Manor Park, where visitors can see the Great Egg Harbor National Scenic and Recreational River, is located 3.5 miles South of Mays Landing, New Jersey, off of Route 50. It is approximately 17 miles west of Atlantic City. There is a stamper for Passport Stamp Books at the Fox Nature Center, and a stamp can be obtained at the mailing address provided below.
properties.weatherInfo: Temperate, with a moderating influence of the Atlantic Ocean.
properties.name: Great Egg Harbor River
properties.description: The River gradually widens as it picks up the waters of 17 tributaries on its way to Great Egg Harbor and the Atlantic Ocean. Established by Congress in 1992, nearly all of this 129-mile river system rests within the Pinelands National Reserve. This National Park Service unit is unusual in that local jurisdictions continue to administer the lands.

entranceFees.description: Reservations are free. No park fee required.
entranceFees.title: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial

properties.directionsInfo: The Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial is on an active military base, so it is only accessible by reservation. The shuttle picks up visitors with reservations at the John Muir National Historic Site. Please know that all visitors for the memorial must have a reservation. Please visit our website for information on how to obtain reservations.

entrancePasses.description: Park passes are not sold or required for reservations. Reservations are free.
entrancePasses.title: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial

properties.weatherInfo: The Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial is on a base and sits on the waterfront. There is no shelter at the memorial, aside from the shuttle. It can be windy and cold during any season. Many people prefer to at least bring a light jacket during the summer, or coat during the other seasons.
properties.name: Port Chicago Naval Magazine
properties.description: On the evening of July 17, 1944, residents in the San Francisco east bay area were jolted awake by a massive explosion that cracked windows and lit up the night sky. At Port Chicago Naval Magazine, 320 men were instantly killed when two ships being loaded with ammunition for the Pacific theater troops blew up. It was WWII's worst home front disaster.

images.altText: Port Chicago Memorial
images.title: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial
images.caption: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial

properties.fullName: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial

entranceFees.description: The Rio Grande Wild & Scenic River does not have an entry fee however, if you float the portions of the Wild & Scenic River inside Big Bend National Park, you will be charged for entry into the National Park.

properties.directionsInfo: Hwy 118 south from Alpine; Hwy 385 south from Marathon; FM 170 from Presidio through Study Butte.
properties.weatherInfo:
Variable
-- February-April: High temperatures range from mid-70sF (23C) to low-90sF (32C) with lows from the mid-30sF (2C) to mid-50sF (12C). Cold fronts can bring freezing weather with rain or snow.
-- May-August: Temperatures are hot and the weather can be stormy. Temperatures over 100F (more than 38C) degrees.
-- September-January:Temperatures are cooler. The weather can turn cold any time during these months.
properties.name: Rio Grande
properties.description: It is an irresistible playground where unruly rapids check your skills as a canyon wren’s definitive call cascades down ancient limestone cliffs. Below the chasm, the canyon’s raw beauty dances across mirrored water. While the primal nature of the river stirs hunger for spirited adventure, the river is also an undulant ribbon of wetland corridor and, against all odds, the lifeblood of the desert.

properties.directionsInfo: The administrative office for the NPS Potomac Heritage NST is located at the National Capital Area Office.  This is not a visitor center.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather associated with the PHT network is typical of a temperate climate, with four distinct seasons and variable precipitation throughout the year.  Temperatures can vary from a high of 100 degrees Fahrenheit in the summer to 0 degrees in the winter.
properties.name: Potomac Heritage
properties.description: Linking the tidal Potomac and upper Youghiogheny river basins, the evolving Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail network lies within a corridor rich in historic pathways and waterways. You can travel this historic corridor today—on foot, bicycle and horse and by boat—exploring contrasting landscapes between the Chesapeake Bay and the Allegheny Plateau.

images.altText: A man, woman and child stand overlooking a valley of mountains and trees on a sunny summer day.

images.altText: A bicycle sits on a bright summer day overlooking the rolling mountains in the distance.
images.title: Great Allegheny Passage (GAP)
images.caption: Great Allegheny Passage is a bicyclist enthusiasts' dream come true!

properties.directionsInfo: The park's main visitor center is in New Orleans' French Quarter, near the Mississippi River levee on North Peters Street between Dumaine Street and St. Phillip Street. The park also produces educational concerts at the New Orleans Jazz Museum at 400 Esplanade Avenue.
properties.weatherInfo:
All temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit. Note that relative humidity, especially in summer months, can reach 90%, so temperatures can feel 10-20 degrees hotter than actual temperature.
Spring (March, April, May) average high 77, low 61
Summer (June, July, August) average high 89, low 75
Fall (September, October, November) average high 78, low 64
Winter (December, January, February) average high 64, low 48
properties.name: New Orleans Jazz
properties.description: Only in New Orleans could there be a National Park for jazz! Drop by our visitor center at 916 North Peters St. to inquire about musical events around town. In the mood for a world class musical experience? Attend a jazz concert or ranger performance at the state of the New Orleans Jazz Museum.

images.altText: Exhibit titled "What Is New Orleans Jazz?"
images.title: Visitor Center Exhibit at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: "What is New Orleans Jazz?" A visit to the park's main visitor center at 916 North Peters Street will answer the question.

images.altText: Kids and adults playing instruments on a stage
images.title: Visitor Center Concert at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: Passing jazz traditions from one generation to the next is an important part of the park's mission---and great listening too!

images.altText: Singer with jazz band, including park rangers
images.title: US Mint Concert by New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: The park's state-of-the-art concert space at the Old US Mint is the perfect place to enjoy some jazz.

images.altText: Rangers and others sing and play on a stage
images.title: US Mint Voting Rights Act Program at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: Programs like this celebration of the Voting Rights Act bring together history, culture, and music.

images.altText: A young brass band musician plays a trumpet
images.title: Community Events by New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: The park works with local partners to share jazz at community events, festivals, and other venues.

properties.fullName: New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: Entrance to the Pearl Harbor Visitor Center and museums is free.
entranceFees.title: Pearl Harbor Visitor Center

entranceFees.description: Tickets for the USS Arizona Memorial program are free. However, there are a limited number of timed tickets. Tickets can be reserved via www.recreation.gov up to 60 days in advance, or visitors can get same-day walk-in tickets on a first come, first served basis. 1,300 walk-in tickets are handed out daily.
entranceFees.title: USS Arizona Memorial program

properties.directionsInfo: Please input our address rather than just "Pearl Harbor," as this will take you to the active military base, not the Pearl Harbor Visitor Center.
properties.weatherInfo: Hawaii has two seasons – winter (ho'oilo) and summer (kau wela) – and temperatures don't change drastically the way they do in the mainland United States. During the day, expect temperatures in the mid-70s to the mid-80s all year around. Expect lows in the winter months (November to March) to be around 60 degrees. The Hawaiian winter is also considered the rainy season, and flash floods are not uncommon. You can expect to see lots of rainbows as the rain clears.
properties.name: Pearl Harbor
properties.description: At the Pearl Harbor National Memorial, learn about one of the most pivotal moments in US history: the attack on Pearl Harbor, and the subsequent entry of the United States into World War II.

images.altText: The USS Arizona Memorial in front of the USS Missouri.
images.title: USS Arizona Memorial
images.caption: About 1.4 million people from all over the world visit the USS Arizona Memorial every year.

images.altText: The USS Arizona Memorial
images.title: The USS Arizona and Memorial
images.caption: The USS Arizona is the final resting place for many of the ship's 1,177 crewmen who lost their lives on December 7, 1941. The memorial

images.altText: The USS Utah off the coast of Ford Island
images.title: The USS Utah
images.caption: The USS Utah lays where she fell on the north side of Ford Island. This decision was made in 1944 after several attempts at raising the ship failed. The quiet decision was made to leave the bodies of 58 crewmen onboard, considering them buried at sea.

images.altText: USS Arizona Memorial
images.title: USS Arizona Memorial
images.caption: USS Arizona Memorial and turret

images.altText: Visitors at the USS Arizona Memorial
images.title: USS Arizona Memorial
images.caption: Daily visitation to the USS Arizona Memorial is often more than 4,000 visitors.

images.altText: The USS Oklahoma Memorial
images.title: The USS Oklahoma Memorial
images.caption: After receiving seven to nine torpedo hits on the port (left) side, the USS Oklahoma capsized in roughly 20 minutes after the attack began. Over 400 men were trapped inside, of which only 32 were rescued.

Continue traveling north on 12th Street NW, until you come to Rhode Island Avenue. Make a right turn onto Rhode Island Avenue. Keep straight on Rhode Island Avenue, until you come to 9th Street. Make a right turn onto 9th Street. Keep straight and 1538 9th Street will be the third house on the right (the red brick one).

properties.weatherInfo:
Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30 to 50 F. There is occasional snow.

Spring: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Rain is common.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70 to 90 F. Humidity is usually high. Be prepared and drink plenty of water. There is a water fountain in the visitor center.

Fall: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Humidity can remain high in the earlier part of the season.
properties.name: Carter G. Woodson Home
properties.description: Before Dr. Carter G. Woodson, there was very little accurate written history about the lives and experiences of Americans of African descent. Today a National Historic Site, Dr. Woodson’s home served as the headquarters for the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. Dr. Woodson established Negro History Week here in 1926, which we celebrate today as Black History Month.

images.title: Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site
images.caption: Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site

entranceFees.description:
There is no fee to tour George Rogers Clark National Historical Park. As a result of being a fee-free park, George Rogers Clark NHP no longer sells the America the Beautiful National Park passes.

The nearest locations to purchase these passes is Hoosier National Forest in Bedford, Indiana (www.fs.usda.gov/hoosier), and is located approximately 70 miles from Vincennes.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The George Rogers Clark National Historical Park is located within the city of Vincennes, Indiana. Evansville is approximately 50 miles to the south and Terre Haute is approximately 50 miles to the north. Highway 41 provides good roads from the north or south. Highway 50 provides access from the east and west. From Hwy 50 east and west or from Hwy 41 from the north use the 6th Street exit. On Hwy 41 from the South use the Willow Street exit. From there follow the blue directional signs for the park.
properties.weatherInfo: The weather in the area is quite typical for the Midwest.  The average temperature for the winter months is the mid-30s, but the summers can often be hot and humid with temperatures reaching into the 90s.
properties.name: George Rogers Clark
properties.description: The British flag would not be raised above Fort Sackville Feb. 25, 1779. At 10 a.m., the garrison surrendered to American Colonel George Rogers Clark. His American army, aided by French residents of the Illinois country, had marched through freezing floodwaters to gain this victory. The fort’s capture assured United States claims to the frontier, an area nearly as large as the original 13 states.

images.altText: George Rogers Clark Memorial entrance
images.title: George Rogers Clark Memorial
images.caption: Thousands of visitors ascend the steps of the Clark Memorial and gain a glimpse of the heroic eagle above the entrance doors.

images.altText: Sun setting behind the Francis Vigo Statue
images.title: Francis Vigo Statue
images.caption: At the end of each day, visitors gather in the shadow of Vigo to watch the sun set over the Wabash River

images.altText: Sun setting behind the Clark Memorial
images.title: Clark Memorial at Sunset
images.caption: Many people enjoy watching the sun set behind the George Rogers Clark Memorial on the banks of the Wabash River

properties.fullName: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: Admission to most park sites is free. Timed entry tickets are required to enter Independence Hall from March through December, but there is no charge for those tickets if obtained at the Independence Visitor Center on the morning of your visit. The Benjamin Franklin Museum charges an interpretive fee.
entranceFees.title: Admission

properties.directionsInfo: Independence National Historical Park is located in an urban area served by Interstates 95 and 676. The park is also easily accessible by public transportation, including SEPTA and PATCO mass transit routes. Whether you choose driving, the bus or the train, we recommend that you start your visit at the Independence Visitor Center at 6th and Market Streets.  See the park's website for specific directions.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
properties.name: Independence
properties.description: Goods, ideas, and people intermingled in early Philadelphia.  In this diverse city, a new republic was born.  The Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both debated and signed inside Independence Hall.  Nearby sits the Liberty Bell, an international symbol of liberty.

images.altText: Color photo of the Liberty Bell with Independence Hall in the background.
images.title: The Liberty Bell
images.caption: Recognizable for its crack, the Liberty Bell remains significant today for its message of liberty.

images.altText: Color photo of Independence Hall as seen from the north side of Chestnut Street.
images.title: Independence Hall
images.caption: Known as the birthplace of the United States, Independence Hall houses the room where the Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both signed.

images.altText: A color photo of the Independence Visitor Center showing a brick building with tall windows.
images.title: Independence Visitor Center
images.caption: Pick up Independence Hall tickets, plan your visit, and watch films in the Independence Visitor Center.

images.altText: A color photo of the exterior of the Benjamin Franklin Museum in Franklin Court.
images.title: The Benjamin Franklin Museum
images.caption: Explore Franklin's life and character in the Benjamin Franklin Museum. The museum features artifacts, computer animations, and interactive displays that are geared toward visitors of all ages.

images.altText: A color photo of a printing press in the Franklin Court Printing Office.
images.title: The Franklin Court Printing Office
images.caption: Discover the pivotal role the printed word played in the American Revolution and the founding of the nation.  Franklin's printing office no longer survives, but it would have had equipment similar to what you'll see in the Franklin Court Printing Office.

images.altText: The exterior of the Second Bank of the United States showing a marble building with eight columns.
images.title: Portrait Gallery in the Second Bank of the United States
images.caption: The Second bank of the United States houses a fine collection of over 100 portraits, many of them by 18th century artist Charles Willson Peale.

images.altText: A color photo of the Assembly Room showing 18th century chairs and green, cloth covered tables
images.title: The Assembly Room in Independence Hall
images.caption: The Assembly Room in Independence Hall is where the Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both signed.

properties.name: Gateway Arch
properties.description: The Gateway Arch reflects St. Louis' role in the Westward Expansion of the United States during the nineteenth century. The park is a memorial to Thomas Jefferson's role in opening the West, to the pioneers who helped shape its history, and to Dred Scott who sued for his freedom in the Old Courthouse.

entranceFees.description: New Bedford Whaling National Historical is a fee free park. Fees are however collected at other privately owned and operated sites by self-supporting associations working cooperatively with the park, including partners. These sites rely on admission fees as they do not receive federal funding for operations and therefore do not accept the National Parks Pass for admission.

properties.name: New Bedford Whaling
properties.description:
"The town itself is perhaps the dearest place to live in, in all New England..nowhere in all America will you find more patrician-like houses, parks and gardens more opulent, than in New Bedford…all these brave houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans. One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up hither from the bottom of the sea."

H. Melville, "Moby-Dick"
