entranceFees.description: There is no cost for visitors to enter Saint Croix Island International Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Saint Croix Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Saint Croix Island International Historic Site is best reached by private vehicle. The site is located 8 miles (13 km) south of Calais, Maine, on US Route 1, and can be reached either by Route 9 from Bangor or US Route 1, the coastal route from Portland and points south. From US Route 1, turn onto St. Croix Drive. The entrance gate is on the right. The visitor center is inside the ranger station.
properties.weatherInfo: Located in Maine, Saint Croix Island experiences all four seasons. Summer temperatures range from 50-80F (10-27C). Fall temperatures range from 25-70F (-4-21C). Typically the first is in frost mid-October and first snowfall begins in November and can continue through April with an average accumulation of 67 inches (170 cm). Winter temperatures range from 5-30F (-15 - -1C). Spring temperatures range from 20-60F (-6-16C).
properties.name: Saint Croix Island
properties.description: The winter of 1604-1605 on Saint Croix Island was a cruel one for Pierre Dugua's French expedition. Iced in by freezing temperatures and cut off from fresh water and game, 35 of 79 men died. As spring arrived and native people traded game for bread, the health of those remaining improved. Although the expedition moved on by summer, the beginning of French presence in North America had begun.

images.altText: View of the drive into Saint Croix Island International Historic Site.
images.title: Saint Croix Island Entrance
images.caption: View of the drive into Saint Croix Island International Historic Site.

images.altText: A wayside discussing the history of the island along the interpretive trail.
images.title: Interpretive Trail
images.caption: An interpretive trail guides visitors through the history of the island and the people who called it home.

images.altText: A bronze sculpture of a Passamaquoddy person reaching out to assist the French settlers.
images.title: Bronze Sculpture
images.caption: The Passamaquoddy's assistance kept the French explorers alive.

images.altText: A bronze sculpture of Pierre Dugua with a reenactor standing nearby.
images.title: Pierre Dugua, Sieur de Mons
images.caption: Pierre Dugua and his men spent a dealthy winter on Saint Croix Island.

images.altText: Three visitors read an interpretive wayside along the trail.
images.title: Visitors reading a wayside along the trail
images.caption: As you walk along the trail waysides provide more information about surviving that deadly winter of 1604-05.

properties.fullName: Saint Croix Island International Historic Site

entranceFees.description: There are no fees in the park. All tours, education programs, and community events are free.
entranceFees.title: Park Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate 95 Northbound: Take exit 43 to Walnut Street. Turn right onto Walnut Street. Dive 2.3 miles, then turn right onto Central Street. Stay on Central Street for 1.1 miles. Turn left to stay on Central Street (road makes a sharp turn).

From Interstate 95 Southbound: Take exit 43 to Walnut Street. Turn left onto Walnut Street. Drive 2.3 miles and turn right onto Central Street. Stay on Central Street for 1.1 Miles. Turn left to stay on Central Street (road makes a sharp turn).
properties.weatherInfo: Hot, humid in the summer. Cold, snowy in winter (the park is closed in the winter).
properties.name: Saugus Iron Works
properties.description: In the 1600's, on the banks of the Saugus River, something extraordinary happened.  Explore the place where European iron makers brought their special skills to a young Massachusetts colony. This nine-acre National Park includes working waterwheels, forges, mills, an historic 17th century home, and a lush river basin.

images.altText: A view of Saugus Iron Works from the Saugus River
images.title: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site
images.caption: A view of Saugus Iron Works from the Saugus River

properties.fullName: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee. All visitors must purchase ferry tickets through Statue Cruises (1-877-LADYTIX (877-523-9849) or at statuecruises.com).  Advanced reservations are necessary to visit the crown and pedestal. Please visit our 'Plan Your Visit' page for additional information.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Liberty Island is located in New York Harbor, and can only be reached by boat. Ferries operated by Statue Cruises depart from Battery Park in Lower Manhattan in New York City, New York and Liberty State Park in Jersey City, New Jersey.
properties.weatherInfo: It is typically colder and more windy in New York Harbor than in elsewhere in the New York City metropolitan area. Winters are cold and damp. Spring and Fall can range from chilly to warm. Summers are warm to hot and humid.
properties.name: Statue Of Liberty
properties.description: "The Statue of Liberty Enlightening the World" was a gift of friendship from the people of France to the United States and is recognized as a universal symbol of freedom and democracy. The Statue of Liberty was dedicated on October 28, 1886.  It was designated as a National Monument in 1924.  Employees of the National Park Service have been caring for the colossal copper statue since 1933.

images.altText: Patina green statue atop her pedestal on Liberty Island; grey cloudy sky in the distance
images.title: The Statue of Liberty on Liberty Island from Statue Cruises Ferry
images.caption: The Statue of Liberty's patina green stands out brilliantly on a cloudy day.

images.altText: The Statue of Liberty in front of the New York City skyline.
images.title: The Statue of Liberty with New York City Skyline
images.caption: Statue of Liberty stands tall on Liberty Island with the skyline of bustling New York City in view.

images.altText: Close-up of the Statue of Liberty's head, crown, and the folds of her robe
images.title: Close-up of the Statue of Liberty's Head
images.caption: This close-up reveals fine details of the Statue of Liberty's face, hair, crown, and robe, which can be difficult to see even in person.

images.altText: Entire patina green Statue of Liberty and very top of granite pedestal
images.title: The Statue of Liberty taken on Liberty Island
images.caption: The Statue of Liberty stands tall on her pedestal: from the ground to the tip of the torch, she measures 305 feet 1 inch (93 meters)!

images.altText: Shoulders, head, and raised right arm of the Statue of Liberty from behind the statue.
images.title: Statue of Liberty from Flagpole Plaza on Liberty Island
images.caption: Millions visit the Statue of Liberty each year, but only a select few, like this peregrine falcon perched on the left-most ray, enjoy the view from above the crown.

phoneNumbers.description: General park info (recorded) with options to select specific departments, offices or employee extensions.

emailAddresses.description: General park information

entranceFees.description: Effective October 1, 2017, this park no longer charges an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Our GPS coordinates are:
N 41.410730 (latitude), W 75.671329 (longitude) using our park entrance, Lackawanna Ave at Cliff St, 18503

Be careful NOT to use the park's MAILING address with a GPS unit as there is no entrance at that location. If the location info above fails, you can try 350 Cliff St with ZIP Code 18503 (the bookstore mail address).

General Driving Directions
Take I-81 to exit 185. At first traffic light turn left on Lackawanna Avenue. Continue on Lackawanna Ave to Cliff St and park entrance.
properties.weatherInfo: Warm and sometimes humid summers; cold and rainy or snowy winters. Wear seasonable clothing and good walking shoes. For travel aboard the summer and fall seasonal excursion trains, please note that the commuter-type coaches are not air-conditioned, or may not be heated. Therefore, we recommend that you dress appropriately for the season that you plan to visit us!
properties.name: Steamtown
properties.description: You'd feel heat from the firebox, smell hot steam and oil; you'd hear the whistle, feel the ground vibrate, and watch as one-ton drive rods turned steel wheels. Remember the sound of "chuff-chuff" from the smokestack? Today, you can learn the history of steam railroad transportation, and the people who built, repaired and rode, as we work to preserve a special era in America's industrial history!

images.altText: An aerial overview of Steamtown National Historic Site
images.title: Steamtown NHS  - aerial overview
images.caption: This aerial overview of Steamtown NHS, which was created within the former railyards of the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western "Scranton Yards"

images.altText: Sparks fly as a park mechanic grinds metal in the Steamtown Locomotive Shops
images.title: Sparks fly
images.caption: Visitors can observe locomotive maintenance and repairs taking place in the Locomotive Shops on a guided tour

images.altText: A park ranger displays Roundhouse building details to a group of students
images.title: Education Programs
images.caption: Ranger-led educational programs are available at Steamtown NHS.  Here, a park ranger works with a group of students to explain Roundhouse architecture

images.altText: Park rangers assist children at a new temporary exhibit within the History Museum
images.title: Architectural Dig Exhibit
images.caption: The site features tempoary, changing exhibits in its History and Technology museums

images.altText: Visitors await to board a seasonal train excursion at their diesel locomotive passes
images.title: Train rides
images.caption: Seasonal train rides, both inside the park boundaries and to further destinations, are part of the Steamtown experience, whether with vintage diesel or steam locomotives

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for Tuskegee Institute National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Tuskegee Institute Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: From Atlanta - Follow I-85S towards Montgomery, AL  Take Exit 32 and turn left on the overpass onto Pleasant Springs Dr. Travel approximately 2 miles and turn left on Franklin Rd. (Co. Rd. 30).  Follow Franklin Rd. for 3 miles to the traffic light. Park headquarters on the left corner..
properties.weatherInfo: The weather in Tuskegee is generally sunny with an average of 218 sunny days annually.  Tuskegee gets an average of 52 inches of rain per year. The high in July averages 92 degrees, and the average low in January is 34 degrees.
properties.name: Tuskegee Institute
properties.description: In 1881, Booker T. Washington arrived in Alabama and started building Tuskegee Institute both in reputation and literally brick by brick.  He recruited the best and the brightest to come and teach here including George Washington Carver who arrived in 1896.  Carver’s innovations in agriculture, especially with peanuts, expanded Tuskegee’s standing throughout the country.  The story continues….

images.altText: A three story Queen Anne Revival style red brick house
images.title: The Oaks - The Home of Booker T. Washington
images.caption: This house, like Washington himself, was a lesson plan to both students and benefactors of Tuskegee Institute.

images.altText: Sunset of blue, red, and orange sky behind The Oaks, Booker T. Washngton home
images.title: Sunset Over The Oaks
images.caption: As the the sun sets behind The Oaks, the beauty of the Tuskegee sky shines through.

images.altText: A  brown colored modified school bus with two windows
images.title: The Movable School
images.caption: Many are amazed to see the last Movable School that was used by Dr. George W. Carver to bring education to the rural communities surrounding Tuskegee

images.altText: George W. Carver and Henry Ford seated facing one another talking
images.title: Carver with Friend and Fellow Inventor, Henry Ford
images.caption: Millions have been impressed by the genious of George W. Carver, including Henry Ford, Founder of Ford Motor Company

images.altText: Bottle of Peanut Oil with green label - one of Dr. Carver's many uses for the peanut
images.title: Carver's Peanut Oil
images.caption: Hundreds flocked to Tuskegee for polio treatment using George W. Carver's peanut oil

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to visit Weir Farm National Historic Site
entranceFees.title: Weir Farm NHS Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
House tours are offered May through October, Wednesday until Sunday at 11:00 am, 1:00 pm, 2:00 pm, and 3:00 pm. Approximately 45 minutes in length.

Tours will be filled by same-day registration only, first-come, first-served. One person may register for a maximum of four people (including themselves). Tour size is limited to 12 visitors. Registration will be managed at the Burlingham House Visitor Center.
entranceFees.title: Weir House Tour Fee

entranceFees.description:
From May through October, the Young Studio and the Weir Studio are open to the public from 10:00 am until 4:00 pm, Wednesday through Sunday. Explore the artists's studios and learn about their techniques, styles, influences, and creating art at Weir Farm National Historic Site.
A member of the park's staff or a park volunteer docent will be stationed in the studios to answer questions and provide guidance for interpreting these spaces.
entranceFees.title: Studios Tour Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
If you are coming to Weir Farm National Historic Site as part of a group that will require three or more vehicles, please call in advance to arrange a group visit.
 
-Follow Route 7 the Branchville section of Ridgefield.
-Turn onto Route 102 West at a traffic light.
-Take 2nd left onto Old Branchville Road.
-Turn left at first stop sign onto Nod Hill Road.
-Follow Nod Hill Road one mile; continue straight after stop sign at Pelham Lane to 735 Nod Hill Road
properties.weatherInfo:
Weir Farm’s grounds are open all year and each season offers a unique experience. For a comfortable visit please note the following information.
Winter: Temperatures average from 20 F to 40 F.  Storms and colder weather are possible. 
Spring: Temperatures average from 30 F to 70 F.  Rain is common. 
Summer: Temperatures average from 60 F to 85 F.  High humidity is common in July and August. 
Fall: Temperatures average from 35 F to 75 F.  Foliage season runs from mid-September to mid-to-late October.
properties.name: Weir Farm
properties.description: Visit the home and studio of America's most beloved Impressionist, J. Alden Weir, and walk in the footsteps of generations of world-class artists. Set amidst more than 60 acres of painterly woods, fields, and waterways, you’ll soon see why Weir described his home as the "Great Good Place." Weir’s farm is a national legacy to American Impressionism, the creative spirit, and historic preservation.

images.altText: A park ranger, with a giant paintbrush leads a procession of girl scouts through the landscape.
images.title: Ranger with Girl Scouts
images.caption: Park Rangers lead tours of students and Girl Scouts throughout the year.

images.altText: Students paint in one of the fields at the park just beyond an open fence gate in a stone wall.
images.title: Students painting in the landscape
images.caption: Students from Rockwell Elementary School continue a 130+ year old tradition of artists painting in the landscape.

images.altText: A solitary artist is facing away from the viewer and painting in a meadow with just their easel.
images.title: Artist painting at Weir Farm National Historic Site
images.caption: A plein air artist captures the beauty of the landscape at Weir Farm National Historic Site

images.altText: A park ranger talks to two visitors in the entrance to a historic painting stuido
images.title: Park Ranger in the Weir Studio
images.caption: Park Ranger Andrew Lowe, talks to two visitors about the Weir Studio in May 2014.

images.altText: Looking at their backs, we see a Park Ranger lead a group of elementary students down a path.
images.title: Park Ranger and students walking to the pond
images.caption: Park Ranger Andrew Lowe leads a group of students on a trip to Weir Pond.

images.altText: A group of visitors are in a line, from left to right, that curves onto the porch of the Weir Hosue.
images.title: Opening of the Weir House - May 2014
images.caption: Visitors wait in line to enter the Weir House on the first day it was opened, May 2014.

images.altText: A view of the south side of the Weir House with porch visable, showing a fence in front of the home
images.title: Weir House, 2014
images.caption: The Weir House during Grand Opening Weekend, 2014

images.altText: A view of the north side of a c. 1835 era barn. A thrown stone wall cuts across the lower left side.
images.title: Weir Barn
images.caption: View of the north side of the Weir Barn. The Weir Studio and the Young Studio are visible in the background.

images.altText: A fall view up a slight ridge to northeastern corner of the Weir Studio.
images.title: Weir Studio by Peter Margonelli
images.caption: The color and light of the park amplifies during the fall season as reds and yellows surround the historic studios.

images.altText: A large still pond in the foreground reflects the tree line that rims the pond
images.title: Weir Pond
images.caption: Weir Pond was built in 1896 after Julian Alden Weir won 1st prize at the Boston Art Club Exposition.

images.altText: A Park Ranger is walking away from the viewer on a path to the historic Weir House and two studios
images.title: Park Ranger headed to the Weir House
images.caption: A Park Ranger is taking the Visitor Use Path toward the Weir House.

images.altText: A northeast looking view of the Weir Studio, Tool Shed and behind that the Weir Barn
images.title: Weir Studio - Autumn
images.caption: A filtered view of the Weir Studio on a gorgeous fall day.

properties.weatherInfo:
Puerto Rico enjoys year round tropical climate. Winters are breeze and summers are mostly hot and humid. It rains all year long with a "dry" season in April. Temperatures range from 80's in the winter to 90's in the summer.

The hurricane season starts in June and ends in November. On the longest day, June 22nd, the sun sets around 7 PM. On the shortest day, December 22nd, the sun sets around 4:30 PM.
properties.name: San Juan
properties.description: San Juan National Historic Site preserves stories of great ambition and aspirations. Countries fought for control of this tiny yet strategic island for centuries. Generations of soldiers have lived and worked within the forts. Visitors today are as inspired by these stories as they are by the beauty of the architecture and the ingenuity of design and engineering of this World Heritage Site.

images.altText: Castillo San Felipe del Morro Aereal View
images.title: Castillo San Felipe del Morro Aereal View
images.caption: Castillo San Felipe del Morro Aereal View

images.altText: Castillo San Cristobal Aereal View

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to visit Maggie L. Walker National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Traveling north on I-95 take exit 76A, Chamberlayne Avenue, turn left at the light, go to the first light and turn left onto West Leigh Street. Go 3 blocks to 2nd Street; the site is located on the left.
Traveling south on I-95, take exit 76B at Belvidere and turn left at the stop sign onto West Leigh Street. Go approximately 8 blocks to 2nd Street; the site is located on the left.
Traveling east on I-64: follow directions for traveling south on I-95.
Traveling west on I-64: take Downtown/5th Street exit
properties.weatherInfo: Summer is hot and humid, spring and winter are pleasant/mild, winter can be cold and occasionally snowy.
properties.name: Maggie L Walker
properties.description: Maggie Lena Walker devoted her life to civil rights advancement, economic empowerment, and educational opportunities for Jim Crow-era African Americans and women. As a bank president, newspaper editor, and fraternal leader, Walker served as an inspiration of pride and progress. Today, Walker’s home is preserved as a tribute to her enduring legacy of vision, courage, and determination.

images.altText: Maggie L. Walker's home and adjacent buildings
images.title: Maggie L. Walker National Historic Site
images.caption: Maggie L. Walker's stately home was located on a street dubbed "Quality Row."

properties.fullName: Maggie L Walker National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Yucca House National Monument.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
•From Cortez, take Hwy. 491 south approximately 8 miles. 
•Take a right on MC County Road B (green sign), which is a dirt road one mile south of MC Road C. 
•Drive 0.8 miles, crossing a paved road (MC Road 21), and take the next dirt road on the right (before the farmhouse on the left). 
•Follow this road north and west for 1.4 miles, and head towards a white ranch house with a red roof on the west horizon.
•Once at the ranch house, Yucca House NM is on the left side if the driveway.

entrancePasses.description: There is no entrance fee for Yucca House National Monument. No passes are available.
entrancePasses.title: No Entrance Pass is available.

properties.weatherInfo: Spring and Fall are mild with daytime temperatures ranging from 50 F to 80 F.  Winter temperatures are below 50 F with occasional snowstorms.  Summers are hot and dry, with highs in the 90s.
properties.name: Yucca House
properties.description: Through a continuing tradition of public and private cooperation, Yucca House National Monument preserves one of the largest archeological sites in SW Colorado. The unexcavated nature of the site preserves its integrity and beauty for future generations of scientists and visitors. Experience a sense of discovery by visiting a site that has remained largely untouched for the past 800 years!

images.altText: Cattails with mesa in background.
images.title: Yucca House Spring
images.caption: Cattails define marshy locations watered by springs.

images.altText: View of Mesa Verde landform
images.title: View of Mesa Verde from Yucca House
images.caption: View of Mesa Verde above from Yucca House in the valley below.

images.altText: Masonry walls seen through shrubbery
images.title: Walls of the Yucca House Pueblo
images.caption: Ancient walls of Yucca House still standing today.

images.altText: Close up view of an ancient wall at Yucca House
images.title: Ancestral Puebloan Wall at Yucca House
images.caption: View of an Ancestral Puebloan wall still standing at Yucca House.

images.altText: View of  ancient wall in the center of agricultural land surrounding it.
images.title: Yucca House in Context
images.caption: The Yucca House archeological site is surrounded by agricultural land today.

properties.directionsInfo: On State Route A1A overlooking Matanzas Bay in the heart of the historic district of Saint Augustine, the Castillo is approximately a five mile drive from Interstate 95.

entrancePasses.description: One year admission pass for the card holder and up to three additional adults.
entrancePasses.title: Castillo Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
St. Augustine has a semi-tropical climate with over 300 days of sunshine each year. Summers (May-September) are hot, bright, and humid with afternoon thunderstorms common. Temperatures range from the lower 70s to the mid 90s F.
 
Spring (March-mid-May) and Autumn (October-late November) can be pleasant with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s into the 80s F.
 
The Winter months (December-March) are usually dry. Temperatures can be cool ranging from the upper 30s through the 60sF.
properties.name: Castillo de San Marcos
properties.description: A monument not only of stone and mortar but of human determination and endurance, the Castillo de San Marcos symbolizes the clash between cultures which ultimately resulted in our uniquely unified nation.  Still resonant with the struggles of an earlier time, these original walls provide tangible evidence of America’s grim but remarkable history.

images.altText: Drawbridge entrance to the Castillo de San Marcos
images.title: Castillo Drawbridge
images.caption: Crossing a dry moat, this drawbridge was the only way into the Castillo.

images.altText: Furnace for heating cannon balls
images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Hot Shot Furnace
images.caption: This furnace, in the water battery on the east side of the Castillo, heated cannonballs red hot to be fired at wooden vessels.

images.altText: Four black iron cannon mounted on carriages line the walls of the Castillo.
images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Cannon
images.caption: The Castillo features both iron and bronze cannon and mortar from the period.

images.altText: Re-enactors of the first Spanish period cover their ears while firing a cannon.
images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Cannon Firing
images.caption: Cannon firing demonstrations are scheduled five times a day every Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.

images.altText: Aerial view of the Castillo and the city of St. Augustine
images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Aerial View
images.caption: the Castillo commands the northern edge of the heart of downtown St. Augsutine.

properties.fullName: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument

entranceFees.description: There is no fee for Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial
entranceFees.title: No Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Public Transportation: The Memorial is accessible by the Blue Line of the Metro subway system. The Arlington Cemetery subway station is near the Visitor Center for the cemetery.

Car: Arlington House is located inside Arlington National Cemetery. 

Parking:  Handicapped parking is available at the Old Administration Building, located behind Arlington House.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers on the parkway are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning.

Winters on the parkway are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. Please be alert for snowplows and icy spots on roadways.

Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
properties.name: Arlington House, The Robert  E. Lee Memorial
properties.description: Arlington House is the nation’s memorial to Robert E. Lee. It honors him for specific reasons, including his role in promoting peace and reunion after the Civil War. In a larger sense it exists as a place of study and contemplation of the meaning of some of the most difficult aspects of American History: military service; sacrifice; citizenship; duty; loyalty; slavery and freedom.

images.altText: Wreaths at Arlington Cemetery
images.title: Arlington House
images.caption: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial

images.altText: Spring in the Garden
images.title: The Kitchen Garden
images.caption: The Kitchen Garden at Arlington House has been feeding people for over 200 years

images.altText: The Tomb of the Civil War Unknown
images.title: The Tomb of the Civil War Unknown
images.caption: The Tomb of the Civil War Unknown was established in Mrs. Lee's rose garden during the Civil War

images.altText: The Custis- Lee Wedding
images.title: The Custis- Lee Wedding
images.caption: Robert E. Lee and Mary Custis were married on June 30th, 1831.

images.altText: Two images of Arlington House from 1933
images.title: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial
images.caption: Arlington House was transferred from the War Department to the National Park Service in 1933. On the same day many other parks in Virginia and the District of Columbia were placed under the jurisdiction of the National Park Service.

addresses.line1: Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial
Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial

entranceFees.description: The Jimmy Carter National Historic Site consists of three locations: Plains High School Visitor Center, Plains Depot, and The Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm. All locations are fee free.
entranceFees.title: The Jimmy Carter National Historic Site is fee free.

properties.directionsInfo: The Jimmy Carter National Historic Site, Plains High School Museum and Visitor Center is located in Plains, Georgia. The address is 300 North Bond Street. The zip code is 31780
properties.weatherInfo: Weather in Southwest Georgia can change in the blink of an eye during the summer months. Thunderstorms and high temperatures can make it unpleasant for visitors. Check the local forecast and dress appropriately.
properties.name: Jimmy Carter
properties.description: Few U.S. Presidents have had such close ties with where they were born and raised. The rural southern culture of Plains, Georgia, that revolves around farming, church and school, had a large influence in molding the character and in shaping the political policies of the 39th President of the United States.

images.altText: A picture of the front of the home Jimmy Carter lived in as a young boy.
images.title: Jimmy Carter's Boyhood Home
images.caption: Front view of the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home in Archery, Georgia.

images.altText: Front view of Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum
images.title: Plains High School Museum and Visitors Center
images.caption: Almost one hundred thousand visitors visit Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum yearly.

images.altText: The Plains train depot that President Carter used as the 1976 campaign headquarters.
images.title: Plains Depot, 1976 Campaign Headquarters
images.caption: The oldest building in Plains, the train depot, was used as the 1976 campaign headquarters for President Carter.

images.altText: Jimmy Carter speaking to the crowd; Presidents' Day 2016
images.title: Jimmy Carter Presidents' Day 2016
images.caption: President Jimmy Carter speaking to the crowd at Plains High School for Presidents' Day 2016

images.altText: Rosalynn Carter signing a book, Presidents' Day 2016
images.title: Rosalynn Carter, Presidents' Day 2016
images.caption: Rosalynn Carter signing a book she authored during Presidents' Day 2016

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to enter Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: NO ADDMISSION FEE

properties.directionsInfo: The park is accessible via public transportation and by car.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers typically are warm and humid with average afternoon high temperatures are in the lower 90s.  During winter the high temperatures average from the mid-50s to  the lower 60s.  Lows average in the mid-30s.   Spring and Autumn seasons are characterized by much variability from day to day and from year to year.  The average date of first freeze is in mid-November and the date of the last freeze is mid to late March.
properties.name: Martin Luther King, Jr.
properties.description: A young boy grows up in a time of segregation…A dreamer is moved by destiny into leadership of the modern civil rights movement…This was Martin Luther King, Jr.  Come hear his story, visit the home of his birth, and where he played as a child.  Walk in his footsteps, and hear his voice in the church where he moved hearts and minds.  Marvel at how he was an instrument for social change.

images.altText: The Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.title: Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.caption: The Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr.

images.altText: Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church
images.title: Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church
images.caption: The spiritual home of the King Family.

images.altText: Visitor center and the "I Have a Dream" Internrational World Peace Rose
images.title: The Visitor Center at Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park
images.caption: The visitor center features an exhibit entitled "Courage To Lead".

images.altText: Fire Station No. 6
images.title: Fire Station No. 6
images.caption: The second Fire Station integrated in the City of Atlanta.

images.altText: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.title: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.caption: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.  rests on a brick island within a reflecting pool.

properties.fullName: Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees to visit this site.
entranceFees.title: Fee-Free Site

properties.directionsInfo: The park is located on the south side of Long Point Road .7 miles from US Highway 17, or 3 miles if coming from I-526.
properties.weatherInfo: Winters are generally mild. Summers are hot and humid.
properties.name: Charles Pinckney
properties.description: Charles Pinckney was a principal author and signer of the United States Constitution. This remnant of his coastal plantation is preserved to tell the story of a "founding father," his life of public service, the lives of enslaved African Americans on South Carolina Lowcountry plantations and their influences on Charles Pinckney.

images.altText: 1828 Lowcountry cottage and grounds
images.title: Historic House and Grounds
images.caption: The historic house serves as the park's visitor center and features exhibits, film options, and a museum shop.

images.credit: New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation
images.altText: Charles Pinckney portrait
images.title: Charles Pinckney
images.caption: American founding father, Charles Pinckney, was a contributing author and signer of the U.S. Constitution.

images.altText: Live Oak
images.title: Live Oak
images.caption: Spanish Moss drape Live Oak in the early morning sun.

images.altText: Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
images.title: Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
images.caption: Flowering plants, like this Southern Magnolia, are remnant of historic ornamental gardens once enjoyed by former farm owners and still marveled over by modern visitors.

images.altText: Corn Crib
images.title: Corn Crib
images.caption: Snee Farm, once owned by Charles Pinckney, was a working farm for over 200 years. This corn crib, built in 1910, is one of the few remaining structures of a bygone era.

images.altText: Boardwalk and Marsh
images.title: Boardwalk and Marsh
images.caption: A .25 mile loop trail is a popular activity for visitors to enjoy the grounds and see points of cultural and natural interest along the way.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee is for individual admittance into the exhibits inside the visitor center building. Your receipt will be good for seven days from the time of purchase. There is no fee for viewing the grounds.
entranceFees.title: Entrance walk in - per person

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate 40 Eastbound: Exit at Roland, and drive six miles on highway 64 to downtown Fort Smith.
From Interstate 40 Westbound & from North I 540 & Fayetteville, take Interstate 40 westbound to I 540 south. Exit west on Rogers Ave. and continue to downtown.

In the downtown area: On Rogers or Garrison Ave turn south at 4th St. Turn right onto Garland Ave. At the end of the next block is the entrance to the main parking lot. Parking is also available on Third Street.

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass allows the pass holder and 3 adults (16 and older) free entrance to all the exhibits in the visitor center. The pass is valid for 12 months from the month of purchase, expiring the last day of that month.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Smith National Historic Site Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Fort Smith weather includes four distinct, yet temperate seasons. Spring and fall are usually mild while late summer is hot and humid. During winter months, temperatures occasionally dip into the teens.

Forecast often changes dramatically due to surrounding weather influences. Arkansas's central location allows weather systems from all directions to influence its climate. The area is prone to flash flooding and river flooding in rainy seasons.
properties.name: Fort Smith
properties.description:
From the establishment of the first Fort Smith on December 25, 1817, to the final days of Judge Isaac C. Parker's jurisdiction over Indian Territory in 1896, Fort Smith National Historic Site preserves almost 80 years of history. 

Explore life on the edge of Indian Territory through the stories of soldiers, the Trail of Tears, dangerous outlaws, and the brave lawmen who pursued them.

images.altText: Commissary and Supply Wagon
images.title: Commissary and Supply Wagon
images.caption: In 1845, Fort Smith was converted to a supply depot. With this mission, Fort Smith became one of the busiest supply posts in the southwest.

images.altText: Aerial view of visitor center
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: The former barracks, courthouse, and jail serves as the park's visitor center

images.altText: Entrance sign in snow
images.title: Entrance sign
images.caption: Entrance sign along the river trail on a snowy day.

images.altText: Foundations of first Fort Smith and Arkansas River
images.title: Foundations of First Fort Smith
images.caption: Foundations of the first Fort Smith with Arkansas River in the background

images.altText: Jail Wagon and Gallows
images.title: Jail Wagon and Gallows
images.caption: A jail wagon like this one was use the transport prisoners to the Federal Courthouse 6th Street.

images.altText: Supply Wagon and visitor center
images.title: Supply Wagon and Visitor Center
images.caption: Supply Wagon and visitor center

entranceFees.description: Entrance to Pipe Spring is $10.00 per person for up to 7 days (includes $3.00 tribal use fee). Beginning January 2, 2020, cash payments will no longer be accepted (credit or debit cards only). Visitors may pay entrance fees or purchase an Interagency Annual Pass with cash at the Zion Forever Project bookstore in the Visitor Center. Children 15 and under are admitted for free.
entranceFees.title: Pipe Spring Entrance Fee - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo:
Pipe Spring National Monument is located 15 miles west of Fredonia, AZ and 45 miles east of Hurricane, UT. 

From Interstate 15, turn onto Utah State Route 9 in Hurricane, Utah. Take Utah State Route 59 east out of Hurricane. This road turns into Arizona State Route 389 at the state line. Pipe Spring is 45 miles east of Hurricane. 

From Utah Highway 89 and 89A, turn onto Arizona State Route 389 in Fredonia, Arizona. Pipe Spring is 15 miles west of Fredonia.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather is hot in summer and cold in winter. Expect summer highs to be 80-100 degrees Fahrenheit and winter highs to be 30-50 degrees. Early morning and late afternoon can be considerably cooler; dress in layers and bring plenty of sunscreen. Arizona climate is very dry -- bring at least 1 liter of water per person per visit to Pipe Spring.
properties.name: Pipe Spring
properties.description: Beneath vermilion cliffs, American Indians, Mormon ranchers, plants, animals, and many others have depended on the life-giving water found at the desert oasis at Pipe Spring. Learn about settler and Kaibab Paiute life by exploring the museum, historic fort and cabins, garden, and Ridge Trail. Visit with rangers and ranch animals, and attend living history demonstrations and talks.

images.altText: A glittering sky of stars glows above a historic covered wagon.
images.title: Milky Way over the Chuckwagon
images.caption: The Milky Way glitters above the chuckwagon at Pipe Spring National Monument. The monument has great night sky clarity because it is located inside the first Dark Sky Nation: The Kaibab Indian Reservation.

images.altText: A sandstone fort rests between desert scrub in the foreground and a mountain in the distance.
images.title: Winsor Castle
images.caption: Winsor Castle, constructed in 1870-72, is surrounded by the harsh beauty of Utah and Arizona's canyon country.

images.altText: A lush garden filled with settler and native crops grows in front of a sandstone fort
images.title: Historic Garden at Pipe Spring
images.caption: Pipe Spring maintains a living history garden that grows settler and native crops as they would have grown in the 1870s. In the fall, visitors may harvest free fruit and veggies.

images.altText: A red-orange sandstone cabin surrounded by white snow.
images.title: West Cabin in Snow
images.caption: Wintertime showcases a stark peace and stillness at the historic buildings. Pictured here, West Cabin sticks out after a snowstorm.

images.altText: A large longhorn cattle steer shows off his 6-foot span horns inside a corral.
images.title: Longhorn Cattle
images.caption: Whitmore and Tess, two Texas Longhorns, greet visitors. Longhorns were brought to Pipe Spring in the 1860s.

phoneNumbers.description: main

entranceFees.description: Governors Island National Monument does not charge an entrance fee. The Trust for Governors Island does charge a $2 fee to ride the ferry. Seniors pay $1 and children are free. All ferries before Noon on weekends are free.
entranceFees.title: No park entrance fees

properties.directionsInfo: Governors Island is located in New York Harbor, 1/2 mile from the southern tip of Lower Manhattan and 400 yards west of the end of Brooklyn's Atlantic Avenue and Red Hook waterfront. It is accessible only via ferry. Ferry service from Manhattan is the main way to access the island. During the summer public access season, the ferry departs from Battery Maritime Building at 10 South Street, at South and Whitehall Streets (next to the Staten Island ferry terminal). Check www.govisland.com for ferry schedules.
properties.weatherInfo: During the summer public access season from May to September, the weather is typical of the mid-Atlantic region. Thunderstorms can come quickly with short downpours. There may be extended periods of heat or humidity that might last a week or more. The island is generally a few degrees cooler than the city due to the fairly constant breeze.
properties.name: Governors Island
properties.description: From 1794 to 1966, the U.S. Army on Governors Island was part of the social, political, and economic tapestry of New York City. Today, the island is a vibrant summer seasonal venue of art, culture, and performance against the backdrop of two centuries of military heritage and the skyline of one of the great cities of the world. The island is open to the public,  May 1st thru Oct 31st

images.altText: Bridge over dry moat leading into a gated fort.
images.title: Fort Jay gate house and moat.
images.caption: An early spring morning view of Fort Jay. The gate house is the oldest structure on Governors Island dating back to 1794.

images.altText: Front of sandstone brick fort with arched entrance way.
images.title: Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument
images.caption: Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument was constructed in 1811 and was a pioneering design in American fortifications.

images.altText: A park ranger talking to a group of visitors inside a large stone room in a fort.
images.title: Ranger guided tour of Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument
images.caption: Ranger-led tours of Castle Williams show the pioneering features of fortification architecture that would be used in other masonry forts constructed in the 1800s.

images.altText: Manhattan Skyline stands behind the barracks of Fort Jay
images.title: Manhattan from Fort Jay
images.caption: History frames our understanding of the present

images.altText: Canon and Manhattan Skyline from top of castle
images.title: Manhattan from Castle Williams
images.caption: A civil war era canon sitting upon the top of Castle Williams juxtaposes the new and old, with the glimering shine of Manhattan in the background

entranceFees.description: The Lincoln Home Visitor Center parking lot fee is $2.00 per hour per vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Parking lot fee

properties.directionsInfo:
By car:
The Visitor Center is located at 426 South Seventh Street. Use this address when seeking GPS or on-line directions. The 4-block Lincoln Home Neighborhood is open to pedestrians and closed to vehicles. 
For specific directions go to http://www.nps.gov/liho/planyourvisit/directions.htm

entrancePasses.description: No Lincoln Home passes
entrancePasses.title: No Lincoln Home passes

properties.weatherInfo: Temperatures can range from 0 degrees Fahrenheit in the winter to 95+ degrees in the summer. High humidity is common during the summer months.
properties.name: Lincoln Home
properties.description: Abraham Lincoln believed in the ideal that everyone in America should have the opportunity to improve their economic and social condition.  Lincoln’s life was the embodiment of that idea.  We know him as the sixteenth president but he was also a spouse, parent, and neighbor who experienced the same hopes, dreams, and challenges of life that are still experienced by many people today.

images.altText: Lincoln Home with snow
images.title: Lincoln Home in winter
images.caption: Lincoln Home during a snowstorm

images.altText: Lincoln Home surrounded by trees in autumn
images.title: Lincoln Home in autumn
images.caption: View of Lincoln Home in autumn

images.altText: Lincoln Home with bunting draped below its fence
images.title: Lincoln Home draped in bunting
images.caption: Lincoln Home with bunting

images.altText: Lincoln Home light up at night
images.title: Lincoln Home at night
images.caption: Lincoln Home at night

images.altText: A diversity of visitors standing outside Lincoln Home
images.title: Lincoln Home
images.caption: Thousands of visitors tour Lincoln Home every year

entranceFees.description: The Park and all areas, programs, and events are free of charge.
entranceFees.title: De Soto National Memorial

properties.directionsInfo:
Driving Directions:
From I-75 Take exit 220 SR 64/Manatee Ave, Gulf Beaches exit. Travel west on SR 64 for approximately 12 miles to 75th St. W. Turn right onto 75th St. W. travel north approximately 2 miles to the northern terminus 75th St. W. turns into De Soto Memorial Hwy and dead ends into the park.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers avg. Temperature is 90 degrees Fahrenheit with a relative humidity of 80-90% Late afternoon showers and thunderstorms are common usually lasting only 10-20 minutes. Winters are mild and dry with lows reaching on average 60 degrees.
properties.name: De Soto
properties.description: In May 1539, Conquistador Hernando de Soto’s army of soldiers, hired mercenaries, craftsmen, and clergy made landfall in Tampa Bay. They were met with fierce resistance of indigenous people protecting their homelands. De Soto’s quest for glory and gold would be a four year, four thousand mile odyssey of intrigue, warfare, disease, and discovery that would form the history of the United States.

images.altText: Reenactor Bill Boston on his horse Dixie in front of the De Soto Monument.
images.title: De Soto Monument
images.caption: Reenactor Bill Boston on his horse Dixie in front of the De Soto Monument.

images.altText: De Soto Tim Burke greets on of the parks Junior Rangers
images.title: De Soto and the Junior Ranger
images.caption: De Soto Tim Burke greets on of the parks Junior Rangers

images.altText: Sunset at the Park
images.title: Sunset at De Soto
images.caption: The Sunsets on another day at De Soto NM

images.altText: Rangers lead visitors on a unique park fishing experience
images.title: De Soto Ranchero Fish Camps
images.caption: Superintendent Souder helps a young fisherman show off his catch at the De Soto Ranchero Fish Camp

images.altText: Rangers lead visitors on a unique park fishing experience
images.title: De Soto Ranchero Fish Camps
images.caption: Superintendent Souder helps a young fisherman show off his catch at the De Soto Ranchero Fish Camp

phoneNumbers.description: Phone are regularly monitored, but in the event that a ranger is unavailable to take your call, please leave us a detailed message with return contact information, and we will be happy to get back to you as soon as we can.

emailAddresses.description: Please use this email to send us your questions/concerns.

entranceFees.description: A per person entrance fee is charged for anyone 16 years of age and older. Anyone under 16 years of age is free. It is valid for seven days.  It admits the visitor to programs and buildings open to the public during their visit.  Some buildings/programs require a ticket as there is limited space.  There is no extra charge for the tickets which are distributed on a first-come, first-served basis the day of the program.
entranceFees.title: Thomas Edison NHP - Per Person Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Permits the use of the audio tour equipment for the day's visit. The tour has several opens:  a standard audio tour, family or children's version, plus numerous in-depth stops along tour route.  The standard tour is also available in German, Spanish, and Japanese
entranceFees.title: Laboratory Complex Audio Tour

properties.directionsInfo:
From the Garden State Parkway take exit 145 or from the New Jersey Turnpike take Exit 15W to Route 280 West. Take Route 280 West to Exit 10. Turn right onto Northfield Avenue. At second light turn left onto Main Street. Go about 0.75 mile  to parking on left and Laboratory Complex on the right.
From Route 280 East take exit 9. Turn left onto Mt. Pleasant Avenue.  At second traffic light turn left onto Main Street. Go about 0.50 mile to parking on left and Laboratory Complex on the right.

entrancePasses.description:
Valid at Thomas Edison National Historical Park only for 12 months from date of purchase. This pass permits the pass holder and three other adult guests free entrance into the park and programs. All visitors 15 years old and under are free.
Important Note: Entering the park using an Edison Annual Park Pass does not guarantee entry into the Edison Home, Glenmont. Tickets are available on a first-come basis only. Early arrival is strongly advised.
entrancePasses.title: Thomas Edison NHP Park Specific Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Spring and Fall weather can be cool, while summer is usually warm and humid.  Winter is frequently snowy and cold.  It is recommended that visitors dress for the weather.  Visitors may need jackets or rain gear as they will be walking between buildings as they tour the park during inclement weather. Please keep any rain gear/umbrellas with you during your visit.
properties.name: Thomas Edison
properties.description: Thomas Edison’s home and laboratory are a step back in time, when machines were run by belts and pulleys and music was played on phonographs.  Where to the passerby, the buildings betray little evidence of the industries they once started.  Discover where America’s greatest inventor changed our world forever.

images.altText: Large salmon colored house with green lawn and blue sky
images.title: Glenmont - Home of Thomas Edison
images.caption: Thomas Edison purchased Glenmont as a wedding present for his wife Mina.

images.altText: large room with machines connected to belts and pullies
images.title: Heavy Machine Shop at Laboratory Complex
images.caption: One of two machine shops where Thomas Edison and his staff worked on new ideas and products.

images.altText: Cream colored, two story cement building
images.title: Glenmont Garage
images.caption: Thomas Edison's poured concrete garage houses several electric and gas vehicles belonging to the family.

images.altText: Small red building next to large brick building with a water tower in the background.
images.title: Park Entrance
images.caption: Just as Thomas Edison did every morning, visitors enter through the main laboratory gates.

images.altText: Large black building.
images.title: Replica Black Maria
images.caption: The Black Maria was the first building built for the recording of motion pictures.

entranceFees.description:
Hubbell Home tour fee is $2.00 per person for above the age of 15 years. Free for children under 15.
Group size is 15 people per tour.
School trips and special groups, please call the park for more information.
entranceFees.title: Hubbell Home Tours Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site is located at mile post 446.3 on AZ state route 264. Visitors traveling on I-40 can take U.S. Highway 191 North to Ganado and drive west on Hwy. 264. If you are traveling from Gallup, New Mexico, you may take U.S. Highway 491 North to U.S. Highway 264 west toward Ganado, through Window Rock,Arizona. When you are driving south from Chinle, Arizona on Hwy. 191 you will drive east when you reach Hwy. 264.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring is normally windy.
Summer can reach into high 90s with thunderstorms beginning in July into August.
Fall is cooling off.
Last couple of Winters have been dry and with a couple of inches of snow.
properties.name: Hubbell Trading Post
properties.description:
The squeaky wooden floor greets your entry into the oldest operating trading post on the Navajo Nation.  When your eyes adjust to the dim light in the "bullpen" you find you’ve just entered a mercantile.  Hubbell Trading Post has been serving Ganado selling goods and Native American Art since 1878.

Discover Hubbell Trading Post NHS, where history is made every day!

images.altText: Spring lambs with their Navajo-Churro ewe.
images.title: Navajo-Churro ewe with lambs
images.caption: Each spring Navajo-Churro ewes give birth to their lambs at Hubbell Trading Post.

images.altText: Steer skull greets visitors.
images.title: Front of Trading Post
images.caption: Above the entry way into the trading post, there is a sun-bleached steer skull.

images.altText: Inside the Hubbell Family home, looking south.
images.title: Hubbell Family Home
images.caption: Thousands of visitors have visited the Hubbell Family home in the past 50 years.

images.altText: Bullpen inside the trading post.
images.title: Hubbell Trading Post bullpen
images.caption: Thousands of visitors and community members walk through the bullpen of the trading post.

images.altText: Interpretive exhibit has Mr. JL Hubbell holding his grand daughter LaCharles.
images.title: Interpretive exhibits inside the Visitor Center
images.caption: New interpretive exhibits on the family, trading post, and weaving.

addresses.line1: Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site

properties.fullName: Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: Chamizal National Memorial is a fee-free park.  There is no entrance fee for the park grounds or Cultural Center exhibit. Programs and events sponsored or presented by the Memorial's park rangers are free to the general public.
entranceFees.title: Chamizal Entrance and Sponsored Programs

properties.directionsInfo: From the west take exit 21 off of I-10 toward Piedras Street. Turn right onto Piedras and follow it to Paisano Drive. Turn left onto Paisano and then turn right onto San Marcial Street. From the north take exit 20A off of US-54 for US-62 toward Paisano Drive. Turn right onto Paisano and follow it until you reach San Marcial Street. From the east take exit 22B on I-10 toward US-54. Stay left until two lanes merge, move into the right lane toward Paisano Drive. Turn right at the light and merge onto Paisano.
properties.weatherInfo: Chamizal National Memorial is open year-round, but periodic winter weather conditions may cause closure. Please check for alerts on the park website: www.nps.gov/cham. Thunderstorms typically occur during summer and early fall. There may be no shelter to avoid lightning, so please prepare by looking at weather forecasts and paying attention to developing weather conditions.
properties.name: Chamizal
properties.description: Chamizal is more than just an urban park to recreate or enjoy a quiet afternoon. These grounds are a reminder of the harmonious settlement of a 100-year border dispute between the United States and Mexico. We celebrate the cultures of the borderlands to promote the same mutual respect that helped to diplomatically resolve an international disagreement.

images.altText: a bench next to a tree with U.S. and Mexican flags flying against a mountain background
images.title: Mountain View
images.caption: Chamizal National Memorial stands as a reminder of the effectiveness of diplomacy and the power of friendship.

images.altText: a group of children with hand raised in front of park rangers and ground squirrel mascot
images.title: Junior Rangers
images.caption: Junior Rangers learn about Chamizal National Memorial.

images.altText: walking trails cross a field of green grass with mountain in the background
images.title: Trails
images.caption: Enjoy the green space of Chamizal in the heart of El Paso.

images.altText: Women in swirling skirts and men with sombreros and colorful ponchos dance onstage
images.title: Theater Performances
images.caption: Take in a theater performance such as this ballet folklorico.

images.altText: paintings hang from art gallery walls
images.title: Franklin G. Smith Gallery
images.caption: Browse art from the borderland in the Franklin G. Smith Gallery.

entranceFees.description: The park does does not charge an entrance fee but does have expanded amenity fees for Delta-01 tours.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: All ranger-led tours of the Delta-01 Launch Control Facility require advanced reservations and an amenity fee. Reservations can be made on-line or by phone at 866-601-5129. Reservations can be made up to 90 days prior to tour date. The forty-five minute ranger-guided tour of the control center at  Delta-01 begins with a walk through of the grounds and topside support building. Visitors then descend via elevator 31 feet underground to the Launch Control Center. Each tour is limited to six participants.
entranceFees.title: Delta-01 Tour expanded amenity fee - Adult

entranceFees.description: All ranger-led tours of the Delta-01 Launch Control Facility require advanced reservations and an amenity fee. Reservations can be made on-line or by phone at 866-601-5129. Reservations can be made up to 90 days prior to tour date. The forty-five minute ranger-guided tour of the control center at  Delta-01 begins with a walk through of the grounds and topside support building. Visitors then descend via elevator 31 feet underground to the Launch Control Center. Each tour is limited to six participants.
entranceFees.title: Delta-01 Tour expanded amenity fee - Youth (ages 6-16)

properties.directionsInfo: Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is located at three sites along a fifteen mile stretch of Interstate 90 in western South Dakota. The Visitor Center is located immediately north of I-90, exit 131. The two historic sites which make up the park are four miles (Launch Control Facility Delta-01) and 15 miles (Launch Facility Delta-09) from the Visitor Center. No public transportation systems serve the park.
properties.weatherInfo:
Rapid weather changes are common in the western South Dakota area where Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is located. Variations from season to season and from year to year are great. Characteristics of the climate are hot dry summers and bitterly cold winters.

Wind is a constant on the Great Plains, winds in excess of 50 mph not uncommon. During the winter season, winds typically blow from the north-northwest and have been known to cause wind chills in excess of -40 degrees.
properties.name: Minuteman Missile
properties.description: During the Cold War, a vast arsenal of nuclear missiles were placed in the Great Plains. Hidden in plain sight, for thirty years 1,000 missiles were kept on constant alert; hundreds remain today. The Minuteman Missile remains an iconic weapon in the American nuclear arsenal. It holds the power to destroy civilization, but is meant as a nuclear deterrent to maintain peace and prevent war.

images.altText: Glass structure over the silo allows visitors to look down at the missile
images.title: Delta-09 enclosure
images.caption: The glass enclosure allows visitors to view a Minuteman II missile in the silo.

images.altText: A cylindrical missile inside an underground silo.
images.title: Minuteman II Missile
images.caption: A Minuteman II nuclear missile remains on alert, representing the 1,000 missiles which kept a constant vigil during the Cold War.

images.altText: A brown building behind a tall fence with warning signs
images.title: Delta-01
images.caption: For thirty years, US Air Force staff monitored a flight of ten nuclear missiles at the Delta-01 Launch Control Facility.

images.altText: Two people are visible at the missile silo through a chain link fence
images.title: A winter visit to Delta-09
images.caption: A visit to the Delta-09 missile silo allows the opportunity to consider the role of these missile in America's defense during the Cold War.

images.altText: A large metal blast door with art of a Domino with a nuclear missile
images.title: "Thirty Minutes or Less"
images.caption: Behind this blast door is the control center where two missileers kept a constant watch over ten nuclear missiles.

images.altText: A painting of a nuclear missile bursting through a Soviet Flag
images.title: Morale Art of the Cold War
images.caption: Located next to the elevator, this painting served as a reminder to missileers who they were defending the United States against.

images.altText: View down a silo at a nuclear missile
images.title: Nose-to-Nose with Armegeddon
images.caption: Visitors can peer through the glass at a Minuteman II missile in the silo at Delta-09.

images.altText: Night view of the Delta-09 site
images.title: Night view of Delta-09
images.caption: Night view of the Delta-09 site

images.altText: A modern building with a prominent glass clerestory dominates a prairie landscape at sunset
images.title: Minuteman Missile Visitor Center
images.caption: The visitor center at sunset.

images.altText: A view of a concrete wall with a painting and a blastdoor with art
images.title: Cold War "Blast Door" art at Delta-01
images.caption: Morale art reminded missile officers who the enemy was during the Cold War

images.altText: A ranger talks to visitors next to electronic cabinets.
images.title: Park Ranger leads a tour in the underground control center
images.caption: A park ranger leads a tour in the underground control center

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for Tuskegee Airmen National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Tuskegee Airmen Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
To reach Tuskegee Airmen National Historic Site...

From Atlanta, GA - Take I-85S towards Montgomery, AL for approximately 127 miles to Exit 38.  Turn left at the stop sign and travel 1/2 mile and turn left on Chappie James Ave.  Follow the signs to the Parking Area on left.  Follow the path downhill to the Historic Site.  

From Montgomery, AL - Take I-85N towards Atlanta, GA for approximately 36 miles to Exit 38.  Turn right at the stop sign and travel 1/2 mile and turn left on Chappie James Ave.
properties.weatherInfo: The weather in Tuskegee is generally sunny, averaging around 218 sunny days annually.  Average rainfall is 52 inches a year, with an average snowfall of 0 inches.  The high temperature in July is around 92 degrees, and average low in January is around 42 degrees.
properties.name: Tuskegee Airmen
properties.description: Before the first African American military pilots became known as the "Red Tails" they wore striped tails as they began their flight training in the Army's PT-17 Stearman bi-plane.  Their flying adventure started at Moton Field, in Tuskegee, Alabama, where the Army Air Corps conducted a military test to determine if African Americans could be trained to fly combat aircraft.

images.altText: Red-Tail P-51D Mustang In Flight Exhibit
images.title: The "Duchess Arlene" -  flown by Robert Williams, Pilot class
images.caption: One of the most beloved and recognized airplanes of World War II -  North American P-51D Mustang

images.altText: A World War II flight simulator and PT-17 bi-wing training plane
images.title: Training Days at Tuskegee
images.caption: Take a  "Walk Back In Time" in Hangar #1 to see the faces and visit the places where cadets trained as America's first African-American military pilots and support crews.

images.altText: Female Mechanic works on military aircraft
images.title: And There Were Women...
images.caption: Many are amazed to learn of the vital role women played as part of the Tuskee "Airmen" Experience.

images.altText: Small Yellow training plane used in the Civilian Pilot Training Prograj - J3 Piper Cub
images.title: First Flight - Eleanor Roosevelt was the first First Lady to fly with a Negro Pilot.
images.caption: Visitors are surprised to see the small size of the airplane in which First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt took a flight with Negro Pilot Charles A. Anderson.

images.altText: Two airplane hangars - Hangar #1 in foreground and Hangar #2 in background at Moton Field.
images.title: History Lives at Moton Field
images.caption: Come, experience the "power of place" where the Tuskegee Airmen blazed a trail that led to the civil rights movement.of the 1950's and 1960's.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for this site. Entrance is by reservation only.
entranceFees.title: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site

properties.directionsInfo: Due to the nature of the The Eugene O'Neill NHS, visitors are not able to drive directly to the park site. Instead, reservations are required and we offer a free shuttle that will pick up the visitor in downtown Danville, CA. The shuttle meets at 205 Railroad Avenue in downtown Danville, just outside the Museum of the San Ramon Valley. Parking is available next to the museum. More information will be given once you call and make a reservation with the park staff. Danville, CA, is approximately 31 miles east

entrancePasses.description: Passes are not required or sold at this site. Entrance is by reservations only.
entrancePasses.title: Eugne O'Neill National Historic Site

properties.weatherInfo: The Mediterranean climate of Danville features hot, dry summers with lower temperatures near 60º F and upper temperatures near 100º F. The heat gives way to cool, rainy winters with lows near 45º F and highs near 75º F. Fall and spring can bring rain and temperatures from 55-80º F.
properties.name: Eugene O'Neill
properties.description: America's only Nobel Prize winning playwright, Eugene O'Neill, chose to live in Northern California at the height of his writing career. Isolated from the world and within the walls of his home, O'Neill wrote his final and most memorable plays; The Iceman Cometh, Long Day's Journey Into Night, and A Moon for the Misbegotten.

images.altText: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California
images.title: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California
images.caption: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California

entranceFees.description:
There are no fees at the federally or municipally owned historic sites within Boston National Historical Park, including Faneuil Hall, Bunker Hill Monument, Bunker Hill Museum, USS Constitution, and the Dorchester Heights Monument.

Fees and suggested donations are collected at the park's privately owned and operated partner sites. These sites are maintained and run by self-supporting historical associations working cooperatively with Boston National Historical Park.

properties.directionsInfo: Visitor Centers are located at Historic Faneuil Hall, 1 Faneuil Hall Sq, and the Charlestown Navy Yard, Building 5. Go to the Directions page for more detailed information.
properties.weatherInfo: Temperatures range from warm, humid summer days to cold New England winter days. Wear comfortable sportswear in season, with comfortable walking shoes.
properties.name: Boston
properties.description: Discover how one city could be the Cradle of Liberty, site of the first major battle of American Revolution, and home to many who espoused that freedom can be extended to all.

images.altText: Commandant's House in Spring
images.title: Commandant's House
images.caption: Commandant's House is the oldest structure in the Charlestown Navy Yard.

images.altText: Paul Revere House Sign
images.title: Paul Revere House Sign
images.caption: Paul Revere House is a proud partner of Boston National Historical Park

images.altText: Rainbow over Faneuil Hall
images.title: Rainbow over Faneuil Hall
images.caption: Rare image of rainbow was captured over Faneuil Hall

images.altText: View of the Colonial Town Meeting program from the desk
images.title: Colonial Town Meeting
images.caption: The Revolutionary Town Meeting program is one of the park's most popular.

images.altText: View of the Navy Yard from the harbor showing the USS Constution, USS Cassin Young and Bunker Hill
images.title: Navy Yard from the harbor
images.caption: More than 200 years of Navy history and tradition can be found in the Charlestown Navy Yard.

phoneNumbers.description:
617-773-1177 (Headquarters)

Superintendent Marianne Peak
marianne_peak@nps.gov
617-773-1177

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee is for all visitors age 16 and older.  Children under 16 are free. Credit or Debit Card only.
entranceFees.title: Individual Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Traveling on U.S. Interstate 93, take exit 7 - Route 3 South to Braintree and Cape Cod. Take the first exit off Route 3 south - exit 19 - and follow signs toward Quincy Center. Continue straight on Burgin Parkway through six traffic lights. At the seventh traffic light, turn right onto Dimmock Street. Follow Dimmock Street one block and turn right onto Hancock Street. The National Park Service Visitor Center, located at 1250 Hancock Street on your left.  Validated parking is in the garage to the rear.
properties.weatherInfo:
Be prepared for hot, humid weather.  The historic homes are not air conditioned.

While the visitor center remains open all year, the historic homes are closed from November 11 through May 5.
properties.name: Adams
properties.description: From the sweet little farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill to the gentleman’s country estate at Peace field, Adams National Historical Park is the story of “heroes, statesman, philosophers … and learned women” whose ideas and actions helped to transform thirteen disparate colonies into one united nation.

images.altText: The Birthplaces of Presidents John Adams (right) and John Quincy Adams (left)
images.title: The John and John Quincy Adams Birthplaces
images.caption: The Birthplaces of John and John Quincy Adams sit right next  to each other on Franklin Street.

images.altText: The Birthplace of John Adams
images.title: The Birthplace of John Adams
images.caption: The house where President John Adams was born in 1735.

images.altText: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.title: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.caption: The house where President John Quincy Adams was born in 1767.

images.altText: A view of Old House at Peace field
images.title: Old House at Peace field
images.caption: Old House at Peace field, where four generations of the Adams family lived from 1788 to 1927.

images.altText: The Paneled Room located inside Old House at Peace field.
images.title: The Paneled Room
images.caption: The Paneled Room greets everyone who enters Old House at Peace field.

images.altText: The Stone Library located outside Old House at Peace field.
images.title: The Stone Library
images.caption: The Stone Library houses up to 14,000 books belonging to the Adams family.

images.altText: Inside the Stone Library
images.title: Inside the Stone Library
images.caption: A view into the Stone Library

images.altText: The gardens located at Old House at Peace field.
images.title: The Gardens Located at Old House at Peace field
images.caption: The gardens located by Old House at Peace field bloom in every color you can imagine.

entranceFees.description: There is no charge to visit Fort Point.
entranceFees.title: Entry to Fort Point is FREE!

properties.directionsInfo:
Fort Point is located at the south anchorage of the Golden Gate Bridge at the end of Marine Drive on the Presidio of San Francisco.

By car take Highway 101 N or S, exit at the Golden Gate Bridge toll plaza at south end of bridge. From S turn right at end of exit ramp, or from N go straight on Merchant Drive. Turn left onto Lincoln Boulevard. Take a left onto Long Avenue and follow onto Marine Drive.
properties.weatherInfo: Fort Point is typically cold and windy throughout the year. Fog is especially common in the summer months.  Come prepared with layers and windbreakers for maximum comfort.
properties.name: Fort Point
properties.description: From its vantage point overlooking the spectacular Golden Gate, Fort Point defended the San Francisco Bay following California's Gold Rush through World War II. Its beautifully arched casemates display the art of 3rd system brick masonry and interacts gracefully with the Golden Gate Bridge.

images.altText: Fort Point with visitors approaching on road in front and Golden Gate Bridge above.
images.title: Fort Point from Marine Drive
images.caption: Fort Point offers stunning views from under the south end of the Golden Gate Bridge.

images.altText: Golden sunset light on the roof of Fort Point with Golden Gate Bridge and bay behind.
images.title: Fort Point Sunset View
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy winter sunsets from the top of Fort Point.

images.altText: Arched red brick casemates extend into the distance at Fort Point.
images.title: Brick Casemates
images.caption: Fort Point is known for its masterful masonry work.

images.altText: A cannon stands in front of Civil War re-enactors talking to the public.
images.title: Civil War Days at Fort Point
images.caption: Visitors can interact with Civil War re-enactors twice in January and August at the Fort.

images.altText: View of Fort Point lighthouse through red brick arches
images.title: Fort Point Lighthouse
images.caption: Fort Point has a historic lighthouse mounted on its top.

entranceFees.description: Admission to Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site Visitor Center is free.  Guided tours are admission free, but must be reserved in advance to guarantee availability.
entranceFees.title: Admission and Program Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-630, take Exit 2B - Dr. Martin Luther King Drive - south (away from the Arkansas State Capitol) to Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive.  Turn right (head west) and continue 0.5 miles.  The National Historic Site Visitor Center is on the right at the corner of Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive and Park St. 
Parking lot entrance is located just before the intersection with Park Street, directly across from the historic Magnolia Gas Station and diagonally across from Central High, which is still an operating school.
properties.weatherInfo: Arkansas weather can change quickly.  While the state is in a moderate temperate zone, it does experience strong thunderstorms, tornadoes and flash floods.  In winter, "snow" events tend to quickly turn to thin ice which can be difficult to see and to clear.  Summer temperatures and humidity can lead to dehydration, heat exhaustion and heat stroke.  Visitors are advised to dress in layers and be prepared for precipitation.
properties.name: Little Rock Central High School
properties.description: Little Rock Central High School, the only operating high school in the nation to be designated a National Historic Site, is a place important beyond its past.  Come and learn how the sacrifice and struggle endured by nine African-Americans teenagers over a half century ago have provided opportunities and opened doors to those seeking equality – and education - around the world.

images.altText: National Park Visitor Center
images.title: Little Rock Central High School Visitor Center
images.caption: Exhibits, films, restrooms and a bookstore are located in the National Park Visitor Center.

images.altText: Central High
images.title: Little Rock Central High School
images.caption: Built in 1927, Little Rock Central High School has been a public school for almost 90 years.

images.credit: National Park Service/Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
images.altText: Nine African American students began integration at Central High
images.title: Little Rock Nine
images.caption: The Little Rock desegregated Central High in 1957 making it the test case for the Supreme Court's Brown v. Board of Eduction decision.

addresses.line2: 2120 W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive
2120 W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive

properties.fullName: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site

phoneNumbers.description: This phone is answered during regular business hours. After hours calls will be answered the next day. Please select a mailbox or leave a message on the main extension when the fort is closed.

emailAddresses.description: This e-mail address is monitored during park operating hours by a member of the ranger division. Most messages will be answered within 24 hours. Inquiries directed to facilities and maintenance staff may take additional time to receive a response, especially on weekends.

entranceFees.description: No charge for any of the park's activities.
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

properties.directionsInfo: Fort Larned National Historic Site is located on KS Hwy 156, six miles west of Larned, Kansas.
properties.weatherInfo: Central Kansas has a four-season climate. Winter tends to be cold and dry, with average daytime highs below 40F (4C). Foehn winds blowing across the Great Plains from the Southwest periodically raise temperatures above 80F (27C). Unsettled warmer air, higher winds, and severe weather arrive in the spring and often last through early July. Late summer days hover above 90F (32C) and readings over 100F (38C) are not uncommon. Fall is variable but generally milder with showers changing to snow and ice later.
properties.name: Fort Larned
properties.description:
Discover a complete and authentic army post from the 1860s -1870s! This well-preserved fort on the Santa Fe Trail shares a tumultuous history of the Indian Wars era. The sandstone constructed buildings sheltered troops who were known as the Guardians of the Santa Fe Trail.  

Although the Visitor Center is closed we do have alternative ways to explore the fort. Check them out below.

images.altText: Sandstone army buildings arranged in a square around parade ground.
images.title: Aerial Photo of Fort Larned
images.caption: The historic sandstone buildings at Fort Larned date to 1868

images.altText: Man in leather apron hammering hot steel in blacksmith shop.
images.title: Blacksmith Demonstrations at Fort Larned
images.caption: The blacksmith demonstration is one of the most popular living history demonstrations.

images.altText: Men in 19th century U.S. Army uniforms fire a reproduction period cannon.
images.title: Artillery Demonstration
images.caption: Volunteers demonstrating the use of a mountain howitzer during one of Fort Larned's living history weekends.

images.altText: Men in 19th century U.S. Army uniforms lower an American flag.
images.title: Flag Retreat
images.caption: Volunteers help recreate the U.S. Army flag lowering ceremony known as Retreat.

images.altText: Man in 19th century U.S. Army uniform interacts with visitors in period barracks.
images.title: Visitors in the Barracks
