images.caption: A volunteer shows visitors how soldiers lived during the 1860s at Fort Larned.

images.altText: Three young children having their picture taken with Santa Claus in a period room.
images.title: Visiting Santa
images.caption: Young visitors get their picture taken with Santa during the fort's Christmas Past event.

images.altText: African American men in 19th century cavalry uniforms on horseback.
images.title: Buffalo Soldiers
images.caption: Buffalo Soldier re-enactors help bring Fort Larned's history to life.

entranceFees.description: Entrance is free to the Visitor Education Center. No park passes are needed or sold.
entranceFees.title: Visitor Education Center Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: Please visit the "Directions and Transportation" link on the main website at http://www.nps.gov/rori/planyourvisit/directions.htm

entrancePasses.description: Park passes are not required and not sold at this location.
entrancePasses.title: No Passes Required/ Passes not available

properties.weatherInfo: Weather typical for San Francisco Bay Area.  Can be cold and windy year round.  Fog in the summer.
properties.name: Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front
properties.description: Explore and honor the efforts and sacrifices of American civilians on the World War II home front.  Find out how they lived, worked and got along. Many faces, many stories, many truths weave a complex tapestry of myths and realities from this time of opportunity and loss.

images.altText: Rosie the Riveter Visitor Education Center
images.title: Rosie the Riveter Visitor Education Center
images.caption: Rosie the Riveter Visitor Education Center

properties.fullName: Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: The site does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Fort Scott National Historic Site is located in downtown Fort Scott, Kansas. U.S. Highways 69 and 54 intersect here. Fort Scott is about 90 miles south of Kansas City and 60 miles northwest of Joplin, Missouri. It is 4 miles from the Kansas-Missouri border.

Signs directing visitors to Fort Scott are posted on highway 69 for visitors coming from the north and the south and on highway 54 for visitors coming from the east and the west. Highway 69 between Fort Scott and Kansas City is a four lane highway,
properties.weatherInfo: Spring and autumn are pleasant with mild temperatures. Summers are generally hot and humid, while winters are mild with periods of cold weather, snowfall, and ice storms. Thunderstorms, some severe, are common throughout the spring and summer. During periods of severe weather, visitors should seek shelter, as the area is prone to lightning strikes Visitors are advised to check the weather prior to traveling.
properties.name: Fort Scott
properties.description: Promises made and broken! A town attacked at dawn! Thousands made homeless by war! Soldiers fighting settlers! Each of these stories is a link in the chain of events that encircled Fort Scott from 1842-1873. All of the site's structures, its parade ground, and its tallgrass prairie bear witness to this era when the country was forged from a young republic into a united transcontinental nation.

images.altText: A field of sunflowers next to a stone building.  Wood frame structures in background.
images.title: Sunflowers at Fort Scott
images.caption: A field of sunflowers adds a splash of color to a view of the parade ground at Fort Scott.

images.altText: Wood frame structures with stairs next to a stone walkway. Structures reflect afternoon sunlight.
images.title: Officers Quarters at Sunset
images.caption: Officers quarters at Fort Scott bathed in the light of the afternoon sun.

images.altText: Four soldiers on horseback in a line riding through prairie grass
images.title: Dragoons on the Prairie
images.caption: Soldiers on horseback patrolling the prairie

images.altText: Two men in infantry uniform surrounded by students
images.title: On Guard Duty
images.caption: High school students interpreting guard duty to elementary students.

images.altText: Women dressed as laundresses with laundry buckets and scrub boards
images.title: Laundry Day
images.caption: High school students dressed as laundresses demonstrate laundry methods of the 1840s

entranceFees.description: The fee grants access to the Memorial's Observation Deck 317 feet above Lake Erie. The Visitor Center and grounds have no admission fee.
entranceFees.title: Adult Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Youth 15 years or younger are not charge entrance fees.
entranceFees.title: Youth Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Perry's Victory and International Peace Memorial is located within the Village of Put-in-Bay, Ohio on South Bass Island. The most common way to reach the island is by the Jet Express or Miller Boat Line ferries.  When traveling east, use Ohio Turnpike to US 250 north to SR 2 west. When traveling west, use Ohio Turnpike to SR 53 north to SR 2 east. From SR 2 take the SR 163 exit OR the ST 250 exit for the Jet Express passenger ferry, Or take the SR 53 exit for Miller Boat Line vehicle and passenger ferry.

entrancePasses.description: This pass grants holder and 3 accompanying adults admission to Memorial Observation Deck. The pass is good for 1 year.
entrancePasses.title: Perry's Victory and International Peace Memorial Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Summer months can be extremely hot and humid, with occasional and sudden severe thunderstorms. Fall and spring are pleasant with cool temperatures and brisk winds. During the Winter the Memorial and Visitor Center are closed.
properties.name: Perry's Victory & International Peace
properties.description: Perry's Victory and International Peace Memorial was established to honor those who fought in the Battle of Lake Erie, during the War of 1812, and to celebrate the long-lasting peace among Great Britain, Canada and the U.S. The Memorial, a Doric column, rising 352 feet over Lake Erie is situated 5 miles from the longest undefended border in the world.

images.altText: Night sky with Memorial Column in the middle with sun just starting to come up in lower right corner
images.title: Night Sky and Memorial

images.altText: Sun setting over Put-in-Bay Harbor
images.title: Sun setting over the Bay

images.altText: The Memorial Column with the United Kingdom, Canadian, and US Flags flying from poles on the lawn.
images.title: Perry's Victory and International Peace Memorial

entranceFees.description: There is no fee for using the park, but there are special use permits needed for large groups to use the park. Call 670-483-7252 for information on special use permits.
entranceFees.title: Park entrance fees

properties.directionsInfo:
The park is centrally located along the western shoreline of Saipan, adjacent to downtown Garapan.
From airport, proceed north on Airport Road (Tun Herman Pan Highway) until the road ends at Monsignor Guerrero Road (Highway 16). Turn left and continue until the road ends at Beach Road. Turn right until the road ends at the American Memorial Park Mall. Turn left onto Micro Beach Road. The parking lot is on the right.
properties.weatherInfo: The temperature varies from 75°F to 88°F and is rarely below 73°F or above 90°F.The climate is tropical, hot and humid throughout the year, with a relatively cool and dry season from December to June, and a warmer and rainy season from July to November.  The temperatures are stable throughout the year.
properties.name: American Memorial
properties.description: American Memorial Park honors the American and Marianas people who gave their lives during the Marianas Campaign of World War II. At the park, memorials stand in tribute to the courage and sacrifice of the US Servicemen and Chamorro and Carolinian civilians who were killed in the battles between the United States and Japan that took place on Saipan, Tinian, and the Philippine Sea in 1944.

images.altText: Large lawn in front of the memorial.
images.title: Lawn at American Memorial Park
images.caption: A popular place for visitors.

images.altText: Rehearsing at the American Memorial Park ampitheater
images.title: Ampitheater at American Memorial Park
images.caption: The ampitheater is where many performances take place.

images.altText: The visitor center is open daily.
images.title: Visitor Center at American Memorial Park
images.caption: The visitor center  is a popular place to learn about Saipan's role in WWII history.

images.altText: People walking the paths at the American Memorial Park.
images.title: Walking the path at American Memorial Park.
images.caption: The paths at the American Memorial Park are always in use.

images.altText: Crystal clear blue swimming at the park.
images.title: The beach at American Memorial Park.
images.caption: The beach is an inviting place to swim and relax.

entranceFees.description: Andersonville National Historic Site is a fee free park. No fee is charged to enter the park or visit the National Prisoner of War Museum.
entranceFees.title: Park Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Andersonville National Historic Site is located in southwest Georgia. The park is approximately 12 miles north of Americus and 11 miles south of Montezuma on GA-49.

entrancePasses.description: Because no fees are charged at the park, no entrance passes are available at Andersonville National Historic Site.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Passes

properties.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures reach highs in the 80s-90s and high humidity. Winter temperatures tend to be in the 40s and below. Snow can occur but is rare. Average annual precipitation is 46.24 inches and is fairly evenly distributed throughout the year. The National Prisoner of War Museum is maintained at a cool temperature to help preserve artifacts; dressing in layers is recommended.
properties.name: Andersonville
properties.description: The Camp Sumter military prison at Andersonville was one of the largest Confederate military prisons during the Civil War. During the 14 months the prison existed, more than 45,000 Union soldiers were confined here. Of these, almost 13,000 died here. Today, Andersonville National Historic Site is a memorial to all American prisoners of war throughout the nation's history.

images.altText: A cannon sits out in front of a replica of part of the wooden stockade walls once at Andersonville
images.title: Historic Site of Camp Sumter Civil War Military Prison at Andersonville
images.caption: Camp Sumter Military Prison, known as Andersonville, was the deadliest ground of the Civil War. Nearly 13,000 American soldiers died here.

images.altText: A historic photo of thousands of emaciated Union soldiers held prisoner in 1865
images.title: Summer of 1865 at Andersonville Photo by A.J. Riddle
images.caption: Over 32,000 Union soldiers languished at Andersonville in August 1865 when this photo was taken by A.J. Riddle.

images.altText: Fog rests on a stone monument of a Civil War soldier standing among hundreds of graves.
images.title: Andersonville National Cemetery
images.caption: The site where the nearly 13,000 Union soldiers who died at Andersonville, designated as a National Cemetery in 1865, is still an active cemetery. Nearly 21,000 American military veterans rest here in honor.

images.altText: A large stone monument with 2 Civil War soldiers, a female figure, and 2 children.
images.title: The Illinois Monument at Andersonville National Historic Site
images.caption: Many states honored their fallen sons with monuments placed at Andersonville National Historic Site.

images.altText: A military garrison cap with a small U.S. flag and silver bar in an exhibit case
images.title: National Prisoner of War Museum
images.caption: Andersonville is the only National Park Service site with the mission of preserving the stories of all American Prisoners of War throughout history.

emailAddresses.description: Visitor Use Program Manager

entranceFees.description:
The entrance fee to the Historic Zone (including the Star Fort) is $15.00 per adult 16 years of age and older. Children 15 and younger are free.

All 'America the Beautiful' Interagency Passes are accepted. All passes cover admission for the pass holder and three additional guests ages 16 and older. Passes may be purchased/obtained at the main desk inside the Visitor and Education Center.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
The park is three miles southeast of the Baltimore Inner Harbor and just off I-95. Follow the brown Fort McHenry directional signs along all major routes to the park. 

From I-95 northbound, take Exit 55 Key Highway and follow Fort McHenry signs.

entrancePasses.description: The America the Beautiful Interagency Annual Pass may be purchased by anyone and is valid for one year following the month of purchase. The pass covers entrance fees for the pass holder and three adult guests.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful: Interagency Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Senior Lifetime Pass is a lifetime pass for American citizens ages 62 and over. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Senior Lifetime Passes do not expire.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Senior Lifetime Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Senior Annual Pass is an annual pass for U.S. seniors aged 62 or older. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Senior Annual Passes are valid for one year from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Senior Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Access Pass is a lifetime pass for any citizen or permanent resident of the U.S. who has been medically determined to have a permanent disability. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Access Passes do not expire.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Military Pass is an annual pass for current U.S. military members and their dependents with a valid U.S. Department of Defense CAC card or DoD Form 1173 for proof of identification.The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. The pass is valid for one year from the month that it is issued.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Military Pass

entrancePasses.description:
The Interagency 4th Grade Annual Pass is for 4th graders including home-schooled and free-choice learners. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. The pass is valid from September through August of the year that the student is in the 4th grade.

Students may obtain a pass with a printed voucher from the Every Kid in a Park website. A paper voucher must be presented in order to receive a pass.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency 4th Grade Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Temperatures and weather in the spring and fall months tend to be mild. Ice, snow, and freezing temperatures can occur during winter. Extreme heat can occur during the summer months.

Inclement weather may impact park hours of operation year round. Refer to the park alerts or call ahead to confirm operating hours.
properties.name: Fort McHenry
properties.description: by the dawn's early light, a large red, white and blue banner? Whose broad stripes and bright stars . . . were so gallantly streaming! over the star-shaped Fort McHenry during the Battle of Baltimore, September 13-14, 1814. The valiant defense of the fort inspired Francis Scott Key to write "The Star-Spangled Banner."

images.altText: Fort McHenry
images.title: Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine
images.caption: Blue Angels fly over Fort McHenry

properties.fullName: Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee collected at Fort Raleigh National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site is located on the northern end of Roanoke Island, north of the town of Manteo, NC.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather on the Outer Banks varies seasonally and daily. Please check the National Weather Service at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for up-to-date weather forecast information.
properties.name: Fort Raleigh
properties.description:
Fort Raleigh National Historic Site protects and preserves known portions of England's first New World settlements from 1584 to 1590.

This site also preserves the cultural heritage of the Native Americans, European Americans and African Americans who have lived on Roanoke Island.

images.altText: View of the ditch and wall of the reconstructed earthwork
images.title: Reconstructed Earthwork
images.caption: Part of the ditch and wall of the earthwork

images.altText: Back of the monument commemorating the Roanoke Island Freedmen's Colony
images.title: First Light of Freedom
images.caption: Commemorating the Roanoke Island Freedmen's Colony

images.altText: Tree standing next to the maritime forest path of the Thomas Hariot Trail
images.title: Thomas Hariot Trail
images.caption: Venture through a maritime forest

images.altText: Pieces of a crucible left behind by the 1585 English expedition
images.title: Crucible Artifact
images.caption: Shards unearthed here provide clues to the English expedition of 1585

images.altText: Stage of the Waterside Theatre with a view of the Roanoke Sound in the background
images.title: Waterside Theatre
images.caption: Home of The Lost Colony drama performed every summer

entranceFees.description:
Hampton National Historic Site is a fee-free park. 

Mansion tours are free on a first come, first served basis. There is a limit of 15 people per guided tour. Groups of 10 or more are required to make an advanced reservation.

Hampton National Historic Site is not a sales outlet for interagency parks passes.
entranceFees.title: Hampton National Historic Site

properties.directionsInfo:
Hampton is easy to get to because it's close to three interstate highways--routes 695, 70, and 95. From the Baltimore Beltway (I 695) eastbound or westbound: Take Exit 27B, Dulaney Valley Road northbound. Take the first right turn onto Hampton Lane. The park will be on your right, about one mile from the intersection.

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION: Bus #11 stops at Goucher College, less than one mile from Hampton. The Light Rail stop at Lutherville is approximately three miles from Hampton NHS.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather during the spring and fall months tend to be mild. Visitors can expect mild to severe seasonal weather during the winter and summer months.  Inclement weather may impact park hours of operation year round. Refer to the park alerts or call ahead to confirm operating hours.
properties.name: Hampton
properties.description: Once possibly the largest private home in America by 1790, the Hampton mansion serves as a grand example of late-Georgian architecture in America. Hampton is also the story of its people, as the estate evolved through the actions of the Ridgely family, enslaved African Americans, European indentured servants, and paid laborers within a nation struggling to define its own concept of freedom.

images.altText: Hampton Mansion in the fall
images.title: Hampton Mansion Historic Site
images.caption: Hampton Mansion in the Fall

entranceFees.description: Johnstown Flood National Memorial is a fee free park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee.

properties.directionsInfo: Take US Route 219 to the St Michael/Sidman exit. At the end of the exit ramp head East on PA 869 (there is a park sign at the end of the exit ramp). Travel approximately 1.5 miles on PA 869 watching for a left turn onto Lake Road at the sign for Johnstown Flood National Memorial. Follow Lake Road 1.5 miles until the visitor center appears on your right. Please park safely in the designated parking lot and not block any emergency access roads.

entrancePasses.description: For US Citizens or Permanent Residents of any age who have a permanent disability (must bring proper documentation); good for life. This admits the guest and three additional adult guests in the party.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: Yearly pass for Active US Military members, including the National Guard and Reserves; renewable each year during your active duty service, including the National Guard and Reservies. This admits the servicemember and his/her dependents in the party.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful-U.S. Military Pass

entrancePasses.description: With the help of an adult, fourth graders can go to this website, https://www.everykidinapark.gov/, complete a short, fun activity, and then bring their certificate into the park to exchange it for a Fourth Grade Pass, which entitles all adults in the fourth graders party to fee admission to any National Park. Adults may not use the pass without the fourth grader present.
entrancePasses.title: Every Kid in a Park-4th Grade Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Winters can be cold and severe. Spring can be seasonable and wet. Summer can be hot with potentials for thunderstorms. Fall can be seasonal, with cold temperatures into October and November.
properties.name: Johnstown Flood
properties.description: The South Fork dam failed on Friday, May 31, 1889 and unleashed 20,000,000 tons of water that devastated Johnstown, PA.  The flood killed 2,209 people but it brought the nation and the world together to aid the "Johnstown sufferers."  The story of the Johnstown Flood reminds us all, "...that we must leave nothing undone for the preservation and protection of our brother men."

images.altText: Remnants of the South Fork Dam
images.title: Remnants of the South Fork Dam
images.caption: Remains of the South Fork Dam, The Spillway Bridge, Visitor Center, and Lake View (Unger) House.

entranceFees.description: Interpretive Demonstration fees at the Boott Mills Museum- $6 for Adults, $4 Senior (62+), $3 Student, $3 Youth (under 17), Free for 5 or under. Discounts for America the Beautiful Interagency Pass holders. Free for 4th grade holders of the Every Kid in a Park Pass.
entranceFees.title: Boott Cotton Mills Museum

entranceFees.description: 90 minute-2 hour Canal Boat Tours offered Memorial Day- Columbus Day. $12 adults, $10 Senior, $8 Student, $8 Youth (6-16 yrs.), Free for under 5.
entranceFees.title: Canal Boat Tour Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate Route 495 take Exit 35C on to the Lowell Connector.
From Route 3 take Exit 30A if traveling southbound, Exit 30B if traveling northbound.
 
• Take the Lowell Connector to Exit 5B (Thorndike Street).
• Continue right on to Thorndike Street, which becomes Dutton Street.
• At the third traffic light continue straight under the overpass.
• At the next light turn right into the Visitor Center Parking Lot. Take a ticket at the gate and bring the ticket inside for free validation.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summer: Throughout the summer, temperatures range from the mid 60s to mid 90s during the day, with rain and thunderstorms more common in the months of July and August. Boats and trolleys operate rain or shine and are only cancelled in cases of extreme weather or the presence of thunder and lightning.
 
Winter: Winters are typically cold with temperatures in the mid 30s and 40s (with occasional single digit temperatures) and snow storms with a few inches accumulation occur frequently throughout the season.
properties.name: Lowell
properties.description: Discover the Continuing Revolution. Lowell’s water-powered textile mills catapulted the nation – including immigrant families and early female factory workers – into an uncertain new industrial era. Nearly 200 years later, the changes that began here still reverberate in our shifting global economy. Explore Lowell, a living monument to the dynamic human story of the Industrial Revolution.

images.altText: Group of visitors on a boat on a canal with large brick factory buildings on either side.
images.title: Industrial Canyon Tour
images.caption: A ranger-guided trip down the Industrial Canyon on part of Lowell's 5.6 mile canal system is one of the signature experiences at Lowell National Historical Park.

images.altText: 5 story brick factories with a clocktower surrounding a central courtyard
images.title: Boott Cotton Mills
images.caption: The Boott Cotton Mills is one of the best, most-intact complexes of cotton mills from Lowell's heyday in the 19th century.

images.altText: Streetcar guided through Lowell by motormen with lots of passengers
images.title: Lowell NHP Trolley
images.caption: Lowell National Historical Park operates reproduction vintage streetcars throughout the park and downtown Lowell. Climb onboard for a ride or a ranger-guided tour.

images.altText: Two young visitors look over the rail at a room full of working looms
images.title: Boott Mills Weave Room
images.caption: The working weave room at the Boott Cotton Mills Museum surrounds you with the sights and sounds of a turn-of-the-century working cotton textile factory.

images.altText: Two students weaving on the looms at the education center.
images.title: Tsongas Center Programs
images.caption: The Tsongas Industrial History Center, a partnership of Lowell National Historical Park and UMass Lowell's Graduate School of Education, offers hands-on interactive education workshops for more than 50,000 students each year.

images.altText: Street scene with lots of tents and crowds listening to Folk Festival music at Boardinghouse Park.
images.title: Lowell Folk Festival
images.caption: The Lowell Folk Festival, Lowell's signature annual event, brings traditional folk performers to 5 stages throughout the city and a huge variety of traditional ethnic foods from all around the world.

entranceFees.description: There is no charge for entering or visiting Minidoka National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Minidoka Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Minidoka National Historic Site is located between the towns of Twin Falls and Jerome, Idaho in south central Idaho. There are minimal facilities and services at the site. Many buildings and features that were part of the center are located on private property surrounding the Historic Site. Please do not enter any private property.
properties.weatherInfo: Jerome and Twin Falls, Idaho, gets 10 inches of rain per year. On average, there are 213 sunny days per year here. The July high is around 94 degrees. The January low is 22. Our comfort index, which is based on humidity during the hot months, is a 78 out of 100, where higher is more comfortable. The US average on the comfort index is 44.
properties.name: Minidoka
properties.description:
The Pearl Harbor attack intensified existing hostility towards Japanese Americans. As wartime hysteria mounted, President Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066 forcing over 120,000 West Coast persons of Japanese ancestry (Nikkei) to leave their homes, jobs, and lives behind, forcing them into one of ten prison camps spread across the nation because of their ethnicity.  

This is Minidoka's story.

images.altText: Origami cranes twirl on carousel
images.title: Origami Go Around
images.caption: Origami cranes twirl on a colorful carousel.

images.altText: The replicated Minidoka Honor Roll is part of the history at Minidoka NHS.
images.title: The Replicated Minidoka Honor Roll
images.caption: The replicated Minidoka Honor Roll is part of the history at Minidoka NHS.

images.altText: A view from Minidoka through the barbed wire fence.
images.title: View Across the Barbed Wire
images.caption: A view from Minidoka through the barbed wire fence.

images.altText: A view of the Northside Canal and reconstructed barbed wire fence.
images.title: Looking at the northside Canal
images.caption: Looking northeast from the entrance area to the Northside Canal and reconstructed barbed wire fence.

images.altText: An original barrack was retuned to Minidoka and placed on site.
images.title: An Original Barrack Returns to the Site
images.caption: An original barrack was retuned to Minidoka and placed on site.

entranceFees.description: The entry fee to Muir Woods is $15 a person, ages 16 and over. Children are free.
entranceFees.title: Muir Woods Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From San Francisco

Muir Woods is located 11 miles north of the Golden Gate Bridge
Take Hwy 101 North 
Then the Mill Valley/Highway 1/ Stinson Beach Exit
Follow the signs to Hwy 1
Follow the signs to Muir Woods

From the East Bay

Take Hwy 580/Richmond/San Rafael Bridge West
Then Hwy 101 South
Take the Stinson Beach/Mill Valley Exit
Follow the signs to Highway 1
Follow the signs to Muir Woods

Vehicles over 35 feet long are prohibited. There are no RV parking facilities.

entrancePasses.description: This pass admits the pass holder and three guests into Muir Woods. This pass is good for one year.
entrancePasses.title: Muir Woods Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The coast redwood forest is cool most times of the year with temperatures ranging from 40 - 70 degrees F or 4 - 21 degrees C. From late October to early May expect rain. Summer months (June-August) can be warmer but it is generally cool and dry. Expect heavy fog in the morning, burning off in the afternoon. Some say fall (August-October) is the best weather of the year. But, don't let the weather stop you from having fun. If you're dressed for the elements and wearing sturdy shoes, you will enjoy your walk.
properties.name: Muir Woods
properties.description: Walk among old growth coast redwoods, cooling their roots in the fresh water of Redwood Creek and lifting their crowns to reach the sun and fog. Federally protected as a National Monument since 1908, this primeval forest is both refuge and laboratory, revealing our relationship with the living landscape. What will you discover in Muir Woods?

images.altText: A wooden bridge crosses Redwood Creek in the redwood forest
images.title: Bridge through Muir Woods
images.caption: Summer is a busy time at Muir Woods. Visit early in the morning for the most pleasant experience.

images.altText: Black fire scars are visible on trunks of large redwood trees
images.title: Redwood trees
images.caption: Many fires over the centuries have encouraged new growth and opened up the under story of the redwood forest. Black scars are present among the oldest of redwoods in Muir Woods.

images.altText: Sun rays shine down on a visitor among very tall redwood trees
images.title: Bohemian Grove
images.caption: Later afternoon is a gorgeous time of day to visit Bohemian Grove, inside Muir Woods.

images.altText: A Lady Fern grows over Redwood Creek
images.title: Lady Fern
images.caption: At least ten species of ferns grow in Muir Woods - fern seem to grow larger in redwood forests than other forests - possibly competing for attention from the redwoods?

images.altText: soft, spindly horsetail fern
images.title: Horestail Fern
images.caption: Horsetail fern, an Equisetum, is common along Redwood Creek. Horsetail fern is one of the oldest plant species in the world.

images.altText: trillium, a white flower with large green leaves in bloom on the forest floor
images.title: Trillium ovatum
images.caption: Trillium ovatum blooms in late winter and early spring along the forest floor.

images.altText: A yellow banana slug creeping along a twig
images.title: Banana Slug
images.caption: Banana slugs creep along the forest floor in Muir Woods and are likely to be abundant in the warmer days of winter.

images.altText: two scientists hanging from branches in a redwood tree
images.title: Tree Climbing
images.caption: Scientists Marie Antoine and Steve Sillett climbing a redwood tree in Muir Woods for the 2014 BioBlitz.

images.altText: A bench along the boardwalk with the sun shining through the redwoods
images.title: Bench along main trail
images.caption: Relax in the sunshine on this quiet bench along Muir Woods main trail.

images.altText: A hiker appears very small among the redwood trees
images.title: Redwood trees
images.caption: Meander along the main trail and consider your size compared to these giants.

entranceFees.description: Admission is FREE. Except for special events sponsored by the Ocmulgee Mounds Association no fees are charged to enter and visit Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park. During the special events of the Ocmulgee Indian Celebration (third weekend in September) event fee is $6.00 for 13 &up, 6-12 $3.00, 5 &under are free and active military with I.D. $3.00. The spring Lantern light Tours (March) an event fee of $5.00 is charged for anyone 13 years and older.
entranceFees.title: Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Drive on I-75 to Macon. Exit I-75 onto I-16 east (exit on left) . Get off I-16 at exit 2 (Coliseum Drive), take a left under the highway and proceed to where Coliseum Dr. ends at Emery Highway. Turn right on Emery Highway and proceed to the third light. Our entrance is on the right side of the road.

entrancePasses.description: We do not carry the Entrance Passes at the park.
entrancePasses.title: No Entrance Passes Available at Ocmulgee Mounds NHP

properties.weatherInfo:
Macon has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification Cfa). The normal monthly mean temperature ranges from 46.3 °F (7.9 °C) in January to 81.8 °F (27.7 °C) in July. On average, there are 4.8 days with 100 °F (38 °C


Winter's are mild. Temps ranging from 30 degrees to 50 degrees. Spring is mild but wet. Temps ranging from 50 degrees to low 70 degrees. Summers are hot and very humid. Temp ranging from upper 80 degrees to 100 degrees. Fall is pleasant. Temps ranging from 60 to 80 degrees.
properties.name: Ocmulgee Mounds
properties.description: Welcome to Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park. This park is a prehistoric American Indian site.  American Indians first came here during the Paleo-Indian period hunting Ice Age mammals. Many different American Indian cultures occupied this land for thousands of years.  Around 900 CE, the Mississippian Period began. They constructed mounds for their elite, which remain today.

images.altText: mounds
images.title: Great Temple and Lesser Temple Mound
images.caption: The Great Temple Mound is the largest mound at the park, it stands at 55 feet tall.

images.altText: earth lodge
images.title: Earth Lodge
images.caption: The Earth Lodge was used as a council chamber for the Mississippian Culture (900-1600)

images.altText: earth lodge floor
images.title: Earth Lodge Floor
images.caption: The earth Lodge floor is original it was carbon dated to 1015.

images.altText: funeral mound
images.title: The Funeral Mound
images.caption: The Funeral Mound was by prehistoric cultures to bury their dead. Today there are still remains instead the mound

images.altText: spear point
images.title: Clovis Point
images.caption: This Clovis point is the first spear found east of the Mississippi River. It was carbon dated to 10,000 BC

entranceFees.description: There is not an entrance fee to this park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee "FREE"

properties.directionsInfo: Russell Cave National Monument is located at 3729 County Road 98 in Bridgeport, Alabama. It is situated in the northeast corner of Alabama, just south of the Tennessee state line.
properties.weatherInfo: The weather in Bridgeport, Alabama is mild. The average temperature in the winter is in the low 50's. The average summer temperature is in the high 80's. We receive about 50 inches of rain each year. Snowfall varies, but only lasts a few days per event.
properties.name: Russell Cave
properties.description: Russell Cave is an archaeological site with one of the most complete records of prehistoric cultures in the Southeast. Thousands of years ago a portion of Russell Cave's entrance collapsed, creating a shelter that, for more than 10,000 years, was home to prehistoric peoples. Today it provides clues to the daily lifeways of early North American inhabitants dating from 10,000 B.C. to 1650 A.D.

images.altText: Winter flood in December 2015
images.title: Winter flood in December 2015
images.caption: 14,000 acres drain into Russell Cave

images.altText: Russell Cave in Spring
images.title: Russell Cave in Spring
images.caption: Prehistoric people continuously used Russell Cave for over 10,000 years

images.altText: Northern Cardinal
images.title: Northern Cardinal
images.caption: Russell Cave is site 44 on the Alabama birding Trail.

images.altText: Deer behind visitor center
images.title: Deer behind visitor center
images.caption: For a park of its size, Russell Cave National Monument has a diverse landscape that provides a remarkable habitat for wildlife observation.

images.altText: Looking out of the cave shelter
images.title: Looking out of the cave shelter
images.caption: Looking out of the cave shelter in the fall

entranceFees.description: Entry to and parking at the grounds is free between sunrise and sunset. This includes the historic farm and orchard and the nature trail to the beach on Cold Spring Harbor.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance

entranceFees.description: Individual tour tickets are required to enter the Theodore Roosevelt Home. Tours are every half-hour from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and are approximately 45 minutes to one hour in length. Children 15 years old and under are free. Visitors 62 years of age and older may be eligible for a Senior Pass that covers them and up to three other people. A limited number of reservations can be made at recreation.gov or by calling 1-877-444-6777.
entranceFees.title: Theodore Roosevelt Home

entranceFees.description: The Old Orchard Museum is housed in the historic home of Theodore Roosevelt's oldest son Ted and his wife Eleanor Alexander-Roosevelt. Admission is free during regular business hours.
entranceFees.title: Old Orchard Museum

properties.directionsInfo: Take either the Northern State Parkway to Exit 35N or the Long Island Expressway (I-495) to Exit 41N. At those exits, take Route 106 North for approximately 6 miles to downtown Oyster Bay. Turn right onto East Main Street (at Nobman's Hardware Store) and travel 2 miles on East Main Street/Cove Road. Turn left onto Cove Neck Road and drive 1.5 miles to Sagamore Hill National Historic Site.

entrancePasses.description: The Sagamore Hill Annual Pass covers the cost of tour tickets for the bearer and three others for an unlimited number of visits during one year.
entrancePasses.title: Sagamore Hill Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
The Atlantic Ocean and Long Island Sound moderates the climate of Long Island and Sagamore Hill.

Spring: Highs average between 50 F and 70 F. Snow in early March becomes rain by April.
Summer: Average highs range between 70 F and the upper 80s F. Summers are drier but thunderstorms are possible.
Fall: Highs are from the mid-50s F to the mid-70s F. Fall is the driest season, but showers are possible.
Winter: Highs are around 40 F. Snow showers are common; the largest accumulations come in February.
properties.name: Sagamore Hill
properties.description: Sagamore Hill was the home of Theodore Roosevelt, 26th President of the United States, from 1885 until his death in 1919. During Roosevelt's time in office, his "Summer White House" was the focus of international attention. Explore 83 acres of natural surroundings and historic buildings and become inspired by the legacy of one of America's most popular presidents.

images.altText: Theodore Roosevelt House with state historical society signage
images.title: Theodore Roosevelt House
images.caption: Theodore Roosevelt House at Sagamore Hill

images.altText: A nature trail to Cold Spring Harbor passes through woods.
images.title: Nature Trail
images.caption: Walk the grounds and explore the place the Roosevelt family called home.

images.altText: Papers, pens, and an inkwell arranged on a wooden desk.
images.title: Roosevelt's Library
images.caption: World War I-era papers on Theodore Roosevelt's library desk

phoneNumbers.description: The public information office is open from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. PST during weekdays and we will respond to all messages within two business days.

emailAddresses.description: Thank you very much for your message! Our email account is monitored weekdays between 8 A.M. and 5 P.M. and we will respond to all messages within two business days.

entranceFees.description: Per person fee to board the historic ships at Hyde Street Pier. Good for seven days. Children 15 and younger are free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee to Board the Historic Vessels

properties.directionsInfo: The park is located within the city limits of San Francisco, in the Fisherman's Wharf neighborhood, on the shoreline of San Francisco Bay.

entrancePasses.description: Good for one year. Only valid for San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park. The pass holder may enter with three additional adults and any number of children 15 years old and younger.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Park Pass

properties.weatherInfo: San Francisco is located in a Mediterranean climate. The rainy season usually lasts from November to March. The warmest months are usually September and October. The famous San Francisco fog begins rolling in through the Golden Gate in the spring and can persist throughout the summer months. That said, the city can be foggy and windy any time of the year, so if your visit to “sunny California” includes a stop in San Francisco, bring some warm clothing. The average annual temperature is 62.5°F (16.9°C).
properties.name: San Francisco Maritime
properties.description: Located in the Fisherman's Wharf neighborhood, San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park offers visitors the sights, sounds, smells and stories of Pacific Coast maritime history. The Park includes a magnificent fleet of historic ships, a Visitor Center, Maritime Museum, Maritime Research Center, and Aquatic Park Historic District.

images.altText: The bow and masts of a 19th century sailing ship.
images.title: 1886 Square-Rigger Balclutha
images.caption: The 1886 square-rigged Balclutha is moored at Hyde Street Pier.

images.altText: A red-roofed building with water and a pier behind it.
images.title: The Maritime Museum in the Aquatic Park Bathhouse Building
images.caption: The Maritime Museum, Aquatic Park cove, and Hyde Street Pier.

images.altText: A group of vessels moored at at pier.
images.title: Hyde Street Pier
images.caption: A view of Hyde Street Pier, Coit Tower and downtown San Francisco.

images.altText: An open double door into a brick building.
images.title: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park Visitor Center
images.caption: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park Visitor Center

images.altText: A close up of a spar on the bow of a sailing ship.
images.title: Balclutha's Bowsprit and Figurehead
images.caption: Balclutha's Bowsprit and Figurehead

images.altText: A group of vessels moored at a pier with a rainbow.
images.title: A Rainbow Adorns Hyde Street Pier
images.caption: A Rainbow Adorns Hyde Street Pier

properties.fullName: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit Springfield Armory National Historic Site
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The entrance to Armory Square is on Federal Street in Springfield, MA. Armory Square is shared by Springfield Armory NHS and Springfield Technical Community College (STCC).  The park is located on the STCC campus.  Follow the one way roadway around until you see the entrance sign for the park.  If stopped by campus security let them know you are visiting the park.  Parking is available in front of the Springfield Armory visitor center.
properties.weatherInfo: Springfield Armory National Historic Site is situated in the heart of Western Massachusetts and the Pioneer Valley. Our year is marked by four distinct seasons. Summers tend to be pleasant, but can at times be very hot and very humid. Autumn features brilliant foliage and cooler, calmer weather. Winter storms are capable of closing the park and can make travel dangerous. Springtime in New England is pleasant.
properties.name: Springfield Armory
properties.description: For nearly two centuries, the US Armed Forces and American industry looked to Springfield Armory for innovative engineering and superior firearms. Springfield Armory National Historic Site commemorates the critical role of the nation’s first armory by preserving and interpreting the world's largest historic US military small arms collection, along with historic archives, buildings, and landscapes.

images.altText: The Main Arsenal
images.title: Springfield Armory National Historic Site
images.caption: The Main Arsenal at Springfield Armory National Historic Site was first built in 1850 and today houses the park's amazing collection of historic firearms.

entranceFees.description: Provides the ticket holder a one hour guided tour of the Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site.  Entrance to the mansion is by guided tour only.
entranceFees.title: Vanderbilt Mansion Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Located on Route 9 in the town of Hyde Park, NY.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40°F to 70°F.  Rain is not uncommon.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70° F to 100° F.  Humidity can be high throughout the summer months with periods of rain.

Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40° F to 70° F.  Peak leaf season is mid-October.  Rain is not uncommon.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30° F to 50°F.   Ice, Freezing Rain and Snow are not uncommon.
properties.name: Vanderbilt Mansion
properties.description: Built by of one of the first families of wealth in America. Designed by one of the nation's preeminent architects. The Vanderbilt Mansion is a home built expressly for the aristocratic lifestyle.

images.altText: Misty April Morning
images.title: Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site
images.caption: A misty Spring morning at the Vanderbilt Mansion

images.altText: Fall Colors in the Hudson Valley
images.title: Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site
images.caption: Thousands of visitors flock to the Hudson Valley in the Fall to see the leaves change colors.

images.altText: The Formal Gardens
images.title: The F. W. Vanderbilt Formal Gardens
images.caption: The formal gardens of the Vanderbilt Estate consist of multiple tiers defined over a hillside, surrounded by a graceful landscape.

images.altText: View of the Hudson River looking North from the Overlook
images.title: Overlook
images.caption: The inspiring historic view of the Hudson River from the Overlook at Vanderbilt Mansion.

images.altText: West Point Band performs at the Vanderbilt Mansion
images.title: Summer Concert Series
images.caption: West Point Band performs at Vanderbilt Mansion, part of the Summer Concert Series.

entranceFees.description: As of August 2019 Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument is a fee free park.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Passenger vehicles can drive north of Silver City, New Mexico to the monument on NM Hwy 15. The 46 mile trip can take up to two hours due to the narrow and mountainous curving nature of the road.

Large RVs and vehicles pulling trailers should NOT use NM Hwy 15. From Silver City, take US Highway 180 to Santa Clara. Turn left onto NM Hwy 152 and drive to San Lorenzo. At San Lorenzo, turn left onto NM Hwy 35 and follow it to its termination at NM Hwy 15. Turn right on NM Hwy 15 and follow signs to the park.

entrancePasses.description: Active duty military personnel and their dependents may qualify for this pass. Covers entrance or standard amenity fees at Federal Recreation sites for the pass holder and occupants of a single, private, non-commercial vehicle OR the pass holder and 3 persons over the age of 16 where per person fees are charged. Must show proof of active duty or active duty dependent status.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Military Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: For US citizens and permanent residents medically determined to have a permanent disability that severely limits one or more major life activities. Free entrance for the pass holder and occupants of a single, private, non-commercial vehicle OR the pass holder and three persons (16 or older) where per person fees are charged. Disability documentation is required.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Access Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Weather is extremely variable. Summers are usually in the 80s but approach 100 °F. Winters have occasional snow or temperatures near 0 °F. Thunderstorms are common in the summer and early fall, usually in the afternoon. Thunderstorms and lightning may cause temporary closures of the monument.
properties.name: Gila Cliff Dwellings
properties.description: For thousands of years, groups of nomadic people used the caves of the Gila River as temporary shelter. In the late 1200's, people of the Mogollon Culture decided it would be a good place to call home. They built rooms, crafted pottery and raised children in the cliff dwellings for about twenty years. Then the Mogollon moved on, leaving the walls for us as a glimpse into the past.

images.altText: Exterior view of Mogollon Cliff Dwelling
images.title: Mogollon Cliff Dwelling with T Door
images.caption: The T-shaped door suggests trade between Mogollon and Ancestral Puebloan.

images.altText: Cliff Dwellings walls and rooms with narrow catwalk
images.title: A Place to Call Home
images.caption: Most of the dwellings walls are original. Some even preserve a builder's fingerprints that are over 700 years old.

images.altText: Sunrise view of Gila Cliff Dwellings with brilliant sky.
images.title: Winter Solstice Sunrise at Gila Cliff Dwellings
images.caption: Visitors enjoy panoramic views of the canyon and dwellings at Gila Cliff Dwellings.

images.altText: View of Mogollon dwelling rooms within a cave.
images.title: Looking Back in Time
images.caption: Tularosa Phase Mogollon people made these caves their home in the late 1200's.

images.altText: Distant view of Gila river valley and mountains beyond.
images.title: View of the Gila River Valley near Gila Cliff Dwellings NM
images.caption: The Oldest Wilderness Area in the United States Awaits.

images.altText: Light snowfall on red rock cliffs along river.
images.title: Gila National Forest Approach to Gila National Monument in Winter
images.caption: Winter wonderland along the Gila River

images.altText: Eroded cliffs reflecting off a river
images.title: Eroded Cliffs Along the Gila River
images.caption: As the first designated Wilderness Area, the Gila offers endless opportunites peaceful reflection.

entranceFees.description: Required for anyone 16 and older unless a guest of other pass holder. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Tumacácori Entrance Fee - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo: Tumacácori National Historical Park is located off of Exit 29 of Interstate 19, forty-five miles (80 kilometers) south of Tucson, Arizona, and eighteen miles (26 kilometers) north of Nogales, Arizona.

entrancePasses.description: Covers pass holder(s) plus three adult guests. Kids under 16 are always free. Photo ID of either pass holder required. Valid for 12 months from month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Tumacácori Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Located above the heat of the low desert, Tumacácori National Historical Park is in the mesquite highlands, close to 3,300 feet in elevation, where temperatures are five to ten degrees cooler than Tucson or Phoenix. Visiting the park in this moderate climate is pleasurable during any season of the year but remember to prepare accordingly. Bring layered clothing and drink plenty of water.
properties.name: Tumacácori
properties.description: Tumacácori sits at a cultural crossroads in the Santa Cruz River valley. Here O’odham, Yaqui, and Apache people met and mingled with European Jesuit and Franciscan missionaries, settlers, and soldiers, sometimes in conflict and sometimes in cooperation. Follow the timeworn paths and discover stories that connect us to enduring relationships, vibrant cultures, and traditions of long ago.

images.altText: panorama of mission church with green grass and clouds
images.title: Tumacácori on a Summer Day
images.caption: A summer day yields beautiful colors and a striking scene on the mission grounds.

images.altText: folklorico dancers in front of church
images.title: La Fiesta de Tumacácori
images.caption: The Fiesta de Tumacácori, held annually in December, has over 40 years of history and hundreds of years of heritage.

images.altText: long paved sidewalk leads to adobe mission church
images.title: Visiting Tumacácori
images.caption: Modern facilities like paved sidewalks and restrooms complement a visit to this site's rich history.

images.altText: milky way in sky over dimly lit bell tower
images.title: Milky Way over the Bell Tower
images.caption: Several times each year, the park opens late to invite visitors to experience dark night skies and the legacy of astronomy priest Padre Eusebio Francisco Kino.

images.altText: ranger and visitors looking at church facade
images.title: Visitors on a Mission Tour
images.caption: Guided mission tours explore the hidden treasures and untold stories of Tumacácori's past.

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee covers one adult, aged 16 and over, for entrance to Montezuma Castle and Tuzigoot National Monuments for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Tuzigoot Entrance Fee - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Children aged 15 and under are free.
entranceFees.title: Tuzigoot Entrance Fee - Children

properties.directionsInfo: From Phoenix or Flagstaff take I-17 to exit 287, and then travel west on Hwy 260 to Cottonwood. Once in Cottonwood travel north through the town on Main Street. Just before Clarkdale you will see signs directing visitors onto Tuzigoot Rd.

entrancePasses.description: The Montezuma Castle and Tuzigoot Annual Pass covers the card holder and 3 other adults (aged 16 and over) into both Montezuma Castle and Tuzigoot for one year from date of purchase. Children 15 and under are free.
entrancePasses.title: Tuzigoot and Montezuma Castle Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Summer: Hot. Temperatures range from 95°F (35°C) beyond 110°F (42°C). Nighttime temperatures can be much cooler, around 70°F (21°C). From late June through early August, heavy rains called monsoons are common in the afternoons.  

Winter: Cool. Highs average around 55°F (13°C); lows may be in the teens (-10°C). Snow is rare, but possible.

For detailed information, visit the National Weather Service: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-112.02729309051725&lat=34.7698307603777#.VmWtK3arSUk
properties.name: Tuzigoot
properties.description: Crowning a desert hilltop is an ancient pueblo. A child scans the desert landscape for the arrival of traders. What riches will they bring? What stories will they tell? From the rooftop of the Tuzigoot pueblo it is easy to imagine such a moment. The pueblo shows us this ancient village built by the Sinagua people. They were farmers and artists with trade connections that spanned hundreds of miles.

images.altText: 4 foot masonry walls covered in snow
images.title: Tuzigoot with Snow!
images.caption: Even central Arizona can get a lot of snow!  Check out the dwellings at Tuzigoot covered in a winter storm.

images.altText: 4 foot masonry walls with mountains and clouds behind them.
images.title: Tuzigoot with Black Hills
images.caption: Tuzigoot was built on a low hilltop in the Verde Valley. The Verde River and Black Hills provided a variety of resource areas for the Sinagua.

images.altText: A marsh with open water, cattails, and a masonry dwelling beyond.
images.title: Tuzigoot with Tavasci Marsh
images.caption: Tuzigoot Pueblo sits on a hilltop above an area perfect for farming. Tavasci Marsh provides water and other resources.

images.altText: The inside of a masonry room with wood posts supporting the roof.
images.title: Inside Tuzigoot
images.caption: Rebuilt in the 1930s, this room at Tuzigoot would not originally have had a roof. Today, you can climb through the room to experience the landscape that surrounds this enduring Pueblo.

images.altText: Two women stand with 8 large ceramic pots
images.title: Tuzigoot Ollas
images.caption: During the 1930s, when Tuzigoot was excavated, the procedure was to rebuild artifacts. These women were employed as part of the CCC to glue back together these large olla pots. Today we know that gluing them back together can actually damage the pots.

entranceFees.description: None
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
The site can be reached from US Highway 12, 8 miles west of Walla Walla, Wa.

Airports are located in Walla Walla (11 miles east of park), Pasco (43 miles west), and Pendleton, Oregon (46 miles south).
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are hot. Hats, water and sunblock are recommended.
Winters are mild and rainy with a few snow storms. Layered clothing is advised.
properties.name: Whitman Mission
properties.description: The 1847 attack on the Whitmans horrified Americans and impacted the lives of the peoples of the Columbia Plateau for decades afterwards. Was killing the Whitmans justified legal retribution, an act of revenge, or some combination of both? The circumstances that surround this tragic event resonate with modern issues of cultural interaction and differing perspectives.

images.altText: Ranger and students
images.title: WHMI Monument Hill
images.caption: Ranger Lenihan describes the mission site to school field trip participants.

images.altText: Tule Lodge in Visitor Center
images.title: WHMI Tule Lodge
images.caption: Visitors have access to many cultural items in the tule lodge.

images.altText: Tipi near the Visitor Center
images.title: WHMI Mission grounds
images.caption: Nez Perce style tipis are used for school programs each spring.

images.altText: Marcus Whitman
images.title: Marcus Whitman
images.caption: Painting of Marcus Whitman from a sketch by Paul Kane 1847.

images.altText: Cornhusk Flat Bag
images.title: Cayuse Woven Cornhusk Bag
images.caption: Traditional Cayuse Cornhusk Bag

entranceFees.description: All trails, visitor centers, historic structures, ranger programs and events
entranceFees.title: ALL LOCATIONS

properties.directionsInfo: The park is 4 miles west of Beatrice on State Highway 4. From the U.S. 77 and U.S. 136 intersection in downtown Beatrice take U.S. 136 approximately 1.2 miles west. Turn right onto Nebraska Highway 4 and follow the signs.After the road has curved west and you have traveled 4 miles, you will enter Homestead National Monument and see signs for the different buildings at the park.
properties.weatherInfo: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?textField1=40.26805750000045&textField2=-96.74696994099969#.Vk5FthH4-Uk
properties.name: Homestead
properties.description: With the promise of Free Land, the Homestead Act of 1862 enticed millions to cultivate the frontier. Families, immigrants, women, and freed slaves flooded 10 percent of the nation’s land to chase their American Dream. American Indian cultures and natural environments gave way to diverse settlement, agricultural success, and industrial advancement—building our nation and changing the land forever.

images.credit: Mel Mann, artist in residence of Homestead National Monument of America
images.altText: The Homestead Heritage Center on the tallgrass prairie
images.title: Homestead Heritage Center
images.caption: Thousands of visitors stop to view the oldest restored tallgrass prairie in the National Park Service from the Heritage Center back patio.

images.altText: The Homestead Education Center
images.title: Homestead Education Center
images.caption: The Homestead Education Center holds historic farm implements from the vast archives and collections of the Monument.

images.altText: A historic one room schoolhouse
images.title: Freeman One-Room Schoolhouse
images.caption: An original one-room schoolhouse, the Freeman School preserves educational history and allows for visitors of all ages to walk into history.

images.altText: A homestead cabin at sunset
images.title: Palmer-Epard Homestead Cabin
images.caption: The historic homestead cabin that can be found on the America the Beautiful Homestead Quarter, this cabin has been preserved in it's original condition for visitors to enter and see the inside of a historic structure.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee at Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts is located in Vienna, Virginia. The park can be accessed by traveling from Route 7, the Dulles Toll Road (Route 267), Beulah Road or Old Courthouse Road. For more detailed information visit the park's directions page.
properties.weatherInfo: The weather at Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts is typical for the mid-Atlantic area. There are four seasons. The majority of visitation is during the summers, which can be hot and humid during the day and cooler at night.
properties.name: Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts
properties.description:
No matter what your age or taste in shows, you'll find something you like onstage at Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts. From May through September, multiple amphitheaters in the park present performances such as musicals, dance, opera, jazz, and popular and country music.

A good time to explore the beauty  and history of the park without the crowds is October - April.

images.altText: The Filene Center House full of patrons
images.title: Filene Center Blast Off
images.caption: Everyone is ready to kickoff the Filene Center season.

images.altText: Bust of Catherine Filene Shouse with building in back
images.title: Catherine Filene Shouse Bust
images.caption: Catherine Filene Shouse donated her land to the National Park Service, which Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts was established.

images.altText: A ranger swears in two new Jr. Rangers during Jr. Ranger Day activities at the park.
images.title: Junior Ranger Day
images.caption: Junior Ranger Days occur throughout the summer.

images.altText: Native garden with the Filene Center in the background
images.title: Dimple Meadow
images.caption: In 2012, park staff and volunteers planted 42 species of native grasses and wildflowers here to create a habitat that now supports over 40 kinds of bees and 25 types of butterflies.

images.altText: Filene Center in the background with autumn leaves
images.title: Natural Side of a Park for the Performing Arts
images.caption: There are opportunities year-round to hike and enjoy the outdoors, picnic and participate in ranger programs or walks.

images.altText: Sold out show at Theatre-in-the-Woods
images.title: Children's Theatre-in-the-Woods Performances
images.caption: Most of the activities in the park during the summer are centered around performances at the Filene Center and Theatre-in-the-Woods.

properties.fullName: Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit Timpanogos Cave National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Timpanogos Cave NM Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-15: Take Exit 284 (Alpine-Highland exit), turn east on State Highway 92 and proceed ten miles (16km) to the monument.

UT 40 or U.S. 189: Travel UT 189 through Provo Canyon, west on Orem 800 North (UT 52). After 2.4 miles turn right on State Street UT- 89. After 3.8 miles, turn onto Pleasant Grove 100 East (UT 146). Stay on this road for almost five miles, as it turns in Canyon Road and takes you to the mouth of American Fork Canyon. Turn right up American Fork Canyon to visitor center.
properties.weatherInfo: Although inside the caves its always 43-48 F, temperatures on the cave trail can range from the 30s up to above 100 degrees F, depending on time of year. Carrying drinking water is a necessity, especially in summer. In the mountains, weather sometimes presents interesting challenges. The cave and cave trail do not close due to rain, unless that rain is heavy enough to bring rockfall. They will close due to high winds/rockfall, or in lightning storms. Call the visitor center if you have specific concerns.
properties.name: Timpanogos Cave
properties.description:
Hike your way past stunning vistas to explore a hidden underground world. Taste the thrill of caving as you twist and bend to enter beautifully decorated rooms. Learn the science behind formations and hear stories of cave exploration and preservation.  Experience and discover as you go – geologic mysteries await.

Due to CDC guidance on COVID-19, summer plans will be announced as soon as possible.

images.altText: Twisty helictites growing off a stalactite
images.title: Helictites in Timpanogos Cave
images.caption: Timpanogos Cave is filled with twisting helictites and other beautiful formations

images.altText: Visitors gaze at delicate cave formations in Timpanogos Cave's Chimes Chamber
images.title: Timpanogos Cave's "Chimes Chamber"
images.caption: Timpanogos Cave's beautiful Chimes Chamber is filled with delicate cave formations

images.altText: Two cavers look at large formations in Hansen Cave
images.title: Hansen Cave-Introduction to Caving Tour
images.caption: Cavers on the Introduction to Caving Tour admire magnificent formations.

images.altText: Utah Valley beyond the steep cliffs and fir trees of American Fork Canyon
images.title: View from the Timpanogos Cave Trail
images.caption: The scenic view from the trail to the caves is one people often remember.

images.altText: White-orange quartzite surrounded by greenery stands against a blue sky
images.title: Along the Trail to the Caves
images.caption: The trail to the cave leads the hiker past layer after layer of geologic time

entranceFees.description: no fee
entranceFees.title: Theodore Roosevelt Island Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
By Car: accessible from the northbound lanes of the George Washington Memorial Parkway, after Roosevelt Bridge, exit sign, turn right into the parking lot. Please note: park in a designated parking space, US Park Police regularly tickets drivers who park on the grass.
By Metro: exit Rosslyn Metro station, walk toward Key Bridge, take short connecting trail downhill from the downstream side of the bridge, across the parkway, and into the parking lot for the island.
By Bike: Mount Vernon Trail north end

entrancePasses.description: no pass, no fee
entrancePasses.title: no pass

properties.weatherInfo: Outdoor trails and memorial plaza subject to weather for Washington, D.C. and Arlington, VA.
properties.name: Theodore Roosevelt Island
properties.description: In the 1930s, landscape architects transformed Mason’s Island from neglected, overgrown farmland into Theodore Roosevelt Island, a memorial to America’s 26th president. They conceived a “real forest” designed to mimic the natural forest that once covered the island. Today miles of trails through wooded uplands and swampy bottomlands honor the legacy of a great outdoorsman and conservationist.

images.altText: A bronze statue of Theodore Roosevelt standing and pointing.
images.title: Staute of Theodore Roosevelt
images.caption: Theodore Roosevelt memorial plaza on Theodore Roosevelt Island.

images.altText: woodland trail in the shadow of tall trees
images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Island Trail
images.caption: Hike the trails around the island

images.altText: Three people with Park Ranger at Theodore Roosevelt Memorial.
images.title: Ranger answers Question
images.caption: National Park Service Ranger discussing Theodore Roosevelt with visitors at his memorial.

images.altText: long stone plaza with statue of Theodore Roosevelt at end surround by the shadows of tall trees
images.title: Across Theodore Roosevelt Island Memorial Plaza
images.caption: Enjoy a hidden gem, an island oasis, in the busy Washington, D.C region.

images.altText: three people walking on wooden boardwalk under trees
images.title: Trail on Theodore Roosevelt Island
images.caption: Hike the trails throughout Theodore Roosevelt Island for a grand adventure.

addresses.line2: northbound lanes between Roosevelt Bridge and Key Bridge

entranceFees.description: There is no fee for visiting the Lyndon Baines Johnson Memorial Grove on the Potomac.
entranceFees.title: No Fee

properties.directionsInfo: From the southbound lanes of the George Washington Memorial Parkway, follow the sign to turn right to enter the parking lot. This entrance to the park can only be reached from the southbound lanes of the parkway.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers in the park are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning.

Winters in the park are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. Please be alert for snowplows and icy spots on roadways.

Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
properties.name: LBJ Memorial Grove on the Potomac
properties.description: From this distance the seat of national power appears pristine across the river, so President Johnson came here often when he needed to escape from the stresses of building a Great Society. After he died, his wife chose this place for his memorial. A landscape of serpentine paths, white pines, a granite monolith, and an open meadow honors his legacy of social justice and conservation legislation.

images.altText: The Memorial
images.title: The Lyndon Baines Johnson Memorial Grove on the Potomac
images.caption: The Memorial mirrors the Washington Monument across the River in Washington D.C.

images.altText: Springtime in the Grove
images.title: Lyndon Baines Johnson Memorial Grove
images.caption: The grove come to life with blooming flowers in the Spring.

images.altText: A place for reflection
images.title: Birds at Lyndon Baines Johnson Memorial Grove on the Potomac
images.caption: Lyndon Baines Johnson came to this location many times to pause and reflect.

properties.fullName: LBJ Memorial Grove on the Potomac

entranceFees.description: There is an entrance fee for Fort Moultrie, the grounds and visitor center. Adults 16 and older are $10. Children 15 and younger are free. All America the Beautiful passes are accepted and available for purchase in the Fort Moultrie Visitor Center. Passes are available for purchase from 9:00 am-4:00 pm daily.
entranceFees.title: Fort Moultrie Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
The park concessioner charges a fee for the ferry ride to Fort Sumter. This is the only way to get to the fort. Ferry boats depart from 2 locations: the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center in Charleston; and Patriots Point in Mount Pleasant. Adults-$24.00; Seniors and Military-$22.00; Children (ages 4-11) $16.00. 

Concessioner does not honor the America the Beautiful-National Parks and Federal Lands Pass.
entranceFees.title: Transportation Fee for Concession Ferry Ride to Fort Sumter

entranceFees.description:
The Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center, located at 340 Concord Street in Charleston is the primary departure point for the ferries to Fort Sumter. Museum exhibits, park rangers and a museum store are on site. This visitor education center is free to visit.

There is a cost for the concession ferry ride to Fort Sumter which is separate from the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center.
entranceFees.title: Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center

properties.directionsInfo:
Fort Sumter is accessible only by ferry boat. Boats depart at scheduled times from two locations. The primary departure point is the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center, 340 Concord Street, Charleston. Boats also depart from Patriots Point, 40 Patriots Point Boulevard, Mount Pleasant. There is a fee for riding the concession-operated ferry.

Fort Moultrie and park headquarters is accessible by car. The address is 1214 Middle Street, Sullivan's Island. A park entrance fee is charged for the park.

entrancePasses.description: Annual Pass for Fort Moultrie valid for pass holder and three additional adults. Valid for one year from purchase date. The Fort Moultrie Pass is available for purchase from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm daily in the Fort Moultrie Visitor Center.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Moultrie Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Mild winters. Hot and humid during the summer.
properties.name: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie
properties.description: Charleston, victorious over the Royal Navy in 1776 and scene of the largest patriot defeat in 1780, played a key role in the American Revolution. Charleston's appetite for revolution continued in the 1800s as the city blazed a path to secession to safeguard slavery. The Confederacy fired on the US garrison of Fort Sumter on April 12, 1861, opening the Civil War, which redefined American freedom.

images.altText: A row of cannon with Fort Moultrie in the background. A US flag is flying in the fort.
images.title: Fort Moultrie
images.caption: Fort Moultrie spans 171 years from 1776-1947

images.altText: Fort Sumter with a US flag flying above the fort with the tour boat docked in front
images.title: Fort Sumter
images.caption: Fort Sumter is located on an island in Charleston Harbor and is only accessible by boat.

images.altText: A three-story brick structure with a staircase in front and water in the background
images.title: Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center
images.caption: The Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center is the primary departure point for the ferries to Fort Sumter.

images.altText: A tattered 33-star United States flag
images.title: Fort Sumter Garrison Flag
images.caption: Fort Sumter's 33-star garrison flag was flown over Fort Sumter during the Union's April 14, 1861 surrender ceremony, and again on April 14, 1865 to mark the end of the Civil War in Charleston. On display at the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center.

images.altText: Remnants of the 33-star Fort Sumter Storm Flag
images.title: Fort Sumter Storm Flag
images.caption: The 33-star "storm" flag was flown over Fort Sumter during the April 12-13, 1861 bombardment of Fort Sumter. The larger garrison flag had been lowered to repair a tear on April 11. On display at the Fort Sumter Museum.

properties.fullName: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: Online house tour reservations available at https://www.recreation.gov/ticket/facility/300005
entranceFees.title: House Tour Fee - Adults age 16-61

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter the park to hike the trails, enjoy the grounds or visit the barn and bookstore.  Start your visit in the ground floor of the Sandburg Home for information, house tour tickets, videos and more.

Child reservations online will incur $1.00 processing fee.  Day-of-tour walk up child tickets are free.

properties.directionsInfo: The park is located three miles south of Hendersonville, NC on Little River Road off of the Greenville Highway/Rt. 225 in Flat Rock, NC. Visitors using GPS or mapping software should use 1800 Little River Road and look for the signs directing you to the visitor parking lot on Little River Road.

properties.name: Carl Sandburg Home
properties.description:
Carl Sandburg provided a popular voice for the American people of the twentieth century and still speaks to us through his words, activism, music and the beauty and serenity of Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site.

Explore Sandburg's legacy and Experience Your America!

images.altText: A view of the Sandburg Home as visitors enter the park
images.title: Carl Sandburg Home NHS
images.caption: The Sandburg family enjoyed living in the Carolina mountains along with a collection of 12,000 books and a herd of dairy goats.

images.altText: Dairy goats graze peacefully near the Sandburg barn
images.title: Connemara Farms
images.caption: Connemara Farms dairy goats graze peacefully near the Sandburg barn

images.altText: Spring-born kid goats greet visitors to the barn
images.title: Kid Goats Greet Visitors
images.caption: Spring-born kid goats greet visitors to the barn.

images.altText: A view of Sandburg's study as visitors see it today
images.title: Carl Sandburg's Study
images.caption: A view of Sandburg's study as visitors see it today

images.altText: A view of the front lake and Sandburg Home as visitors enter the park
images.title: Visitor Entrance to Carl Sandburg Home NHS
images.caption: A view of the front lake and Sandburg Home as visitors enter the park

images.altText: Two visitors enjoy a stroll through the trees on a park trail
images.title: Hiking Trails in the Park
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy more than five miles of hiking trails through the park.

properties.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site

emailAddresses.description: If you have general questions about Tonto National Monument and the cliff dwellings, please send us an email. We will respond as soon as possible.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee applies to everyone 16 and older. Children under 16 are free. Tonto National Monument accepts all interagency federal public lands passes in places of the entrance fee. These Include the Annual, Senior, Access, Military, and Fourth Grader passes.
entranceFees.title: Per Person Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The cliff dwellings at Tonto National Monument are roughly two hours from the Phoenix metro area, located in the Tonto Basin. The monument is off AZ Highway 188 near Roosevelt Lake. The nearest major towns are Globe (30 miles) and Payson (50 miles). See our Directions page for recommendations on the best way to drive here from the larger metro areas of Arizona.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather during the summer can be extremely hot. It is typically 10 degrees Fahrenheit cooler than Phoenix. Winter weather may create hazardous conditions on the roads to Tonto National Monument. Severe thunderstorms may lead to a closer of the hiking trails.
properties.name: Tonto
properties.description: The Salado Phenomena, 700 years ago, blended ideas of neighboring Native American cultures to emerge a unique and vibrant society. Tonto National Monument showcases two Salado-style cliff dwellings. Colorful pottery, woven cotton cloth, and other artifacts tell a story of people living and using resources from the northern Sonoran Desert from 1250 to 1450 CE.

images.altText: cliff cwelling in the desert with wildflowers
images.title: Lower Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: The Lower Cliff Dwelling in Spring

images.altText: 700 year old walls of the cliff dwelling

images.caption: Inside the Lower Cliff Dwelling

images.altText: Visitor Center with cliff dwelling and a rainbow in the background
