images.caption: The Visitor Center sits below the Lower Cliff Dwelling

images.altText: the walls still standing for over 700 years
images.title: Upper Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: The of the front view of the Upper Cliff Dwelling

images.altText: the view looking out from the cliff dwelling over Roosevelt Lake
images.title: Upper Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: The view from the back of the Upper Cliff Dwelling

entranceFees.description: Some public lands such as state and county parks located along the Trail may charge entrance fees. Camping registration, permits, and fees may also be needed. Before your visit you should check with the local land manager regarding possible fees and registration requirements.
entranceFees.title: Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
The Ice Age National Scenic Trail stretches nearly 1,200 miles across Wisconsin. 

Plane

Commercial airports are located in major cities and regional communities throughout the state at varying distances from the Ice Age National Scenic Trail.

Car

Numerous trailheads with parking are located throughout the state.

entrancePasses.description: Available for purchase online.
entrancePasses.title: Passes

properties.weatherInfo: Wisconsin has four distinctly different seasons. Wisconsin's continental climate means this state enjoys a little bit of everything, weather-wise. Summers are generally warm and pleasant, while the area is covered with a thick blanket of white snow in winter.
properties.name: Ice Age
properties.description: A mere 15,000 years ago during the Ice Age, much of North America lay under a huge glacier. Mammoths, saber tooth cats and cave lions roamed the earth! Some of the best evidence of this glacier is found in Wisconsin such as the state’s many lakes, river valleys, gently rolling hills, and ridges. The nearly 1,200 mile Ice Age National Scenic Trail, established in 1980, traces the glacier's edge.

images.altText: volunteers build a boardwalk
images.title: Volunteers build a boardwalk at Straight Lake State Park
images.caption: Volunteers work to construct a boardwalk at Straight Lake State Park using only hand tools.

images.altText: New trail takes hikers into the forest
images.title: skunk and foster
images.caption: Newly consstructed trail in the Skunk and Foster State Wildlife Area invites kikers to explore the forest.

images.altText: For a short time, the trail follows a beach along the Lake Michigan Shore.
images.title: Lake Michigan
images.caption: The trail takes hikers to the beach to enjoy the state's largest glacial feature- Lake Michigan!

images.altText: expansive view as seen from atop Gibraltar Rock
images.title: gibralter Rock
images.caption: The view extends for many miles from atop Gibraltar Rock.

images.altText: A boardwalks stretched accross conservancy lands.
images.title: riverland
images.caption: A group of school children explore the trail in Sauk County.

entranceFees.description: Herbert Hoover National Historic Site charges no fee to enter. Admission to the Herbert Hoover Presidential Library and Museum costs $10.00 for adults with discounts for seniors, children, active and retired military, and college students. Free federal recreational lands passes (Access, Military, and 4th Grade passes) are issued at the Visitor Center.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Take exit 254 off Interstate 80 to West Branch, Iowa. The Visitor Center is 0.3 mile north of Interstate 80.
properties.weatherInfo: Spring and fall are mild with moderate temperatures. Average high temperatures in the spring and fall are between 50° and 60° F, with lows from 40° F to 50° F. Summer is hot and humid with average highs around 85° F. Winter can be cold, windy, and snowy with highs averaging 30° F or lower. Rain and thunderstorms are most frequent in the spring and summer.
properties.name: Herbert Hoover
properties.description: Orphaned at age nine, Herbert Hoover left West Branch never to live here again. In later years, he returned to his humble birthplace to celebrate his long career of public service. A memorial landscape remains to tell his story: how community, hard work, honesty, and usefulness to others opened a world of opportunity— and the presidency of the United States— to a child of simple beginnings.

images.altText: A one story wood frame house has board-and-batten exterior siding and a picket fence painted white.
images.title: Herbert Hoover Birthplace Cottage
images.caption: Herbert Hoover called his humble birthplace "physical proof of the unbounded opportunity of American life."

images.altText: A low brown barn-like building with three large doorways has a large horseshoe on its facade.
images.title: Blacksmith Shop
images.caption: Herbert Hoover's father Jesse owned a blacksmith shop similar to the one at Herbert Hoover NHS.

images.altText: Two marble ledger stones each mark a grave in a semicircular landscaped plot with a flagpole.
images.title: Gravesite of President & Mrs. Hoover
images.caption: Two simple marble slabs mark the graves of Herbert and Lou Henry Hoover.

images.altText: A one-story wooden building painted off-white has two windows and a central doorway.
images.title: Schoolhouse
images.caption: Many rural Midwestern towns like West Branch placed a high value on education.

images.altText: A cast bronze figure of a veiled goddess sits on a throne mounted on a concrete pedestal.
images.title: Statue of Isis
images.caption: The people of Belgium gave Herbert Hoover the statue "Isis, Goddess of Life" in gratitude for his famine relief efforts on their behalf during the First World War.

images.altText: A sprawling one story public building of rough-faced yellowish stone has a white portico entrance.
images.title: Herbert Hoover Presidential Library & Museum
images.caption: Exhibit galleries and archival collections tell of the triumphs and tragedies of Hoover’s long career in public service.

images.altText: Two doorways, one on either side, of a broad white wood frame building divides the sexes.
images.title: Friends Meetinghouse
images.caption: The plainly appointed Friends Meetinghouse and the practices within express Quaker values of peace, simplicity, integrity, and service to others.

properties.directionsInfo:
From the east or west - From Interstate 64, exit onto US 231, (exit 57A). Travel south on US 231 to Indiana Highway 162. Take the Santa Claus/Gentryville exit. Turn west (right) on Indiana Highway 162; go 1-1/2 miles to the park entrance on the right.

From the north or south - From US 231 take the Santa Claus/Gentryville exit. Turn west on Indiana Highway 162; go 1-1/2 miles to the park entrance on the right.
properties.weatherInfo: Southern Indiana has a moderate climate, characterized by warm, yet moist conditions. Summers are usually warm, and winters cool. Much of the area's average 46 inches of precipitation falls in spring, the rainiest season.
properties.name: Lincoln Boyhood
properties.description: Abraham Lincoln grew from youth to manhood on this southern Indiana soil.  Many character and moral traits of one of the world's most respected leaders was formed and nurtured here.  Explore Lincoln's boyhood and learn about the boy who would one day become the leader of our nation.

images.altText: Park ranger is period dress standing near fireplace cooking in the cabin.
images.title: Cabin at Living Historical Farm
images.caption: Park rangers depict pioneer life in the 1820s.

images.altText: Bronze casting on the ground covering bottom logs of a cabin and fireplace.
images.title: Cabin Site Memorial
images.caption: The site of what is believed Memorial at the site of the third Lincoln cabin.

images.altText: Cabin and smokehouse in the fall
images.title: Lincoln Living Historical Farm
images.caption: Replica cabin at re-created 1820s homestead which is on four of the original 160 acres owned by Thomas LIncoln.

images.altText: White marble headstone of Nancy Hanks Lincoln
images.title: Gravesite of Nancy Hanks Lincoln
images.caption: The headstone, erected in 1879, marks the burial spot of Abraham Lincoln's mother, who died of milk sickness in 1818.

images.altText: Memorial Building
images.title: Memorial Visitor Center
images.caption: Memorial Building contains memorial halls to remember Abraham Lincoln and his family.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee associated with visiting either unit of the park.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

properties.directionsInfo: The Birthplace Unit of the park is located approximately 2 miles south of the town of Hodgenville on U.S. Highway 31E South. The Boyhood Home Unit at Knob Creek is located approximately 10 miles northeast of the Birthplace Unit of the park.
properties.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in Central Kentucky. However, temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer is usually hot and humid. Winter is moderately cold with mixed precipitation.
properties.name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace
properties.description: For over a century people from around the world have come to rural Central Kentucky to honor the humble beginnings of our 16th president, Abraham Lincoln.  His early life on Kentucky's frontier shaped his character and prepared him to lead the nation through Civil War.  The country's first memorial to Lincoln, built with donations from young and old, enshrines the symbolic birthplace cabin.

images.altText: The Memorial Building surrounded by fall colors
images.title: The Memorial Building with fall colors
images.caption: Over 200,000 people a year come to walk up the steps of the Memorial Building to visit the site where Abraham Lincoln was born

images.altText: The first memorial erected to honor Abraham Lincoln
images.title: The Memorial Building
images.caption: The Memorial Building constructed on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

images.altText: The symbolic birth cabin on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
images.title: The Symbolic Birth Cabin of Abraham Lincoln
images.caption: The symbolic birth cabin of Abraham Lincoln.

images.altText: Statue of the Lincoln family in the park's Visitor Center
images.title: Statue of the Lincoln Family in the Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitors to the park can view the statue of the Lincoln family.

properties.fullName: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park

properties.directionsInfo:
Montezuma Castle: Follow I-17 to exit 289 (90 minutes north of Phoenix, 45 minutes south of Flagstaff).  Drive east (through two traffic circles) for approximately 1/2 mile to the blinking red light. Turn left onto Montezuma Castle Road.

Montezuma Well: Follow I-17 to exit 293 (north of the exit for Montezuma Castle). Continue through the towns of McGuireville and Rimrock, following the signs for 4 miles to the entrance to the Well.

entrancePasses.description: The Montezuma Castle and Tuzigoot Annual Pass covers the card holder and 3 other adults (aged 16 and over) into both Montezuma Castle and Tuzigoot for one year from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Montezuma Castle and Tuzigoot Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Summer: Hot. Temperatures range from 95°F (35°C) beyond 110°F (42°C). Nighttime temperatures can be much cooler, around 70°F (21°C). From late June through early August, heavy rains called monsoons are common in the afternoons.  

Winter: Cool. Highs average around 55°F (13°C); lows may be in the teens (-10°C). Snow is rare, but possible.

For detailed information, visit the National Weather Service: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=34.61151944900047&lon=-111.8389592099997#.Vi_FZX6rSUk
properties.name: Montezuma Castle
properties.description:
Today we gaze through the windows of the past into one of the best preserved cliff dwellings in North America. This 20 room high-rise apartment, nestled into a towering limestone cliff, tells a story of ingenuity, survival and ultimately, prosperity in an unforgiving desert landscape.

Come marvel at this enduring legacy of the Sinagua culture and reveal a people surprisingly similar to ourselves.

images.altText: Two masonry walls with a dark doorway in a short cliff ledge.
images.title: Storage Room at Montezuma Castle
images.caption: The Sinagua used space efficiently - here a storage room sits in a short cliff space below the main Castle.

images.altText: Sun shines on the window sill in a masonry wall; trees in fall color are seen outside the window.
images.title: Window in Montezuma Castle
images.caption: Visitors to Montezuma Castle usually only get to see the dwelling from the outside.  This view shows what the Sinagua might have seen.

images.altText: A 5-story masonry dwelling sits in a cliff alcove.
images.title: Montezuma Castle in the Cliff
images.caption: Montezuma Castle was built in an alcove about 90 feet up a cliff. This protects the dwelling from flooding.

images.altText: Low masonry walls without roofs against the base of a cliff.
images.title: Castle A at Montezuma Castle National Monument
images.caption: The remains of the dwelling called Castle A show what 600 years of weather can do to a building.

images.altText: Two cliff dwellings and a tree with yellow leaves above a pond.
images.title: Montezuma Well
images.caption: Montezuma Well provided a stable source of water to the Sinagua.

entranceFees.description: Free admission to the park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

Take Causeway to St. Simons Island. Take first left onto Sea Island Rd. Go 1.5 miles to third traffic light, and Left onto Frederica Road. Follow Frederica Road for two miles (take second right off roundabout). The park entrance 300 yards past Christ Church.

entrancePasses.title: Free Admission to Park, no passes needed.

properties.weatherInfo: The site enjoys mild climate from fall through early summer, followed by hot, humid summers.
properties.name: Fort Frederica
properties.description: Georgia's fate was decided in 1742 when Spanish and British forces clashed on St. Simons Island. Fort Frederica's troops defeated the Spanish, ensuring Georgia's future as a British colony. Today, the archeological remnants of Frederica are protected by the National Park Service.

images.altText: Ruin of Soldier Barracks at Fort Frederica NM
images.title: Ruin of Soldier Barracks at Fort Frederica NM
images.caption: The Barracks ruin is one of the few above ground structures at Fort Frederica

images.altText: A large grapevine draped among the Live Oaks

images.caption: 100 year old grapevine at Frederica which still produces "Summer Grapes"

images.altText: The shadow of the ruin of Fort Frederica highlighted by a sunset along the Frederica River.

properties.weatherInfo: George Washington Carver National Monument is located in southwestern Missouri just outside of Diamond and about 10 miles from Joplin.  Summer temperatures generally range from 75-100 degrees with high humidity.  Winter temperatures generally range from 0-50 degrees with periods of intermittent freezing.
properties.name: George Washington Carver
properties.description: The young child known as the "Plant Doctor" tended his secret garden while observing the day-to-day operations of a 19th century farm. Nature and nurture ultimately influenced George on his quest for education to becoming a renowned agricultural scientist, educator, and humanitarian.

images.altText: The Carver Trail is approximately 3/4 miles in length.
images.title: Carver Trail
images.caption: Boy Carver Statue, sculpted by Robert Amendola in 1960.

images.altText: An entrance sign to George Washington Carver National Monument with wildflower and plants.
images.title: George Washington Carver NM Entrance
images.caption: Entrance sign to George Washington Carver NM will wildflower and plants.

images.altText: Sunflowers in a prairie at George Washington Carver NM.
images.title: George Washington Carver NM Prairie
images.caption: Prairie at George Washington Carver NM with sunflowers.

images.altText: Park's science classroom with lab tables and wall exhibits on George Washington Carver.
images.title: George Washington Carver NM Science Classroom
images.caption: George Washington Carver NM science classroom modeled after one of the George Washington Carver's lab at Tuskegee Institute.

images.altText: A cast concrete bust of George Washington Carver and prairie in the background.
images.title: George Washington Carver Bust
images.caption: A cast concrete bust for George Washington Carver by Audrey Corwin, 1952.

properties.weatherInfo: The weather in the park is typically hot and sunny with daytime temperatures in the upper 80's. An excellent time to experience the park is in the morning and in the late afternoon when the temperatures are a bit cooler. The park is open daily from 8 a.m. until 5 p.m. However the park does occasionally close because of high winds or dangerous storm conditions. Please check with the visitor center or your hotel for any weather advisories or hazardous conditions on the day of your visit.
properties.name: Pu`ukoholā Heiau
properties.description: How many places in America can you walk in the footsteps of a king? Where else has a stranded sailor risen up to become a great chief over an entire island? Where else can you experience the culminating event of a people, foretold from centuries past? Where else can you stand on a beach and watch as sharks pass over a submerged temple? Experience all this and much more – only at Pu'ukoholā Heiau!

images.altText: Sun set at Pu'ukohol$#257; Heiau NHS
images.title: Pu'ukohol$#257; Heiau National Historic Site Banner
images.caption: Pelekane Bay sits below the majestic Pu'ukohol$#257; Heiau and Mailekini Heiau

entranceFees.description:
Cabrillo National Monument welcomes your commercial tour group. A "commercial tour" is defined as an organized tour that is booked and paid through a third party. Your group is welcome to come whenever it's convenient for you (no reservations are necessary), and we have plenty of bus parking available.

"Passenger Capacity" is based on the number of seats on the vehicle, rather than number of actual passengers.

The commercial pass is only valid for one visit.

properties.weatherInfo:
Near Perfection
Almost three million county residents can't be wrong: it's the weather. While many areas of the country are hibernating under blankets of snow or sweltering in muggy mid-summer humidity, San Diego's climate is generally sunny and mild year-round.
properties.name: Cabrillo
properties.description: Climbing out of his boat and onto shore in 1542, Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo stepped into history as the first European to set foot on what is now the West Coast of the United States. In addition to telling the story of 16th century exploration, the park is home to a wealth of cultural and natural resources. Join us and embark on your own Voyage of Exploration.

properties.directionsInfo:
Natchez National Historical Park Headquarters and the Natchez Visitor Center is located at the intersection of U.S. Highway 84 and Canal Street in Natchez, MS.  

Melrose Estate is located at 1 Melrose-Montebello Parkway, Natchez, MS 39120.

The William Johnson House is located at 212 State Street, Natchez, MS 39120.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 50 F to 83 F. Rain is common.

Summer:  Temperatures usually range from 70 F to 95 F. Rain and sun are equally common.  On very sunny days, be prepared with plenty of water - heat exhaustion is common if you are not prepared.

Fall:  Temperatures usually range from 55 F to 79 F. 

Winter:  Temperatures range from 40 F to 63 F.  Rain is common.
properties.name: Natchez
properties.description: Discover the history of all the peoples of Natchez, Mississippi, from European settlement, African enslavement, the American cotton economy, to the Civil Rights struggle on the lower Mississippi River.

images.altText: Two story brick mansion with four white columns
images.title: Melrose Mansion
images.caption: Melrose and its landscape present a comprehensive picture of the Southern planter class and the enslaved people who lived and worked there.

images.altText: Two story brick townhouse
images.title: William Johnson House
images.caption: The William Johnson House provides a window into the life of a free man of color whose published diary and personal papers provide a detailed account of daily life in the antebellum south.

images.altText: One story wood frame house with two doors and two windows
images.title: Melrose Slave Cabin
images.caption: One of two remaining slave cabins at the Melrose estate

images.altText: Room containing very simple wood table and chair, and baby cradle with fireplace in background
images.title: Inside Melrose Slave Cabin
images.caption: The furnished slave cabin at Melrose helps to illustrate  the daily life of the enslaved.

images.altText: room with tall windows and fireplace, round table containing lamp and surrounded by chairs
images.title: Inside the William Johnson House
images.caption: Visitors to the William Johnson House can see many original furnishings.

entranceFees.description: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center  in Omaha, NE does not charge an entrance fee, but some of our park partners do. Be sure to check with each visitor and interpretative center to find out their fees.

properties.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside the National Park Service Mid-West Regional Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.
properties.weatherInfo:
In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks.
 
In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days.

Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
properties.name: Lewis & Clark
properties.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail is approximately 4,900 miles long, extending from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to the mouth of the Columbia River, near present day Astoria, Oregon.  It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition as well as the preparatory section from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to Wood River, Illinois.

images.altText: MWRO office building with arrowhead logo.

images.caption: Mid-West Regional Office Building and Visitor Center for Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail.

From Durango, CO: Follow Hwy 550 south into Aztec, where it will become 516. Turn right onto Ruins Road. Follow Ruins Road 1/2 mile to the monument.

From Farmington, NM 
Follow Highway 516 east into Aztec. 1/4 mile past Lightplant Road, turn left onto Ruins Road. Follow Ruins Road 1/2 mile to the monument.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summer
High temperatures range between 80°F and 99°F degrees with a few days over 100°F. Afternoon thunderstorms usually cool things down in late July and August.

Fall
Usually pleasant, with mild days and crisp nights.

Winter
Daytime temperatures range between 20°F and 50°F with cold nights that can reach 0°F. Snow is periodic, but accumulations are typically only 1-2 inches.

Spring
Weather is especially unpredictable: it can be windy, cold, and wet, or still, warm, and dry.
properties.name: Aztec Ruins
properties.description: Pueblo people describe this site as part of their migration journey. Today you can follow their ancient passageways to a distant time. Explore a 900-year old ancestral Pueblo Great House of over 400 masonry rooms. Look up and see original timbers holding up the roof. Search for the fingerprints of ancient workers in the mortar. Listen for an echo of ritual drums in the reconstructed Great Kiva.

properties.name: Navajo
properties.description: Navajo National Monument was established in 1909 to preserve and interpret the archaeological and cultural heritage of the Ancestral Pueblo people who built Tsegi Phase villages within the natural sandstone alcoves of the canyons. Betatakin, Keet Seel, and Inscription House were occupied from approximately 1250 AD to 1300 AD and are among the best preserved cliff dwellings in the state of Arizona.

images.altText: view from inside the Betatakin Cliff Dwelling looking out.
images.title: Betatakin Cliff dwelling and Alcove
images.caption: Betatakin Cliff Dwelling was home to the Ancestral Puebloans over 700 years ago.

entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
To reach Oakland Plantation, take I-49 to Exit 127, Flora/Cypress. Head east on LA Highway 120 toward Cypress. Cross over LA Highway 1 onto LA Highway 494. The parking lot and entrance pavilion for Oakland is 4.5 miles east of Highway 1 on the left.

To reach the grounds of Magnolia Plantation, take I-49 to Exit 119, Derry. Head east on LA Highway 119. Cross over LA Highway 1 and proceed for 1.1 miles. The parking area of Magnolia Plantation is on the right just before the road closure.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather in central Louisiana can be unpredictable. Summers are hot and humid. Winter is relatively mild with measurable snowfall every 5-10 years. Average rainfall is approximately 55-60 inches per year. The area is also subject to severe thunderstorms, hail, damaging winds, and tornadoes. Visitors might want to bring hats, umbrellas, and drink plenty of water. Please check the local weather forecast before planning your visit to the park.
properties.name: Cane River Creole
properties.description: The Cane River region is home to a unique culture; the Creoles. Generations of the same families of owners and workers, enslaved and tenant, lived on these lands for over 200 years. The park tells their stories and preserves the cultural landscape of Oakland and Magnolia Plantations, two of the most intact Creole cotton plantations in the United States.

images.altText: Magnolia quarters
images.title: Fall perennials in front of Magnolia Quarters
images.caption: Magnolia plantation quarters were once occupied by the enslaved; they were used in the 20th century by sharecroppers.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees to Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: From I-75, take U.S. Route 35 West (Exit 52b).  Keep right and follow signs for State Route 4/Germantown. Turn slightly right onto S. Williams St. Continue to Fourth Street & turn right and proceed into parking lot on your left. Visitor Center will be directly next to parking lot.

entrancePasses.description: The park no longer sells the America the Beautiful National Parks & Federal Recreation Lands Pass (as of 01/01/15). However, you can go online to purchase select passes and to order select passes.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 39 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 74 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just above 41". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of about 25".
properties.name: Dayton Aviation Heritage
properties.description: Three exceptional men from Dayton, Ohio, Wilbur Wright, Orville Wright and Paul Laurence Dunbar, found their creative outlet here through accomplishments and failures, and finally success. However, these men offered the world something far greater, they offered the world hope, and the ability to take a dream and make it a reality.

images.altText: The Wright-Dunbar Interpretive Center as viewed from Williams St.
images.title: Wright-Dunbar Interprevitive Center
images.caption: The Wright-Dunbar Interpretive Center as viewed from Williams St.

images.altText: The Wright Glider on display in the visitor center lobby

images.altText: People mingling on the Huffman Prairie

images.caption: Visitors walk and enjoy exhibits during the 2015 Aero Carnival event

images.altText: Visitors and guests walking on sidewalk in front of park

images.altText: Entrance and windows to the Wright Cycle Company building

images.caption: A view of the entrance to the Wright Cycle Company on Williams St.

images.altText: A Wright Flyer glides through the air in front of a tree line
images.title: 1905 Wright Flyer replica
images.caption: The 1905 Wright Flyer replica during a demonstration flight.

properties.fullName: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: An entrance fee of $10.00 per person is charged for visitors age 16 and over. The receipt is valid for seven days and may be used for re-entry to the park. Children 15 and under are always free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo:
From West Lebanon, NH, (at Exit 20 of Interstate Rt 89) take Route 12A south for about 12 miles, Saint-Gaudens Road will be on the left. Proceed up Saint-Gaudens Road .5 miles. The parking lot will be on your right.

From Windsor, Vermont, For passenger vehicles, take bridge Street cross the Connecticut River via the covered bridge. Caution: the bridge is closed to RVs, trucks and busses. At the end of the covered Bridge in New Hampshire, turn left. Saint Gaudens Road will be on you right in one mile.

entrancePasses.description: An annual park pass, specifically for Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site, is available for $40. As a "walk in" park, all of these passes allow the pass holder and three other adults entry to the park (must be present at the time with passholder).
entrancePasses.title: Saint-Gaudens NHS Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
The upper Connecticut River valley is located in a temperate climate. While some summer days may be hot and humid, the average summer temperature ranges in the 70s and lower 80s. Temperatures in the fall are normally in the upper 60s, with evenings dropping into the upper 40s and lower 50s.

Winters can be cold with daily temperatures usually in the 20s and occasionally dropping to below zero. Snow may be heavy from mid December through March.
properties.name: Saint-Gaudens
properties.description: Augustus Saint-Gaudens, one of America's greatest sculptors lived here seasonally starting in 1885, and year-round 1900 until his death in 1907. Experience the park grounds, where several of Saint-Gaudens bronze sculptures are on view throughout the year, & trails wind through the woods. Learn more about the park.

images.altText: Looking toward Aspet from the Pan Garden
images.title: Aspet, home of Augustus Saint-Gaudens
images.caption: Built in 1817, Saint-Gaudens came here in 1885. He named it Aspet after the birthplace of his father in France.

images.altText: Interior of the Little Studio, Sculpture of Diana in foreground
images.title: Interior of the Little Studio
images.caption: The Little Studio where Augustus Saint-Gaudens worked, exhibits some his well known works.

images.altText: Visitors looking at the Shaw Memorial
images.title: The Shaw Memorial
images.caption: Visitors looking at the bronze cast of the Shaw Memorial, Saint-Gaudens' masterpiece.

images.altText: View of the Formal Gardens
images.title: Formal Gardens
images.caption: The Formal Gardens remain much like they were in the artist's time.

images.altText: Obverse of the twenty dollar gold coin, 1907
images.title: Twenty dollar gold coin, 1907
images.caption: The 20 dollar gold piece Saint-Gaudens designed, is considered the most beautiful American coin ever minted

entranceFees.description: Free Admission
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Moores Creek National Battlefield is located 20 miles NW of Wilmington, North Carolina.
·  From Highway 17, follow US 421 to NC 210, then West on NC 210
·  From Interstate 40, take exit 408 (NC 210) West at Rocky Point.
·  From Interstate 95 North, take exit 13-A for NC 74 East towards Wilmington. 
·  From Interstate 95 South: take exit 81-B for I-40 East towards Wilmington. 
·  From Fayetteville, North Carolina, take Interstate 95 South to Exit 13-A

Questions please call us as 910-283-5591 x2234
properties.weatherInfo: Currie, North Carolina has mild Winters and moderate to hot Summers with varying humidity.
properties.name: Moores Creek
properties.description: In the early morning hours of February 27, 1776 Loyalist forces charged across a partially dismantled Moores Creek Bridge. Beyond the bridge, nearly 1,000 North Carolina Patriots waited quietly with cannons and muskets poised to fire. This battle marked the last broadsword charge by Scottish Highlanders and the first significant victory for the Patriots in the American Revolution.

images.altText: Artillery Demonstration at Moore's Creek
images.title: Artillery Demonstration at Moore's Creek
images.caption: Artillery Demonstration at Moore's Creek.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee for visiting any portion of Fort Matanzas.
entranceFees.title: Fort Matanzas Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Fort Matanzas is 14 miles south of Saint Augustine on State Route A1A.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are hot and humid with afternoon thundershowers. Sunscreen, a hat, UV protective sunglasses, and are recommended. Drink plenty of water.
 
Winters are cool to mild with some cold spells, especially with wind from the north or off the water. Fall and spring are temperate with temperatures around 70F-80F (21C-26C).
 
During danger of lightning, the fort will be closed and ferry service will be suspended.

June-November is hurricane season so check for tropical storms before visiting.
properties.name: Fort Matanzas
properties.description: The ferry boat to Fort Matanzas is again operating after the completion of repairs to the park's dock.  Effective 2/27/20 ferry service will resume normal operating hours.  Boat trips depart every hour at half past; first trip departs at 9:30 am, final trip of the day departs at 4:30 pm.  All trips depart weather permitting.

images.altText: A nature trail boardwalk with seating area.
images.title: Nature Trail
images.caption: Follow an elevated boardwalk through some pristine Florida barrier island habitat.

images.altText: Fort Matanzas, a fortified watch tower made form coquina.
images.title: Fort Matanzas
images.caption: Fort Matanzas sits on Rattlesnake Island in the middle of the Matanzas River.

images.altText: Wooden bunks and uniform items in the soldier's quarters.
images.title: Soldier's Quarters
images.caption: The few enlisted soldiers at Fort Matanzas shared a small, sparse room as living space.

images.altText: The cannon of Fort Matanzas point toward the river's inlet.
images.title: Protecting the riverway
images.caption: Fort Matanzas protected the southern river approach to Saint Augustine.

images.altText: People wading in the river and relaxing on the beach.
images.title: Recreational Opportunities
images.caption: More the half-a-million people visit Fort Matanzas each year to enjoy both the river and ocean beaches.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to explore Martin Van Buren National Historic Site or take a tour of the president's home.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
The park entrance road is located off of route 9H  two miles south of Kinderhook Village.  

GPS Coordinates:  42° 22' 52'' N   -73° 42' 13'' W
properties.weatherInfo: The weather at Martin Van Buren National Historic Site is typical of the northeast United States; it varies considerably throughout the year. Always check the forecast prior to your visit and dress accordingly. Be sure to wear comfortable walking shoes.
properties.name: Martin Van Buren
properties.description: Today, Martin Van Buren is an obscure man, often little more than a footnote. In pre-Civil War America, however, it was impossible not to have an opinion of him. Van Buren was central to the issues of his day: the creation of political parties, and the largest crisis of his time, slavery. The above quote is from Davy Crockett, one of many Americans trying to understand the Red Fox of Kinderhook.

images.altText: Sunset over the farm fields of Lindewald
images.title: Sunset over the farm fields of Lindewald
images.caption: A stunning sunset over the the fields of Lindenwald with the Catskill Mountains rising in the distance.

images.altText: President Van Buren's Home
images.title: President Van Buren's Home
images.caption: Van Buren called his home and farm Lindenwald.  He lived here after his term as president from 1841 to 1862.  He ran two presidential campaign from Lindenwald in 1844 and 1848.He ran presidential vam

images.credit: National Park Service by Michael Fredericks
images.altText: Paycheck from Martin Van Buren to Irish Servant Catherine Kelly
images.title: Paycheck from Martin Van Buren to Irish Servant Catherine Kelly
images.caption: Many of the domestic workers at Lindenwald were Irsh.  They are emblamatic of the great waves of immigrants which beagn arriving in the United states during the ante bellum period.

images.credit: national Park Service by Michael Fredericks
images.altText: Martin Van Buren by Hiram Powers
images.title: Martin Van Buren by Hiram Powers
images.caption: This bust of van Buren which is in the library of Lindenwald was sculpted by Hiram Powers.  Another version of the bust may be found in the Red Room of the White House.

images.altText: Lindenwald's Main Hall
images.title: Lindenwald's Main Hall
images.caption: The main hall and dining table at Lindenwald were used by President Van Buren to not only entertain, but to use his skills to bend political issues his way through the ante bellum period.

properties.fullName: Martin Van Buren National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: There are no fees for visiting Rainbow Bridge National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Rainbow Bridge Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Rainbow Bridge National Monument is located between Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and the Navajo Nation. There are no roads in the vicinity of the monument. Rainbow Bridge can be reached by boat on Lake Powell or by hiking one of two trails around Navajo Mountain on the Navajo Nation, by permit only. Boat tours are available.

The entrance to Forbidding Canyon is located at buoy 49 on Lake Powell. Boaters should be familiar with the Aids to Navigation (buoy) system and use a navigational map.

entrancePasses.description: As there are no fees for Rainbow Bridge, there is no pass.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Summers are extremely hot with little, if any, shade. Winters are moderately cold with night time lows often below freezing. Spring weather is highly variable with extended periods of strong winds. Fall is generally mild. Temperatures range from 110°F (43°C) in June & July to 20°F (-7°C) in December & January. Although precipitation is generally less than 6 inches (15cm) annually, both heavy rains and flash flooding can occur, particularly during the summer monsoon season.
properties.name: Rainbow Bridge
properties.description:
Rainbow Bridge is one of the world's largest known natural bridges. The span has undoubtedly inspired people throughout time--from the neighboring American Indian tribes who consider Rainbow Bridge sacred, to the 85,000 people from around the world who visit it each year.

Please visit Rainbow Bridge in a spirit that honors and respects the cultures to whom it is sacred.

images.altText: A large sandstone arch - a natural bridge.
images.title: Rainbow Bridge
images.caption: Stand here and take in the majesty of Rainbow Bridge - the largest natural bridge in the National Park Service.

images.altText: A view of Rainbow Bridge from the air.
images.title: Aerial View of Rainbow Bridge
images.caption: Seen from the air, Rainbow Bridge is a graceful curve over the dry stream bed.

images.altText: A large crowd faces away from the camera at the scenery.
images.title: A Crowd Views Rainbow Bridge From Its Shadow
images.caption: In the desert heat after the rough walk up to Rainbow Bridge from the docks, you take shade where you can get it.

images.altText: Boats and personal watercraft sidle up to docks.
images.title: Rainbow Bridge Docks
images.caption: The only way to access Rainbow Bridge is by a two-day hike across the Navajo Nation, or a fifty-mile boat trip up Lake Powell.

images.altText: An elderly Native American man sits in a lawn chair under Rainbow Bridge
images.title: Jim Mike Returns to Rainbow Bridge
images.caption: In 1974, Ute Mountain Ute Jim Mike, one of the  guides who led the original expedition to Rainbow Bridge, returned to see how he had led the way for many more visitors.

addresses.line1: c/o Glen Canyon National Recreation Area

entranceFees.description:
Pipestone National Monument has temporarily suspended entrance fees until the program can be further evaluated.

Visitors can access the Circle Trail, which leads to several points of interest around the park, and the Visitor Center, which includes a 22-minute film, museum, exhibits, and seasonal carving demonstrations.
entranceFees.title: Pipestone National Monument Entrance Fee Temporarily Suspended

properties.directionsInfo:
Plane: Commercial service - located at Sioux Falls, SD -Joe Foss Field airport. 50 miles from Pipestone National Monument. Rental cars are available at the airport.

Non-Commercial service - located at Pipestone MN airport. Courtesy car or transit service available to Pipestone National Monument from the airport.

Car: Pipestone National Monument is easily accessible from local highways. When you reach the city of Pipestone, road signs will lead you to Pipestone National Monument.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather varies seasonally from warm and humid in the summer to cold and snowy in the winter. Visitors should be prepared for seasonal weather and for rapidly-changing conditions.
properties.name: Pipestone
properties.description: For countless generations, American Indians have quarried the red pipestone found at this site. These grounds are sacred to many people because the pipestone quarried here is carved into pipes used for prayer. Many believe that the pipe's smoke carries one's prayer to the Great Spirit. The traditions of quarrying and pipemaking continue here today.

images.altText: Beautiful view of Lake Hiawatha from Monument's Circle Trail.
images.title: Interp_CircleTrail-LakeHiawatha_8-2009
images.caption: Lake Hiawatha, one of many scenic sites visitors can see from the Monument Circle Trail.

images.caption: Winnewissa Falls, one of many scenic sites visitors can see from the Monument Circle Trail.

images.altText: Called Nicollet Marker, the initials on this rock were carved by Joseph Nicollet and his expedition

properties.directionsInfo: We are approximately 2.5 hours south of Midland/Odessa starting on I-20 to HWY 17, 3.5 hours North West of Del Rio starting on HWY 90 to HWY 118, 4 hours east of El Paso starting on I-10 to HWY 118 and 7 hours west of San Antonio starting on I-10 to HWY 17.

entrancePasses.description: You can buy an annual pass to Fort Davis National Historic Site for $30.00. This pass will admit the pass owners and three other adults to the Fort for 12 months from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Davis Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Summer Temperatures average a High of 95 and low of 65. Winter Temperatures average a High of 60 and a low of 20.  Wind is very common and heavy rainfall is very sporadic.
properties.name: Fort Davis
properties.description: Fort Davis is one of the best surviving examples of an Indian Wars' frontier military post in the Southwest. From 1854 to 1891, Fort Davis was strategically located to protect emigrants, mail coaches, and freight wagons on the Trans-Pecos portion of the San Antonio-El Paso Road and on the Chihuahua Trail.

images.altText: Two ladies working in the kitchen
images.title: Kitchen
images.caption: Special events bring back the smells of an 1800s Kitchen

images.altText: Garrison Flag flying over the post.
images.title: Parade Ground
images.caption: Garrison flag flying over the post within the box canyon Fort Davis is located.

images.altText: Artillery Crew stands at the ready
images.title: Artillery Crew
images.caption: The Artillery Crew stand ready for orders to post at their positions and fire the U.S. 3-inch Ordnance Rifle.

images.altText: Soldier mounted on his horse
images.title: Cavalry
images.caption: The U.S. Cavalry was utilized at Fort Davis for most of its existence. Here a soldier shows off the uniform and equipment of the 1800s.

images.altText: Building and trees at Fort Davis during the fall with yellow leaves.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: This sky island habitat is known for its dramatic season changes. Fall brings the end of our rainy season allowing the bright yellow Cottonwoods to shine. In spring /summer waving grasses and wildflowers show off their vivid colors once again.

Senior and Access pass holders must present their pass at the ticket counter (including for reservations).

properties.name: Oregon Caves
properties.description:
DUE TO CURRENT COVID-19 HEALTH GUIDANCE, CAVE TOUR AND VISITOR CENTER OPERATIONS ARE CLOSED.

Deep within the Siskiyou Mountains are dark, twisting passages that await your discovery.  Eons of acidic water seeping into marble rock created and decorated the wondrous “Marble Halls of Oregon.” Join a tour, get a taste of what caving is all about, and explore a mountain from the inside and out!

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee at the Visitor Center, park grounds, or the Russian Bishop's House.
entranceFees.title: All Park Activities are FREE

properties.directionsInfo: Sitka National Historical Park is located in downtown Sitka, Alaska. Sitka is situated on Baranof Island, on the outer coast of Alaska's Inside Passage. No roads connect the city to the mainland; Sitka can be reached only by air or sea. Visitors can travel to Sitka by scheduled and charter air services, ferry, and cruise ships.
properties.weatherInfo: Sitka experiences a temperate maritime climate, characterized by heavy precipitation and a small temperature range between seasons. Summer temperatures range from high 50s to high 60s F with frequent rain. Winter is rainy and snowy with temperatures from the high teens to the 40s F. Well prepared visitors will have rain gear and layered clothing at any time of year.
properties.name: Sitka
properties.description: On an island amid towering spruce and hemlock, Sitka National Historical Park preserves the site of a battle between invading Russian traders and indigenous Kiks.ádi Tlingit. Park visitors are awed by Tlingit and Haida totem poles standing along the park’s scenic coastal trail, and the restored Russian Bishop’s House speaks of Russia’s little known colonial legacy in North America.

images.altText: Reception room in the Russian Bishop's House
images.title: Russian Bishop's House Reception Room
images.caption: Tour the Russian Bishop's House to see Russian American architecture and lifestyle restored.

images.altText: Russian Bishop's house from the front.
images.title: Russian Bishop's House
images.caption: One of the last remaining examples of Russian American architecture.

images.altText: Salmon run in the Indian River
images.title: Salmon Run
images.caption: Salmon run in the Indian River from mid-July until late September.

images.altText: Mosquito Legend Pole
images.title: Mosquito Legend Pole
images.caption: See the Park's 18 Totem Poles with a walk along the Totem Trail.

images.altText: Visitor Center from the beach.
images.title: Sitka National Historical Park Visitor Center
images.caption: The Visitor Center contains exhibits, a 15 minute park video, and Tlingit and Haida art.

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-5, take the Mill Plain Boulevard exit (Exit 1-C) and head east. Turn south onto Fort Vancouver Way. At the traffic circle, go east on Evergreen Boulevard and follow signs to the Fort Vancouver Visitor Center.

From I-205, go west on Highway 14 about six miles, then take I-5 north. From I-5, take the Mill Plain Boulevard exit (Exit 1-C) and head east. At the traffic circle, go east on Evergreen Boulevard and follow signs to the Fort Vancouver Visitor Center.

entrancePasses.description: Allows free entry for passholder and up to three adults to Fort Vancouver National Historic Site. The pass is valid for one year from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Vancouver Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site is located in a mild, temperate climate. However, in the case of severe weather, park alerts posted on the park's website will provide information about emergency closures.
properties.name: Fort Vancouver
properties.description: Located on the north bank of the Columbia River, in sight of snowy mountain peaks and a vibrant urban landscape, this park has a rich cultural past. From a frontier fur trading post, to a powerful military legacy, the magic of flight, and the origin of the American Pacific Northwest, history is shared at four unique sites. Discover stories of transition, settlement, conflict, and community.

images.altText: Fort Vancouver Garden
images.title: Fort Vancouver Garden
images.caption: The garden at the reconstructed Fort Vancouver showcases the many plants that were grown at the historic Fort Vancouver.

images.altText: Black Powder Demonstrations at Fort Vancouver NHS
images.title: Black Powder Demonstrations at Fort Vancouver NHS
images.caption: The military history at Vancouver Barracks is told through living history demonstrations, including historic weapons demonstrations.

images.altText: Fort Vancouver
images.title: Fort Vancouver
images.caption: A walk through the reconstructed Fort Vancouver is a highlight of any trip to Fort Vancouver National Historic Site.

images.altText: McLoughlin House
images.title: McLoughlin House
images.caption: The McLoughlin House in Oregon City is a unit of Fort Vancouver National Historic Site. Here, visitors learn about Dr. John McLoughlin and the early history of Oregon state.

images.altText: Pearson Air Museum
images.title: Pearson Air Museum
images.caption: At Pearson Air Museum, visitors learn about the history of Pearson Field and early aviation in the Pacific Northwest.

entranceFees.description: Admission is free at Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Per Person Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The park is located just off U.S. Route 22 approximately 12 miles west of Altoona and 10 miles east of Ebensburg. Take the Gallitzin Exit and turn right, following the signs. Visitors prior to 1992 accessed the park in other ways, but the GALLITZIN EXIT of US Route 22 is now the way to access the visitor center and historic area.

entrancePasses.description: Free. Yearly pass for Active US Military members, including the National Guard and Reserves; renewable each year during your active duty service, including the National Guard and Reservies. This admits the service member and his/her dependents in the party.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful-U.S. Military Pass

entrancePasses.description: For US Citizens or Permanent Residents of any age who have a permanent disability (must show proper documentation); good for life. This admits the guest and three additional adult guests in the party.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: Fourth graders may go to this website, https://www.everykidinapark.gov/ and complete a short, fun activity. Students can then bring in their printed certificate and exchange it for a pass good for one year. Students must be in the fourth grade and adults may not use the pass without their 4th grader present.
entrancePasses.title: Every Kid in a Park-4th Grade Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The park is located in Cambria County, PA, and is at the summit of the Allegheny Mountains. Therefore, the park often takes on winter extremes. If planning on traveling from a long distance, please contact the park beforehand to ensure that the facilities are open. Please consult weather forecasts to ensure conditions are safe to travel in. Spring, summer, and fall are generally uneventful, but severe thunderstorms can occur.
properties.name: Allegheny Portage Railroad
properties.description: The first railroad to circumvent the Allegheny Mountains, the Allegheny Portage Railroad was the finishing piece of the Pennsylvania Mainline Canal.  "The Portage," opened in 1834, marking the first time that there was one, direct route between Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.  All things to all people, it served merchants, passengers, slaves in pursuit of freedom, and soldiers from the Mexican War.

images.altText: Lemon House
images.title: Lemon House
images.caption: Lemon House, one of the historic structures in the park.

properties.fullName: Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: Big Hole is fee free! We do sell the Lifetime Senior Pass, the Annual Senior Pass, and the America the Beautiful Annual Pass, and issue the Access Pass to those that qualify.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Big Hole National Battlefield is located on Highway 43 ten miles west of the town of Wisdom in southwestern Montana.

Bear Paw Battlefield is located on Route 240 sixteen miles south of the town of Chinook in north-central Montana.

entrancePasses.description: There are no entrance fees to Big Hole National Battlefield or Bear Paw Battlefield. However, the we sell the Annual Senior Pass, the Lifetime Senior Pass, and the America the Beautiful Annual Pass, and issue the Access Pass to those that qualify at the Big Hole National Battlefield's visitor center.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Passes

properties.weatherInfo: This climatic region is typified by large seasonal temperature differences, with warm to hot (and often humid) summers and cold (sometimes severely cold) winters. Wisdom has a humid continental climate.
properties.name: Big Hole
properties.description: On August 9, 1877 gun shots shattered a chilly dawn on a sleeping camp of Nez Perce. By the time the smoke cleared on August 10, almost 90 Nez Perce were dead along with 31 soldiers and volunteers. Big Hole National Battlefield was created to honor all who were there.

images.altText: Multiple tepee poles and a river are silhouetted against a dawn sky.
images.title: Battlefield at Dawn
images.caption: Today tepee poles stand sentinel at the site of August 9th, 1877 dawn attack at the Big Hole.

images.altText: Blue camas flowers dot a green field with tepee poles in the background.
images.title: Camas Blooms Near the Nez Perce Camp at the Big Hole
images.caption: The Nez Perce chose their camp site in the Big Hole in part due to the Camas, whose roots they gathered prior to the August 9th attack.

images.altText: a cannon overlooks a valley and distant mountains
images.title: Mountain Howitzer at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: Nez Perce warriors captured and dismantled the Mountain Howitzer cannon before the US army could use it effectively at the Battle of the Big Hole.

images.altText: cross country skis rest against a large granite monument on a snowy day.
images.title: Monument to the US Soldiers and Volunteers at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: In 1883 the United States Government erected this monument in honor of the soldiers and volunteers that served and died at the 1877 Battle of the Big Hole.

images.altText: Stone carving of a Nez Perce Warrior's head in full regalia.
images.title: Chief Joseph Memorial at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: This monument, erected on the Big Hole Battlefield in 1928, reads; "To the everlasting memory of the brave warriors Chief Joseph's Band who fought on these grounds in the Nez Perce War of 1877."

images.altText: Three large stone monuments and four interpretive signs overlook a series of low hills.
images.title: Bear Paw Battlefield

entranceFees.description: Fort Donelson does not charge for entrance or interpretive fees.
entranceFees.title: No fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Fort Donelson's main entrance is located along Highway 79, in Dover Tennessee. It is advised to start a visitor experience here.

(From December 7, 2015 until announced, Fort Donelson's temporary visitor center will be at the Stewart County Visitor Center, 117 Visitor Center Lane, Dover, TN, 37058).

Physical address for the park's Fort Heiman unit, in Calloway County, Kentucky (unstaffed and in development): 682 Fort Heiman Road, New Concord, Kentucky.

entrancePasses.description:
Passes are not needed at Fort Donelson National Battlefield, as we have no fees.

Passes are not issued at Fort Donelson...but may be purchased at Land Between the Lakes, a few minutes away.

http://www.landbetweenthelakes.us/
entrancePasses.title: No entrance fees at Fort Donelson

properties.weatherInfo: Fort Donelson National Battlefield traditionally experiences mild to moderate winters and hot summers with an average high of 90 degrees in the summer and 40 in winter; average lows in the winter are 30 degrees but single digits are not unusual. Rainfall in the area averages 53 inches a year with an additional 6 inches of ice/snow and violent thunderstorms can take place at any time of year.
properties.name: Fort Donelson
properties.description: Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant was becoming quite famous as he wrote these words following the surrender of Confederate Fort Donelson on Sunday, February 16, 1862. The Union victory at Fort Donelson elated the North, and stunned the South. Within days of the surrender, Clarksville and Nashville would fall into Union hands. Grant and his troops had created a pathway to victory for the Union.

images.altText: Sunset on the Cumberland River
images.title: The Dover Hotel
images.caption: The Dover Hotel, the headquarters of General Simon B. Buckner (CSA), and location of the Confederate surrender.

images.altText: The View from the Upper River Battery
images.title: Upper River Battery
images.caption: During the battle, the Confederate forces had a commanding view of the Cumberland River.

images.altText: Cannon drills during the 154th anniversary of the Battle of Fort Donelson
images.title: Cannon Drills
images.caption: Members of the 9th Kentucky re-enactment group demonstrate cannon drills for the public.

images.altText: Confederate earthworks.
images.title: Confederate Trenches
images.caption: A view of the Confederate trenches, where Confederate Soldiers once stood watch.

images.altText: Hallowed ground.
images.title: Fort Donelson National Cemetery
images.caption: The Fort Donelson National Cemetery, final resting place for Soldiers who fell in battle during the Civil War, the Spanish-American War, World War I, and World War II.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee at Friendship Hill National Historic Site.   Activities that require a permit may have a fee.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Friendship Hill NHS is located on PA 166 three miles north of Point Marion, Pennsylvania.
properties.weatherInfo:
Weather varies considerably within each season.  Be prepared with layered clothing. Precipitation is common throughout the year.
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 25°F to 70°F.  On average, May is the wettest month.
Summer: Temperatures usually range from 50°F to 80°F. July is the warmest month.
Fall: Temperatures usually range from 30°F to 70°F. Fall foliage is at its peak around mid-October. 
Winter: Temperatures range from 15°F to 40°F.  January is the coldest month.
properties.name: Friendship Hill
properties.description: Albert Gallatin is best remembered for his thirteen year tenure as Secretary of the Treasury during the Jefferson and Madison administrations. In that time he reduced the national debt, purchased the Louisiana Territory and funded the Lewis & Clark exploration. Gallatin's accomplishments and contributions are highlighted at Friendship Hill, his restored country estate.

images.altText: Gallatin house
images.title: Gallatin House - Stone House and well
images.caption: Friendship Hill was the country home of Albert Gallatin

entranceFees.description: The park has no entrance fee
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: George Washington Birthplace is located off two miles from Virginia state route 3 on Virginia state route 204. The park is located 38 miles east of Fredericksburg and 10 miles from Colonial Beach.
properties.weatherInfo: George Washington Birthplace can be very warm and humid in the summer months and cold and dry in the winter. Spring and fall are the best seasons to visit.
properties.name: George Washington Birthplace
properties.description: In the heart of the Northern Neck of Virginia stands a tribute to America’s founding father, George Washington. Although only here a short time, the ideas that Washington learned here, helped shape the man he would become and forever alter the destiny of the United States of America.

images.altText: Washington Family Cemetery
images.title: Cemetery
images.caption: Four generations of Washingtons are buried here.

images.altText: Sunrise on Popes Creek
images.title: Popes Creek
images.caption: This is the scene that our visitors see from our Visitor Center

images.altText: A commemorative house constructed for George Washington's bicentennial birthday
images.title: Memorial House
images.caption: The Memorial House is framed by beautiful crepe mrytles

images.altText: One of our park's special events
images.title: Special Events
images.caption: Our special events draw thousands to the park every year, like this Revolutionary War Encampment

images.altText: A Washington Monument
images.title: Monument
images.caption: This monument was placed in 1896, just 11 years after the Washington Monument in Washington, DC was placed and stands 55 feet tall, 1/10th the size of the original

The park sells Interagency Park Passes in the Battlefield Visitors Center.
entrancePasses.title: No Pass Required

properties.weatherInfo:
https://www.nps.gov/guco/planyourvisit/weather.htm

Summers are warm to hot and humid with the occasional thunderstorm.

Spring and Fall are cool with rainy periods.

Winter is mild and cold with snow and ice possible in January and February.

Wear comfortable clothing for the season and good walking shoes year round!
properties.name: Guilford Courthouse
properties.description:
"I never saw such fighting since God made me. The Americans fought like demons." - Lt. General Charles, Earl Cornwallis
On March 15, 1781, six years into the American Revolution, General Greene and Lord Cornwallis' troops faced off at a small courthouse community. This 2.5 hour battle would change the course of the Southern Campaign of the American Revolution.

images.altText: Hoskins' House and Kitchen Located on the Grounds of the Colonial Heritage Center
images.title: Hoskins' House and Kitchen
images.caption: Hoskins' House and Kitchen Located on the Grounds of the Colonial Heritage Center

images.altText: 18th Century Field Drum at Guilford Courthouse National Military Park
images.title: 18th Century Field Drum
images.caption: 18th Century Field Drum at Guilford Courthouse National Military Park

emailAddresses.description: Email for general park information.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees to any of the park's open sites.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Take U.S. 23.  Exit U.S. 23 at State Route 207 and turn right.  Continue on S.R. 207 for 2 miles until it merges with S.R. 104 (Make no turns, continue straight on road as it turns into S.R. 104).  Follow S.R. 104, turn left into park (approximately 1.8 miles past the S.R. 104 & S.R. 207 intersection), follow entrance road to visitor center.

entrancePasses.description: The park no longer sells the America the Beautiful National Parks & Federal Recreation Lands Pass. However, you can go online to purchase select passes and to order select passes at https://store.usgs.gov/pass/index.html
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful passes

properties.weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 30 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 75 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just under 38". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of less than 24".
properties.name: Hopewell Culture
properties.description: Earthen mounds and embankments forming huge geometric enclosures grace the landscape of the Ohio River Valley. These monumental structures were built by Native American hands almost 2,000 years ago. Hopewellian people gathered at these earthworks for feasts, funerals and rites of passage.  Come learn about these sacred spaces and reflect upon the lives of these American Indians.

images.altText: Three visitors to the park reading an interpretive sign
images.title: Visitors at Mound 7
images.caption: Visitors read a sign in front of Mound #7

images.altText: The early morning sun shining on the mounds
images.title: Dawn at Mound City Group
images.caption: Dawn at the Mound City Group

images.altText: Visitors read an interpretive sign in front of mound
images.title: Visitors at Seip
images.caption: Visitors gather at the front of the Seip Mound at Seip Earthworks

images.altText: A coyote in front of a mound
images.title: Coyote at Mound City Group
images.caption: A coyote stares down the photographer while roaming among the mounds

images.altText: An elevated view of the Mound City Group
images.title: Aerial View of Mound City Group
images.caption: An aerial view of the Mound City Group in fall

images.altText: A copper bird cutout
images.title: Copper Effigy Bird
images.caption: A 2,000 year old copper effigy bird cutout crafted by the Hopewell.

images.altText: A copper cutout of a breastplate
images.title: Copper Breastplate
images.caption: Copper breastplate cutout made by the Hopewell culture 2,000 years ago

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for persons or vehicles the entering park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: On PA Route 345, 5 miles South of Birdsboro, Pennsylvania.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are generally humid with daily temps. averaging 83 degrees (F) for a high and 60 degrees (F) for a low.  Daily temps. in January average 38 degrees (F) for a high and 20 degrees (F) for a low.

Precipitation averages 3-5 inches of rain per month during spring, summer and autumn.  During winter conditions can be icy with snow accumulating up to several inches.
properties.name: Hopewell Furnace
properties.description: Hopewell Furnace showcases an early American industrial landscape from natural resource extraction to enlightened conservation. Operating from 1771-1883, Hopewell and other "iron plantations" laid the foundation for the transformation of the United States into an industrial giant. The park's 848 acres and historic structures illustrate the business, technology and lifestyle of our growing nation.

images.altText: Artists' Illustaration of Hopewell Furnace in operation circa 1840.
images.title: Historical Rendering of Hopewell Furnace in Operation, 1840
images.caption: Overview of the Hopewell Furnace "iron plantation" community in operation during its prime.

images.altText: Front of Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House
images.title: Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House
images.caption: Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House housed single men or those living away from their families, who came to work at the furnace.

images.altText: Side view of blacksmith shop with cast house behind it.
images.title: Blacksmith Shop & Cast House
images.caption: The Cast House was the industrial center of the ironworks.  It is were iron ore was smelted into iron metal and products.  The smaller blacksmith shop formed iron metal into all kinds of necessary tools and goods used in everyday life.

images.altText: Side view of Hopewell Stove in front of wagon running gear.
images.title: Hopewell Stove
images.caption: The most notable manufactured product Hopewell Furnace made was its stoves.  They were produced by the thousands at Hopewell and other like furnaces in the early 19th century and were transported for sale by horse and wagon.

images.altText: Demonstration charcoal pile smoldering.
images.title: Charcoal Pile
images.caption: Charcoal was the fuel used to fire Hopewell Furnace and other furnaces of its age.  Thousands of bushles of charcoal were made from hardwood trees on the furnace lands and entered into the furnace to keep it "in blast."

entranceFees.description:
The park does not charge an entrance fee. 
A fee is charged for tours of the ground floor of the Texas White House and is as follows:

    Ages 18 and older: $3.00
    Ages 17 and younger: free
entranceFees.title: Entrance

properties.directionsInfo:
By car to National Park Headquarters and the Visitor Center in Johnson City:

From Austin, take Highway 290 west.
From San Antonio, take Highway 281 north.
From Fredericksburg, take Highway 290 east. 

By car to the LBJ Ranch and LBJ State Park and Historic Site:

From Johnson City, take Highway 290 fourteen miles west to the LBJ State Park.
From Fredericksburg, take Highway 290 sixteen miles east to the LBJ State Park.

The nearest major airports are in Austin and San Antonio.
properties.weatherInfo:
Overall, the park enjoys a sunny, mild climate during three seasons of the year.

Spring: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C). Rain is common in April and May.

Summer: Temperatures range from 70 F to 95 F (21 C/35 C). Temperatures can exceed 100 F (38 C) in July and August. Lightweight clothing and sunscreen are advisable. Be prepared with plenty of water.

Fall: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C).

Winter: Temperatures range from 35 F to 65 F (2 C/18 C) . Snow and ice are rare.
properties.name: Lyndon B Johnson
properties.description:
---Lyndon Baines Johnson

Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park tells the story of our 36th President beginning with his ancestors until his final resting place on his beloved LBJ Ranch. This entire "circle of life" gives the visitor a unique perspective into one of America's most noteworthy citizens by providing the most complete picture of any American president.

images.altText: View of Texas White House from front lawn.
images.title: Texas White House
images.caption: Because President Johnson spent one-fourth of his term a president in Texas, the press referred to this home as the "Texas White House"

images.altText: View of Boyhood Home from the front street.
images.title: Boyhood Home
images.caption: Lyndon Johnson was 5 years old when he moved to this home with his family. His childhood in a small rural town had great impact on his futur.

images.altText: A park visitor meets one of the ranch's Hereford cattle while driving the tour route.
images.title: Touring the LBJ Ranch
images.caption: A park visitor meets one of the ranch's Hereford cattle while driving the tour route.

images.altText: Luci Johnson (center in gray jersey) leads a bike tour
images.title: Cyclists in the LBJ 100
images.caption: Many special events, such as the LBJ 100 bike ride, take place during the year.

images.altText: Pink granite headstones mark the graves of President Lyndon Johnson and First Lady Lady Bird Johnson
images.title: Gravestones for Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson
images.caption: Pink granite headstones mark the graves of President Lyndon Johnson and First Lady Lady Bird Johnson

images.credit: LBJ Library Photo by Frank Wolfe
images.altText: President and Mrs. Johnson stand outside the Texas White House with dog Yuki.
images.title: Portrait of the Johnsons
images.caption: For their 1972 Christmas card, the Johnsons stand outside the Texas White House with their dog Yuki.

images.altText: View of the Pedernales River
images.title: Pedernales River
images.caption: The Pedernales River forms flows past the LBJ Ranch

images.altText: An exterior view of a Lockheed Jetstar used by President Johnson.
images.title: Lockheed Jetstar
images.caption: One of the five Lockheed Jetstars in service during the Johnson Presidency is now on display at the LBJ Ranch..

properties.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park

properties.directionsInfo:
The three closest major airports are Burlington, VT (95 miles from park), Manchester, NH (97 miles), and Boston, MA (143 miles). There are small regional airports in Rutland, VT (37 miles) and West Lebanon, NH (16 miles).

Dartmouth Coach offers shuttle service from Boston's Logan Airport to Hanover, NH (20 miles) and Lebanon, NH (16 miles). No other airports are connected to this area by shuttle service. (The Dartmouth Coach also offers service from New York City to Hanover, NH and Lebanon, NH.)
properties.weatherInfo: The weather in Vermont is dramatic and varied depending on location, terrain, distance from a body of water like Lake Champlain, and elevation and can change from year to year. In the Woodstock area, summer daily high temperatures range between 60 to 80 degrees, with some days reaching into the 90s. Winter is Vermont's longest season and temps in winter vary more than those in summer. Common to experience freezing temperatures from Nov to March, many sub-zero days, seasonal snowfall averages 80 inches.
properties.name: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller
properties.description: Walk through one of Vermont's most beautiful landscapes, under the shade of sugar maples and 400-year-old hemlocks, across covered bridges and alongside rambling stone walls. This is a landscape of loss, recovery, and conservation. This is a story of stewardship, of people taking care of places - sharing an enduring connection to land and a sense of hope for the future.

images.altText: Winter sports at the park
images.title: Winter at Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller
images.caption: Cross-country skiiers enjoy a brilliant day in the park!

images.altText: Visitors amongst the blooms in the Mansions formal gardens
images.title: Mansion Gardens
images.caption: Celebrate Spring in the glorious Mansion gardens and grounds

images.altText: Family enjoys a tranquil stroll during summer community days
images.title: Summer Community Days at the Park
images.caption: Fun for the entire family during the Park's summer community day celebration

images.altText: Hikers enjoying fall foliage during a park event
images.title: Autumn Hikers in the Park
images.caption: Hikers frolic in the fall foliage during a park event

properties.directionsInfo: By car, from Interstate 20, take the Delhi exit and travel north on LA 17, east on LA 134 and north on LA 577.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are sunny, hot, and humid. Winters tend to be mild; however, humid rainy periods occur throughout the year. Sudden and severe thunderstorms are common, so stay alert to weather forecasts. Check with rangers at the Visitor Center and/or USS Cairo Museum for updates on weather patterns.

Wear comfortable sportswear appropriate for the season, with walking or hiking shoes recommended.
properties.name: Poverty Point
properties.description: Now a nearly forgotten culture, Poverty Point at its peak 3,000 years ago was part of an enormous trading network that stretched for hundreds of miles across the continent. It was - and is - also an engineering marvel, the product of five million hours of labor. Explore the culture of a highly sophisticated people who left behind one of North America’s most important archeological sites.

images.altText: A grassy green mound.
images.title: Bird Mound
images.caption: A grassy green mound.

images.altText: Bird Mound - a grassy green mound.
images.title: Bird Mound
images.caption: Bird Mound - a grassy green mound.

images.altText: Bird Mound - a grassy green mound.
images.title: Bird Mound
images.caption: Bird Mound - a grassy green mound.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Salinas Pueblo Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Reach the Mountainair Headquarters by taking I-25 south from Albuquerque to Belen, then NM 47 diagonally to US 60, then east 21 miles to Mountainair. To travel the historic highway route (Turquoise Highway) from the north, take I-40 east from Albuquerque to NM 337, drive south 47 miles (76K) to junction with NM State Highway 55. Proceed right (west) on Hwy 55 about 16 miles (26 K). Turn right on Highway 60 and proceed one block to HQ.  Information on the ruins & surrounding area is available here.
properties.weatherInfo: Salinas Pueblo Missions is located at an elevation of 6100-6500 ft (1860-1980 m) in an arid climate. Average annual rainfall is about 15 inches. Winters can be cold and snowy. Summer highs are above 90°F/32°C with cool evenings. The months of June-September often have thunderstorms. Flash flooding may occur in the area. Abó is especially prone to road closures as a result. Spring highs average 75°F/24°C.  Fall temperatures are a little cooler. High winds often occur, which may result in trail closures.
properties.name: Salinas Pueblo Missions
properties.description: Tucked away in the middle of New Mexico you’ll find Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument.  Its three distinct sites offer a glimpse into a unique time in history—a time entrenched with cultural borrowing, conflict and struggles.  These sites continue to stand as reminders of the Spanish and Pueblo peoples’ early encounters and prompt exploration of today’s interactions among different people.

images.altText: A path through stone walls of an old church.
images.title: Inside the Abo Church
images.caption: A view inside the Abo Church looking north. A nice carpet of grass is usually present during summer months.

images.altText: Stone foundations of an old mission structure.
images.title: An overview of the Abo Mission

images.altText: An solar eclipse outlines an old stone structure at Salinas Pueblo NM.
images.title: Annular Eclipse seen from Gran Quivira
images.caption: An annular eclipse was visible from Gran Quivira in 2012. A special program allowed visitors to experience this amazing celestrial event.

images.title: Kivas at Gran Quivira
images.caption: An overview of kivas at Gran Quivira
