entranceFees.description: Entrance to the park is free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Park Headquarter's is located 4 miles south of downtown San Antonio.
The four mission sites lay as a chain south of downtown. Mission Concepción is 3 miles, Mission San José and the park visitor center is 6 miles south, Mission San Juan is 3 miles south of San José, and Mission Espada lays another mile beyond. 
Written directions and GPS addresses can be found at the link below.
properties.weatherInfo:
Over the course of a year, the temperature typically varies from 40°F to 95°F and is rarely below 29°F or above 100°F. The warm season lasts from May through September with an average daily high temperature above 90°F and a low of 75°F. The cold season lasts from November through February with an average daily high below 68°F and an average low of 40°F.
The relative humidity ranges from 40-80% over the course of the year, which can be very uncomfortable to many people.
properties.name: San Antonio Missions
properties.description: After 10,000 years, the people of South Texas found their cultures, their very lives under attack. In the early 1700s Apache raided from the north, deadly diseases traveled from Mexico, and drought lingered. Survival lay in the missions. By entering a mission, they foreswore their traditional life to become Spanish, accepting a new religion and pledging fealty to a distant and unseen king.

images.altText: Mission Concepción, World Heritage Site
images.title: Mission Concepción, World Heritage Site
images.caption: Mission Concepción has colorful frescos inside that date to the 1750s.

images.altText: Mission San José, World Heritage Site
images.title: Mission San José, World Heritage Site
images.caption: Mission San José shows many aspects of a Spanish colonial mission.

images.altText: Mission San Juan, World Heritage Site
images.title: Mission San Juan, World Heritage Site
images.caption: Mission San Juan has a farm watered with an historic irrigation system.

images.altText: Mission Espada, World Heritage Site
images.title: Mission Espada, World Heritage Site
images.caption: A part of Mission Espada's ranch is located 30 miles south-east, outside of Floresville, TX.

images.altText: The Rose Window, Mission San José
images.title: The Rose Window, Mission San José
images.caption: Legend has Pedro Huizar constructing this window for his beloved Rosa, who died at sea on her way from Spain to join him in new Spain.

images.altText: Park Ranger leads a tour through Mission San José
images.title: Tours of Mission San José
images.caption: Catch a tour at Mission San José at 10:00, 11:00, 1:00 and 3:00 daily.

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate 24 - Take Exit 76 and turn left (eastbound) or right (westbound) onto Medical Center Parkway. Turn left onto Thompson Lane. Turn left at the park entrance at 1563 N. Thompson Lane. Follow the tour road to the visitor center.

From Interstate 40 - Take Exit 235 onto TN 840. Take Exit 55 onto US 41/TN 70 and follow the signs for Murfreesboro. Turn right onto Thompson Lane at the first traffic light. Turn right at the park entrance at 1563 N. Thompson Lane.
properties.weatherInfo: Summer is hot and humid with highs in the 90s. Spring and fall are pleasant. Winter temperatures are variable, but temperatures may drop below freezing with occasional snow.
properties.name: Stones River
properties.description: The Battle of Stones River began on the last day of 1862 and was one of the bloodiest conflicts of the Civil War. The battle produced important military and political gains for the Union, and it changed forever the people who lived and fought here.

images.altText: The sun rises behind a green field with a cannon in the foreground.
images.title: Sunrise at Mendenhall's Artillery Trail
images.caption: On January 2, 1863, fifty-seven Union cannons fired from this line ending the Battle of Stones River by killing or wounding more than 1,800 Confederates in less than an hour.

images.altText: A ray of sunlight shines on the ground at Stones River National Cemetery.
images.title: Stones River National Cemetery
images.caption: More than 6,100 Union soldiers lie in Stones River National Cemetery.

images.altText: Two cannons sit in an icy field.
images.title: The Chicago Board of Trade Battery
images.caption: The men of the Chicago Board of Trade Battery got their first taste of combat at the Battle of Stones River and helped stem the Confederate tide from this position during the afternoon of December 31, 1862.

images.altText: Union soldiers fire muskets.
images.title: Union Infantry Program
images.caption: Living history programs help visitors visualize the trials of soldiers during the Battle of Stones River.

images.altText: Bicyclists ride down a road bracketed by trees.
images.title: Bike Tour
images.caption: Thousands of visitors enjoy biking and hiking through the park.

properties.directionsInfo:
Plane —
Closest commercial airport:
Jackson, MS, 50 miles to the east. 

Car —
Directions to Vicksburg:
From the east — Take Interstate 20 west to Vicksburg, MS. Use exit ramp 4B. Follow Clay Street (US-80) west 0.25 miles to park entrance.

From the north — Take Interstate 55 south to Jackson, MS. To save time, use Interstate 220 bypass on west side of Jackson. Take Interstate 20 west to Vicksburg approximately 40 miles. Use exit ramp 4B. Follow Clay Street (US-80) west 0.25 miles to park entrance.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year from date of purchase; does not offer discounts at the cooperating association bookstores.
entrancePasses.title: Vicksburg Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Spring and fall in Vicksburg are always very pleasant with cool nights and warm, sunny days with temperatures ranging from lows of 40-50 degrees to highs of 70 degrees. Winter weather in Mississippi is usually mild except for occasional cold air invasions, which normally last only a couple of days. Temperatures range from lows of 30 degrees to highs of 50 degrees. In the summer, weather is consistently hot, beginning in the low 70's and climbing to highs ranging from 80-90 degrees in the afternoon.
properties.name: Vicksburg
properties.description:
To Confederate President Jefferson Davis, Vicksburg was the "nailhead that holds the South's two halves together."  President Abraham Lincoln remarked "Vicksburg is the key" to victory, and could be the north's lifeline into the south.  

As the federals closed in on the Fortress City, they were met by a ring of forts with over 170 cannon. The resulting battle would determine the war's outcome.

images.altText: Union cannon aimed at Confederate lines
images.title: Union Cannon
images.caption: The Union artillery played a major role in the outcome of the Vicksburg Campaign.

images.altText: a headstone is seen in a tree
images.title: Headstone in Tree
images.caption: A headstone in the Vicksburg National Cemetery rest beside a tree.

images.altText: Stars behind the Illinois State Memorial
images.title: Illinois State Memorial
images.caption: Stars gleam behind the Illinois State Memorial.

images.altText: Roses in bloom in front of the Shirley House
images.title: The Shirley House
images.caption: Roses in bloom in front of the Shirley House, the only remaining Civil War structure in the park.

entranceFees.description: The fee allows entrance to Wright Brothers National Memorial for one person, 16 years old or older, for seven consecutive days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Adult

entranceFees.title: Children

properties.directionsInfo: Wright Brothers National Memorial is located along US 158 in the town of Kill Devil Hills on the Outer Banks of North Carolina.

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass (available for purchase at the entrance station) allows unlimited entry to Wright Brothers National Memorial for 12 months from date of purchase. Pass admits the passholder(s) + 3 adults (16 years of age and older).
entrancePasses.title: Wright Brothers Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Weather on the Outer Banks varies seasonally and daily. Please check the National Weather Service at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for up-to-date weather forecast information.
properties.name: Wright Brothers
properties.description:
Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane flights on December 17, 1903.

With courage and perseverance, these self-taught engineers relied on teamwork and application of the scientific process. What they achieved changed our world forever.

images.credit: Wilbur Wright, Orville Wright, and John Daniels
images.altText: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time as Wilbur assists.
images.title: First Flight
images.caption: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time on December 17, 1903.

images.altText: Copper busts of the two brothers with the moon visible in the blue sky.
images.title: Busts and Moon
images.caption: Copper busts of Wilbur and Orville Wright stand atop Big Kill Devil Hill.

images.altText: The large boulder and plaque sit where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.
images.title: First Flight Boulder
images.caption: This boulder marks the spot where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.

images.altText: Visitors walk along the flight line where Wilbur and Orville Wright flew and landed.
images.title: Walking Along History
images.caption: Visitors explore the landing spots of the Wright brothers' first flights.

images.altText: View straight up at the monument with the Sun directly behind the stonework.
images.title: Wright Brothers Monument
images.caption: Black-and-white image of the Wright Brothers Monument

images.altText: Two young girls look across the grounds of Wright Brothers National Memorial.
images.title: National Aviation Day
images.caption: Visitors enjoy celebrating aviation where modern aviation was born.

images.altText: Visitors moving along a sidewalk to the top of the hill where the monument stands.
images.title: Journey to the Top
images.caption: Visitors climb Big Kill Devil Hill to visit the Wright Brothers Monument.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to visit any of the sites of Nez Perce National Historical Park. Also, as of 2007 Big Hole National Battlefield stopped collecting entrance fees. Entrance to the battlefield is now free!
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Driving south bound on  U.S. Highway 95 you will find the Visitor Center 10 miles from Lewiston, ID.  Roughly one mile after crossing the Clearwater River you will find the park entrance on your left.

When driving north on U.S. Highway 95 the Visitor Center will be 3 miles north of Lapwai, ID.  The park entrance will be on your right.
properties.weatherInfo:
Elevations in the Park range from 700 feet above sea level to over 8,000, providing a wide range of climatic conditions, that follow the four seasons.
Be prepared for very warm weather in the summer months, in particular in the river valleys. The spring and fall are moderate and comfortable. Winter conditions can be severe in the higher elevations, with snow and ice making travel difficult and dangerous.
Please visit the National Weather Service for comprehensive weather information.
properties.name: Nez Perce
properties.description: For thousands of years the valleys, prairies, mountains, and plateaus of the inland northwest have been home to the nimí·pu· (Nez Perce) people. Extremely resilient, they have adapted and survived the settling of the United States. Explore these places. Learn their stories.

images.altText: Birds in flight across a grassy field.
images.title: Take Flight
images.caption: Birds take flight across a grassy field.

images.altText: Petroglyph carvings on the bank of the Snake River.
images.title: Buffalo Eddy
images.caption: Buffalo Eddy contains many petroglyphs and is considered a ancient crossing place.

images.altText: Colorful painted tipi on green lawn
images.title: Painted Tipi
images.caption: Every morning in the summer Rangers put a tipi on the front lawn of the visitor center. Visitors are always welcome to help.

images.altText: Elder (Mylie Lawyer) sitting in front of Old Buffalo hide tipi.
images.title: Buffalo Hide Tipi
images.caption: The only known remaining complete buffalo hide tipi belonging to a Nez Perce.

images.altText: Horses and riders dressed in native regalia.
images.title: Appaloosa Horse Parade
images.caption: This horse parade was held in the Spalding picnic area during the parks 50th anniversary in 2015.

images.altText: Blue Camas flowers in a prairie field.
images.title: Weippe Camas
images.caption: Camas has been a food staple of the Nez Perce for thousands of years.

entranceFees.title: Commercial Bus Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Take Interstate I-90 and get off at Crow Agency Exit 510 at Jct 212. To reach Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument, take Battlefield Tour Road 756

entrancePasses.description: The Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument Annual Pass covers entrance fees for the pass holder and accompanying passengers in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle. This pass does not cover camping fees and is non-transferable and non-refundable. This pass must be purchased on site.
entrancePasses.title: Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument weather: 
Spring: 50-60 (F) degree days/ 30+/- (F) degree nights
Summer: 70-100 (F) degree days/ 45-60+ (F) degree nights
Fall: 50 degree (F) days/ 25+/- (F) degree nights
Winter: 20 degree (F) days/ 0+/- (F) degree nights
properties.name: Little Bighorn Battlefield
properties.description: This area memorializes the US Army's 7th Cavalry and the Lakotas and Cheyennes in one of the Indian's last armed efforts to preserve their way of life. Here on June 25 and 26 of 1876, 263 soldiers, including Lt. Col. George A. Custer and attached personnel of the US Army, died fighting several thousand Lakota and Cheyenne warriors.

images.altText: A rising hunter's moon peaks above the horizon. Stars fill the night sky.
images.title: Rising Full Hunters Moon
images.caption: Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument has an incredible night sky. A full hunter's moon peaks above the horizon.

images.altText: Headstone can still been seen even with the fresh snow that blankets the battlefield .
images.title: Headstones in the winter
images.caption: The monument and battlefield are open year round, even in winter when snow coats the ground.

images.altText: The Seventh Calvary Memorial at dusk.
images.title: Seventh Calvary Memorial
images.caption: About 40 to 50 men of the original 210 were cornered on the hill where the monument now stands.

images.altText: The sun sets behind the Indian Memorial.
images.title: Indian Memorial
images.caption: The Indian Memorial is a circular earthwork carved gently into the prairie. The walls carry the names of those who fell here as well as the words of some who fought in the battle.

images.altText: The stone house sits on the edge of the Custer National Cemetery.
images.title: Stone House
images.caption: The stone house once served as a house for the Superintendent and their family. It has been renovated and  restored and now serves as an office and research area.

Please contact us in advance if you are arriving in a large vehicle (RV) or bus. The maximum size of a vehicle allowed on the Volcano Road without a permit is 26 feet in length and/or 8 feet in width.

Individuals or families with a valid Annual or Lifetime pass may use their pass for entry at the per person rate. Present pass & photo ID on entry. Contact us in advance if you're in a large vehicle (RV) or bus. Max vehicle size allowed on the Volcano Road without a permit: 26' long, 8' wide

properties.directionsInfo: Capulin Volcano National Monument is located in northeast New Mexico. The monument is located 34 miles east of Raton, NM, and 60 miles west of Clayton, NM on NM325 North of US64. No public transportation systems serve the park.
properties.weatherInfo:
Elevations in the park range from approximately 7,000 feet to 8,182 feet on the crater rim. Windy conditions may exist at the top of the volcano.

Summers are mild (highs in the mid-80sF/approximately 30C). Thunderstorms are common in July and August. The top of the Volcano will be closed during thunderstorms. Light jackets may be needed during the summer.

Winters are cold, and blizzards may result in temporary park closures. Warm and layered clothing should be worn the rest of the year.
properties.name: Capulin Volcano
properties.description:
As a public health precaution, the Visitor center, Volcano Road, and the Park Store are temporarily closed for the safety of staff and visitors. The trails are open and the monument hours are dawn to dusk. There are no emergency services on site. In case of emergencies dial 911.

Please take all proper health precautions while hiking and respect the social distance of a minimum of 6 feet.

images.altText: A cloud shrouded volcano rises behind a field of yellow flowers.
images.title: Capulin Volcano
images.caption: Capulin Volcano in summer.

images.altText: View of cinder cone volcano and the road leading to the top of the volcano as seen from the air.
images.title: Aerial View of Capulin Volcano
images.caption: Capulin Volcano is a classic example of a cinder cone. The crater is approximately 130 m (420 ft) deep and 440 m (1,450 ft) across. The base of the mountain is 6 km (4 mi) in circumference. Volcano Road spirals up the volcano, providing panoramic views.

images.altText: A shaded bench on the side of a paved nature trail wending through juniper trees and grasses.
images.title: Nature Trail at Capulin Volcano
images.caption: A paved nature trail at Capulin Volcano NM.

images.altText: Layers of rock are visible in the steep hillside along a road.
images.title: Volcano Road
images.caption: Layers of volcanic material can be seen in the Volcano Road that takes visitors to the top of Capulin Volcano.

images.altText: View of a cinder cone volcano covered with grasses, small trees, and other plants.
images.title: Capulin Volcano-Best Example of a Cinder Cone in North America
images.caption: Although Capulin Mountain is considered no longer active, because its excellent condition, the cinder cone is considered one of the best and most accessible examples of a cinder cone in North America.

entranceFees.description: Fort Bowie National Historic Site is a fee free park. No entrance fee is required.
entranceFees.title: Fort Bowie Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: From Willcox, AZ / points west on I-10: drive 23 miles east of Willcox on Interstate 10 to the the town of Bowie. Exit at the first Bowie exit and drive through the town. Follow the signs for Fort Bowie National Historic Site and turn south on Apache Pass Road. Drive 13 miles to the Fort Bowie Trailhead (the last mile of the road is unpaved). Be prepared to walk the three miles round trip to the ruins and back to your car.
properties.weatherInfo: Please check the Fort Bowie weather page for up to date weather conditions: http://www.wunderground.com/personal-weather-station/dashboard?ID=MAU921
properties.name: Fort Bowie
properties.description: Fort Bowie witnessed almost 25 years of conflict between the Chiricahua Apache and the US Army, and remains a tangible connection to the turbulent era of the late 1800s. Explore the history of Fort Bowie and Apache Pass as you hike the 1.5 mile trail to the visitor center and old fort ruins. Today, this peaceful landscape stands in stark contrast to the violence that once gripped this land.

images.altText: Ruined walls of the old buildings and mountains in the background
images.title: Fort Bowie landscape and ruins
images.caption: Fort Bowie was once a bustling frontier military fort. Today, the ruins offer a place of reflection.

images.altText: Close up of a canon barrel
images.title: Mountain howitzer
images.caption: The mountain howitzer is a symbolic relic from the active days of Fort Bowie

images.altText: Black and white photo of white tombstones in a cemetery, mountains in the background
images.title: Fort Bowie Cemetery
images.caption: Fort Bowie cemetery is accessed via the Fort Bowie Trail, and in addition to many US troops buried here, some Apache/Indeh are buried here as well.

images.altText: A group gathers as a ranger displays the heliograph equipment
images.title: Heliograph demonstration
images.caption: The heliograph was an important communications tool in the late 1880s. Stationed on top of high desert peaks, sunlight was reflected off mirrors in coded patterns to send a message miles away.

images.altText: Weathered remains of an adobe building at Fort Bowie
images.title: Fort Bowie Ruins
images.caption: After the fort's abandonment in the late 1800s the unmaintained buildings slowly weathered until the 1950s when the park service acquired the site.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to Washita Battlefield National Historic Site
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

properties.directionsInfo: Cheyenne is situated in western Oklahoma approximately 140 miles west of Oklahoma City and 128 miles east of Amarillo, Texas; just 22 miles north of I-40 on State Highway 283. The town of Cheyenne is the county seat of Roger Mills and inhabits 23.3% of the entire county population.Cheyenne is approximately 30 miles north of I-40 on Hwy 283 and approxima
properties.weatherInfo: Weather in western Oklahoma can vary considerably. Winters can be mild to severe with ice storms being the biggest concern. Spring is usually short but pleasant although severe weather, including tornadoes, is still a possibility. Usually a strong breeze is associated with spring weather. Summers are brutally hot and visitors should be cautioned about spending any length of time in the heat. Falls are cool with a bitter wind.
properties.name: Washita Battlefield
properties.description: On November 27, 1868, Lt. Colonel George Armstrong Custer led the 7th U.S. Cavalry on a surprise dawn attack on a Cheyenne village led by Peace Chief Black Kettle. The event was an example of the tragic clash of cultures that occurred during the Great Plains Wars. It is also a place of remembrance and reflection for those who died here.

images.altText: The Washita River in winter covered in ice and snow
images.title: Washita River
images.caption: The Washita River looking much the same as it did during the attack on November 27, 1868

images.altText: Cheyenne tipis backlite by sunset
images.title: Tipis at Sunset
images.caption: Cheyenne tipis backlite by sunset

images.altText: A Cheyenne Dog Soldier tells stories inside his tipi
images.title: Cheyenne Dog Soldier Telling Stories
images.caption: A Cheyenne Dog Soldier tells stories inside his tipi

images.altText: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center on a summer day
images.title: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center
images.caption: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center on a summer day

images.altText: A Park Ranger knells down among Junior Rangers so only his hat shows within the crowd of children.
images.title: Learning Something New at Washita
images.caption: A Park Ranger helps children with their Jr. Ranger books.

images.altText: A Cheyenne Warrior and U.S. Cavalry soldier hold a meeting next to a tipi
images.title: "Meeting the Enemy"
images.caption: A Cheyenne Warrior and U.S. Cavalry soldier hold a meeting next to a tipi

entranceFees.description: The Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt (National Park Service) and the FDR Presidential Library and Museum (National Archives and Records Administration) offer a $20 joint admission ticket. These tickets are valid for 2 days at the FDR Library and Museum.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site is located on Route 9 in Hyde Park, NY about 90 miles north of New York City and 70 miles south of Albany.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40°F to 70°F.  Rain is not uncommon.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70° F to 100° F.  Humidity can be high throughout the summer months with periods of rain.

Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40° F to 70° F.  Peak leaf season is mid-October.  Rain is not uncommon.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30° F to 50°F.   Ice, Freezing Rain and Snow are not uncommon.
properties.name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt
properties.description: Home to the 32nd and longest-serving president of the United States, Franklin D. Roosevelt returned to Hyde Park often, drawing on this place to renew his spirit during times of personal and political crisis. Explore the Roosevelt Saga in the homes of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt, the exhibits at the nation’s first Presidential Library, and over a thousand acres of gardens and trails.

images.altText: Springwood, the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt
images.title: Springwood - Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt
images.caption: Spingwood, the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt

images.altText: The Rose Garden at the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt
images.title: The Rose Garden
images.caption: The Rose Garden at the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt

images.altText: The Crew of the USS Roosevelt with Eleanor and Franklin
images.title: Memorial Day at the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt
images.caption: The Crew of the USS Roosevelt with Eleanor and Franklin

images.altText: Springwood
images.title: Springwood
images.caption: Springwood

images.altText: Christmas at Springwood
images.title: Christmas at Springwood
images.caption: Christmas at Springwood

properties.fullName: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site

entranceFees.title: Eleanor Roosevelt Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site is located on Route 9G in the Town of Hyde Park, NY.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40°F to 70°F.  Rain is not uncommon.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70° F to 100° F.  Humidity can be high throughout the summer months with periods of rain.

Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40° F to 70° F.  Peak leaf season is mid-October.  Rain is not uncommon.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30° F to 50°F.   Ice, Freezing Rain and Snow are not uncommon.
properties.name: Eleanor Roosevelt
properties.description:
"The greatest thing I have learned is how good it is to come home again." Eleanor Roosevelt 

This simple statement expresses her love for the modest house she called Val-Kill. The only National Historic Site dedicated to a first lady, Val-Kill welcomes visitors in the style of Mrs. Roosevelt. Come and be part of the entire Roosevelt Experience at Val-Kill.

images.altText: A view of the buildings at Val-Kill
images.title: Eleanor Roosevelt's Val-Kill
images.caption: Looking across the water at the Stone Cottage and Val-Kill Cottage

images.altText: Stone Cottage at Val-Kill
images.title: Stone Cottage at Val-Kill
images.caption: Val-Kill is a special place that serves as a window into Eleanor Roosevelt's private and public life.

images.altText: Val-Kill Cottage
images.title: Val-Kill Cottage
images.caption: Val-Kill became the nucleus of Franklin and Eleanor's overlapping network of friends and political associates. After FDR's death in 1945, Val-Kill became Mrs. Roosevelt's permanent home.

images.altText: View of Val-Kill cottage from the garden
images.title: View of Val-Kill Cottage from the garden
images.caption: Mrs. Roosevelt's favorite room was the sleeping porch on the second floor overlooking the garden.

images.altText: Bridge at Val-Kill
images.title: Bridge at Val-Kill
images.caption: Mrs. Roosevelt would hear her guests approach as they drove over the bridge.

entranceFees.description: Free!
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: 2 miles south of Ninety Six, SC on Hwy 248. For more detailed information, click on "Directions Details" below.
properties.weatherInfo: Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.
properties.name: Ninety Six
properties.description: Settlers struggled against the harsh backcountry to survive. Cherokee Indians hunted and fought to keep their land. Two towns and a trading post were formed then abandoned to the elements. And two Revolutionary War battles claimed over 100 lives. Come discover the 18th century history of South Carolina.

images.altText: A cannon is in the left foreground with the Maham rifle tower in the distance.
images.title: Cannon and Maham Tower
images.caption: Cannon and Maham Tower

images.altText: A corten steel figure of a Native American stands sentinel in the fog.
images.title: Exhibit in the Fog
images.caption: A corten steel figure of a Native American stands sentinel in the fog.

images.altText: The walking trail winds past a cannon and a rifle tower.
images.title: 1781 Battlefield View
images.caption: The walking trail winds past a cannon and a rifle tower.

images.altText: A wooden sign shows the direction of important places in 1781.

images.altText: A monument to James Birmingham, the first South Carolinian to die in the American Revolution

images.caption: A monument to patriot James Birmingham, the first South Carolinian to die in the American Revolution

images.altText: A British regimental coat hangs on a tent.

images.caption: A British regimental coat hangs on the middle tent during a special event.

images.altText: Reenactors listen as another reenactor presents and 18th century church service.
images.title: Divine Service
images.caption: Reenactors sit in chairs in front of the Black Swan Tavern as another reenactor presents and 18th century church service.

entranceFees.description:
Boston Harbor Islands is a Partnership park; fees and reservations vary. 

The park does not charge an admission fee, but a transportation fee applies for the public ferry. Reservations are recommended. Please note that National Park Land Passes do not cover transportation fees.

Visit bostonharborislands.org to plan your trip.
entranceFees.title: Fees and Reservations Vary

properties.directionsInfo: There are many ways to enjoy Boston Harbor Islands and many ways to get there. For more information on how to get to the park by ferry, car, or private boat, please visit www.bostonharborislands.org.
properties.weatherInfo: The Boston Harbor Islands have a humid maritime climate characterized by slightly cooler temperatures than the mainland, so dress in layers. Typical summer conditions feature air temperatures approximately 5-10 degrees cooler than the mainland between 60-80 Fahrenheit, winds of 0-15 knots and waves of 1-3 feet.
properties.name: Boston Harbor Islands
properties.description: . . . where you can walk a Civil War-era fort, visit historic lighthouses, explore tide pools, hike lush trails, camp under the stars, or relax while fishing, picnicking or swimming-all within reach of downtown Boston. Youth programs, visitor services, research, wildlife management, and more are coordinated on the park's 34 islands and peninsulas by the Boston Harbor Islands Partnership.

images.altText: A child dancing on the beach at dusk
images.title: Beach Dancing
images.caption: A child dancing on the beach at dusk

images.altText: A man on a kayak in Boston Harbor
images.title: Kayaking Boston Harbor Islands
images.caption: Kayaking in Boston Harbor Islands National Recreational Area

images.altText: An image of the sun setting over the Boston skyline from the Islands
images.title: Sunset Over Boston
images.caption: Watch the sunset from Boston Harbor Islands

images.altText: Children looking out at Boston from the Harbor Islands
images.title: Come Explore The Islands
images.caption: Looking out at the city from the Boston Harbor Islands

images.altText: Historic Fort Warren on Georges Island
images.title: Fort Warren
images.caption: Visit historic Fort Warren on Georges Island in Boston Harbor

properties.fullName: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area

entranceFees.description: All park units, including the T Snell Visitor Center, are free of charge.
entranceFees.title: There is no entrance fee to any of the park units.

properties.directionsInfo: From the airport or Tumon, where most hotels are located, make your way to Route 1, Marine Corps Drive. Head south until the road ends and you arrive at the Naval Station Guam front gate. To the right, adjacent to the large 2-man Type-C Japanese midget submarine, is the T. Stell Newman Visitor Center.
properties.weatherInfo: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=13.47190933300044&lon=144.74977715100056
properties.name: War In The Pacific
properties.description: War in the Pacific National Historical Park was established to commemorate the bravery, courage, and sacrifice of those participating in the campaigns of the Pacific Theater of World War II.  At War in the Pacific National Historical Park, the former battlefields, gun emplacements, trenches, and historic structures all serve as silent reminders of the bloody World War II battles.

images.altText: Mountain view down toward beach.
images.title: Asan Beach Overlook
images.caption: Overlooking the invasion Asan Beach, this overlook honors the men and women killed on Guam in World War II.

images.altText: Night view of light up US flags.
images.title: Memorial Day Flag Honors at Asan Beach
images.caption: Honoring the Chamorro citizens and US service personnel killed during World War II.

images.altText: Calm water beach at sunset.
images.title: Apaca point
images.caption: This serene scene of Apaca Point does not reveal the intensity felt on the July 21, 1944 invasion.

properties.fullName: War In The Pacific National Historical Park

phoneNumbers.description: Visitor Center front desk.

entranceFees.description: No fee to enjoy the Visitor Center and all trails.
entranceFees.title: Visitor Center and Trails

properties.directionsInfo: Located 3 miles north of Marquette, Iowa on Hwy 76.
properties.weatherInfo: All four seasons are represented in this area with summer temperature in the upper 80’s with higher heat indexes due to humidity and winter daytime highs in the 20's. Temperatures are in °Fahrenheit.
properties.name: Effigy Mounds
properties.description: The mounds preserved here are considered sacred by many Americans, especially the Monument's 20 culturally associated American Indian tribes. A visit offers opportunities to contemplate the meanings of the mounds and the people who built them. The 200 plus American Indian mounds are located in one of the most picturesque sections of the Upper Mississippi River Valley.

images.altText: Bear Effigy Mounds with visitor walking nearby.
images.title: Marching Bear in Spring
images.caption: Marching Bear Mound Group in summer.

images.altText: Scenic view of the steep bluffs adjacent to the Mississippi River as trees start to change color.
images.title: Scenic Overlook at Fire Point
images.caption: Scenic overlook from the popular Fire Point Trail overlooking the Mississippi River and Driftless area bluffs.

images.altText: Three conical mounds in a foggy morning setting.
images.title: Mounds on a Foggy Morning
images.caption: Three Conical mounds along the Fire Point Trail during a foggy morning.

images.altText: Circular mounds in a single line.
images.title: Conical Mounds Leading to Fire Point
images.caption: Follow a line of conical mounds that will lead you out to Fire Point which overlooks the Mississippi River.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to Hovenweep National Monument
entranceFees.title: No Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Do not use GPS to find your way. There are numerous paved and dirt roads intersecting each other in this remote corner of Utah. The Hovenweep Visitor Center is located 40-45 miles from Cortez, Colorado, and Blanding and Bluff, Utah. Follow driving directions on our webpage.
properties.weatherInfo: Hovenweep is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
properties.name: Hovenweep
properties.description: Once home to over 2,500 people, Hovenweep includes six prehistoric villages built between A.D. 1200 and 1300. Explore a variety of structures, including multistory towers perched on canyon rims and balanced on boulders. The construction and attention to detail will leave you marveling at the skill and motivation of the builders.

images.altText: a green lizard with yellow head, yellow spots and black collar
images.title: Collared Lizard
images.caption: Collard lizards are one of many species that call Hovenweep home.

images.altText: a stone structure at night with the Milky Way arcing overhead
images.title: Milky Way at Square Tower Group
images.caption: Hovenweep National Monument was designated an International Dark Sky Park in 2014.

images.altText: a stone structure with blue sky and clouds overhead
images.title: Cajon Unit
images.caption: The Cajon Unit is one of several outlying units at Hovenweep National Monument.

images.altText: a stone structure resting on a cliff edge
images.title: Stronghold House
images.caption: Stronghole House is one of several structures at the Square Tower Group

images.altText: a bright red cactus flower
images.title: Claretcup Cactus
images.caption: Claretcup Cactus is a common plant at Hovenweep National Monument

addresses.line1: Along the border between southeast Utah and southwest Colorado
addresses.line2: Just north and west of Cortez, CO

entranceFees.description: There is NO FEE to enter Fort Union National Monument. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Fort Union National Monument is located in the Northeastern portion of the state of New Mexico. 8 miles off of Interstate I-25 on State Highway NM 161.
New Mexico: From Albuquerque (156 miles), Santa Fe (94 miles) or Las Vegas, NM (28 miles) take I-25 North, exit 366 at Watrous, 8 miles on NM 161.
Colorado: From Denver (313 miles), Colorado Springs (243 miles) or Raton (95 miles) take I-25 South, exit 366 at Watrous, 8 miles on NM 161.

entrancePasses.description:
Available to U.S. 4th graders (including home-schooled and free-choice learners 10 years of age) with a valid Every Kid in a Park paper voucher. The pass is valid for the duration of the 4th grade school year through the following summer (September - August.)

Paper vouchers can be obtained by visiting the Every Kid in a Park website and can be exchanged for the pass at Federal recreation sites that charge Entrance or Standard Amenity fees.Digital versions of the voucher will not be accepted.
entrancePasses.title: Annual "Every Kid In a Park" 4th Grade Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Fort Union is situated at 6,760 feet above sea level. Daytime temperatures between June and September may exceed 90 degrees Fahrenheit. Winter temperatures often drop below 32 degrees Fahrenheit. Temperatures may vary within 50 degrees in a 24-hour period.
During the winter, it is not uncommon for the temperatures to drop below 0°F (-18°C.) 
During the summer, expect high temperatures, intense sunlight and extreme low humidity.
properties.name: Fort Union
properties.description: Exposed to the wind, within a sweeping valley of short grass prairie, amid the swales of the Santa Fe Trail, lie the territorial-style adobe remnants of the largest 19th century military fort in the region. For forty years, 1851-1891, Fort Union functioned as an agent of political and cultural change, whether desired or not, in New Mexico and throughout the Southwest.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.altText: Wagons encrusted in frost
images.title: Freezing Fog in Mechanics Corral
images.caption: One of the most photographed areas of the monument, the Mechanics Corral onced serviced wagons that travelled along the Santa Fe Trail.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.altText: Panorama of Officers Row
images.title: Big Skies Over Officers Row
images.caption: Blue skies and billowing clouds frequently add to the incredible viewshed that surrounds the monument grounds.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.altText: Sunflower in Enlisted Barracks
images.title: Sunflower in Enlisted Barracks
images.caption: Located deep within the Mora Valley, Fort Union National Monument contains a vast array of plant and animal life.

images.altText: Moon in sky above adobe remnants
images.title: Remnants of the Past
images.caption: Located on the monument grounds is the world's largest collection of Territorial-Style adobe remanants.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.altText: Fort Union Visitor Center Sign
images.title: Fort Union NM Visitor Center
images.caption: Completed in 1960, the Visitor Center at Fort Union was one of the first built during the "MIssion 66" program for the National Park Service. It was designed by the internationally known architect Cecil Doty.

entranceFees.description:
Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all of its passengers (up to 8 persons). Organized non-profit groups (service organizations, scouts, church groups, college/school clubs) are not eligible for the vehicle permit.

Good for entry into Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau National Historical Park for seven days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau (non-commercial vehicle)

entranceFees.description:
Admits one individual when entering by foot or bicycle. 
Good for entry into Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau National Historical Park for seven days from the date of purchase. 
Individuals 15 years old and younger are admitted free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau (individual on foot, bicycle, etc.)

entranceFees.description:
Admits one motorcycle. 
Good for entry into Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau National Historical Park for seven days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau (motorcycle)

properties.directionsInfo: From Kailua-Kona: Take Highway 11 south, approximately 20 miles. Between mileposts 103 and 104, at the Honaunau Post Office, turn right towards the ocean onto Hwy 160. Travel 3.5 miles and turn left at the Pu'uhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park sign. Travel times will vary due to ongoing construction in North Kona.

entrancePasses.description: Allows access for one full year from date of purchase. Hawaiʻi Tri-Park Pass is valid at Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau National Historical Park, Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park and Haleakalā National Park.
entrancePasses.title: Hawaiʻi Tri-Park Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description:
Allows access for 12 months from date of purchase at Pu‘uhonua o Hōnaunau National Historical Park.

The pass admits the pass owner and/or spouse along with accompanying persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle. 

When entry is by other means (bicycle, foot, Hele-On bus, etc.) the pass covers the purchaser and accompanying immediate family (spouse, children, and parents). Pass is not refundable or transferable.
entrancePasses.title: Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The weather in the park is typically hot and sunny with daytime temperatures in the upper 80's. An excellent time to experience the park is in the morning and in the late afternoon when the temperatures are a bit cooler. The park is open daily from 7 a.m. until sunset. However the park does occasionally close because of high winds or dangerous storm conditions. Please check with the visitor center or your hotel for any weather advisories or hazardous conditions on the day of your visit.
properties.name: Pu`uhonua O Hōnaunau
properties.description: Imagine you had just broken the sacred laws, the kapu, and the only punishment was death. Your only chance of survival is to elude your pursuers and reach the Pu'uhonua, a place of refuge. The Pu'uhonua protected the kapu breaker, defeated warriors, as well as civilians during the time of battle. No physical harm could come to those who reached the boundaries of the Pu'uhonua.

images.altText: Hula dancers
images.title: Hula
images.caption: Hula dancers

images.altText: An a-frame canoe hale (house) in the Royal Grounds
images.title: Canoe Hale in the Royal Grounds
images.caption: Visitors from around the world visit Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau NHP every year to learn more about Hawaiian history and culture

images.altText: A glowing sunset reflects in the calm waters of a tide pool.
images.title: Sunset in the Tide Pools
images.caption: The Picnic Area is a fantastic place to catch a beautiful Hawaiian sunset.

images.altText: A double-hulled canoe sits in Keoneʻele Cove with Hale o Keawe in the background.
images.title: Hale o Keawe & Keoneʻele Cove
images.caption: Hale o Keawe (the royal mausoleum) brings visitors and current cultural practitioners to Puʻuhonua o Hōnaunau.

images.altText: Close up image looking along the stones of the Great Wall in the Puʻuhonua with coconut trees
images.title: The Great Wall and Puʻuhonua
images.caption: The Great Wall separates the Royal Grounds from the Puʻuhonua and demonstrates the impressive Hawaiian dry stacked masonry technique.

properties.fullName: Pu`uhonua O Hōnaunau National Historical Park

properties.directionsInfo:
Shuttle Bus: Most visitors must park at the Mammoth Mountain Ski Area and use the mandatory shuttle. The shuttle bus operates from mid-June through the Wednesday after Labor Day.

By car: From U.S. Highway 395, drive 10 miles west on S.R. 203 to Minaret Vista and then another 8 miles on a paved, steep mountain road. Please note that this road is single lane for approximately 3 miles.

By plane: The closest commercial airport is the Mammoth Lakes/Yosemite Airport (MMH), located on U.S. Highway 395.
properties.weatherInfo:
Devils Postpile National Monument is located at 7,560 feet above sea level just west of the Sierra Nevada crest. As such, it experiences typical summer weather in the Sierras.

Afternoon thunderstorms are possible in July and August. Daytime temperatures can range from the mid-70s to to mid-80s (degrees Fahrenheit). Evening temperatures can drop into the low 40s (and even the low 30s in the months of September and October).
properties.name: Devils Postpile
properties.description: Established in 1911 by presidential proclamation, Devils Postpile National Monument protects and preserves the Devils Postpile formation, the 101-foot high Rainbow Falls, and pristine mountain scenery.  The formation is a rare sight in the geologic world and ranks as one of the world's finest examples of columnar basalt. Its' columns tower up to 60 feet and display a striking symmetry.

images.altText: The Devils Postpile basalt formation resembles tall columns.
images.title: Devils  Postpile Formation
images.caption: Devils Postpile formation is one of many features to see at Devils Postpile National Monument.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site - Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance to Fort Union Trading Post NHS

properties.directionsInfo: Located on North Dakota 1804, the park is 25 miles southwest of Williston, ND, and 24 miles northeast of Sidney, MT.
properties.weatherInfo:
Weather in western North Dakota can be harsh, with extremes in temperature and sudden, violent storms. Be prepared for rapidly changing conditions.

Summers are warm with average high temperatures in the 80s-90s May through September. Winters are cold with average lows in the single digits December through February. Wind is considerable year-round. Conditions can change quickly.

Travelers should be aware of the potential for violent thunderstorms in the summer and the possibility of blizzards.
properties.name: Fort Union Trading Post
properties.description: Between 1828 and 1867, Fort Union was the most important fur trade post on the Upper Missouri River. Here, the Assiniboine and six other Northern Plains Indian Tribes exchanged buffalo robes and smaller furs for goods from around the world, including cloth, guns, blankets, and beads. A bastion of peaceful coexistence, the post annually traded over 25,000 buffalo robes and $100,000 in merchandise.

images.altText: Trade House with fire in hearth and plates/foodstuffs set up on buffalo robe.
images.title: Trade House Prepared for Guests
images.caption: Before trading began at Fort Union the Trade House's reception room was prepared for feasting. Traditionally  a meal was shared between the Upper Missouri Tribes and American Fur Company employees

images.altText: View from Missouri River bottoms of Southwest bastion
images.title: River View of Fort Union
images.caption: Viewing Fort Union Trading Post from the Missouri River bottoms one can imagine how grandiose the site would appear to weary steamboat travelers.

images.altText: Candles illuminate the Bourgeois House porch at dusk
images.title: Twilight View of the Bourgeois House
images.caption: Volunteer reenactors relax on the Bourgeois House porch

images.altText: Courtyard of Fort Union Trading Post with Bourgeois House, Tipis and US Flag
images.title: Fort Union Trading Post Courtyard
images.caption: Ranging from employee housing, workshops, storage warehouses, domestic animal pens and horse corrals, the courtyard housed the world at Fort Union.

images.altText: View of Fort Union and the Missouri River looking south
images.title: Fort Union and the Missouri River Valley
images.caption: Visitors hiking the scenic Bodmer Trail experience a historical view of Fort Union, and the same view painted by Karl Bodmer in 1833.

properties.fullName: Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: It is free to visit Cowpens National Battlefield.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-85 N, take exit 83. Turn left on Hwy 110, approx. 8 miles. Turn right on Hwy 11. The park is about a half mile on the right.

From I-85 S, take exit 92, turn right toward Chesnee on Hwy 11, approx.10 miles on the left.

From I-26 E, take exit 5, turn left toward Chesnee on Hwy 11, approx. 20 miles on the right.

From I-26 W, take I-85 North, take exit 83. Turn left on Hwy 110, approx. 8 miles. Turn right on Hwy 11. The park is about a half mile on the right.
properties.weatherInfo:
Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=35.1346&lon=-81.7036#.VhkrZ-xVhBc
properties.name: Cowpens
properties.description:
“…our success was complete…”
  -- Daniel Morgan to Nathanael Greene, January 19, 1781

A pasturing area at the time of the battle, this Revolutionary War site commemorates the place where Daniel Morgan and his army turned the flanks of Banastre Tarleton's British army. This classic military tactic, known as a double envelopment, was one of only a few in history.

images.altText: The sun is coming up on the battlefield in the direction that the Americans would have been facing.
images.title: Sunrise on Green River Road
images.caption: Sunrise on Green River Road

images.altText: The Visitor Center and US Monument are framed by orange and yellow trees.
images.title: Visitor Center and US Monument in the Fall
images.caption: Visitor Center and US Monument in the Fall

images.altText: Robert Scruggs House
images.title: Robert Scruggs House
images.caption: Robert Scruggs House

images.altText: Fog shrouds the 1856 Washington Light Infantry Monument
images.title: Washington Light Infantry Monument in the Fog
images.caption: Washington Light Infantry Monument in the Fog

images.altText: A tom turkey displays his feathers behind the Visitor Center.
images.title: Tom Turkey
images.caption: Tom Turkey

images.altText: Smoke puffs up from the vent and a flame shoots out of the muzzle as a militiaman fires his musket.
images.title: Militiaman Firing Musket
images.caption: Militiaman Firing Musket

entranceFees.description: No Entrance Fee
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Thomas Stone NHS is located on Rose Hill Road, between Maryland state routes 225 and 6, four miles west of LaPlata, MD.
properties.weatherInfo: Temperatures can be very warm and humid in the summer months and wet and cold in the winter months.
properties.name: Thomas Stone
properties.description: Prior to the Revolutionary War, Thomas Stone led a very comfortable life as a planter and lawyer. After realizing war with Great Britain was inevitable, he risked everything he held dear-- life, fortune, and sacred honor-- to safeguard American rights. To that end, Thomas Stone became one of 56 men to sign one of the most important documents in World History; the Declaration of Independence.

images.altText: Snow covers the Stone family cemetery
images.title: THST Cemetery
images.caption: Visitors come to see the grave of a signer of the Declaration of Independence

images.altText: Militia drilling in a field
images.title: Special Events at THST
images.caption: THST Special Events encompass many different topics including the English Civil War

images.altText: An opossum guarding her young
images.title: A Fierce Mother
images.caption: One never knows what one might find at THST

images.altText: Snow falls on the country home of Thomas Stone
images.title: Haberdeventure in the Snow
images.caption: THST has one of the few remaining homes of a signer of the Declaration of Independence

images.altText: The Stone family spent hours in this comfortable family room
images.title: THST Family Room
images.caption: The Stone family lived in this house for more than 150 years

entranceFees.description:
Grand Portage National Monument is fee free.  This includes visiting the heritage (visitor) center and the historic depot (great hall, kitchen, canoe warehouse, gatehouse, stockade and picnic grounds.

Camping at Fort Charlotte requires a free camping reservation for the two back country campsites.  To preserve the campsites, no more than nine campers may occupy a campsite at one time.
entranceFees.title: Grand Portage National Monument is fee free.

properties.directionsInfo: Traveling northeast or southwest on MN Hwy 61 visitors will see signs alerting the approach to Grand Portage National Monument.  A right turn exit lane or left turn from Hwy 61 at the Grand Portage Trading Post will take visitors onto Casino Road.  Turn left at the first stop sign from Casino Road to Mile Creek Road.   About 3/4 mile on Mile Creek Road, look for the large wooden entrance sign. Turn left up the short hill into the Heritage Center parking lot.
properties.weatherInfo:
Short, warm summers and long, cold winters define the climate of northern Minnesota.
Average range of summer temperature is from 55°F to 78°F in July and average range of winter
temperatures is from –11°F to 12°F in January.
Average annual precipitation in Grand Portage, MN is about 32 inches.
properties.name: Grand Portage
properties.description: Travel into the past to discover the present. Explore the partnership of the Grand Portage Ojibwe and the North West Company during the North American fur trade and the NPS today. Follow pathways into a distant time. Experience the sights and smells of a bustling depot reconstructed in its exact location. Hear the beat of the drum echo over Gichigami - Lake Superior.

images.altText: Stockade fence and log building overlooking Lake Superior
images.title: Mount Rose Trail overlooks Historic Depot & Grand Portage Bay
images.caption: Beautiful scenary welcomes Fall visitors to Grand Portage.

images.altText: Sunflowers blossoms in front of log building
images.title: Seneca Sunflowers Canoe Warehouse
images.caption: Colorful blossoms in the Three Sister's Garden

images.altText: Three log buildings with Lake and point of land in background.
images.title: Historic Depot, Hat Point
images.caption: Fall is a great time to hike the Mount Rose Trail

images.altText: Log buildings, stockade fence and dock near Lake.
images.title: Historic Depot From Mount Rose
images.caption: Fall is a great time to hike to the mount Rose overlook.

images.altText: Birch bark lodges among trees.
images.title: Ojibwe Village (Anishinaabe Odena)
images.caption: The Ojibwe Village is located in the Historic Depot

entranceFees.description: Horseshoe Bend is a fee free Park.
entranceFees.title: Horseshoe Bend Entrance Fee - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo: Located in northeastern Tallapoosa County, Horseshoe Bend National Military Park is accessible from US Highway 280, as well as AL Highways 22 and 49. The Park is located 5 miles south of the town of Newsite, AL and 12 miles north of the city of Dadeville, AL.
properties.weatherInfo: Temperatures can soar to extremes of heat and humidity in the summer and fall to a damp, wet, cold in the winter. During the summer season visitors should dress in light, comfortable clothing, wear comfortable shoes and use sunscreen. High temperatures and high humidity create higher risk of heat cramps, heat exhaustion and heatstroke. Drink plenty of fluids to maintain hydration. In the spring and fall visitors should have a light jacket available as temperatures can drop suddenly.
properties.name: Horseshoe Bend
properties.description: On 27 March 1814, Major General Andrew Jackson ‘s army of 3,300 men attacked Chief Menawa’s 1,000 Red Stick Creek warriors fortified in a horseshoe shaped bend of the Tallapoosa River.  Over 800 Red Sticks died that day.  The battle ended the Creek War, resulted in a land cession of 23,000,000 acres to the United States and created a national hero of Andrew Jackson.

images.altText: blue canon in front of park visitors center
images.title: Visitors Center
images.caption: The blue canon welcomes thousands of people to the visitors center.

images.altText: inside view of museum area of visitor center
images.title: Inside Museum
images.caption: Artifacts take you back over 200 years to explore American Indian life and the Battle of Horseshoe Bend

images.altText: blue canon sits on hill facing the battlefield
images.title: Canon on Gun Hill
images.caption: The King of Battle, the canon sits watch over the battlefield at a place in the park known as Gun Hill.

images.altText: sunlight peaking through the trees covering the nature trail
images.title: Nature Trail
images.caption: The beauty of nature calls and many visitors hike our nearly 3 mile trail through the park.

images.altText: aerial view of the horseshoe shaped bend of the Tallapoosa River
images.title: Horseshoe Bend
images.caption: Aerial view of what was called the "horses flat foot" shows where the park gets its name Horseshoe Bend.

images.altText: flat river, green trees lining banks, old bridge pier made of stones in river on left side of photo
images.title: Tallapoosa River and Miller's Bridge Piers
images.caption: Tallapoosa River and Miller's Bridge Piers

entranceFees.description: No charge to visit Booker T. Washington NM
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

properties.directionsInfo: The monument is located on AV 122 (Booker T. Washington Highway), 22 miles southeast of Roanoke, VA. From I-81 take I-581, then U.S. 220 south from Roanoke to VA 122. From the Blule Ridge Parkway take VA 43 south to VA 122. From Lynchburg take U.S. 460 west to VA 122.

entrancePasses.description: No Entrance Passes because park has free admission
entrancePasses.title: No Entrance Passes because park has free admission

properties.weatherInfo: Please contact the park at 540/721-2094 during inclement weather conditions to find out about closures.
properties.name: Booker T Washington
properties.description: Booker T. Washington was born a slave in April 1856 on the 207-acre farm of James Burroughs. After the Civil War, Washington became the first principal of Tuskegee Normal and Industrial School. Later as an adviser, author and orator, his past would influence his philosophies as the most influential African American of his era. Come explore his birthplace.

images.altText: Tobacco field being plowed by man with two draft horses
images.title: Tobacco, the cash crop
images.caption: The main crop on the plantation where Booker T. Washington was born was tobacco. This photograph shows a man with draft horses preparing to plow a field.

images.altText: Back side of kitchen cabin and smokehouse in snow with blue sky and trees
images.title: The reconstructed kitchen cabin and smoke house in the snow
images.caption: The reconstructed kitchen cabin and smoke house on the farm where Booker T. Washington was born.

images.altText: Four people dressed as enslaved people in front of the fireplace in cabin
images.title: Re-enactors in the reconstructed kitchen cabin at the Old Virginia Christmas Event
images.caption: Re-enactors portraying enslaved people in the reconstructed kitchen cabin where Booker T. Washington was born and lived for 9 years.

properties.directionsInfo:
By car:  Jewel Cave National Monument is located 13 miles west of Custer, South Dakota and 24 miles east of Newcastle, Wyoming on U.S. Highway 16. The Monument is about 54 miles from Rapid City, South Dakota via U.S. Highway 16 / 385.

By plane:  The nearest major airport, Rapid City Regional Airport, is 63 miles away.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring:  Rain or snow is common.  Temperatures vary.

Summer:  Rain is common in June.  Sunny and dry in July and August.  Temperatures range from 70 to 95 degrees Fahrenheit.

Fall:  Mild temperatures and occasional rain or snow showers.

Winter:  Cold temperatures are common with occasional snow.
properties.name: Jewel Cave
properties.description: Immerse yourself within the third longest cave in the world. With over 208 miles of mapped and surveyed passages, this underground wilderness appeals to human curiosity. Its splendor is revealed through fragile formations and glimpses of brilliant color. Its maze of passages lure explorers, and its scientific wealth remains a mystery. This resource is truly a jewel in the National Park Service.

images.altText: A cave explorer rests by large stalagmites that are covered in cave popcorn.
images.title: Pinnacles Expressway
images.caption: The logomites or popcorn stalagmites this explorer sits near are hollow and sometimes grow taller than a person.

images.altText: A cave explorer looks at a clear blue lake in Jewel Cave
images.title: Hourglass Lake
images.caption: Hourglass Lake was discovered in October 2015 and is the first sizable body of water to be found in Jewel Cave.

images.altText: A park ranger walks on the Scenic Tour Route in Jewel Cave
images.title: Inner Sanctum
images.caption: The Inner Sanctum is a large passage on the Jewel Cave Scenic Tour near the Torture Room

images.altText: A tour participant squeezes through a very small passage on the Wild Caving Tour
images.title: The Brain Drain
images.caption: The Brain Drain is approximately 8 inches high by 24 inches wide and is the tightest passage on the Wild Caving Tour.

images.altText: A park ranger stands in a medium-sized room in Jewel Cave
images.title: The Heavenly Room
images.caption: The Heavenly Room lies at the end of the Jewel Cave Historic Lantern Tour.

images.altText: These calcite crystals, called Nailhead Spar, are the jewels of Jewel Cave
images.title: Nailhead Spar
images.caption: These calcite crystals, called Nailhead Spar, are the jewels of Jewel Cave

emailAddresses.description: Supervisory Park Ranger- Interpretation.    Website and Social Media manager

entranceFees.description: No Entrance Fees
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Kaloko-Honokōhau National Historical Park is located on the west coast of the island of Hawai'i, approximately 3 miles south of the Keahole International Airport and 3 miles north of the town of Kailua-Kona, on the ocean side of Highway 19.

The visitor center, Hale Ho'okipa, is located half a mile north of the entrance to Honokōhau Harbor. The Kaloko road gate is located across the highway from the Kaloko New Industrial Park (across from the big yellow "Kona Trade Center" building).
properties.weatherInfo: The weather in the park is typically hot and sunny, with temperatures in the upper 80's.
properties.name: Kaloko-Honokōhau
properties.description: To survive in a hot and arid environment the native Hawaiians (kanaka maoli) used ancient fishing skills, including the building of fishponds, and the knowledge of the location of precious fresh water (wai) that flows into the many brackish pools throughout the park. The spirit of the people (poe) and the knowledge of the elders (kupuna) created a tradition of respect and reverence for this area.

images.altText: The rehabilitation of Kaloko fishpond started in 1998 and still continues today....
images.title: Kaloko Fishpond
images.caption: Kaloko Fishpond is the largest walled fishpond in the state (800 ft. long)

images.altText: Honu (sea turtles) are common on the beach in this area of the park
images.title: Ai'opio fishtrap
images.caption: Ai'opio fishtrap is on the south boundary of the park and is used frequently by visitors and for special events (annual children's cultural festival shown).

images.altText: wall construction
images.title: pu'uoina heiau
images.caption: Great skill was needed to build rock walls

images.altText: Hawaiian cultural festival
images.title: Kids working at station for Archeology game
images.caption: Fourth graders at Park's Cultural Festival

images.altText: Learning from park staff about plants
images.title: Plant activity for fourth graders at Park's Cultural Festival
images.caption: Fourth Graders learn about native plants at the park

images.altText: Making Hawaiian objects
images.title: Hands in Craft
images.caption: The detail of a Hawaiian artist

images.altText: Modern version of Ki'i Pohaku (Petroglyphs)!
images.title: Entrance to Petroglyph Boardwalk
images.caption: When you visit the Petroglyphs in the park you'll see this image in modern stone!

images.altText: Offering
images.title: Ho'okupu
images.caption: Offering during the time of Makahiki

addresses.line1: Visitor Center, Queen Ka'ahumanu Highway, south of 97 mile marker

phoneNumbers.description: General park contact number includes a phone tree for finding the employee you wish to contact. Callers may dial zero for the phone attendant. Voicemail is available for many of the extensions.

emailAddresses.description: General park information and specific questions will be received at this email address and answered by appropriate park staff.

properties.directionsInfo: Transportation is by private vehicle. The park is in Coolidge, Arizona, about an hour-long drive from either Phoenix or Tucson. From Interstate 10 take the Coolidge exits and follow the signs to the park entrance.
properties.weatherInfo: Summer daytime temperatures frequently exceed 100 degrees F. Winter temperatures range from the 60's to the 80's F. Spring and fall are warm and dry, with highs in the 80's and 90's F. During summer months, be prepared for hot temperatures. Protective clothing, hats, sunscreen and personal water containers are highly recommended. BE AWARE: Walls of dirt and debris, usually miles wide and thousands of feet high, are pushed across dry desert terrain by high winds, causing dust to engulf highways.
properties.name: Casa Grande Ruins
properties.description: Explore the mystery and complexity of an extended network of communities and irrigation canals. An Ancestral Sonoran Desert People's farming community and "Great House" are preserved at Casa Grande Ruins. Whether the Casa Grande was a gathering place for the Desert People or simply a waypoint marker in an extensive system of canals and trading partners is but part of the mystique of the Ruins.

images.altText: eathern building under modern roof structure
images.title: Great House
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande Ruins has existed for over 600 years.

images.altText: earthern ruins including the Great House and other parts
images.title: Great House from the South
images.caption: A highlight of Compound A is the Great House but it is not the only earthern building to intrigue visitors.

images.altText: earthern Great House with its roof among desert plants
images.title: Great House in the Sonoran Desert
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande Ruins is a sentinel of the desert.

images.altText: earthern Great House standing out in the Sonoran Desert plants
images.title: Morning from the Northeast
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande may have been an orientation point for travelers and traders.

images.altText: historic copper sign with Great House and saguaro flanking
images.title: Historic Sign
images.caption: The park's historic copper sign was relocated with roadway changes, and now sits near the visitor center.

images.altText: child, adult female, adult male American Indian actors in costume making jewelry in movie shoot
images.title: Actors Recreating Jewelry
images.caption: In this scene from the park movie, actors demonstrate jewelry making as done in ancestral times.

entranceFees.description: The fee allows visitors to experience the fort and its rooms and meet and visit with period clothed interpreters.  It is charge on a per person basis.  Payment allows the holder to visit the site for one week from date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Bent's Old Fort Living History Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 109 north 1 mile to Colorado Highway 194, then east on Colorado Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.
properties.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures are are often in the high 90s and low 100s. Weather is generally fair in the fall and spring. Winter temperatures can be below freezing. Most of the fort is unheated and does not have modern cooling systems, so dress accordingly.
properties.name: Bent's Old Fort
properties.description: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site features a reconstructed 1840s adobe fur trading post on the mountain branch of the Santa Fe Trail where traders, trappers, travelers, and the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes came together in peaceful terms for trade. Today, living historians recreate the sights, sounds, and smells of the past with guided tours, demonstrations and special events.

images.altText: Bent's Fort
images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.caption: Bent's Old Fort was the only permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and Santa Fe.

images.altText: Fur trapper in camp
images.title: Fur trapper explains the work of the 1830s.
images.caption: Special events bring the past alive with encampments, fort trade and Plains Indian life.

images.altText: Plains Indian trade in plaza
images.title: A Lakota warrior barters with the traders in the fort plaza
images.caption: Trade with a Lakota warrior for trade goods from around the world.

images.altText: HIkers follow behind the fort's wagon on the Santa Fe Trail
images.title: Hiking the Santa Fe Trail
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail Encampment features a hike with the fort's wagon down the original Santa Fe Trail.

images.altText: Cooking in fort kitchen
images.title: Open hearth cooking in the fort kitchen
images.caption: Buffalo meat is broil in the reflector oven for the fort employees as was done in the 1840s.

images.altText: Swivel cannon firing
images.title: Swivel cannon is fired using 18th century drill
images.caption: The fort's security depended on its ability to resist attack.

properties.fullName: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: Hohokam Pima is NOT open to the public. Attempts to visit the area are considered trespassing and may result in fines or other legal action.
entranceFees.title: No Fees, No Services, NOT OPEN TO PUBLIC

properties.directionsInfo: Please do not attempt to visit this area. The park was not established beyond an administrative action. There is nothing to see and it is trespassing to wander Gila River Indian Community lands.
properties.weatherInfo: Park is not open to the public. Desert landscape, with all its usual inhabitants, is not friendly to trespassers.
properties.name: Hohokam Pima
properties.description: The "Monument" is located on the Gila River Indian Reservation and is under tribal ownership. The Gila River Indian Community has decided not to open the extremely sensitive area to the public. There is no park brochure, passport stamp, picture stamp or other free literature available.

images.altText: two rangers in the distance in desert nothingness
images.title: Pima 1
images.caption: No features, no services, no markers, no signs, NO PUBLIC ACCESS

images.altText: dirt and desert scrub plants in featureless area
images.title: PIMA 2
images.caption: Backfilled old archeological dig, NOT OPEN TO PUBLIC, nothing to see

images.altText: tiny pottery sherds on desert floor
images.title: Pima 3
images.caption: Illegal to collect any artifact, plant, rock. TRESPASSING to atempt a visit.

images.altText: telephone pole, female ranger, dip in rather featureless desert
images.title: PIMA 4
images.caption: Park is NOT open to the public. No special features to view, no signs, no tours, no roads.

images.altText: desert scrub brush and a lumpy hill of tan dirt
images.title: Pima 5
images.caption: It is too easy to get lost, and is trespassing besides. Please do NOT attempt to visit the site.

addresses.line1: c/o Casa Grande Ruins National Monument

addresses.city: No facilities, no city, no signs

addresses.line2: Park is on private Gila River Indian Community Lands

phoneNumbers.description: Park information.  Phones are answered 7 days a week.  Hours are 8:00 - 5:00 October through May, 8:00 - 10:00 June through mid-August and 8:00 - 9:00 mid-August through September.  All times are Mountain Time.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Mount Rushmore National Memorial. However, fees are required to park at the memorial.
entranceFees.title: Mount Rushmore Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
Parking fee is for private passenger vehicles, valid for one year from date of purchase.  Parking fee for Seniors, 62 and older, is $5 and Active Duty Military parking is free.  

Annual Pass, Annual Pass - Military, Senior Pass, Access Pass and Every Kid In A Park Pass do not apply.
entranceFees.title: Mount Rushmore Parking Fee - private vehicles

entranceFees.description: Valid for 24 hours from time of purchase.  Annual Pass, Annual Pass - Military, Senior Pass, Access Pass and Every Kid In A Park Pass do not apply.
entranceFees.title: Mount Rushmore Parking Fee - Commercial Bus

entranceFees.description: Valid for 24 hours from time of purchase.  Annual Pass, Annual Pass - Military, Senior Pass, Access Pass and Every Kid In A Park Pass do not apply.
