properties.directionsInfo: Visitors traveling by car from the East use Exit 61 off I-90 follow signs. Coming from the West use exit 57 exit at Rapid City and follow U.S. Highway 16 southwest to Keystone and then Highway 244 to Mount Rushmore. Visitors coming from the south should follow Highway 385 north to Highway 244, which is the road leading to the memorial.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather at Mount Rushmore can be highly variable in any season.  Summer high temperatures range from 70 to 100 degrees Fahrenheit.  Fall high temperatures range from 45 to 80 degrees Fahrenheit.  Winter high temperatures range from 20 to 40 degrees Fahrenheit.  Spring high temperatures range from 30 to 70 degrees Fahrenheit.  July and August are the warmest months, December and January the coldest.  March and April receive the most snow, while May and June receive the most rain.
properties.name: Mount Rushmore
properties.description: Majestic figures of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln, surrounded by the beauty of the Black Hills of South Dakota, tell the story of the birth, growth, development and preservation of this country. From the history of the first inhabitants to the diversity of America today, Mount Rushmore brings visitors face to face with the rich heritage we all share.

images.altText: Visitors walking along the Avenue of Flags with Mount Rushmore in the background.
images.title: Mount Rushmore and the Avenue of Flags
images.caption: Visitors walking along the Avenue of Flags with Mount Rushmore in the background.

images.altText: Mount Rushmore viewed from a distance through ponderosa pine trees.
images.title: Mount Rushmore Through the Trees
images.caption: Mount Rushmore viewed from a distance through ponderosa pine trees.

images.altText: Closeup photo of Mount Rushmore under a bright blue sky.
images.title: Closeup of Mount Rushmore
images.caption: Closeup photo of Mount Rushmore under a bright blue sky.

images.altText: Mount Rushmore above the talus slope, where rock removed from the mountain fell.
images.title: Mount Rushmore With Talus Slope
images.caption: Mount Rushmore above the talus slope, where rock removed from the mountain fell.

images.altText: Mount Rushmore illuminated under a darkening evening sky.
images.title: Mount Rushmore At Night
images.caption: Mount Rushmore illuminated under a darkening evening sky.

entranceFees.description: Entrance to the park, including all facilities and public programs.
entranceFees.title: Fort Necessity NB Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: The main unit of the park is located 11 miles east of Uniontown, Pennsylvania on U.S. Highway 40. The visitor center, reconstructed Fort Necessity, Mount Washington Tavern and picnic area are located in the main unit of the park.
properties.weatherInfo:
Weather varies considerably within each season.  Be prepared with layered clothing. Precipitation is common throughout the year.
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 25°F to 70°F.  On average, May is the wettest month.
Summer: Temperatures usually range from 50°F to 80°F. July is the warmest month.
Fall: Temperatures usually range from 30°F to 70°F. Fall foliage is at its peak around mid-October. 
Winter: Temperatures range from 15°F to 40°F.  January is the coldest month.
properties.name: Fort Necessity
properties.description: The battle at Fort Necessity in the summer of 1754 was the opening action of the French and Indian War. This war was a clash of British, French and American Indian cultures. It ended with the removal of French power from North America. The stage was set for the American Revolution.

images.altText: cabin and stockade casting shadows on the snow
images.title: Fort Necessity in Winter
images.caption: Fort Necessity National Battlefield is open year round.

images.altText: Fort Necessity and the Great Meadow with trail and tree in the foreground
images.title: Fort Necessity
images.caption: Fort Necessity was the site of George Washington's first military experience at the beginning of the French and Indian War

entranceFees.description: The John Muir National Historic Site and Mount Wanda are free to visit.
entranceFees.title: John Muir National Historic Site

properties.directionsInfo: Please visit our main website for specific directions to our park. You may call the John Muir Visitor Center for additional information.

entrancePasses.description: Passes are not require and are not sold at this location.
entrancePasses.title: John Muir National Historic Site

properties.weatherInfo:
The Mediterranean climate of Martinez features hot, dry summers with lower temperatures near 60º F and upper temperatures near 100º F. The heat gives way to cool, rainy winters with lows near 45º F and highs near 75º F. Fall and spring can bring rain and temperatures from 55-80º F.

March to April: wet/dry, 60-80º F
May to September: very dry, 60-100º+ F
October to November: dry/wet, 55-80º F
December to February: wet, 45-75º F
properties.name: John Muir
properties.description: John Muir played many roles in his life, all of which helped him succeed in his role as an advocate for Nature. As America’s most famous naturalist and conservationist, Muir fought to protect the wild places he loved, places we can still visit today. Muir’s writings convinced the U.S. government to protect Yosemite, Sequoia, Grand Canyon and Mt. Rainier as national parks.

images.altText: John Muir Home at the John Muir National Historic Site
images.title: John Muir Home at the John Muir National Historic Site
images.caption: John Muir Home at the John Muir National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: There are no fees associated with Upper Delaware S&RR.
entranceFees.title: There are no fees associated with Upper Delaware S&RR.

properties.directionsInfo: See complete directions on Upper Delaware S&RR's webpage.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from lows of 26 F to highs of 80 F with average rainfall of 5 inches.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from lows of 55 F to highs of 85 F with average rainfall of 4 inches. 

Fall: Temperatures usually range from lows of 30 F to highs of 83F. Fall foliage is at its peak sometime in October as daily mountain temperatures vary frequently and influence the change.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from lows of 15 F to highs of 49 F.
properties.name: Upper Delaware
properties.description: Canoe through rapids and quiet pools as the Delaware River winds its way through a valley of swiftly changing scenery or fish amid rolling hills and riverfront villages in one of the finest fishing rivers in the northeastern United States. The clean water of the Delaware, the last major undammed river in the eastern United States, supports a healthy ecosystem and offers tranquility and excitement.

images.altText: a view of the Delaware River
images.title: Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.caption: A view of Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River

images.altText: a Park Ranger shows children the wonders of nature
images.title: Park Ranger - Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.caption: A Park Ranger shows children the wonders of nature

images.altText: a rocky shore of the Delaware River
images.title: Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.caption: Geological wonders of Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River

images.altText: the Zane Grey Museum at Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.title: Zane Grey Museum - Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.caption: The Zane Grey Museum at Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River

images.altText: Roebling's Delaware Aqueduct at Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.title: Roebling's Delaware Aqueduct - Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.caption: Roebling's Delaware Aqueduct at Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River

images.altText: park ranger canoes on the shore at Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.title: Lackawaxen, PA River Access at Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.caption: Park Ranger canoes on the shore at Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River

entranceFees.description: The daily parking fee allows a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) to park in a designated parking lot of the park during regular park hours for one day. Proof of payment of the daily parking fee is a Daily Park Pass which may be obtained at the fee station located at all parking areas. The pass must be placed on the dashboard of your vehicle making sure the face of the pass is visible from the outside. Valid America The Beautiful Passes are also valid for parking in the park.
entranceFees.title: Daily Parking Fee

entranceFees.description: The annual parking fee allows a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) to park in any designated parking area of the park during regular park hours for one year. Proof of payment of the annual parking fee is an Annual Park Pass, available on line from Pay.gov at https://www.pay.gov/public/form/start/11655368/. The pass must be hung from the inside rear-view mirror, or placed on the dashboard, of your vehicle. A valid America The Beautiful Pass are is also valid for parking in the park.
entranceFees.title: Annual Parking Fee

properties.directionsInfo: To find the Island Ford Visitor Center enter the physical address, 8800 Roberts Drive, Sandy Springs, GA 30350, into your GPS unit or your favorite map software. Once you have arrived at the park entrance turn onto Island Ford Parkway and follow the signs to the park headquarters.

entrancePasses.description: The annual parking fee allows a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) to park in any designated parking lot of the park during regular park hours for one year. Proof of payment of the annual parking fee is an Annual Park Pass, available on line from Pay.gov at https://www.pay.gov/public/form/start/11655368/. The pass must be hung from the inside rear-view mirror, or placed on the dashboard, of your vehicle. A valid America The Beautiful Pass are is also valid for parking in the park
entrancePasses.title: Annual Park Pass

entrancePasses.description: A daily parking fee allows a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) to park in a designated parking lot of the park during regular park hours for one day. Proof of payment of the daily parking fee is a Daily Park Pass which may be obtained at the fee station located at all parking areas. The pass must be placed on the dashboard of your vehicle making sure the face of the pass is visible from the outside. Valid America The Beautiful Passes are also valid for parking in the park.
entrancePasses.title: Daily Park Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Summers typically consist of long spells of warm, humid weather. Average highs are in the lower 90's and overnight lows range from the upper 60's to lower 70's. 

Winters are more variable with highs averaging from the mid 50's to lower 60's while the lows average in the mid 30's. Oftentimes, stretches of mild weather will alternate with cold spells.

Spring and Autumn seasons are characterized by much variability from day to day and from year to year.
properties.name: Chattahoochee River
properties.description: Today the river valley attracts us for so many reasons. Take a solitary walk to enjoy nature’s display, raft leisurely through the rocky shoals with friends, fish the misty waters as the sun comes up, or have a picnic on a Sunday afternoon. Get Outdoors and experience your Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area as you have never done before.

images.altText: Two adult Great Blue Herons stand watch over their 3 young chicks in the nest.
images.title: Family Time
images.caption: Great Blue Herons are plentyful along the river. Look towards the tree tops along the river to spot their nest. If you're lucky the whole will be home.

images.altText: Park ranger showing a group of school children the critter on his arm.
images.title: Look Closely
images.caption: School children from the city enjoy visiting the park on a ranger-led hike.

images.altText: Stone ruins of the Marietta Paper Mill surrounded by lush green vegatation.
images.title: Marietta Paper Mill
images.caption: All that is left of the Marietta Paper Mill is a few stone walls in the woods. Hike to the ruins and you'll get a closeup of Sope Creek that was harnessed by the mills.

images.altText: Angler in waders landing a fish using a landing net.
images.title: Landing A Rainbow
images.caption: Fishing the Chattahoochee River can be a great way to spend an afternoon out of the office or as a diversion from rush hour traffic.

images.altText: Trail heading off under a canopy of trees.
images.title: Inviting Trail
images.caption: Trails along the Chattahoochee River are calling you to visit.

entranceFees.description:
An entry fee is charged per person, ages 16 and older, ages 15 and under enter the park for free. The entrance ticket covers the number of individuals entering Point Park and is valid for 7 days from the time of purchase. Entrance tickets must be purchased at the fee station at the Point Park gate.    

**Annual Passes, Volunteer Passes, Senior Passes, and Access Passes are accepted at Point Park (these passes cannot be scanned in the fee machines)**
entranceFees.title: Point Park (Lookout Mountain Battlefield) Entrance Fee - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-75, take exit 350 onto Battlefield Parkway (GA HWY 2) and continue to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway and LaFayette Road. Turn left onto LaFayette Road and continue for approximately 1 mile. The visitor center will be on the right. 

From I-24, take exit 180 onto Rossville Boulevard (US HWY 27). Continue south to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway. Drive through the intersection, continuing on the LaFayette Road. The visitor center will be on the right.

entrancePasses.description:
Visitors who purchase a Point Park Annual Pass can visit Point Park on an unlimited basis throughout the year. The pass allows entry to the park for the pass owner and three other individuals. 

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Point Park Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description:
A lifetime pass for citizens or permanent residents of the US, age 62 or older. One person can sign the pass. 

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Lifetime Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description:
An annual pass valid 12 months from month of purchase. Two people can sign the pass. 

*current US Military Members and 4th graders are eligible for different annual passes*

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description:
A lifetime pass for citizens or permanent residents of the US who have a permanent disability, regardless of age. One person can sign the pass.

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description:
A yearly pass for citizens or permanent residents of the US, age 62 or older. One person can sign the pass. Four annual Senior Passes purchased in consecutive years can be traded in for a lifetime pass.

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description:
A yearly pass for students in the 4th grade. You must complete the activities at www.everkidinapark.gov and present a printed voucher to be exchanged for a pass. 

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: 4th Grade Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The climate in northern Georgia is generally temperate. Short, cool winters give relief from hot summers. Most visitors enjoy this area during long, mild fall and spring seasons.
properties.name: Chickamauga & Chattanooga
properties.description: In 1863, Union and Confederate forces fought for control of Chattanooga, known as the "Gateway to the Deep South." The Confederates were victorious at nearby Chickamauga in September. However, renewed fighting in Chattanooga that November provided Union troops victory and control of the city. After the fighting, a Confederate soldier ominously wrote, "This...is the death-knell of the Confederacy."

images.altText: Kelley Cabin
images.title: Kelley Cabin on Chickamauga Battlefield
images.caption: Living Historians are seen in Kelley Field and in the distance at the Kelley Cabin during the 150th anniversary

images.altText: Illinois Monument
images.title: Illinois Monument at Bragg Reservation on Missionary Ridge
images.caption: Silent sentinels stand on the Illinois Monument at the Bragg Reservation on Missionary Ridge Battlefield

images.altText: Cannon on Lookout Mountain
images.title: Cannon on Lookout Mountain
images.caption: As the sun sets on Lookout Mountain, a lone cannon guards the valley below.

images.altText: Lookout Mountain and the National Cemetery
images.title: Lookout Mountain and the National Cemetery
images.caption: The graves of fallen soldiers from Chickamauga to present dot the landscape in Chattanooga as Lookout Mountain looms in the background

images.altText: Living Historians on Orchard Knob
images.title: Living Historians on Orchard Knob in Chattanooga
images.caption: Confederate soldiers stand watch from Orchard Knob during the 150th anniversary of the Battles for Chattanooga in 2013.

entranceFees.description: Coronado National Memorial is a Fee Free park, no entrance fee is required.
entranceFees.title: Coronado National Memorial Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: From the city of Sierra Vista continue south on Hwy 92 about 20 miles and turn right onto S. Coronado Memorial Drive. Follow Coronado Memorial Drive (it will turn into E Montezuma Canyon Rd) 5 miles to the Visitor Center.
properties.weatherInfo:
Though the park shares a border with our southern neighbors, the elevation and the mountain ecosystem keep Coronado National Memorial relatively cool in the summer, and winter can bring snow. 
Summers are warm, with daytime temps in the 90s F (32-37 C) and low humidity in May, June, and July. The summer rainy season (monsoon) is between late June and early September. Monsoon thunderstorms can cause flash floods. Winter temps can fall below freezing at night, with highs 40-60 F (4-15 C).
properties.name: Coronado
properties.description: It was a journey of conquest filled with exploration, wonder - and cruelty. Inspired by tales of vast cities of gold, 339 European soldiers and hundreds of Aztec allies embarked on an epic journey through arid deserts and rugged mountains. They encountered rich traditions and brought new technologies. The resulting collision and combination of cultures reverberates today.

images.altText: Pink morning glories with mountain and grasslands
images.title: Pink-throated morning glories in the grasslands
images.caption: Each year the pink-throated morning glories bloom during monsoon season in the grasslands

images.altText: Agave stalks and wildflowers with mountains in the distance
images.title: Wildflowers and Montezuma Peak

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate I-95, take Exit 99 onto Interstate I-16 East (James L Gillis Memorial Hwy) for 7 miles.
Take Exit 164A onto Interstate I-516 East toward US-80 East.
Take Exit 3 (US-17 S/US-80 E) toward US-80 East. 
Turn left onto Ocean Highway, Ogeechee Rd (US-17 N, US-80 East). 
Bear right onto West Victory Drive (US-80 East).
Continue on US-80 East for 13 miles.

GPS Coordinates for Fort Pulaski National Monument:

N32° 01.680 W080° 53.525

entrancePasses.description: The Fort Pulaski Annual Pass covers the pass holder and three additional people for admission to the monument for one full year.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Pulaski Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Savannah has a humid sub tropical climate with over two hundred days of sunshine each year. Summers are typically hot, bright and humid with afternoon thunderstorms common. Temperatures often range from the lower 70s to the mid 90s F. Spring and autumn can be quite pleasant with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s into the 80s F. The winter months are usually dry. Temperatures can be cooler than one would expect, ranging from the upper 30s through the 60s F generally, though sudden cold snaps can occur.
properties.name: Fort Pulaski
properties.description: For much of the 19th century, masonry fortifications were the United States’ main defense against overseas enemies. However, during the Civil War, new technology proved its superiority to these forts. The Union army used rifled cannon and compelled the Confederate garrison inside Fort Pulaski to surrender. The siege was a landmark experiment in the history of military science and invention.

images.altText: The white masonry Cockspur Island lighthouse sits in the Savannah River.
images.title: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse
images.caption: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse still stands guard over the south channel of the Savannah River and Fort Pulaski.

images.altText: The red masonry walls of Fort Pulaski still show battle damage over 150 years later.
images.title: The Battered Walls of Fort Pulaski
images.caption: A walk along the outside of Fort Pulaski reveals damaged walls over 150 years after the Civil War.

images.altText: The brick of the fort glow in the late afternoon light. The arches inside the fort reveal a cannon i
images.title: The Casemates of a Fort
images.caption: Fort Pulaski shows off its classic arched architecture and cannon.

images.altText: A great blue heron stands watch on top of the fort's brick walls.
images.title: The Sentinel
images.caption: A great blue heron stands on the top of Fort Pulaski like a lonely sentinel.

images.altText: Two women dressed in mid nineteenth century civilian attire watch through looking glasses
images.title: The Ladies of a Fort
images.caption: Volunteer living historians play an important role for the National Park Service and Fort Pulaski National Monument.

images.altText: The night sky is illuminated as a cannon fires at Fort Pulaski
images.title: Night Cannon Firing at Fort Pulaski
images.caption: Artillery demonstrations are an important part of the interpretation program at Fort Pulaski.

entranceFees.description:
The motorcycle fee admits the driver and one passenger. The fee will allow visitors access to all resources to the public; including auto tours, walking trails, films, exhibit area, ranger guided programs, other seasonal activities. 

If visitors have any of the America the Beautiful Inter-agency passes, these will cover the pass holder and anyone that is in their personal vehicle. 

During the colder winter season the per vehicle fee is reduced and some activities may be unavailable.
entranceFees.title: Golden Spike Motorcycle Fee

entranceFees.description:
The per vehicle fee covers all occupants in a single private vehicle. The fee will allow visitors access to all resources to the public; including auto tours, walking trails, films, exhibit area, ranger guided programs, other seasonal activities. 

If visitors have any of the America the Beautiful Inter-agency passes, these will cover the pass holder and anyone that is in their personal vehicle. 

During the warmer summer season usually all of the resources are available. Check with our staff for times
entranceFees.title: Golden Spike Private Vehicle Fee

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car. This pass is typically used for bicyclists, and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: Per Person Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate 15 headed north, take exit 365 via Utah State Highway 13/83; approximately 32 miles west of Brigham City.

From Interstate 15 headed south, take exit 40 via Utah State Highway 102 to highway 83; approximately 32 miles west of Tremonton.

From Interstate 84 headed south, take exit 26 via Utah Sate Highway 83; approximately 22 miles form Howell.

entrancePasses.description:
This is an annual pass that covers entrance fees at Golden Spike National Historical Park for the pass holder and occupants within a single noncommercial vehicle OR the pass holder and three persons (16 and older) where per person fees apply. This pass is available to anyone 16 or older.

The Agencies are NOT responsible for misplaced, lost or stolen cards. 

The pass can be signed by two pass holders.
entrancePasses.title: Golden Spike National Historical Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Golden Spike National Historical Park is located in a high desert environment on the north end of the Great Salt Lake. The lake and channeling of winds through the valley, where the site is located, can cause very unique weather conditions. The temperatures can reach over 100 degrees in the summer and into single digits in the winter. Winds can cause severe cold in the winter. Visitors are recommended to check forecasts before coming to our site and come prepared for changing weather conditions.
properties.name: Golden Spike
properties.description: One of the greatest technological achievements of the 19th century, the completion of the first transcontinental railroad across the United States. Visitors to the park can see the location of the Last Spike Site, 1869 railroad construction features, walk or drive on the original railroad grade, and get an up close view of Victorian era replica locomotives.

images.altText: The Flag flies over Golden Spike National Historical Park's Visitor Center, with trees and monument
images.title: Golden Spike National Historical Park Visitor Center
images.caption: Golden Spike's Visitor Center is the best the best place to start your exploration of this unique piece of American History.

images.altText: An exact replica of the Golden Spike
images.title: The Golden Spike
images.caption: The original solid gold spike was only on site for the ceremony for a brief moment, but the symbolism of the engineering feat lives on

images.altText: Reenactors dressed in period costume stand in front of the replica steam locomotive #119
images.title: Re-enactment of the Driving of the Last Spike Ceremony
images.caption: Thousands of visitors connect with the history of the site during re-enactments of the ceremony that are offered Saturdays and holidays throughout the summer

images.altText: The Big Fill is a 400 foot long 80 foot high mound of packed earth that bridged a ravine
images.title: The Big Fill
images.caption: Visitors can explore fifteen miles of the historic grade that was prepared for track by the two railroad companies

images.altText: Two replica victorian age steam locomotives face each other on the original railroad grade
images.title: Replica Locomotives Jupiter and #119
images.caption: Connect with the history by viewing the site's replica steam locomotives in action

entranceFees.description: It is free to visit Kings Mountain National Military Park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Kings Mountain National Military Park is located on South Carolina Highway 216.
From Greenville, SC travel on I-85 North to NC Exit #2. Turn right onto Hwy 216.
From Charlotte, NC travel on I- 85 South to NC Exit #2. Turn left onto Hwy 216.
properties.weatherInfo: Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.
properties.name: Kings Mountain
properties.description: Thomas Jefferson called it "The turn of the tide of success." The battle of Kings Mountain, fought October 7th, 1780, was an important American victory during the Revolutionary War. The battle was the first major patriot victory to occur after the British invasion of Charleston, SC in May 1780. The park preserves the site of this important battle.

images.altText: An oval gravestone for Maj Patrick Ferguson is in front of his stone covered grave.
images.title: Ferguson's Grave
images.caption: Major Patrick Ferguson's Grave

images.altText: A patriot rifleman stands ready to fire his weapon.
images.title: Patriot Rifleman
images.caption: A patriot rifleman stands ready to fire his weapon.

images.altText: Snow covers the ground in front of the Centennial Monument.
images.title: Centennial Monument in Snow
images.caption: Centennial Monument in the Snow

images.altText: The US Monument is surrounded by trees that are turning orange and yellow.
images.title: US Monument in Fall
images.caption: US Monument in the Fall

images.altText: Militia reenactors march with weapons on their shoulders as they prepare to demonstrate them.
images.title: Militia Marching with Arms
images.caption: Militia reenactors march with weapons on their shoulders as they prepare to give a firing demonstration.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees to visit this National Park nor is a fee to visit the Lewis and Clark Visitor Center adjacent to Gavins Point Dam. However, our state park partners do charge.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The National Park Service headquarters is located at 508 East Second Street in Yankton, South Dakota.
properties.weatherInfo: Rapid weather changes are common along the Missouri National Recreational River corridor. Variations from season to season and from year to year are great. Characteristics of the climate are hot summers and cold winters. Sunshine is abundant, particularly in the summer months. Average annual rainfall is 25 inches. Thunderstorms can be dangerous and visitors should be prepared for them, especially from June until late August. Winter snowfall averages 34 inches annually.
properties.name: Missouri
properties.description: Imagine a 100-mile stretch of North America's longest river, a vestige of the untamed American West. The Missouri National Recreational River is where imagination meets reality. Two free flowing stretches of the Missouri make up the National Park. Relive the past by making an exploration of the wild, untamed and mighty river that continues to flow as nature intended.

images.altText: Aerial view of the Missouri River and surrounding landscape.
images.title: Aerial of Missouri River
images.caption: Aerial view of the Missouri River and surrounding landscape.

images.altText: Sunken remains of the North Alabama steamboat appears only when water is low.
images.title: Remains of a sunken steamboat in Missouri River.
images.caption: Sunken remains of the North Alabama steamboat appears only when water is low.

images.altText: Scenic view of Missouri River on a sunny day
images.title: View of Missouri River
images.caption: Scenic view of Missouri River on a sunny day

images.altText: Park educational trailer
images.title: Park trailer
images.caption: Educational trailer with painted pictures

entranceFees.description: Morristown National Historical Park does not charge admission. All park grounds and facilities are free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Morristown National Historical Park is the easiest to see by car. We have 4 different locations throughout the greater Morristown area. Washington's Headquarters Museum and Ford Mansion as well as Jockey Hollow Visitor Center and Wick House are the two main areas of the Park. Detailed directions are on the park website. They are the best places to start and Rangers can give you directions to the Cross Estate Gardens/New Jersey Brigade Area and Fort Nonsense Area of the park.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather in this part of New Jersey is typical of the mid-Atlantic region.
properties.name: Morristown
properties.description: Morristown National Historical Park commemorates the sites of General Washington and the Continental army’s winter encampment of December 1779 to June 1780, where they survived through what would be the coldest winter on record. The park also maintains a museum & library collection related to the encampments & George Washington, as well as items relating to pre- and post-Revolutionary America.

images.altText: The front facade of the Ford Mansion in summer.
images.title: Ford Mansion
images.caption: The front facade of the Ford Mansion in summer.

images.altText: The Wick House surrounded by colorful fall leaves
images.title: Wick House
images.caption: The Wick House in the fall.

images.altText: The front facade of the Washington's Headquarters Museum
images.title: Washington's Headquarters Museum
images.caption: The front facade of the Washington's Headquarters Museum, which was designed in 1933 to look similar to Washington's Mt Vernon home.

images.altText: Four replica wooden soldier huts on a hillside in winter
images.title: Replica Soldier Huts in Jockey Hollow
images.caption: These replica soldier huts represent the location of the Pennsylvania Brigade encampment site in Jockey Hollow

images.altText: The Cross Estate mansion in the springtime
images.title: Cross Estate Mansion and Gardens
images.caption: The Cross Estate property was the site of the New Jersey Brigade winter encampement in 1779-1780. Today the encampment site is preserved while the estate is host to several beautiful gardens.

entranceFees.description: No fees or reservations are required to visit the national park.
entranceFees.title: Fees or reservations

properties.directionsInfo: The visitor center is located in the village of Pago Pago, across from the Pago Way Service Station. The national park is located in the villages of Vatia, Pago Pago, Fagasa, Afono (on Tutuila Island), Fitiuta, Faleasao (on Ta'u Island), and Ofu Island

entrancePasses.description: Since there are no fees or reservations required, entrance passes are all waived.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
American Samoa is in the South Pacific Ocean, between the Equator and the Tropic of Capricorn. A tropical climate prevails with warm or hot temperatures year-round and high humidity. Rain showers are frequent and can last only for a few minutes or all-day.

The average annual rainfall is 125-inches in the dryer areas to as much as 300-inches in the highest mountains. Tropical storms are more prevalent during the long, wet summer season (October -May) and a slightly cooler and drier season (June-September)
properties.name: National Park of American Samoa
properties.description:
The National Park of American Samoa welcomes you into the heart of the South Pacific, to a world of sights, sounds, and experiences that you will find in no other national park in the United States. 

Enjoy this unique national park and the welcoming people of American Samoa. We are here to protect its rich culture and natural resources. Come explore them with us!

images.altText: Tuafanua Trail
images.title: Back side of Pola Island from Tuafanua Trail
images.caption: Pola Island rises over 400 feet straight out of the ocean off Tutuila. A short walk from Vatia village, Pola is an ideal nesting site for many species of seabirds.

images.altText: Ta'u Island
images.title: Ta'u Island
images.caption: Si'u Point is a good place to view the south coast of Ta'u. some of the tallest sea cliffs in the world stairstep over 3,000 feet to the summit of Lata Mountain.

images.altText: Ofu Island
images.title: Ofu Island
images.caption: With a secluded sandy beach and fringing reef, Ofu unit of the park is an ideal place to snorkel or simply enjoy the solitude. The island of Olosega rises in the distance.

images.altText: King Fisher bird
images.title: King Fisher bird
images.caption: Birds are the most abundant and diverse animals in American Samoa, as they are on most oceanic islands.

properties.directionsInfo: GPS: Lat: 35.139 Long: -106.711 From Interstate 40, take the Unser Blvd. exit (#154) proceed north 3 miles to Western Trail. Turn left or west onto Western Trail and follow road to the Visitor Information Center parking lot. From Interstate 25, take the Paseo del Norte exit (#232) and proceed west to Coors Road exit south (must be in center lane to veer left at the Y). Proceed south on Coors Road to Western Trail. properties.weatherInfo: Altitude approx. 5000 ft. Usually sunny and dry, with low relative humidity. Winter temperatures range from 45 to 50 degrees F. Summer temperatures range from 88-99 degrees F. 278 days of sunshine per year. Spring can be windy with 20 to 30 mph sustained winds which can produce periods of blowing sand and dust. For current weather forecast, Google Albuquerque weather.
properties.name: Petroglyph
properties.description: Petroglyph National Monument protects one of the largest petroglyph sites in North America, featuring designs and symbols carved onto volcanic rocks by Native Americans and Spanish settlers 400 to 700 years ago. These images are a valuable record of cultural expression and hold profound spiritual significance for contemporary Native Americans and for the descendants of the early Spanish settlers.

images.altText: Mammal petroglyph along the Mesa Point Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.
images.title: Desert Mammal petroglyph
images.caption: Mammal petroglyph along the Mesa Point Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.

images.altText: Petroglyph of a macaw parrot along the Macaw Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.
images.title: Macaw petroglyph
images.caption: Petroglyph of a macaw parrot along the Macaw Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.

images.altText: Petroglyph imagery of a coyote and rattlesnake in Rinconada Canyon.
images.title: Coyote and Rattlesnake watching over Rinconada Canyon
images.caption: Petroglyph imagery of a coyote and rattlesnake in Rinconada Canyon.

images.altText: Petroglyph panel of sheep grazing in Rinconada Canyon.
images.title: Grazing Sheep in Rinconada Canyon
images.caption: Petroglyph panel of sheep grazing in Rinconada Canyon.

images.altText: Winter scene of snow covered cinder cones at the Volcanoes Day Use Area.
images.title: Snow Dusted Cinder Cones
images.caption: Winter scene of snow covered cinder cones at the Volcanoes Day Use Area.

entranceFees.description: There is not entry fee.
entranceFees.title: Presidio of San Francisco

properties.directionsInfo: The Presidio lies at the north end of San Francisco at the south end of the Golden Gate Bridge. It can be reached from the north by crossing the Golden Gate Bridge and taking the first exit from Highways 1 and 101; from the east by way of Lombard Street (Highway 101); and from the south via Highway 1 and exiting just before the bridge.
properties.weatherInfo: The weather at the Presidio is typically cool and quite variable from location to location. The summer is often foggy and cool, so a light coat or sweater is appropriate year-round.
properties.name: Presidio of San Francisco
properties.description: For 218 years, the Presidio served as an army post for three nations. World and local events, from military campaigns to World Fairs and earthquakes, left their mark. Come enjoy the history and the natural beauty of the Presidio. Explore centuries of architecture. Reflect in a national cemetery. Walk along an historic airfield, through forests or to beaches, and admire spectacular vistas.

images.altText: Rows of grave markers in the green grass of the cemetery as light shafts through misty trees.
images.title: San Francisco National Cemetery
images.caption: San Francisco National Cemetery in the Presidio offers a place to contemplate service to your country.

images.altText: Rocky bluffs above the blue ocean covered with yellow flowers in the foreground and and trees.
images.title: Coastal Bluffs
images.caption: The coastal bluffs of the Presidio still retain a wild feeling within the city.

images.altText: A long row of red brick barracks with green lawns in front extends into the distance.
images.title: Montgomery Street Barracks
images.caption: The brick barracks on Montgomery Street showcase military architecture from the late 1800s.

images.altText: Scattered Monterey Cypress trunks with green grass and fern cover at their bases.
images.title: Historic Forest
images.caption: The planted historic forests offer tranquil places to walk.

images.altText: A kite boarder with yellow kite on beach with wind surfers behind on the blue bay.
images.title: Wind Surfers at Crissy Field
images.caption: On windy days, Crissy Field is a popular wind surfing and Kite boarding location.

images.altText: White building with red roofs on Crissy Field with blue bay and orange bridge with fog behind.
images.title: Crissy Field
images.caption: Crissy Field is a popular spot to wak and run while viewing the bay and changing fog conditions.l

Fall and spring-mild
Winter-cold with occasional ice and snow
properties.name: Richmond
properties.description: The hub of Confederate manufacturing fueled a modern war, one of the South’s largest hospitals gave care to the sick and wounded, violent clashes of massive armies on open fields, and miles of formidable defensive earthworks meant that from 1861 to 1865, Richmond’s fate would determine America’s future.

images.altText: Shows the main visitor center, Tredegar Iron Works
images.title: Tredegar Iron Works
images.caption: Tredegar Iron Works is the starting point for your visit to Richmond National Battlefield Park

images.altText: a landscape of Gaines' Mill Battlefield
images.title: Gaines' Mill Battlefield
images.caption: Gaines' Mill Battlefield

images.altText: Malvern Hill Battlefield
images.title: Malvern Hill Battlefield
images.caption: Malvern Hill Battlefield is one of several battlefields from the Civil War preserved for the modern day.

images.altText: Ranger leading a tour at Cold Harbor
images.title: Ranger leading a tour at Cold Harbor
images.caption: The park offers tours during the summer and throughout the year.

entranceFees.title: Saratoga Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Saratoga National Historical Park is located between U.S. Route 4 and N.Y. Route 32, about 4 miles north of the Village of Stillwater, N.Y. The park is roughly 40 miles north of Albany, N.Y. and 14 miles southeast of Saratoga Springs, N.Y.  More detailed directions, and downloadable maps, are available on our website.
properties.weatherInfo: The park experiences all four seasons.  Temperatures can be as low as -20 degrees Fahrenheit in winter and as high as 100 degrees Fahrenheit in summer.  Check local weather reports for more detailed information.
properties.name: Saratoga
properties.description: Here, in 1777, during the American War for Independence, American troops battled and beat a British invasion force, marking the first time in world history that a British Army ever surrendered. This crucial victory secured essential foreign recognition and support, instigated world-wide wars, affirmed United States independence, and changed the face of the world.

images.altText: A building shaped slightly like two low, adjoining mushrooms sits on a lush green lawn.
images.title: Battlefield Visitor Center
images.caption: Our Visitor Center boasts a scenic view overlooking part of the Battlefield.

images.altText: A small, red farmhouse sits beside a red cannon and a few green trees.
images.title: John Neilson House
images.caption: Neilson House was a mid-level American headquarters in the Battles of Saratoga.

images.altText: A narrow, winding path leads through some trees to a 2-story yellow house.
images.title: Philip Schuyler House
images.caption: Schuyler House was the country estate of American General Philip Schuyler.

images.altText: A narrow, stone obelisk on top of a green hill reaches into a partly cloudy sky.
images.title: Saratoga Monument
images.caption: This 19th-century obelisk commemorates America's victory in the Battles of Saratoga.

images.altText: An informational sign sits beside a wooden walkway winding amid early autumn trees.
images.title: Victory Woods
images.caption: A half-mile path through Victory Woods tells of this last British camp following the Battles of Saratoga.

properties.directionsInfo: From Portland: Take Highway 26 West to Seaside. Go north on Highway 101 through Seaside. Turn right at the stop light on SE Ensign Lane. Continue to drive about one mile, turn right onto Fort Clatsop Road, the entrance will be on your left.

properties.weatherInfo: During the 106 days the Lewis and Clark Expedition wintered at Fort Clatsop in 1806 it rained all but 12 days and they saw the sun 6 times. While we are usually not so dreary, but we do see an average of 70 inches of rain a year and we are the foggiest location in the Lower 48 states. Summer months are usually nice with days ranging from 55-70 degrees. Winters are wet and mild, usually 40-55 degrees.
properties.name: Lewis and Clark
properties.description: Explore the timeless rainforests and majestic coastal vistas. Discover the rich heritage of the native people. Unfold the dramatic stories of America's most famous explorers. The park encompasses sites along the Columbia River and the Pacific Coast. Follow in the footsteps of the explorers and have an adventure in history.

images.altText: Runners along a fern and tree-lined trail
images.title: Running on History
images.caption: Runners compete in a friendly race along a fern and tree-lined trail.

There are no airports on St. John so you must fly to St. Thomas Cyril E. King Airport (code STT) and travel from there.
From the airport you rent a car and drive or take a taxi to Redhook (west end) St. Thomas.
From there you can either take a car barge to St. John or the people ferry.
Once on St. John you can easily walk from the ferry terminal to the Visitor Center.

properties.weatherInfo:
Mostly Perfect! The Tradewinds (the Easterlies) dominate the weather in the Virgin Islands, blowing east to west across the tropical Atlantic. The winter tends to bring stronger winds and less rain, and the summer tends to bring more rain and lighter winds.

Be sure to check the forecast often during hurricane season or winter swell events.
properties.name: Virgin Islands
properties.description: Virgin Islands National Park is more than just beautiful beaches. Hike to plantation ruins to learn about a time when sugar dominated the island. Visit the ancient petroglyphs carved by the Taino Indians. Come snorkel the coral reefs to discover hidden marine life.  Two-thirds of the island of St. John is national park, making it a unique destination for visitors from around the world.

properties.directionsInfo:
Visitors traveling east-west on Interstate 80 can exit at Kimball, Nebraska and drive 45 miles north on Highway 71. Follow National Park Service signs three miles west of Gering, Nebraska on Old Oregon Trail (State Highway 92 West).

Visitors following Old Oregon Trail along the North Platte River using State Highway 26 or 92, should follow the National Park Service signs.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers at Scotts Bluff are generally dry and high temperatures are usually in the 80's and 90's, although they can reach above 100 on occasion. Hikers are strongly advised to carry water.
Winter daytime temperatures are usually in the 40's or low 50's, with overnight lows below freezing and, on occasion, below 0 degrees Fahrenheit.
Although it can be windy any time of the year, spring is the windiest season.
properties.name: Scotts Bluff
properties.description: Towering 800 feet above the North Platte River, Scotts Bluff has served as a landmark for peoples from Native Americans to emigrants on the Oregon, California and Mormon Trails to modern travelers. Rich with geological and paleontological history as well as human history, there is much to discover while exploring the 3,000 acres of Scotts Bluff National Monument.

images.altText: Conestoga wagon in front of Eagle Rock
images.title: Eagle Rock with Conestoga Wagon
images.caption: Thousands of covered wagons rolled by Eagle Rock in the mid nineteenth century.

images.altText: entrance sign to Scotts Bluff National Monument
images.title: Scotts Bluff National Monument Entrance Sign
images.caption: Scotts Bluff National Monument Entrance Sign

entranceFees.description: Grant-Kohrs Ranch is a fee-free site.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Arriving from the east: Take Interstate 90, exit 187. Drive through town, approximately 2.5 miles. Turn left onto Grant Circle and enter the park. 

Arriving from the west: Take Interstate 90, exit 184. Turn right. Drive approximately 3/4 of a mile. Turn right on to Grant Circle and enter the park.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures can fluctuate greatly. Sub-freezing temperatures in the morning can give way to mild days. Snow in early spring, rain in late season.

Summer: Temperatures can average 70-80 F, but can reach highs of 100 F. Rain rare. Dry and hot.

Fall: Temperatures can fluctuate greatly. Sub-freezing mornings can give way to mild days. Rain in early fall likely.

Winter: Temperature can fall to -30 F, with highs of 10-20 F. Snow is possible. Cold weather gear is highly recommended.
properties.name: Grant-Kohrs Ranch
properties.description: Wide open spaces, the hard-working cowboy, his spirited cow pony, and vast herds of cattle are among the strongest symbols of the American West. Once the headquarters of a 10 million acre cattle empire, Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site preserves these symbols and commemorates the role of cattlemen in American history.

images.altText: A view of the rear of the ranch house.
images.title: The Ranch House
images.caption: The rear portion of the ranch house was an addition put on by Conrad Kohrs in 1891.

images.altText: Deer Lodge Mountain rises up over the pastures of Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site.
images.title: Deer Lodge Mountain
images.caption: Deer Lodge Mountain, and the rest of the Flint Creek Range, directly influence the weather in the valley below.

images.altText: A front view of the ranch house.
images.title: The Ranch House
images.caption: The front portion of the ranch house was originally built by Canadian fur trader Johnny Grant in 1862.

images.altText: Three longhorn cattle standing in a corral.
images.title: Longhorns
images.caption: Longhorns, shorthorns, and Hereford cattle were all historically raised on the ranch.

images.altText: Two Belgian horses pull a wagon, giving visitors a tour of the park.
images.title: Wagon Ride
images.caption: Draft horses, especially Belgians, were utilized on the ranch. The ranch still uses them for putting up hay, feeding cattle, and giving tours of the park.

properties.directionsInfo:
From the North (U.S. 15) or West (Hagerstown):
Use I-70 east and take Exit 54.  Bear right then take a left onto Rt. 355.  The visitor center will be on the left.

From the East (Baltimore):
Use I-70 west and take Exit 54. Bear left then take a left onto Rt. 355. The visitor center will be on the left.

From the South (Washington):
Use I-270 north to I-70 east and take Exit 54.  Bear right then take a left onto Rt. 355.  The visitor center will be on the the left.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring (March - May) Temperatures: Average high is 67 degrees with a low of 53 degrees

Summer (June - August) Temperatures: Average high is 87 degrees with a low of 65 degrees

Fall (September - November) Temperatures: Average high is 68 degrees with a low of 48 degrees

Winter (December - February) Temperatures: Average high is 45 degrees with a low of 27 degrees

(Source: www.usclimatedata.com)
properties.name: Monocacy
properties.description: During the summer of 1864, the Confederacy carried out a bold plan to turn the tide of the Civil War in their favor.  They planned to capture Washington, DC and influence the election of 1864.  On July 9, however, Federal soldiers outnumbered three to one, fought gallantly along the banks of the Monocacy River in an effort to buy time for Union reinforcement to arrive in Washington, DC.

images.altText: The sun setting behind a monument.
images.title: 14 New Jersey Regiment Monument
images.caption: The monument recognizes the sacrifices of the "Monocacy Regiment."

images.altText: Federal style house with trees behind it during the fall season.
images.title: The Worthington House
images.caption: The Worthington House is one of the most iconic locations on the battlefield.

images.altText: Sun rise and fog behind the historic Secondary House on the Best Farm.
images.title: The Secondary House
images.caption: Built in the 1790s this house was one of the first structures in the park.

images.altText: Smoke and fire erupt from an artillery piece as it is fired by Union soldiers.
images.title: Artillery Firing
images.caption: Union soldiers fire an artillery piece in commemoration of the battle.

images.altText: Small flags fly in the breeze in front of the visitor center.
images.title: Memorial Day Flag Display
images.caption: 2,300 Union and Confederate National Flags are set out to commemorate the Battle of Monocacy casualties.

properties.name: Florissant Fossil Beds
properties.description: Beneath a grassy mountain valley in central Colorado lies one of the richest and most diverse fossil deposits in the world. Petrified redwood stumps up to 14 feet wide and thousands of detailed fossils of insects and plants reveal the story of a very different, prehistoric Colorado.

images.altText: Fossil redwood stump
images.title: Big Stump
images.caption: Walk the Petrified Trail Loop to see fossil redwood stumps

images.altText: palaeovespa, ancient wasp
images.title: Ancient Wasp Fossil
images.caption: Captured 34 million years ago, this ancient wasp and other insects are on display at Florissant Fossil Beds NM.

images.altText: Visitors at Hornbek Homestead

images.caption: Visitors explore the Hornbek Homestead, built in 1878.

properties.weatherInfo: Obtain forecast information before beginning your adventure at Devils Tower National Monument and observe changing weather conditions. Thunderstorms can develop quickly bringing lightning, hail, rain, slippery rock surfaces, and hypothermia. Summer days can bring very hot temperatures. Carry enough water, and realize the rock of the Tower can reach over 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Winter weather can bring blowing snow and road closures. Check local forecasts and road conditions before visiting.
properties.name: Devils Tower
properties.description: The Tower is an astounding geologic feature that protrudes out of the prairie surrounding the Black Hills. It is considered sacred by Northern Plains Indians and indigenous people. Hundreds of parallel cracks make it one of the finest crack climbing areas in North America. Devils Tower entices us to learn more, explore more and define our place in the natural and cultural world.

properties.name: Buck Island Reef
properties.description:
Welcome to Buck Island! Before you come, please watch our 2014 Telly Award winning film "Caribbean Gem." Watching this will catch you up on 50+ years of National Park Service protection and civic engagement. Learn what we do every day to preserve this resource for Virgin Islanders and visitors alike.

For the General Management Plan and Environmental Compliance, visit the News page.

properties.directionsInfo: Harpers Ferry NHP's Visitor Center is located along US Route 340 in West Virginia. The park entrance is 8 miles east of Charles Town, WV and 20 miles southwest of Frederick, MD.

entrancePasses.description:

Annual passes can be purchased at the Entrance Station near the park's visitor center.
entrancePasses.title: Harpers Ferry Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Harpers Ferry experiences all four seasons - the cold and snow of winter, the rain and flowers of spring, the humidity and sunshine of summer, and the chill and leave change of fall. We will strive to keep you up-to-date as Harpers Ferry's landscape changes with the seasons.

To see the current weather or the forecasted weather for Harpers Ferry, please visit the National Weather Service site and set the zip code to 25425.
properties.name: Harpers Ferry
properties.description: A visit to this quaint, historic community, at the confluence of the Potomac and Shenandoah rivers, is like stepping into the past.  Stroll the picturesque streets, visit exhibits and museums, or hike our trails and battlefields. Spend a day or a weekend.  We have something for everyone, so come and discover Harpers Ferry!

At Walnut Canyon National Monument, it covers entry for up to four adults; children ages 15 and younger enter for free.

properties.weatherInfo: Be prepared for variable and extreme weather conditions. You may expect high winds any time of year, summer temperatures above 95ºF (35ºC), afternoon storms July–September, and snow from fall to spring. Dress in layers, as weather at Sunset Crater Volcano can change quickly at any time of year.
properties.name: Sunset Crater Volcano
properties.description: The cinder cone volcano's rim is the dusky red of sunset, but the crater is only part of the story. Around 1085 the ground began to shake, and lava spewed high into the air. When the eruption finished, it had changed both the landscape and the people who lived here. Today, it teaches how nature and humankind affect each other—and how rebirth and renewal happen in the wake of disaster.

images.altText: a cinder cone volcano and ponderosa pine trees
images.title: Sunset Crater Volcano
images.caption: Sunset Crater Volcano is named for the color of the rusty red cinders near its peak.

images.altText: a jagged field of lava beneath a cinder cone volcano
images.title: Sunset Crater and Bonito Lava Flow
images.caption: Three trails allow visitors to explore the Bonito Lava Flow.

images.altText: a massive volcano rising behind a smaller, tree-covered volcano in the foreground
images.title: Lenox Crater and the San Francisco Peaks
images.caption: Sunset Crater Volcano is the most recent eruption in the San Francisco volcanic field. Visitors can climb Lenox Crater, foreground, for excellent views of the field, including the San Francisco Peaks.

images.altText: a small ponderosa pine tree in a field of rolling cinder hills
images.title: Lone Ponderosa
images.caption: Geologists and biologists study the area surrounding Sunset Crater Volcano to better understand how landscapes recover after an eruption.

images.altText: tall pine trees grow beneath the Sunset Crater Volcano cinder cone
images.title: Ponderosas Reaching Skyward
images.caption: On warm days, the bark of ponderosa pine trees smells like vanilla or butterscotch.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter El Morro National Monument.
entranceFees.title: El Morro National Monument Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: From Albuquerque, NM, or from the east: take Interstate 40 west to Grants. At exit 81, go south on Highway 53 for 42 miles to El Morro National Monument. From Flagstaff, AZ, or from the west: take Interstate 40 east to Gallup. At exit 20, go south on Highway 602 for about 31 miles. Turn east (left) onto Highway 53. El Morro is 25 more miles.
properties.weatherInfo:
At an elevation of 7,219 feet (2200 meters) winters can be cold and snowy. Summers are warm with afternoon thunder showers from mid-July through mid-September. Trails can close unexpectedly due to severe weather.
Average snowfall: 40 inches per year.
Average precipitation (snowmelt and rain): 16 inches per year.
Warmest month: July, with average highs of 84 degrees and lows of 52 degrees.
Coldest months: December and January, with average lows of 14-15 degrees, and average highs of 44-45 degrees.
properties.name: El Morro
properties.description: Imagine the refreshment of finding water after days of dusty travel. A reliable waterhole hidden at the base of a sandstone bluff made El Morro (the headland) a popular campsite for hundreds of years. Here, Ancestral Puebloans, Spanish and American travelers carved over 2,000 signatures, dates, messages, and petroglyphs.  Make El Morro National Monument a stopping point on your travels.

images.altText: Headland in Snow
images.title: El Morro in snow
images.caption: El Morro blanketed with snow

images.altText: Pool at El Morro
images.title: Pool at El Morro
images.caption: A drinking hole for visitors for hundreds of years, the pool at El Morro has significant cultural and historical value.

images.altText: Trail at El Morro
images.title: Trail at El Morro
images.caption: Constructed by the CCC, the historic headland trail at El Morro offers visitors great views and the archaeological site of Atsinna.

entranceFees.description: Keweenaw National Historical Park has no entrance fees. Exploring the Calumet Visitor Center is also free. Some of our Heritage Sites may charge a fee or request a donation. Contact a specific site for more information: http://www.nps.gov/kewe/learn/management/keweenaw-heritage-sites.htm
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Keweenaw National Historical Park is located is located on the Keweenaw Peninsula, the northernmost part of Upper Michigan.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summer: Keweenaw summers are usually mild, with average highs in the 70s, but can reach into the 80s and 90s. Nighttime temperatures are typically cool, but can also dip into the 40s or stay in the 70s. Summer months are dry, with occasional rain or severe thunderstorms.

Winter: Again influenced by Lake Superior, winter temperatures are mild with highs in the 20s. Cold spells can occur with subzero temperatures. Lake effect snow is common, and 300 inches of snow can fall in a season.
properties.name: Keweenaw
properties.description: From 7,000 years ago to the 1900s people mined Keweenaw copper. Native peoples made copper into tools and trade items. Investors and immigrants arrived in the 1800s in a great mineral rush, developing thriving industries and cosmopolitan communities. Though the mines have since closed, their mark is still visible on the land and people.

images.altText: Park Headquarters in summer
images.title: Keweenaw NHP Headquarters
images.caption: Park Headquarters is housed in the former Calumet & Hecla Mining Company General Office building.

images.altText: a Ranger leads a walk outside the The Keweenaw History Center
images.title: Keweenaw History Center
images.caption: A ranger guided walk outside the former Calumet & Hecla Public Library, now known at the Keweenaw History Center.

images.altText: The Calumet Visitor Center in winter.
images.title: Calumet Visitor Center
images.caption: The Calumet Visitor Center in the historic Union Building showcases three floors of interactive exhibits, films, and museum pieces.

images.altText: Quinicy Mine grounds in winter
images.title: Quincy Mine
images.caption: The Quincy Mining Company #2 Shaft-Rockhouse and Hoist House in winter.

images.altText: Quincy Smelting facilities in fall.
images.title: Quincy Mining Company Smelter
images.caption: The Quincy Smelter is one of the best-preserved copper smelting facilities of its era.

properties.directionsInfo:
Plane
Fly into Bismarck or Minot, ND. Hazen, ND (15 miles from site) has an airport for small planes.

Car
One-half mile north of Stanton, ND on County Road 37. One hour northwest of Bismarck, ND and one and a half hours southwest of Minot, ND.

Public Transportation
Charter and tour bus parking available at Visitor Center parking lot.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers are warm and sunny with temperatures occasionally reaching 100 degrees F and frequent afternoon thunderstorms.  Winters are invigorating, with extremely cold temperatures as low as -35 degrees F.  High winds and sunny skies are common in winter.  Snow is sporadic in the relatively dry climate, but blizzards are common.
properties.name: Knife River Indian Villages
properties.description: Earthlodge people hunted bison and other game, but were in essence farmers living in villages along the Missouri and its tributaries. The site was a major Native American trade center for hundreds of years prior to becoming an important market place for fur traders after 1750.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Manzanar National Historic Site. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Manzanar is located on the west side of U.S. Highway 395, 9 miles north of Lone Pine, California and 6 miles south of Independence, CA.

entrancePasses.description:
No pass is required to enter Manzanar National Historic Site. Enjoy your visit!

If you plan to visit other parks with an entrance fee, learn more about the National Parks and Federal Recreation Lands Passes.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Passes

properties.weatherInfo: Manzanar is located in the Owens Valley at 4,000' elevation, at the eastern base of the Sierra Nevada. We get little precipitation but we do have four distinct seasons. Summer temperatures can soar over 100 degrees. Winter highs are usually in the 40's. Nighttime temperatures year round are 30 to 40 degrees less than daytime highs. High winds are common in any season.
properties.name: Manzanar
properties.description: In 1942, the United States government ordered more than 110,000 men, women, and children to leave their homes and detained them in remote, military-style camps. Manzanar War Relocation Center was one of ten camps where Japanese American citizens and resident Japanese aliens were incarcerated during World War II.

images.altText: People walk to barracks framed by mountain peaks.
images.title: Historic Barracks
images.caption: People walk to long rows of barracks.

entranceFees.description: This fee can be paid for online at recreation.gov or at the Visitor Center between 9 am and 5 pm daily.

properties.directionsInfo: Kennesaw Mountain NBP is fairly spread out with multiple parking lots. Many visitors begin their visit at the Visitor Center located at 900 Kennesaw Mountain Dr. and orient themselves to the park with Ranger or Volunteer. For more detailed directions, please see link below.

entrancePasses.description: Kennesaw Mountain NBP charges for entrance to the park. This is a per vehicle entrance fee. Any vehicle parked at Kennesaw Mountain will be required to purchase a $5 daily pass online or a $40 annual pass (online or at Visitor Center). Digital passes purchased online at Recreation.gov will be tied to a specific license plate; physical passes purchased at Visitor Center will be displayed in the vehicle. America the Beautiful Interagency Passes are also accepted.
entrancePasses.title: Kennesaw Mountain Day Pass

entrancePasses.description: Kennesaw Mountain NBP charges for entrance to the park. This is a per vehicle entrance fee. Any vehicle parked at Kennesaw Mountain will be required to purchase a $5 daily pass online or a $40 annual pass (online or at Visitor Center). Digital passes purchased online at Recreation.gov will be tied to a specific license plate; physical passes purchased at Visitor Center will be displayed in the vehicle. America the Beautiful Interagency Passes are also accepted.
entrancePasses.title: Kennesaw Mountain Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Before you start your trip to the mountain, check the local weather forecast to be sure that you will have a dry time. Though we are located north of Atlanta, we're still have the same hot summers and mild winters as our neighbors. The mountain top generally ranges 8-10 degrees cooler than at the base. In fall and winter, be prepared with a light weight jacket on hand. After planning your activities, check back to see what the weather will have in store for your day.
properties.name: Kennesaw Mountain
properties.description: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park is a 2,965 acre National Battlefield that preserves a Civil War battleground of the Atlanta Campaign. Opposing forces maneuvered and fought here from June 19, 1864 until July 2, 1864. Although most famous as a Civil War battlefield, Kennesaw Mountain has a much richer story.

properties.directionsInfo: Once on St. John, the only part of Virgin Islands Coral Reef National Monument accessible by land is in Hurricane Hole. To get to Hurricane Hole, follow route 10 from Cruz Bay to Estate Hermitage. The Monument extends eastward from Borck Creek to Haulover Bay along the southern shoreline of the Island. Just a sliver of the Monument touches the north shore. To the west of the Monument line is National Park waters, and to the east is territorial waters.
properties.weatherInfo:
Mostly Perfect. 
The Tradewinds (the Easterlies) dominate the weather in the Virgin Islands, blowing east to west across the tropical Atlantic. The winter tends to bring stronger winds and less rain, and the summer tends to bring more rain and lighter winds.
properties.name: Virgin Islands Coral Reef
properties.description: Virgin Islands Coral Reef National Monument includes federal submerged lands within the 3-mile belt off the island of St. John. These waters support a diverse and complex system of coral reefs and other ecosystems such as shoreline mangrove forests and seagrass beds.

images.altText: Parrot Fish posing for the camera over several corals
images.title: Parrot Fish
images.caption: Parrot Fish posing for the camera over several corals

properties.fullName: Virgin Islands Coral Reef National Monument

entranceFees.description: Entrance to Valley Forge is free.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
The park is conveniently located off of U.S. Route 422. The main entrance to the park is at the intersection of State Route 23 and North Gulph Road.

From the Pennsylvania Turnpike, take Exit 326.
From Interstate I-76, take Route 422 West to Route 23 West/Valley Forge.
From State Route 252, take State Route 23 East.
properties.weatherInfo: Winters at Valley Forge are cold and damp with a cool spring and fall and a hot and humid summer. Sturdy hiking shoes are recommended for outdoor recreation during the snowy winter season.
properties.name: Valley Forge
properties.description: Valley Forge was the site of the 1777-78 winter encampment of the Continental Army. The 3,500-acres of monuments, meadows, and woodlands commemorate the sacrifices and perseverance of the Revolutionary War generation. The park honors and celebrates the ability of citizens to pull together and overcome adversity during extraordinary times.

images.altText: Light fog across a grassy meadow with trees on either side
images.title: Fog in a meadow
images.caption: Fog in one of the many grassy meadow in Valley Forge National Historical park

images.altText: Three log cabin style huts in a deep snowy field.
images.title: Huts in the Snow
images.caption: Three replica log huts in the deep snow at Valley Forge.

images.altText: A the-story stone house surrounded by grass and trees on a clear day.
images.title: Washington's Headquarters
images.caption: Washington's Headquarters in spring.

images.altText: The front of the Valley Forge Visitor Center, a triangular building flanked by trees.
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: The front entrance to the Valley Forge Visitor Center.

images.altText: A concrete arch atop a hill with a military person in physical training clothing standing at attenti
images.title: National Memorial Arch
images.caption: The National Memorial Arch at Valley Forge.

entranceFees.description: Effective January 1, 2015 admission to Fort Laramie National Historic Site is FREE!
entranceFees.title: Admission is free.

properties.directionsInfo:
The park is located in Southeast Wyoming approximately 100 miles north of Cheyenne, Wyoming and 55 miles west of Scottsbluff, Nebraska.

From Interstate-25, take exit 92 to U.S. Highway 26, proceed east to the town of Fort Laramie; turn right on State Route 160 and travel 3 miles to the park entrance.
properties.weatherInfo: Fort Laramie is located in the warmest part of Wyoming. Summer days can get quite hot (over 100 degrees Fahrenheit) with average temperatures in the 80s and 90s, though nights are mostly cool.The region is semi-arid with a very distinct winter dry season. About 70% of the normal annual precipitation falls during the spring and early summer. Winters can be cold and breezy with sub-zero days. Visitors should be aware that high winds are possible in the winter and can approach hurricane strength.
properties.name: Fort Laramie
properties.description: Originally established as a private fur trading fort in 1834, Fort Laramie evolved into the largest and best known military post on the Northern Plains before its abandonment in 1890. This “grand old post” witnessed the entire sweeping saga of America’s western expansion and Indian resistance to encroachment on their territories.

images.altText: Living history interpreters firing the park's 1841 Mountain Howitzer
images.title: Artillery Demonstration
images.caption: The black powder demonstrations remain one of the most popular interpretive programs offered at the site.

images.altText: Living history interpreter explaining the life of a trapper/trader to young visitors
images.title: Fur Trade Fort Laramie Event
images.caption: Special attention is given to helping our young visitors understand the past at Fort Laramie NHS.

images.altText: View of the parade ground from the porch of "Old Bedlam".
images.title: Parade Ground from the Porch of "Old Bedlam"
images.caption: A fall view of the parade ground from "Old Bedlam" the oldest surviving structure at Fort Laramie and in the state of Wyoming, constructed in 1849.

images.altText: Living history interpreter portraying the Post Trader.
images.title: Post Trader at Work
images.caption: In the summer living history interpreters bring the post to life, including the Post Trader in the refurnished 1849 store.

images.altText: Ruins of the 1873 Post Hospital at dawn.
images.title: Ruins of the 1873 Post Hospital
images.caption: Sunrises and sunsets are extraordinarily beautiful when set against the many historic structures the site.

images.altText: Aerial view of Fort Laramie NHS from the South
images.title: Arial View of Fort Laramie NHS From the South
images.caption: Overview of Fort Laramie as it exists today with many of the historic buildings fully restored and refurnished and numerous other ruins and foundations.

images.altText: Two tipis across the Laramie River from the fort in fall
images.title: Tipis Across Laramie River in Fall
images.caption: Tipis were a common scene at Fort Laramie from 1834-1872.  At times, during treaty negotiations dozens of tipis could be found here.

properties.directionsInfo: There are several air carriers to St Croix arriving at the Henry E. Rohlesen Airport. The park is five miles from Christiansted National Historic Site and can be reached by car via Rt. 75 from Christiansted, connecting to Route 80. Cars may be rented at the airport and various other island locations. Ask your lodging hosts for information about guided land tours.
properties.weatherInfo: Welcome to the tropics!
properties.name: Salt River Bay
properties.description: Salt River Bay National Historical Park and Ecological Preserve uniquely documents the human and natural Caribbean world from the earliest indigenous settlements in the central Caribbean to their clash with seven different colonial European powers to the present day.

images.altText: View of the Salt River Bay Visitor Contact Station
images.title: Salt River Bay Visitor Contact Station
images.caption: View of the Salt River Bay Visitor Contact Station from below.

images.altText: View from the Salt River Bay Visitor Contact Station in the Bay
images.title: View from the Salt River Bay Visitor Contact Station
images.caption: Many visitors visit the Visitor Contact Station and view Salt River Bay from this scenic vista.

images.altText: Kayak on the beach at Salt River
images.title: Kayak Salt River
images.caption: Kayaking is a great way to see our mangroves and beaches!

images.altText: An aerial view of the Salt River Bay area.
images.title: Salt River Bay Aerial View
images.caption: An aerial view of the Salt River Bay area.

images.altText: Photograph of historic masonry well tower in the woods at Salt River.
images.title: Well Tower
images.caption: This brick and coral block masonry tower, built in the 1790s, used the power of wind to move water from Salt River to neighboring plantation estates.

properties.designation: National Historical Park and Ecological Preserve

properties.directionsInfo:
Hot Springs National Park is 55 miles (88.5 km) from Little Rock, AR

The park's visitor center is located in the Fordyce Bathhouse located at 369 Central Avenue
properties.weatherInfo:
Temperatures range from >100°F (38°C) to <20°F (-7°C). 
Spring has the highest average rainfall. 
Summer temperatures frequently reach the triple-digit range and high humidity 
Fall begins fall colors and cooler temperatures. Frost starts to become more common.
Winter  temperatures often fall below 32 degrees F (0 C) and occasionally drop below 0 F (-18 C). Roads and bridges may be icy. 
Your visit can be more enjoyable by checking the forecast and coming prepared for hikes or walks in the park.
properties.name: Hot Springs
properties.description: Water. That's what first attracted people, and they have been coming here ever since to use these soothing thermal waters to heal and relax. Rich and poor alike came for the baths, and a thriving city built up around the hot springs. Together nicknamed "The American Spa," Hot Springs National Park today surrounds the north end of the city of Hot Springs, Arkansas. Come discover it for yourself.

images.altText: Close up of a hiking boot on the trail a hiker in the distance
images.title: Take A Hike!
images.caption: Hot Springs National Park has 26 miles of hiking trails to explore.

images.altText: Hiker sits at the edge of the creek, with a bridge in the background
images.title: Hiker at bridge Whittington Park Creek
images.caption: Visitors hike and enjoy the cool shady places in the park.

images.altText: Pagoda surrounded by red and yellow leaves
images.title: Pagoda
images.caption: There are many beautiful vistas from the top of Hot Springs Mountain

images.altText: Stone entrance pillars in front of a row of four bathouses
images.title: Bathhouse Row
images.caption: Visitors and patients come to take the thermal waters

images.credit: NPS photo Mark David Artist In Residence 2015
images.altText: Stone bridge surrounded by brilliant yellow and green leaves
images.title: Bridge with fall colors
images.caption: The park is beautiful year round

images.altText: women sitting on the stone wall at the hot water cascade as the vapor rises
images.title: Visitor at the edge of the pools of the hot water cascade
images.caption: The natural curiosity of the thermal water can be seen and experienced
