properties.directionsInfo:
The entrance to the memorial is located on US Route 30/Lincoln Highway.  Traveling east on the PA Turnpike take exit 110 - Somerset and follow the signs.  Traveling west on the PA Turnpike take exit 146 - Bedford.  

GPS Address:  6424 Lincoln Highway, Stoystown, PA 15563.  Please note mapping programs may note alternate entrances, but the only entrance to the memorial is located on US Route 30.

For more details follow the link to our website
properties.weatherInfo:
Fall-Winter Cooler weather starts in September with warm days and cool nights. The first snowfall of the season occurs by mid-October and extends through late March to mid-April. Daytime temperatures range in the mid-20s to 30s, with periodic warming in the 40s and 50s. The average annual snowfall is approximately 80 inches for Somerset County.

Spring-Summer May is more predictable for warmer weather with daytime temperatures in the 60s and 70s. July and August are also mild with highs in the 80s-90s
properties.name: Flight 93
properties.description: On Tuesday morning, September 11, 2001, the U.S. came under attack when four commercial airliners were hijacked and used to strike targets on the ground. Nearly 3,000 people tragically lost their lives. Because of the actions of the 40 passengers and crew aboard one of the planes, Flight 93, the attack on the U.S. Capitol was thwarted.

images.altText: Tall gray walls with a gap and black pathway leading to the gap

images.caption: View of the Memorial Plaza from the Flight Path Overlook

From I-44: exit at Exit 70 (Missouri Highway MM). Continue south to U.S. Highway 60. Proceed through the intersection. Continue 1/2 mile to Missouri Highway ZZ. Turn right on ZZ. Continue south to Farm Road 182 (Elm Street). Turn left; the entrance to the battlefield is on the right.

From U.S. Highway 65 (south of Springfield):  turn left (west) on Missouri Highway 14 at Ozark. Continue on Highway 14 to Missouri Highway ZZ. Follow ZZ north to Farm Road 182.   Turn right; the entrance is on the right.

properties.weatherInfo: Summer months are frequently hot and humid, with occasional showers and thunderstorms.  Winter months (especially January and February) are frequently cold, with occasional ice and light snow.  Spring and fall months are generally pleasant, with occasional showers.
properties.name: Wilson's Creek
properties.description: Wilson's Creek was the first major Civil War battle fought west of the Mississippi River, and the site of the death of Nathaniel Lyon, the first Union general killed in action. The costly Southern victory on August 10, 1861, focused national attention on the war in Missouri.   Wilson’s Creek NB commemorates and interprets the battle within the context of the war in the Trans-Mississippi West.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee for the visitor center or trails at Agate Fossil Beds National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Admission is free.

properties.directionsInfo:
If traveling east or west on U.S. Highway 20 go 22 miles south of Harrison, NE on State Hwy 29 then 3 miles east on River Road (paved) If traveling east or west on U.S. Highway 26 go 34 miles north of Mitchell, NE on State Hwy 29 then 3 miles east on River Road (paved).

Also accessible from State Hwy 71, 25 miles on unpaved River Road.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers can be very warm, high 90's to 100 with the possibility of thunderstorms late afternoons.  Winter temperatures can dip as low as -20 with some snow and wind.  Heaviest snows can be expected in late Spring.
properties.name: Agate Fossil Beds
properties.description:
During the 1890s, scientists rediscovered what the Lakota Sioux already knew—bones preserved in one of the world's most significant Miocene Epoch mammal sites.

Yet, this place called "Agate" is a landscape that reflects many influences—from early animals roaming the valleys and hills, to tribal nations calling the High Plains home, to explorers passing through or settling in the American West.

images.altText: The visitor center sits in the middle of mixed grass prairie.
images.title: Visitor Center on the Prairie
images.caption: From the Fossil Hills Trail the Visitor Center is a ship in a sea of prairie grasses.

images.altText: Tipis and Fossil Hills represent the two subjects that Agate Fossil Beds interprets.
images.title: The Agate Fossil Hills and Tipis
images.caption: One of the first impressions that visitors have are the tipis and the Fossil Hills.

images.altText: Thunderheads are common in July.
images.title: A July Storm Passes
images.caption: Summer storms include thunderheads and lightning and can be exciting and dangerous.

images.altText: The Dinohyus was a scavenger, nicknamed "Terrible Pig"
images.title: Dinohyus in the Visitor Center Fossil Diorama
images.caption: Visitors stare in wonder at the huge head of the "apex" predator of the plains some 20 million years ago.

images.altText: This buckskin shirt decorated with quills was worn by Red Cloud.
images.title: The James H. Cook collection
images.caption: Visitors agree that this shirt decorated with quillwork and worn by Red Cloud of the Oglala Lakota is a priceless piece of history.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Palo Alto Battlefield or attend park programs and events. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: No admission fee

properties.directionsInfo: The park is located on Brownsville's north side, near the city of Los Fresnos. It is just north of the intersection of FM 1847 (Paredes Line Rd.) and FM 511/FM 550.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers are hot and humid. Tropical weather systems generally affect the area from August to October. Winters are usually mild but cold fronts can drop temperatures by up to 30 degrees in about an hour.
properties.name: Palo Alto Battlefield
properties.description: On May 8, 1846, United States and Mexican troops clashed on the prairie of Palo Alto. The battle was the first in a two-year long war that changed the map of North America. Palo Alto Battlefield National Historical Park preserves the site of this notable battle and provides an understanding of the causes, events, and consequences of the U.S.-Mexican War.

images.altText: Shaded structure overlooking the battlefield
images.title: Battlefield overlook
images.caption: The overlook gives you a great view of the battlefield

images.altText: Coiled rattlesnake ready to strike.
images.title: Rattlesnake
images.caption: Rattlesnakes will let you know when you get too close.

images.altText: Sun rising over the battlefield
images.title: Sunrise
images.caption: Get here when the park opens and enjoy views like this.

images.altText: Sunset over the battlefield
images.title: Sunset over the battlefield
images.caption: Early sunsets during winter are a sight to behold.

images.altText: Mexican 8-pounder cannon on the battlefield.
images.title: Mexican 8-pounder
images.caption: A Mexican 8-pound field gun surveys the battlefield.

properties.fullName: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: This fee covers entrance for all visitors 16 years old or older for seven days. Children 15 years old and younger are admitted for free.

entranceFees.description: This fee covers the occupants of one commercial sedan for one day at Walnut Canyon National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Sedan - Walnut Canyon Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Walnut Canyon National Monument is located approximately 7.5 miles (12 km) east of Flagstaff. From Interstate 40, take Exit 204, and turn south. The Walnut Canyon Visitor Center is located at the end of this 3-mile (5 km) road.

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for one year from the month of purchase. At Walnut Canyon National Monument, it covers entry for up to four adults; children ages 15 and younger enter for free. At Sunset Crater Volcano and Wupatki National Monuments, it covers entry for all occupants of one private vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Flagstaff Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Be prepared for variable and extreme weather conditions. You may expect high winds any time of year, summer temperatures above 95ºF (35ºC), afternoon storms July–September, and heavy snow from fall to spring. Dress in layers, as weather at Walnut Canyon can change quickly at any time of year.
properties.name: Walnut Canyon
properties.description: Come gaze across curved canyon walls. Among the remarkable geological formations of the canyon itself, the former homes of ancient inhabitants are easily evident. Along the trails you can imagine life within Walnut Canyon, while visiting actual pueblos and walking in the steps of those who came before.

images.altText: sunlight illuminates stone walls in a canyon cliff dwelling
images.title: Cliff Dwellings
images.caption: Walnut Canyon National Monument protects a series of ancient cliff dwellings built between 1125 and 1250 CE.

images.altText: a circular overlook at the edge of the canyon rim
images.title: Walnut Canyon Rim Overlook
images.caption: The 0.7-mile (1.1 km) Rim Trail reveals expansive views of Walnut Canyon and its cliff dwellings.

images.altText: warm sunlight illuminates a cliff dwelling wall beside a snowy trail
images.title: Walnut Canyon Snow
images.caption: The 0.9-mile (1.4 km) Island Trail leads visitors down 240 stairs to explore 25 cliff dwelling rooms.

images.altText: a common raven landing on a barren juniper branch
images.title: Walnut Canyon Raven
images.caption: At the rim of Walnut Canyon, visitors stand at eye level with soaring ravens, eagles, and other birds

images.altText: a visitor looks out over Walnut Canyon from the trail
images.title: A Visitor at Walnut Canyon
images.caption: More than 125,000 people visit Walnut Canyon each year.

entranceFees.description:
NO ENTRANCE FEE STARTED OCTOBER 1, 2016

Visitors will not be charged an admission fee to visit the park.
Qualifying visitors may obtain any of the passes for which there is no charge. These passes include the Access Pass (persons with a permanent disability), Military Pass (active military) and Every Kid in a Park (4th graders with a printed voucher from www.everykidinapark.gov)
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Appomattox Court House NHP is located 3 miles east of U.S. Highway 460, and 3 miles east of the modern town of Appomattox, Virginia along Rt. 24.
properties.weatherInfo: The park may close due to emergency weather conditions (typically snow or ice).  For updated information about possible closure or altered hours due to weather, please call 434-352-8987 ext. 245.
properties.name: Appomattox Court House
properties.description: On April 9, 1865, the surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia in the McLean House in the village of Appomattox Court House, Virginia signaled the end of the nation's largest war. Two important questions about its future were answered. Could the nation survive a civil war intact, and would that nation exist without slavery? The answer to both was yes and a new nation was born.

properties.weatherInfo: New England weather can be quite unpredictable, so check the regional weather forecasts before you plan your trip. Winters can range in temperature from 20 - 50 degrees Fahrenheit. Summers are quite humid and range in temperature from 60 - 90 degrees Fahrenheit.  Beware of ticks as they can be active year round.
properties.name: Minute Man
properties.description: At Minute Man National Historical Park the opening battle of the Revolution is brought to life as visitors explore the battlefields and structures associated with April 19, 1775, and witness the American revolutionary spirit through the writings of the Concord authors.

images.altText: By daniel Chester French
images.title: Concord Minute Man

properties.directionsInfo: Arkansas Post National Memorial is located in southeastern Arkansas. The entrance to the park is on Arkansas Hwy 169, seven miles south of Gillett, via US Hwy 165 (The Great River Road), and about 20 miles northeast of Dumas, via US 165.
properties.weatherInfo: Arkansas shares the same climate classification as the rest of the southeastern United States: humid subtropical. This type of climate features relatively mild winters and hot, steamy summers.
properties.name: Arkansas Post
properties.description: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures throughout human history - it represents cultural cooperation, conflict, synthesis, and diversity.

images.altText: confluence of two rivers
images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.caption: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures.

images.altText: the Alligator Slough footbridge
images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.caption: The Alligator Slough footbridge

images.altText: Over the three centuries of history at Arkansas Post, the area has been greatly changed by both natu
images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.caption: Located at the northern edge of the Gulf coastal plain, the Arkansas Post's native growth ranges from prairie grasses and lowland hardwood forests to wetland marshes near the bayous and river.

images.altText: Arkansas Post National Monument cannon firing
images.title: Living History
images.caption: During the Civil War, Confederate troops tried to maintain tactical control of the confluence of the Arkansas and White Rivers, and in 1862 they constructed a massive earthen fortification known as Fort Hindman at the Post. In January 1863 Union troops d

images.altText: Arkansas Post National Memorial is in the Lower Mississippi Riverine Forest ecoregion.
images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.caption: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures throughout human history - it represents cultural cooperation, conflict, synthesis, and diversity.

entranceFees.description:
There is no cost to enter the Monument or the Visitor Center. 
Both are completely free to visitors.
entranceFees.title: Hagerman Fossil Beds Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
When visiting Hagerman Fossil Beds NM we recommend you stop at the Visitor Center, located at 221 N State St, to begin your visit. There you get the latest information, see an introductory DVD, view fossils up close, and obtain helpful information about the amenities available in the area.
Hagerman Fossil Beds NM Visitor Center, 221 North State Street, is located along Highway 30 in the town of Hagerman across from the high school.
properties.weatherInfo: Hagerman, Idaho, gets 10 inches of rain per year. On average, there are 213 sunny days per year in Hagerman, Idaho. The July high is around 94 degrees. The January low is 22. Our comfort index, which is based on humidity during the hot months, is a 78 out of 100, where higher is more comfortable. The US average on the comfort index is 44.
properties.name: Hagerman Fossil Beds
properties.description: Do you know horses evolved in North America? The Hagerman Horse, Equus simplicidens, is the first true one toed horse. It's the park's most famous fossil but we have fossil evidence of over two hundred different species. From saber-toothed cat, mastodon, bear, camel, and ground sloth, to smaller animals like rodents and frogs, the scientific study of Pliocene fossils is the key to Hagerman.

images.altText: Jr. Rangers around a dig site learn about paleontology.

properties.directionsInfo:
Pecos National Historical Park is 25 miles east of Santa Fe, New Mexico off of Interstate 25. Visitors travelling north on I-25: take exit 299 on to HWY 50 to Pecos village and south two miles on State Road 63.

Those travelling south on I-25: take exit 307 and proceed four miles north to the Park on State Road 63.
properties.weatherInfo:
Pecos National Historical Park is located at nearly 7,000 feet in altitude in the high desert region of Northern New Mexico. Please know your limits at this high desert altitude. We recommend that you wear clothing appropriate to the season, bring plenty of water, stop for a snack or lunch at one of the picnic tables, wear comfortable shoes, and put on plenty of sunscreen.

Specific daily Pecos weather information may be accessed at this link: http://www.nps.gov/peco/planyourvisit/weather.htm.
properties.name: Pecos
properties.description: In the midst of piñon, juniper, and ponderosa pine woodlands of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains not far from Santa Fe, the remains of Indian pueblos stand as meaningful reminders of people who once prevailed. Pecos National Historical Park helps visitors explore the cultural exchange and geographic features that played such crucial roles in the rich history of the Pecos Valley.

images.altText: fishing access on the Pecos River
images.title: Pecos River
images.caption: There are three fishing seasons at Pecos National Historical Park--always popular with anglers.

images.altText: park superintendent
images.title: Every Kid in a Park
images.caption: Pecos NHP Superintendent with future park stewards in 2015.

images.altText: glorieta pass waysides
images.title: Looking toward the Glorieta Pass
images.caption: Located near Kozlowski's trading post and the entry to the Forked Lightning Ranch, these waysides point the visitor toward the Glorieta Pass.

images.altText: View of pottery in museum case
images.title: Pottery Image with Feathered Serpent
images.caption: This image was found on many pieces of pottery in the Pecos valley.

entranceFees.title: Pea Ridge NMP Entrance Fee - Per Vehicle

properties.directionsInfo: The new entrance road is located on Highway 62 1.3 miles east of the intersection of Highways 62 and 72.

entrancePasses.description: The pass is good for any of the two signers plus three additional visitors in one vehicle. The pass will provide access to the park visitor center and the tour road. The pass is valid for one year from the MONTH of purchase. So purchase the pass at the beginning of the month and you essentially can use it for 13 months!
entrancePasses.title: Pea Ridge NMP Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Hot and humid in summer; winters can be cold with snow and ice.
properties.name: Pea Ridge
properties.description: On March 7-8, 1862, over 23,000 soldiers fought here to decide the fate of Missouri and was a turning point of the war in the West.  The 4,300 acre battlefield honors those who fought and died on these grounds. Pea Ridge was the most pivotal Civil War battle west of the Mississippi River and is one of the most intact Civil War battlefields in the United States.

images.altText: A reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern.
images.title: Elkhorn Tavern
images.caption: Used as a field hospital during the Battle of Pea Ridge, the Elkhorn Tavern is a focal point on the Pea Ridge National Military Park.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Petersburg National Battlefield and passes are not available for purchase.
entranceFees.title: Petersburg National Battlefield has no entrance fees

properties.directionsInfo: The Eastern Front (Main) Visitor Center is located approximately 2.5 miles east of Rt. 95 off of Route 36 in Petersburg. If travelling north on Rt. 95, take exit 50D and follow signs to Wythe Street. Once on Wythe Street, travel 2.5 miles east to entrance of Battlefield. If travelling south on Rt. 95, take Exit 52 (Wythe Street). Again, travel about 2.5 miles to entrance.
properties.weatherInfo:
Winters are usually cool with temperatures averaging in the 40s. 
Spring and fall are mild.
Summer can bring very hot and humid weather.
properties.name: Petersburg
properties.description: Nine and a half months, 70,000 casualties, the suffering of civilians, thousands of U. S. Colored Troops fighting for the freedom of their race, and the decline of Gen. Robert E. Lee's Army of No. Virginia all describe the Siege of Petersburg. It was here Gen. Ulysses S. Grant cut off all of Petersburg's supply lines ensuring the fall of Richmond on April 3, 1865. Six days later, Lee surrendered.

images.altText: Confederate Battery V after the Union Army captured it in June, 1864.
images.title: Battery V
images.caption: Confederate Battery V was stormed on June 15, 1864 during the Union Army's opening attack on Petersburg.

images.altText: Plantation home prior to the War. U.S. Quartermaster Headquarters during the Siege.
images.title: Appomattox Plantation (Eppes Home)
images.caption: This home and the grounds surrounding it were used by General Grant and his staff during the Siege of Petersburg.

images.altText: Snow covered cannon overlooking the Crater Battlefield
images.title: Snow Covered Cannon
images.caption: Soldiers spent months in the trenches around Petersburg, including snowy winter mornings.

images.altText: Exhibits, video, and artifacts inhabit this visitor contact station opened in 2009.
images.title: Five Forks Visitor Contact Station
images.caption: The Battle of Five Forks was nicknames the "Waterloo of the Confederacy" by Confederate General Thomas Munford.

images.altText: Fire! Reenactors fire cannon during 150th Anniv. program.
images.title: Artillery Demonstration
images.caption: Thousands of visitors learn the steps involved in firing off a Civil War cannon by members of the Pegram's Battery Reenactment Unit.

entranceFees.description: Fees are collected at six beaches from late spring through the end of September. Daily fees: vehicles, $20; motorcycles, $15; walk-in, $10. Annual national seashore pass is $60.
entranceFees.title: Beach Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The national seashore is located in eastern Massachusetts and is accessed via Rt. 6. The park is 20 miles east of Hyannis, MA.

entrancePasses.description: Pass entitles free entry into the six national seashore beaches for the season. The pass is assigned to a single vehicle, and may not be transferred to another vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance Pass to Cape Cod National Seashore

entrancePasses.description: Pass provides entrance into six beaches for one day. Multiple beaches managed by the national seashore can be visited in one day using the same pass. Passes may not be transferred to other vehicles.
entrancePasses.title: Daily Entrance Fee for Cape Cod National Seashore

properties.weatherInfo: Cape Cod's weather is generally moderated by its proximity to the ocean. Winter is typically cold with some snow. Spring is often rainy. Summer is usually warm and humid. Fall is generally dry and clear.
properties.name: Cape Cod
properties.description: The great Outer Beach described by Thoreau in the 1800s is protected within the national seashore. Forty miles of pristine sandy beach, marshes, ponds, and uplands support diverse species. Lighthouses, cultural landscapes, and wild cranberry bogs offer a glimpse of Cape Cod's past and continuing ways of life. Swimming beaches and walking and biking trails beckon today's visitors.

images.altText: Pink surise and waves
images.title: Outer beach
images.caption: Many visitors rise early to watch the sun rise over the Atlantic.

images.altText: Water makes an impression in the sand
images.title: Sand and Water
images.caption: A walk on a Cape Cod beach is never the same twice.

images.altText: The front of a red kayak floating on a pond points towards a forest with red and orange leaves
images.title: Exploring the Park by Water
images.caption: Exploring the park by water provides a different perspective on the land.

images.altText: A flock of bird flies by a beach with waves
images.title: Birds and Beach
images.caption: The national seashore is known for its species diversity, including threatened and endangered birds.

images.altText: A park ranger with a bucket and net walks on a sandy path with a boy and a man.
images.title: Fish, Snails, and Horseshoe Crab Tales
images.caption: Rangers and visitors explore the park together during dozens of programs every week during the summer.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enjoy the grounds of Cape Hatteras National Seashore.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance

properties.directionsInfo:
Cape Hatteras National Seashore is located along NC-12 in the Outer Banks of North Carolina. You can reach the seashore from the north by following US 158 to Nag Heads, NC and the turn-off to NC-12 and Cape Hatteras National Seashore. From the south, you can take NCDOT ferries from Swanquarter, NC and Cedar Island, NC to the village of Ocracoke on Ocracoke Island.

The provided physical address is the location of the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse, roughly in the middle of the park.
properties.weatherInfo: The weather along the Outer Banks varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for forecast information.
properties.name: Cape Hatteras
properties.description: The sound of ocean waves, the starry night sky, or the calm of the salt marshes, you can experience it all. Shaped by the forces of water, wind, and storms these islands are ever changing. The plants, wildlife, and people who live here adapt continually. Whether you are enjoying the beach, kayaking the sound, or climbing the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse there is something for everyone to explore!

images.altText: A young girl performs a cartwheel as she enjoys the beach.
images.title: Cartwheel on the Beach
images.caption: Girl enjoys Cape Hatteras by performing a cartwheel.

images.altText: Black and white painting of the brick Cape Hatteras Lighthouse.
images.title: Cape Hatteras Lighthouse
images.caption: Black and white spirals decorate the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse.

images.altText: Two kids play in the sand.
images.title: Playing in the Sand
images.caption: Two kids enjoy the sands of Cape Hatteras.

images.altText: A young girl paddles across the water with the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse visible in the distance.
images.title: Paddling Pamlico Sound
images.caption: Lots of recreation opportunities await visits on the sound side of the barrier islands.

images.altText: The first-order Fresnel lens is visible in the lantern room of the Bodie Island Lighthouse.
images.title: Fresnel Lens
images.caption: Bodie Island Lighthouse still has its first-order Fresnel lens.

entranceFees.description: There is no charge for coming to Cape Lookout National Seashore.  The Harkers Island Visitor Center and the Beaufort Visitor Information Center can be reached by car.  All other locations require a trip by ferry.  There is a charge for the ferry. Contact the ferry company for costs and schedules.
entranceFees.title: Cape Lookout Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Only two areas of Cape Lookout National Seashore can be reached without taking a ferry: the Visitor Center  on Harkers Island and the Visitor Information Center in Beaufort, NC.  Please note: the park mailing address does not bring you to the Harkers Island Visitor Center parking lot. If you are using a GPS device - use the parking lot coordinates (34.68494, -74.52725) or the following "address" which approximates the location of the parking lot entrance: 1800 Island Rd, Harkers Island, NC 28531
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures generally range from 50 F to 70+ F. Rain & wind are common

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 80 F to 100 F with high humidity (80-90%).  Average wind speed is 10-15 mph. Be prepared with plenty of water.  With little shade on the islands, an umbrella to provide shade from the sun is a good idea.
 
Fall: Temperatures usually range from the high 70 F to the upper 40 F.  

Winter: Temperatures usually range from 50 F - 32 F. Winds can be strong. Dress in layers.
properties.name: Cape Lookout
properties.description: A boat ride three miles off-shore brings you to the barrier islands of Cape Lookout National Seashore.  Horse watching, shelling, fishing, birding, camping, lighthouse climbing, and touring historic villages--there’s something for everyone at Cape Lookout.  Be sure to bring all the food, water, and supplies you need (and carry your trash out of the park) when visiting these remote beaches.

images.altText: Mature sea oat plant seed heads gracefully drooping in the sun
images.title: Sea Oats
images.caption: In late summer, Sea Oats are the most conspicuous plant growing on the sand dunes with their graceful, drooping seed heads.

images.altText: small sandpipers poke their bills in the sand while waves break in the background
images.title: Sanderlings
images.caption: Small sandpipers, called Sanderlings, are common sights on the ocean beach as they search for food in the sand between waves

images.altText: : Black & white patterned tower of the Cape Lookout Lighthouse stands against a blue & white cloud f
images.title: Cape Lookout Lighthouse
images.caption: The Cape Lookout Lighthouse is still an active aid-to-navigation, warning ships of the nearby shoals.  Climbing to up to see the view from the gallery level, 14 stories above the ground, is also a popular activity by visitors during the summer.

images.altText: 2 ladies sit in beach chairs on the sand with their feet in the water
images.title: Relaxing by the Ocean
images.caption: Watching the waves, feeling the cool sea breeze and the warmth of the sun make for a relaxing day.

images.altText: A surf fisherman stands in the water holding his surf rod and watching the waves
images.title: Surf fishing
images.caption: Surf fishing is a popular pastime at the beach

entranceFees.description: This per-person fee is valid for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee - Adults 16 and over

entranceFees.description: Permit fee is per night, for an individual campsite at the Sea Camp Campground. Permits are good for up to six people.
entranceFees.title: Sea Camp Campground

entranceFees.description: Permit fee is for one night, for an individual campsite at Stafford Beach Campground. Permit is good for up to six people.
entranceFees.title: Stafford Beach Campground

entranceFees.title: Hickory Hill Campground

entranceFees.description: Permit is good for one night at Yankee Paradise Campground. This is a wilderness campground. Camping must be in the designated campground area but specific sites are not assigned. Permit is good for up to 6 people.
entranceFees.title: Yankee Paradise Campground

entranceFees.description: Permit is good for one night at Brickhill Bluff Campground. This is a wilderness campground. Camping must be in the designated campground area but specific sites are not assigned. Permit is good for up to 6 people.
entranceFees.title: Brickhill Bluff Campground

entranceFees.description: Permit fee is good for one night at a designated groupsite at Sea Camp Campground. Permit is good for 7 - 20 people.
entranceFees.title: Sea Camp Groupsite

properties.directionsInfo:
Driving Directions
To reach the visitor center from Interstate 95:
•	Take Exit 3 for US 40
•	Take US 40 East toward “Historic Downtown St. Marys”
•	US 40 becomes Osborne Rd. Continue on until you reach the waterfront
•	Turn right on St. Marys Rd 
•	The visitor center will be two blocks down on your left (113 St. Marys St W, St Marys GA 31558)

entrancePasses.description: The pass is good for one calendar year from month of purchase. The pass admits only the pass holder.
entrancePasses.title: Cumberland Island National Seashore Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Cumberland Island’s climate is hot and humid during summer when temperatures tend to be in the 80's (>26 C) and mild during winter when temperatures tend to be in the 60's (<20 C). The warmest month of the year is July with an average high of 90 degrees F (32 C), while the coldest is January with an average low of 45 degrees F (44 C). Visit the Current Conditions page for an up-to-date local forecast:
https://www.nps.gov/cuis/planyourvisit/conditions.htm#weather
properties.name: Cumberland Island
properties.description: St Marys is the gateway to Cumberland Island, Georgia's largest and southernmost barrier island. Here pristine maritime forests, undeveloped beaches and wide marshes whisper the stories of both man and nature. Natives, missionaries, enslaved African Americans and Wealthy Industrialists all walked here.  Cumberland Island is also home to over 9,800 acres of Congressionally designated Wilderness.

images.altText: Sand dunes covered with shrubs and grasses
images.title: Vegetated Dunes
images.caption: Vegetation holds dunes in place providing a barrier to erosion forces and creating essential interdune meadows to support island life.

images.altText: Alligator resting on a log in pond
images.title: Home To Wildlife
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses a variety of forest, marsh, and coastal landscapes providing a home for numerous species including American Alligators.

images.altText: Ocean beach at sunrise
images.title: Undeveloped Coast
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses nearly 18 miles of undeveloped beach offering recreation for visitors and essential nesting area for birds and sea turtles.

images.altText: large, white mansion behind oak trees draped with Spanish Moss
images.title: Plum Orchard Mansion
images.caption: Visitors can take a guided tour of the Plum Orchard Mansion and experience the luxuries of Victorian high society as well as the effort and ingenuity it took to make it possible.

images.altText: rippled sands of a beach in front of pine tree covered bluffs
images.title: Island Bluffs Shaped By Tides
images.caption: Tidal forces continue to shape the land today as they have for thousands of years forming high bluffs used for fortifications and ship docking throughout the island’s history.

images.altText: huge oak trees and palm shrubs line a sand road
images.title: Historic Main Road
images.caption: While visitors to the island cannot bring vehicles, they can travel the historic main park road by foot and bicycle. Some remaining island residents will still drive vehicles on the road to reach their residences as they have for generations.

images.altText: brick and stone ruins of a large mansion at sunset under colorful clouds
images.title: Dungeness Ruins
images.caption: Dugeness was the largest mansion built on the island as part of the Carnegie Estate. Though lost to fire in 1959, the ruins of the mansion and several of its support structures are a reminder of the island’s rich history.

images.altText: small white one room church, old red house in the background, under cloudy skies
images.title: The Settlement
images.caption: The remote north end of the island is home to the First African Baptist Church and The Settlement, where African American residents were able to purchase their first deeded property on the island at the end of the 1800s.

images.altText: tidal creek at low tide surrounded by palm and oak trees
images.title: Tidal Creek
images.caption: Rising tides bring valuable nutrients into tidal creeks, while receding tides remove waste. This makes the tide cycle the beating heart of the island’s tidal creeks, salt marshes, and estuaries.

entranceFees.description:
Expanded amenity fees are collected at Smithfield Beach, Milford Beach, Bushkill Access, in Dingmans Access in PA and Turtle Beach and Watergate in NJ.

Daily fees are per vehicle for up to 7 adult occupants. Any additional adults are $2.00 per person. We do not charge for children 15 and younger.
entranceFees.title: Vehicle Expanded amenity fee

entranceFees.description:
Expanded amenity fees are collected at Smithfield Beach, Milford Beach, Bushkill Access, in Dingmans Access in PA and Turtle Beach and Watergate in NJ.

Those who walk or bicycle in to use the beaches are charged a fee.
entranceFees.title: Bicycle expanded amenity fee

entranceFees.description:
Expanded amenity fees are collected at Smithfield Beach, Milford Beach, Bushkill Access, in Dingmans Access in PA and Turtle Beach and Watergate in NJ.

Those who walk in to use the beaches are charged a fee.
entranceFees.title: Pedestrian expanded amenity fee

entranceFees.description: The Park does does not charge an entrance fee but does have expanded amenity fees.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: We have season passes for $45.00 that are good for one vehicle only in this park only (DEWA); a 2nd pass for vehicles registered to same address is $25.00; a 3rd pass for vehicles registered to same address is $12.50, and 4th pass for vehicles registered to same address is $6.25. Senior and Accessible fees are 1/2 price of season passes.
entranceFees.title: Park Vehicle Season Pass

properties.directionsInfo: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area is a long, narrow park that sits between two major interstates, I-80 at the south and I-84 at the north. US 209 is the main north/south road through the park on the Pennsylvania side and Old Mine Road is the main north/south road though the park on the New Jersey side.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from lows of 26 F to highs of 80 F with average rainfall of 5 inches.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from lows of 55 F to highs of 85 F with average rainfall of 4 inches. 

Fall: Temperatures usually range from lows of 30 F to highs of 83F. Fall foliage is at its peak sometime in October as daily mountain temperatures vary frequently and influence the change.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from lows of 15 F to highs of 49 F.
properties.name: Delaware Water Gap
properties.description: Paddlers slip down the river between low forested mountains; anglers wade the trout streams; hikers scan the valley from the ridge or peer into the 1000-foot-deep Water Gap. The valley has known human hand and voice for 10,000 years. Floodplains nourished the Native farmer; waterfalls drew the Victorian vacationer. Today, a 70,000-acre park welcomes those who seek the outdoors close to home.

images.altText: View of the Delaware Water Gap from river level
images.title: Delaware Water Gap
images.caption: The Delaware Water Gap is the best known feature of the park, a distinct notch cut into the Kittatinny Ridge by the Delaware River.

images.altText: A waterfall in the background moves towards the viewer through a rocky riverbed

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for Fire Island National Seashore but plan to pay parking and/or transportation fees for most sites.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Fire Island National Seashore Headquarters:
Via Long Island Expressway/I-495: Take Exit 61 (Patchogue-Holbrook Road) to Waverly Ave. Head south on Waverly Ave to West Ave. Turn right onto Laurel Street.

Via NY-27: Take Exit 52 onto Waverly Ave. Head south on Waverly Ave to West Ave. Turn right onto Laurel Street.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures may range from high 30s to low 50s (F). Rain and sun are equally common.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 65 F to 90 F.

Fall: Temperatures from 70 F in early autumn to 40 F later in the season may be expected.

Winter: Temperatures in the 30s (F) are common, with below freezing temperatures possible.
properties.name: Fire Island
properties.description: Immerse yourself in an enchanting collage of coastal life and history. Rhythmic waves, high dunes, ancient maritime forests, historic landmarks and glimpses of wildlife, Fire Island has been a special place for diverse plants, animals and people for centuries. Far from the pressure of nearby big-city life, dynamic barrier island beaches offer both solitude and camaraderie, and spiritual renewal.

images.altText: Ripple marks in the sand near the shoreline
images.title: Fire Island's shoreline is constantly changing
images.caption: Fire Island beaches are constantly changing, offering first-time and repeat visitors something new each time they come.

images.altText: A view from a meadow of the historic Old Mastic House
images.title: Old Mastic House at William Floyd Estate
images.caption: A view of the Old Mastic House from the grounds of the William Floyd Estate

images.altText: Grasses and shrubs cover the undulating backdune habitat of Fire Island's wilderness.
images.title: Fire Island Wilderness
images.caption: Unparalleled opportunities for solitude and recreation can be found in New York State's only federally designated wilderness, the Otis Pike Fire Island High Dune Wilderness.

images.altText: The Fire Island Lighthouse against a vibrant sunset.
images.title: View of Fire Island Lighthouse from Great South Bay
images.caption: People from around the world come to visit the Fire Island Lighthouse.

images.altText: View of ocean and primary dune with boardwalk winding up to the Sunken Forest overlook.
images.title: View of primary dune from Sunken Forest overlook
images.caption: Get one of the best boardwalk views on a walk through the Sunken Forest - a more than 350 year-old, globally rare ecosystem.

IA Military Pass holders along with their family and IA EKIP (Every Kid in a Park) Fourth Grade Pass holders along with their families   will receive free beach parking.

IA Military Pass holders along with their families and IA EKIP (Every Kid in a Park) Fourth Grade pass holders along with their families will receive free beach parking.

properties.directionsInfo: Gateway is located in two states; NJ and NY, and has three units:  Jamaica Bay, Sandy Hook and Staten Island.  You can access most of our park by car and public transportation.   Please visit our website for specific directions to all of our units

entrancePasses.description: Golden Age Passports are $80 lifetime passes for citizens and permanent residents who are 62 or older.  They will allow a 50% discount for parking fees at both Sandy Hook and Jacob Riis Park.  You may obtain these at any of Gateway's visitor centers, as well as other parks throughout the country.
entrancePasses.title: Golden Age Passport

entrancePasses.description: Golden Access Passes are free, and offer lifetime access to citizens and permanent residents who have been medically determined to have a permanent disability.  Golden Access Pass holders will receive a 50% discount for parking at both Sandy Hook and Jacob Riis Park.  You can obtain these passes at any Gateway visitor center as well as at other national parks.
entrancePasses.title: Golden Access Passes

entrancePasses.description: These are available to U.S. 4th graders and are good for the duration of their fourth grade year.  You can find out more at the Every Kid in a Park website.  Holders of these passes will be able to park for free at both Sandy Hook and Jacob Riis Park.
entrancePasses.title: 4th Grade Passes

entrancePasses.description: This annual pass is for all active military members.  Those who display this pass, along with current military ID will be able to park for free at both Sandy Hook and Jacob Riis Park.  IA military passes are available at all Gateway visitor centers.
entrancePasses.title: IA Military Pass Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Gateway National Recreation Area includes several separate land areas spread throughout the New York metropolitan area. The New York area experiences four distinct seasons. Temperatures are moderate in the spring and fall, but range from the high 90's during the summer to snow and sleet in winter.
properties.name: Gateway
properties.description: Gateway is a large diverse urban park with 27,000 acres spanning Sandy Hook in N.J. and Jamaica Bay and Staten Island in N.Y. It offers green spaces, beaches, wildlife and outdoor recreation, all alongside historic structures and cultural landscapes. It is the 4th most visited National Park Service unit with more than 9.2 million annual visitors. Gateway can be reached by car, ferry, bus or train.

images.altText: Tent at  Floyd Bennett Field campsite in Gateway's Jamaica Bay unit.
images.title: You can camp at all three units of Gateway
images.caption: You can camp at all three units of Gateway, in the shadow of NYC.

images.altText: Visitors enjoying the sun and sand at Jacob Riis Park
images.title: Enjoying a summer's day at Jacob Riis Park
images.caption: Millions of visitors visit Gateway's beaches every summer.

images.altText: The Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge Visitor Center
images.title: Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge
images.caption: The Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge is the only wildlife refuge in the National Park Service

images.altText: The Sandy Hook lighthouse and keepers quarters
images.title: The Sandy Hook Lighthouse
images.caption: The Sandy Hook Lighthouse is the oldest continuously operating lighthouse in the United States.

images.altText: Battery Weed is the fort under the Verrazano Narrows Bridge in Staten Island.
images.title: Battery Weed
images.caption: Battery Weeds guards the entrance to the New York harbor.

entranceFees.description: There are no entry fees at John Day Fossil Beds National Monument.
entranceFees.title: No entrance fees at John Day Fossil Beds National Monument

properties.directionsInfo: John Day Fossil Beds encompasses 14,000 acres in three geographically separated units in Oregon: Sheep Rock, Painted Hills, and Clarno. The Sheep Rock Unit is located between the towns of Dayville and Kimberly. The Painted Hills Unit is located 9 miles northwest of of the town of Mitchell. The Clarno Unit is located on Highway 218 twenty miles west of the town of Fossil.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather conditions at John Day Fossil Beds National Monument are highly variable in this semi-arid desert landscape. Summer highs can climb into the 110's. Winters tend to be fairly mild, with occassional snow and ice and lows occasionally dipping into the single digits.
properties.name: John Day Fossil Beds
properties.description: Colorful rock formations at John Day Fossil Beds preserve a world class record of plant and animal evolution, changing climate, and past ecosystems that span over 40 million years.  Exhibits and a working lab at the Thomas Condon Paleontology and Visitor Center as well as scenic drives and hikes at all three units allow visitors to explore the prehistoric past of Oregon and see science in action.

images.altText: Sheep Rock
images.title: Sheep Rock
images.caption: Sheep Rock, with the John Day River in the foreground

images.altText: Painted Hills
images.title: Painted Hills
images.caption: The Painted Hills on a stormy winter day.

images.altText: Clarno
images.title: Clarno
images.caption: The Clarno Palisades are remains of ancient volcanic mudslides.

images.altText: Miohippus
images.title: Miohippus
images.caption: Miohippus is just one of many amazing fossils found here.

images.altText: Paleontologist at work
images.title: Paleontologist at work
images.caption: The Thomas Condon Paleontology Center is both a visitor center and research center.

properties.fullName: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument

entranceFees.description: Per single passenger vehicle or motorcycle (less than 14 passengers), valid for 7 consecutive days. If someone on the motorcycle has a valid National Park Service annual or lifetime pass, no entrance fee is charged.
entranceFees.title: Prince William Forest Park Vehicle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Per person walk-in or bike-in valid for 7 consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Prince William Forest Park Individual Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Per single motorcycle, valid for 7 consecutive days. If someone on the motorcycle has a valid National Park Service annual or lifetime pass, no entrance fee is charged.
entranceFees.title: Prince William Forest Park Motorcycle Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From Washington, D.C. and points north: 
Take I-95 south to exit 150-B (VA Route 619/Joplin Road). The park entrance is the second right. 

From Fredericksburg and points south:
Take I-95 north to exit 150 (VA Route 619/Joplin Road). Turn left at the bottom of the exit ramp and continue on VA Route 619 West approximately 1/4 mile to the park entrance.

entrancePasses.description: Provides unlimited entry to the park for one year through the month of purchase. Provides entry for pass holders and occupants of a single personal vehicle (capacity of 14 passengers or less). For walk-ins pass is good for holder and 4 additional people.
entrancePasses.title: Prince William Forest Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Prince William Forest Park experiences all four seasons. Spring and fall are generally comfortable with precipitation possible.Summers can be hot and humid with average temperatures in the high 80s and with sudden thunderstorms possible. July and August are the hottest months. Winters can be cold with average temperatures in the winter of 41 degrees with variable precipitation. The main park roads can close due to snowy conditions, though cross-country skiing and snow-shoeing are permitted.
properties.name: Prince William Forest
properties.description: Prince William Forest Park is an oasis, a respite of quiet and calm. In 1936, Chopawamsic Recreation Area opened its gates to house children's 'relief' camps during the Great Depression. Renamed Prince William Forest Park in 1948, these fragrant woods and trickling streams have welcomed generations of campers, hikers, bikers and nature lovers. Discover Northern Virginia's best kept secret!

images.altText: Carter Pond on a sunny day in summer
images.title: Carter Pond
images.caption: Carter Pond is a great place to fish.

images.altText: Farms to Forest Trail surrounded by ferns
images.title: Farms to Forest Trail
images.caption: The Farms to Forest Trail is a favorite among visitors.

images.altText: Mountain Laurel blooming near Parking Lot I.
images.title: Mountain Laurel
images.caption: Mountain Laurel can be spotted throughout the park.

images.altText: A tree with orange leaves against the blue sky
images.title: Fall Foliage
images.caption: Fall is a beautiful time of year in the park.

images.altText: Fall colors come alive near Parking Lot H
images.title: Near Parking Lot H
images.caption: Many people visit the park to see the brilliant fall colors

images.altText: Tuliptrees grow tall with blue sky above them
images.title: Tree on South Valley Trail
images.caption: Tuliptrees are a mid-secession tree in the forest.

images.title: Historic Park Sign for Chopawamsic RDA
images.caption: A sign on Joplin Road marks the park entrance in the mid-1930s.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to access San Juan Island National Historical Park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: San Juan Island is served by Washington State Ferries, several private cruise and shuttle craft and two air carriers (one of which has both land and seaplane service). The Washington State Ferries terminal is 85 miles north of Seattle and 90 miles south of Vancouver, BC in Anacortes, WA.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40 F to 60 F. Wildflowers are at their peak around May.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 45 F to 70 F. On very sunny days, be prepared with water-heat exhaustion is a common complaint among park visitors who are unprepared.

Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40 F to 65 F. Rain is common.

Winter: Temperatures range from 35 F to 50 F. Be prepared with cold and wet weather gear and numerous layers if you intend to be outside. Rain and wind are common.
properties.name: San Juan Island
properties.description: San Juan Island is well known for splendid vistas, saltwater shore, quiet woodlands, orca whales and one of the last remaining native prairies in the Puget Sound/Northern Straits region. But it was also here in 1859 that the United States and Great Britain nearly went to war over possession of the island, the crisis ignited by the death of a pig.

images.altText: a sun setting behind historic parade grounds
images.title: Sunset at American Camp
images.caption: The sun sets on the American Camp parade grounds

images.altText: people visiting a historic building
images.title: English Camp Barracks
images.caption: Visitors come from all over the world to explore English Camp

images.altText: a historic cannon being fired
images.title: Encampment
images.caption: Reenactors fire a cannon at Encampment

images.altText: flowers in bloom
images.title: English Camp Formal Garden
images.caption: The formal garden in bloom

images.altText: a sandy beach and blue sky
images.title: Grandma's Cove
images.caption: Grandma's Cove is a popular spot for park visitors

entranceFees.description: Entrance to the park, visitor centers, and view park films
entranceFees.title: Shiloh National Military Park Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
The park is 110 miles from the Memphis airport and 150 miles from the Nashville airport.

From the west (Memphis, Tennessee, area): Take Highway 72 East to Corinth, Mississippi. From the Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center, take Highway 22 North to the Shiloh Battlefield.

From the northeast (Nashville, Tennessee, area): Take Interstate 40 West to the Parker's Crossroads Exit. Then take Highway 22 South to Shiloh Battlefield. Continue on Highway 22 South to the Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center.
properties.weatherInfo: Shiloh National Military Park traditionally experiences mild winters and hot summers with an average high of 90 degrees in the summer and 50 in winter; average lows in the winter are 34 degrees but single digits are not unusual. Rainfall in the area averages 57 inches a year with an additional 2-3 inches of ice/snow and violent thunderstorms can take place at any time of year.
properties.name: Shiloh
properties.description: Visit the sites of the most epic struggle in the Western Theater of the Civil War. Nearly 110,000 American troops clashed in a bloody contest that resulted in 23,746 casualties; more casualties than in all of America's previous wars combined. Explore both the Shiloh and Corinth battlefields to discover the impact of this struggle on the soldiers and on the nation.

images.altText: Sunrise in the Shiloh National Cemetery
images.title: Cemetery
images.caption: Sunrise in the Shiloh National Cemetery

images.altText: Photo of the front of the visitor center
images.title: Park Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitor Center at Shiloh National Military Park

entranceFees.description:
Cedar Creek and Belle Grove National Historical Park is a no fee park for the interim visitor contact station and ranger led programs. Therefore, the America the Beautiful-National Parks Pass discounts do not apply.

Our partner sites are non-profit organizations and do not receive federal funding from the National Park Service. Therefore, The America the Beautiful-National Parks Pass discounts DO NOT apply at partner sites. This includes all of the America the Beautiful Passes.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: The National Park Service Visitor Contact Station is located at 7712 Main Street, Middletown, Virginia 22645 in the Middletown Courts plaza. The park is located near the intersection of Interstates 81 and 66 in the northern Shenandoah Valley.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers in Virginia are often very hot with high heat indexes. Check the weather in advance of your trip, and plan accordingly. Dress for the heat and for sun protection. Pack lots of water.

The Shenandoah Valley experiences temperate spring and fall seasons and winters with snowfall and cold temperatures.
properties.name: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove
properties.description: The Shenandoah Valley invites you to learn about its rich heritage, from Native Americans who first shaped the land, to pioneers of this frontier; this fertile area became one of the most important wheat producing regions of the entire South. The Valley also witnessed some of the most dramatic events of the Civil War,including the Battle of Cedar Creek, a decisive October 19, 1864 Union victory.

images.altText: Sunrise over Belle Grove
images.title: Sunrise over Belle Grove
images.caption: Sunrise over Belle Grove

images.altText: Image of the Heater House
images.title: The Heater House
images.caption: The Heater House

images.altText: Ranger giving kids Program
images.title: Kids Program
images.caption: Ranger Jeff presenting a kids program.

images.altText: Visitors watching a ranger program at Belle Grove
images.title: Cedar Creek and Belle Grove in a Box
images.caption: Ranger Shannon presents Cedar Creek and Belle Grove in a Box.

images.altText: Ranger presenting program on top of the Massanutten Moutain.
images.title: Signal Knob Program
images.caption: Ranger presenting program at Signal Knob.

properties.fullName: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove National Historical Park

entranceFees.description: Chiricahua National Monument is a fee free park. No entrance fee is required.
entranceFees.title: Chiricahua Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Chiricahua National Monument is located 120 miles southeast of Tucson. Take I-10 east from Tucson to the first exit for Willcox. Travel 3 miles into town to the stoplight and turn right. You will follow Arizona State Highway 186 for 32 miles to the junction of Arizona State Highway 181. Turn left and 4 miles later you will be at the Chiricahua entrance station. Maximum vehicle length is 29 feet to drive beyond the visitor center. A hiking shuttle is available daily at 9 am from the visitor center.
properties.weatherInfo:
Chiricahua National Monument ranges from 5,124 feet / 1,562 meters in elevation at the entrance station to 7,310 feet / 2,228 meters at the summit of Sugarloaf Mountain. You can enjoy the differences of four seasons.
http://www.nps.gov/chir/planyourvisit/weather.htm
properties.name: Chiricahua
properties.description: A "Wonderland of Rocks" is waiting for you to explore at Chiricahua National Monument. The 8-mile paved scenic drive and 17-miles of day-use hiking trails provide opportunities to discover the beauty, natural sounds, and inhabitants of this 11,985 acre site. Visit the Faraway Ranch Historic District to discover more about the people who have called this area home.

images.altText: Hikers make their way through a rock canyon
images.title: Hiking through Echo Canyon
images.caption: A network of easily navigable trails lead hikers into the heart of Chiricahua's standing rocks

images.altText: Children climb through rock archways
images.title: Echo Canyon Grotto
images.caption: The standing rocks at Chiricahua create natural nooks and crannies ready to be explored

images.altText: A hiker stands among rock formations
images.title: View from Massai Point
images.caption: Massai Point offers excellent views of the standing rocks at Chiricahua

images.altText: A ranch house in a green field surrounds by low mountains
images.title: Faraway Ranch
images.caption: Faraway Ranch preserves the heritage of early European settlers in the Chiricahua Mountains

images.altText: A narrow road winds between tall oaks and rock cliffs
images.title: Bonita Canyon
images.caption: Bonita Canyon Scenic Drive winds through standing rocks and rhyolite cliffs, climbing to Massai Point at 6900 ft / 2100 m.

entranceFees.description: This per-person fee is valid year-round.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: Located right off Interstate 66, just 30 miles west of Washington D.C.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Mild weather, with average low/high temperatures from 33 F to 75 F.  Variable rainfall, with May being the wettest month of the year on average.

Summer: Warm and humid weather, with average temperatures from 61 F to 88 F.  Variable rainfall, with occasional downpours during storms.

Fall: Mild weather, with average temperatures from 35 F to 79 F.  Variable rainfall.

Winter: Mild to cool weather, with average temperatures from 24 F to 47 F.  Annual snowfall averages about 22 inches.
properties.name: Manassas
properties.description: On July 21, 1861, two armies clashed for the first time on the fields overlooking Bull Run. Heavy fighting swept away any notion of a quick war. In August 1862, Union and Confederate armies converged for a second time on the plains of Manassas. The Confederates won a solid victory bringing them to the height of their power.

images.altText: Bronze statue of Gen. T. J. "Stonewall" Jackson on horseback in an open field.
images.title: Stonewall Jackson Monument
images.caption: The statue of Confederate Gen. T. J. "Stonewall" Jackson stands on Henry Hill, near the spot where he earned his famous nickname.

images.altText: Red sandstone obelisk surrounded by post and rail fence.
images.title: Bull Run Monument
images.caption: The Bull Run Monument on Henry Hill is among the nation's earliest Civil War monuments.

images.altText: View of Stone House, with worm rail fence and well in front yard.
images.title: Stone House
images.caption: The historic Stone House, a battlefield landmark, sheltered Union wounded in both battles of Manassas.

images.altText: Civil War cannon and granite and bronze monument under a cloudy sky.
images.title: 14th Brooklyn Monument
images.caption: The 14th Brooklyn Monument overlooks the scene of heavy fighting near Groveton during Second Manassas.

images.altText: Rustic farmhouse, flanked by shade tree, stone monument, and white outbuilding, on top of a hill.
images.title: Henry House
images.caption: The Henry House, built over the ruins of the wartime dwelling, welcomed returning veterans to the battlefield after the war.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to visit Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Sand Creek Massacre NHS Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The Sand Creek Massacre is located in Kiowa County, Colorado. To visit the site, follow Colorado State Highway 96 east off Highway 287 near Eads, or west off Highway 385 at Sheridan Lake. Near Chivington, turn north onto County Road 54/Chief White Antelope Way or at Brandon, turn north onto County Road 59. Follow these roads to their intersections with County Road W. The park entrance is along CR W a mile east (right) of CR 54 or several miles west (left) of CR 59. Eight miles of dirt/sand roads lead to the
properties.weatherInfo: Weather conditions at the park vary considerably. Temperatures range from over 100°F in summer to under 20°F in winter. Visitors can expect blowing dust and sand year-round, especially during infrequent storms. Some of these storms produce violent tornadoes or large blizzards, so prepare accordingly.
properties.name: Sand Creek Massacre
properties.description:
The Sand Creek Massacre: profound, symbolic, spiritual, controversial, a site unlike any other in America.  

As 675 cavalrymen came around a prairie bend, the camps of Chiefs Black Kettle, White Antelope, and Left Hand lay in the valley before them.  Chaotic, horrific, tumultuous, and bloody, the events of November 29, 1864 changed the course of history.

images.altText: Four white Indian lodges on a grassy plain.
images.title: Cheyenne Lodges at Dawn
images.caption: Cheyenne and Arapaho Lodges erected in commemoration of the 150th Year of the Sand Creek Massacre

images.altText: A lone tipi frame and two wayside signs stand in a snow-covered landscape
images.title: Remembering the Past
images.caption: A tipi frame is backlit by an evening sky.

images.altText: A stone memorial on the prairie with an evening sky in the background.
images.title: Memorial at Sunset
images.caption: Back lit clouds form an impressive backdrop to the stone memorial dedicated to the memory of the Sand Creek Massacre.

images.altText: The uppermost branches of leafless trees in a grassy plain are lit by the setting sun.
images.title: Sunset along Sand Creek
images.caption: The setting sun highlights trees along Sand Creek, forming a hauntingly beautiful landscape

images.altText: A tipi frame is silhouetted by the evening sky.
images.title: Tipi Frame at Dusk
images.caption: The silhouette of a lone tipi at dusk symbolizes the tragic events that occurred in 1864 and of the indomitable spirit of the Cheyenne and Arapaho people, who overcame the tragedy and continue to work with the NPS to preserve its memory and legacy.

images.altText: An expanse of winter prairie with brown grasses, leafless trees, and low clouds above.
images.title: Winter clouds over Sand Creek
images.caption: Winter on the Southeastern Colorado Plains can produce beautiful scenes such as this.

images.altText: A Sand Creek memorial plaque and fallen tree trunk with trees in fall color behind.
images.title: Fall Colors along the Big Sandy Creek
images.caption: The leaves of Cottonwood trees along the Sand Creek burst with color during the fall.

images.altText: A wayside in the snow-covered foreground with a winter plain stretching behind.
images.title: Snow on Monument Hill Overlook
images.caption: This tranquil winter view shows snow throughout the Sand Creek Valley.

properties.fullName: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site

entrancePasses.description: Interagency Lifetime Senior Pass:  $80 Lifetime.  This is a pass for U.S. Citizens or permanent residents, age 62 or over. This pass provides access to, and the use of Federal recreation sites that charge an Entrance or Standard Amenity Fee*. This pass admits the pass holder and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle at per vehicle areas and pass holder plus 3 adults at per person fee areas.

In order to qualify for the pass, the military member must present a valid Department of Defense, CAC Card. Dependents must present a valid Department of Defense ID (DD Form 1173) that identifies the dependent and his or her sponsor. Some members of the Military Reserve might not be eligible.

This pass provides access to, and the use of Federal recreation sites that charge an Entrance or Standard Amenity Fee*. This pass admits the pass holder and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle at per vehicle areas and pass holder plus 3 adults at per person fee areas.

entrancePasses.description: Fourth grade students and their families can benefit from free admission to fee-collecting parks, public lands and waters by downloading a paper pass from the Every Kid Outdoors website. In addition, if the 4th grader would like to exchange the paper passes for a more durable "keepsake" Fourth Grade Annual Pass, they may do so at the park's visitor center from 9:00 to 4:00 daily.
entrancePasses.title: 4th Grade Student Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The weather is fairly mild.  Summers can be very warm and humid and winters cold and snowy.  We have four distinct seasons with the fall and spring being the best times to visit the battlefield.
properties.name: Antietam
properties.description: 23,000 soldiers were killed, wounded or missing after twelve hours of savage combat on September 17, 1862. The Battle of Antietam ended the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia's first invasion into the North and led Abraham Lincoln to issue the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation.

images.altText: a monument of a soldier in the background with graves in front of the monument
images.title: Antietam National Cemetery
images.caption: Private Soldier Monument at the cemetery

images.altText: fog filling in the low areas of the field at sunset
images.title: Fog Over the Battlefield
images.caption: View from the visitor center looking toward Bloody Lane at sunset

images.altText: a monument of a soldier at sunset
images.title: Monument at Sunset
images.caption: 130th Pennsylvania Monument at Bloody Lane

images.altText: artillery piece sitting on a rock break
images.title: Cannon the Field
images.caption: Artillery played a key role at Antietam.  Over 500 cannon were involved in the fighting.

images.altText: three arch stone bridge over Antietam Creek
images.title: Burnside Bridge
images.caption: Burnside Bridge in the snow from the Union side of Antietam Creek.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees at Cumberland Gap National Historical Park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
By Plane
The closest major airport is located in Knoxville, Tennessee approximately 85 miles away.  Flights can also be made into Lexington, Kentucky approximately 130 miles away.

By Car
The park entrance is located on Highway 25E just south of Middlesboro Kentucky.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers at Cumberland Gap are hot and humid, with temperatures commonly in the mid to upper 90s.

Winters are generally mild with rain and some periods of snow January through March. Temperatures usually range in the 30s and 40s. Weather can sometimes be unpredictable, especially at higher elevations.
properties.name: Cumberland Gap
properties.description: At Cumberland Gap, the first great gateway to the west, follow the buffalo, the Native American, the longhunter, the pioneer... all traveled this route through the mountains into the wilderness of Kentucky. Modern day explorers and travelers stand in awe at this great gateway and the many miles of trails and scenic features found in the park.

images.altText: Cleopatra's Pool in the Gap Cave
images.title: Gap Cave
images.caption: Cleopatra's Pool is located deep in the Gap Cave

images.altText: View from the Pinnacle Overlook
images.title: Mountain View
images.caption: View from the Pinnacle Overlook

images.altText: Hensley Settlement
images.title: Hensley Settlement
images.caption: Weathered log cabins greet visitors to Hensley Settlement

images.altText: Pioneers
images.title: Pioneers Crossing Creek
images.caption: History comes alive

images.altText: Sand Cave
images.title: Hiker in Sand Cave
images.caption: Sand Cave is a massive sandstone rockshelter found in the backcountry

entranceFees.description: This fee is for visitors, age 16 or older and is valid for 7 days from the time of purchase.
entranceFees.title: 16 + Years Old

entranceFees.description: There is no fee for children 15 years old or younger.
entranceFees.title: Age 0-15 Free!

Exit 78 to Parowan
Turn L onto E Cntr St

Drive W to Cedar Breaks NM
