entrancePasses.description:
Admission to Cedar Breaks National Monument for one year from date of purchase. 

This pass covers the entrance fee for the purchaser and three additional people 16 years of age or older. Admission for children 15 & under is free.
entrancePasses.title: Cedar Breaks Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Cedar Breaks sits at over 10,000 feet in elevation and is usually 10-20 degrees cooler than surrounding parks. Be prepared for cooler temperatures and unpredictable weather. Snow, sleet, and hail can occur at any time of the year, even in the summer! 

Summer-time highs are between 60 and 70°F and night-time lows dip to 30-40s°F.

Thunderstorms frequently develop in the afternoons. Be aware of lightning and avoid exposed trails and overlooks until storms pass.
properties.name: Cedar Breaks
properties.description: Discover one of America's most special parks! Crowning the grand staircase, Cedar Breaks sits at over 10,000 feet and looks down into a half-mile deep geologic amphitheater. Come wander among timeless bristlecone pines, stand in lush meadows of wildflower, ponder crystal-clear night skies and experience the richness of our subalpine forest.

images.altText: Photo of Cedar Breaks Visitor's Center
images.title: Cedar Breaks Visitor Center
images.caption: Stop by Cedar Breaks visitors center at Point Supreme for great views and information.

images.altText: Yellow sunflowers and orange paint-brush wildflowers in a meadow.
images.title: Wildflowers
images.caption: Cedar Breaks is famous for wildflowers blooming throughout the summer!

images.altText: Ancient Bristle-cone pine with sun shining through the branches.
images.title: Bristle-cone Pine Tree
images.caption: Ancient Bristle-cone pines grow along the rim at Cedar Breaks National Monument.

images.altText: View of Point Supreme Amphitheater overlook
images.title: Point Supreme Amphitheater
images.caption: Point Supreme Amphitheater

images.altText: Bluebell flowers growing on the rim of Cedar Breaks National Monument.
images.title: Bluebells on the Rim
images.caption: Bluebell flowers growing on the rim.

addresses.line1: Cedar Breaks National Monument: Administrative Office

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Chickasaw National Recreation Area.
entranceFees.title: Chickasaw NRA Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: From US I-35 drive through the towns of Davis and Sulphur to the intersection of State Highway 7 and 177. Drive south on Hwy. 177 and take the first left to the Travertine Nature Center. Park Headquarters is located at 901 W. 1st Street, Sulphur, Oklahoma.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers are hot and humid. Temperatures above 100ºF occur, and humidity often exceeds 50%. Winters are mild and prolonged freezes are rare. Thunderstorms are common April through July.
properties.name: Chickasaw
properties.description: Springs, streams, lakes - whatever its form, water is the attraction at Chickasaw National Recreation Area. Relax in the coolness of shaded streams or take a dip in a swimming hole. Little Niagara and Rock Creek beckon waders and swimmers. Veterans Lake calls anglers to test their skills. Lake of the Arbuckles provides excellent opportunities for motorboating, skiing, fishing, and swimming.

images.altText: Lincoln Bridge with Travertine Creek flowing below
images.title: Lincoln Bridge
images.caption: Lincoln Bridge stands out as one of the oldest park structures

images.altText: Two people hiking over a water feature
images.title: Hiking to Buffalo Springs
images.caption: Two people walk towards Buffalo Springs, one of the park's many fresh water springs

images.altText: Herd of bison
images.title: Park Bison
images.caption: The park has a herd of bison which are very popular

images.altText: Lake boating on a summer day
images.title: Lake of the Arbuckles
images.caption: Lake of the Arbuckles attracts many boaters each summer for various recreational activities

images.altText: Lake fishing with family
images.title: Family Fishing Fun
images.caption: Learning to Fish at Veterns Lake

entranceFees.description: Free
entranceFees.title: Fossil Butte Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
By car: Travel 9 miles west of Kemmerer, Wyoming on U.S. Highway 30. There is a highway sign near mile post 44; turn right onto Lincoln County Road 300. The Historic Quarry Trail is approximately 1/2 mile on the right. Continue west on County Road 300 for approximately 3 miles to Chicken Creek Road which provides access to the visitor center, scenic drive, Nature Trail and picnic area.

Closest airports: Rock Springs, Wyoming (130 miles); Salt Lake City, Utah (150 miles)
properties.weatherInfo:
Expect a variety of weather conditions no matter what time of year you visit. Spring, fall and winter can be very cold; expect snow and winter conditions.

Spring: Day time temperatures usually range from 30 F to 65 F

Summer: Day time temperatures range from 60 F to 90 F

Fall: Day time temperatures range from 45 F to 70 F 

Winter: Day time temperatures range from -20 F to 30 F
properties.name: Fossil Butte
properties.description: Some of the world's best preserved fossils are found in the flat-topped ridges of southwestern Wyoming's cold sagebrush desert. Fossilized fishes, insects, plants, reptiles, birds, and mammals are exceptional for their abundance, variety, and detail of preservation. Most remarkable is the story they tell of ancient life in a subtropical landscape.

images.altText: fossil palm frond
images.title: Palm Frond
images.caption: Fossil palm fronds and other plants indicate a climate similar to the Gulf Coast states.

images.altText: visitor center with Fossil Butte in the background
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: The visitor center is nestled in a sagebrush landscape beneath Fossil Butte. Over 300 fossils are on exhibit.

images.altText: a well preserved fossil fish, Cockerellites liops
images.title: Cockerellites liops, a Common Fossil Fish
images.caption: Fossils from the Green River Formation are known for their excellent preservation, abundance, and diversity. Cockerellites liops is one of the common fishes found here.

images.altText: A scenic view of Fossil Basin in early summer; yellow limestone, red mudstones and green vegetation
images.title: The Limestone Ridges, Remnants of Ancient Fossil Lake, Contrast the Green, Early Summer Landscape.
images.caption: Early Summer Beauty in the High Desert of Southwestern Wyoming

images.altText: Fish fossils, Knightia eocaena, exposed near cliff
images.title: Fossils on the Ridge
images.caption: Knightia eocaena, the most abundant vertebrate fossil in the world, lies exposed near cliff face.

entranceFees.description: The National Park Service does not charge any entrance fees for admission to Kalaupapa National Historical Park. All visitors to Kalaupapa can make reservations with one of the two tour companies (see Guided tour info). For guests of Kalaupapa residents, your sponsor is responsible for applying for a permit. Any persons who have not properly secured a permit into the settlement will not be admitted entrance. Children under the age of 16 are not allowed in Kalaupapa Settlement.
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

properties.directionsInfo: Kalaupapa is an extremely isolated place, surrounded on three sides by ocean and two-thousand foot cliffs on the fourth. Consequently, there is no road access into the peninsula. Kalaupapa cannot be reached by automobile. To get to the park, visitors must travel by air, mule, or on foot. See the park's Direction and Transportation webpage for additional information.

entrancePasses.description: All visitors to Kalaupapa must obtain a health permit, which can be acquired by making reservations with Kekaula Tours (808) 567-6088 or Saint Damien & Mother Marianne Cope Molokai Tours (808) 895-1673.
entrancePasses.title: State Permit

properties.weatherInfo: Hawaii enjoys warm temperatures year-round, although site conditions at the park can vary depending on weather and time of year.  The rainy season is in the winter with the more hot and humid days in the summer. Trade winds are fairly constant and typically blow from the northeast. Daytime temperatures range from 65–75° F in the winter to 80-90°F in the summer. Nighttime temperatures are often in the 60-70°F range.
properties.name: Kalaupapa
properties.description:
When Hansen's disease (leprosy) was introduced to the Hawaiian Islands, King Kamehameha V banished all afflicted to the isolated Kalaupapa peninsula on the north shore of Molokai.  

Since 1866, more than 8000 people, mostly Hawaiians, have died at Kalaupapa. Once a prison, Kalaupapa is now refuge for the few remaining residents who are now cured, but were forced to live their lives in isolation.

images.altText: View of Kalaupapa Peninsula from Overlook
images.title: Overview of Kalaupapa Peninsula
images.caption: The Kalaupapa peninsula was once a prison for those inflicted with Hansen's disease.  Approximately 8000 people were forced to live their lives in isolation here.

images.altText: View of pali (sea cliffs) on the north shore of Molokai
images.title: Pali (Sea cliffs) at Kalaupapa
images.caption: Kalaupapa National Historical Park contains some of the world's tallest sea cliffs, which formed a natural barrier to the Hansen's disease settlement.

images.altText: View of residences along Damien Road
images.title: Kalaupapa Settlement
images.caption: Patients lived in a combination of group homes and single family residences at Kalaupapa.

images.altText: View of the sunrise over the north shore of Molokai
images.title: Kalawao at Sunrise
images.caption: Kalawao with its rocky shoreline was the landing spot for the first Hansen's disease patients sent to Kalaupapa.

images.altText: View of Black Sand Beach and Awahua Bay
images.title: Black Sand Beach
images.caption: Black Sand Beach is one of several sandy beaches at Kalaupapa, most known for its sea turtle nesting habitat.

images.altText: View of rock walls and native Hawaiian archeological sites at Kalaupapa.
images.title: Archeological Sites at Kalaupapa
images.caption: Kalaupapa is also home to one of the most well-preserved archeological complexes in all of Hawaii.

images.altText: Siloama Church at Kalawao settlement
images.title: Siloama Church at Kalawao
images.caption: Siloama Church was the first church established at Kalawao in 1866.  It is one of two remaining buildings at Kalawao today.

images.altText: View of St. Damien's Grave at Kalawao with ocean in background.
images.title: St. Damien's Grave
images.caption: Saint Damien is one of two Catholic saints at Kalaupapa who came to serve the Hansen's disease patients in the late 19th century.

images.altText: View of Paschoal Hall also known as the Kalaupapa Social Hall
images.title: Paschoal Hall
images.caption: Paschoal Hall, also known as the Kalaupapa Social Hall, served as the community's recreational center with movies, entertainers, and dances.

images.altText: View of grave markers at Papaloa Cemetery in Kalaupapa
images.title: Papaloa Cemetery
images.caption: Kalaupapa is the final resting place for approximately 8000 people. Papaloa Cemetery is the largest cemetery located along the west shoreline of the peninsula.

images.altText: View of Kana'ana Hou Church through gates
images.title: Kana'ana Hou Church
images.caption: Religion was a prominent part of patients' lives at Kalaupapa. Protestant, Catholic, and Mormon churches were established at both Kalawao and Kalaupapa settlements.

images.altText: View of warehouse and store at the Kalaupapa Pier
images.title: Kalaupapa Pier
images.caption: The Kalaupapa Pier, warehouse, and store were the lifeline of the settlement during the 20th century. Historically, shipments of goods and supplies were sent to Kalaupapa weekly.

entranceFees.description: All activities are free at the preserve.
entranceFees.title: No entrance fee

properties.directionsInfo:
By Car: The preserve is located in northern Chase County, Kansas 2 miles north of intersection U.S. Hwy 50 and Flint Hills National Scenic Byway 177 (K-177) west of Strong City. Watch for brown attraction signs.

2 miles north of Strong City, KS on K-177
16 miles west of Emporia, KS on U.S. Hwy 50 and 2 miles north on K-177
17 miles south of Council Grove, KS on K-177
85 miles northeast of Wichita on I-35, U.S. Hwy 50, and K-177
60 miles southwest of Topeka on I-335 (Kansas Turnpike) to Em

entrancePasses.description: Entrance to the preserve is free.
entrancePasses.title: No annual passes

properties.weatherInfo: Typical weather for the preserve ranges from lows of zero in the winter and highs of 90 + degrees in the summer. Please check current weather conditions at NOAA before hiking into the preserve. Lightning poses a danger when hiking into the prairie.
properties.name: Tallgrass Prairie
properties.description: Where's the tall grass? Tallgrass prairie once covered 170 million acres of North America. Within a generation the vast majority was developed and plowed under. Today less than 4% remains, mostly here in the Kansas Flint Hills. The preserve protects a nationally significant remnant of the once vast tallgrass prairie and its cultural resources. Here the tallgrass prairie makes its last stand.

images.altText: fall wildflowers at the preserve
images.title: Fall wildflowers at the preserve
images.caption: Fall is the season for another assortment of color on the prairie

images.altText: limestone mansion of the ranch
images.title: Historic 1881 Spring Hill Ranch house
images.caption: Historic 1881 Spring Hill Ranch house

images.altText: three level limestone barn
images.title: Historic 1882 Spring Hill Ranch barn
images.caption: Historic 1882 Spring Hill Ranch barn

images.altText: tallgrass hiking trails
images.title: Hike among the tall grasses in the fall
images.caption: Hike among the tall tallgrass species in the fall

images.altText: butterfly milkweed wildflowers
images.title: Summer wildflowers on the prairie
images.caption: View a collage of summer flowers among a carpet of green in the spring and early summer

phoneNumbers.description: Indiana Dunes Visitor Center phone number.

entranceFees.description: $6.00 per car per day, $30.00 per bus per day (Expanded Amenity Fee). Fee is collected from the Friday of Memorial Day weekend through the Monday of Labor Day weekend from 8:00 am to as late as 7:00 pm Central Time. 50% discount for Senior Annual, Senior Lifetime, and Access Passes. No discount for Annual, Military, Volunteer, and 4th Grade passes.
entranceFees.title: West Beach Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: $25 per night (Expanded Amenity Fee). Campground is open from April 1 through November 1. 50% discount with Senior Annual, Senior Lifetime, and Access Passes. No discount for Annual, Military, Volunteer, and 4th Grade passes.
entranceFees.title: Dunewood Campground

properties.directionsInfo: Visitors can access the national park via Interstate 94, the Indiana Toll Road (Interstate 80/90), U.S. Highway 12, U.S. Highway 20, Indiana State Road 49, and various other local roads. The Indiana Dunes Visitor Center is located on Indiana State Road 49, between U.S. Highway 20 and Interstate 94 (1215 North State Road 49, Porter, IN 46304). For a driving map to the Indiana Dunes Visitor Center or other locations, check out our maps page.

entrancePasses.description: Yearly pass available to the general public that provides free access to, and use of, federal recreation sites that charge an Entrance or Standard Amenity Fee. Valid for one full year from the month of purchase (through last day of that month). No discount for Expanded Amenity Fees. Admits the pass holder and three adult passengers in a non-commercial vehicle. See https://www.nps.gov/indu/planyourvisit/fees.htm for details.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Lifetime senior pass for U.S. citizens or permanent residents, age 62 or over. Provides free access to, and use of, federal recreation sites that charge an Entrance or Standard Amenity Fee. Provides a 50% discount for select Expanded Amenity Fees (park specific). Admits the pass holder and three adult passengers in a non-commercial vehicle at per vehicle fee areas and per person fee areas. Children under 16 are admitted free. See https://www.nps.gov/indu/planyourvisit/fees.htm for details.
entrancePasses.title: Senior Lifetime Pass

entrancePasses.description: Lifetime access pass for U.S. citizens or permanent residents with permanent disabilities. Documentation is requested, but not required, to obtain the pass. Provides free access to, and use of, federal recreation sites that charge an Entrance or Standard Amenity Fee. Provides a 50% discount for select Expanded Amenity Fees (park specific). Admits the pass holder and three adult passengers in a non-commercial vehicle at per vehicle. See http://www.nps.gov/indu/planyourvisit/fees.htm for details.
entrancePasses.title: Access Lifetime Pass

entrancePasses.description: Yearly pass available to US military members and the dependents of deployed military in the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, and Coast Guard, as well as most members of the US Reserves and National Guard. Proper military ID is required (CAC Card or DoD Form 1173). Covers Entrance Fees at Fish and Wildlife Service and National Park Service sites and Standard Amenity Fees at Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management, and Bureau of Reclamation sites. Admits the pass holder and three adult passengers.
entrancePasses.title: Active Military Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Pass for volunteers acquiring 250 service hours on a cumulative basis. Provides free access to, and use of, federal recreation sites that charge an Entrance or Standard Amenity Fee. Valid for one full year from the month of earning the pass (through last day of that month). No discount for Expanded Amenity Fees. Admits the pass holder and three adult passengers in a non-commercial vehicle at per vehicle fee areas and per person fee areas. See http://www.nps.gov/indu/planyourvisit/fees.htm.
entrancePasses.title: Volunteer Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Available to U.S. 4th graders (including home-schooled and free-choice learners, 10 years of age) with a valid Every Kid in a Park paper voucher. The pass is valid for the duration of the 4th grade school year through the following summer (September through August ). Covers Entrance Fees at Fish and Wildlife Service and National Park Service sites and Standard Amenity Fees at Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management, and Bureau of Reclamation sites. See http://www.nps.gov/indu/planyourvisit/fees.htm.
entrancePasses.title: Annual 4th Grade Pass

entrancePasses.description: Yearly senior pass for U.S. citizens or permanent residents, age 62 or over. Valid for one full year from the month of purchase (through last day of that month). The annual senior pass can be upgraded to a lifetime senior pass by exchanging up to four annual senior passes from the same person and paying the difference between the combined value of the annual passes ($20 each) and the $80 purchase price of the lifetime senior pass. The annual senior pass has the same benefits of the lifetime senior pass.
entrancePasses.title: Senior Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: On average, the warmest month is July and the highest recorded temperature was 105F in 1934. The coolest month is January, with the lowest recorded temperature of -25F in 1985. June sees the most precipitation with an average rainfall of 4.66 Inches.
properties.name: Indiana Dunes
properties.description: Indiana Dunes National Park hugs 15 miles of the southern shore of Lake Michigan and has much to offer. Whether you enjoy scouting for rare species of birds or flying kites on the sandy beach, the national park's 15,000 acres will continually enchant you.  Hikers will enjoy 50 miles of trails over rugged dunes, mysterious wetlands, sunny prairies, meandering rivers and peaceful forests.

entranceFees.description: Admission to park visitor centers is always free. Most park programs are free; any fees are always noted on program descriptions.
entranceFees.title: Admission and Program Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Jean Lafitte's headquarters and the park's French Quarter Visitor Center is located at 419 Decatur St. in New Orleans. There are five other park sites scattered throughout south Louisiana. For information on all of the park sites and visitor centers, see the Directions URL.
properties.weatherInfo:
All temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit. Note that relative humidity, especially in summer months, can reach 90%, so temperatures can feel 10-20 degrees hotter than actual temperature.
Spring (March, April, May) average high 77, low 61
Summer (June, July, August) average high 89, low 75
Fall (September, October, November) average high 78, low 64
Winter (December, January, February) average high 64, low 48
properties.name: Jean Lafitte
properties.description: In Jean Lafitte's day, silver and gold filled a pirate's treasure chest, but today's treasures are people, places, and memories. Discover New Orleans’ rich cultural mix. Learn Cajun traditions from people who live them. Watch an alligator bask on a bayou’s bank. Walk in the footsteps of the men who fought at 1815’s Battle of New Orleans. Follow the link to discover the treasure of Jean Lafitte.

images.altText: Spanish moss hangs from live oak tree
images.title: Barataria Preserve of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Spanish moss and lush vegetation provide glimpses of Louisiana's wild wetlands at Jean Lafitte's Barataria Preserve.

images.altText: An oak tree arches over a cannon-guarded rampart with historic house and American flag in background
images.title: Chalmete Battlefield at Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Chalmette Battlefield's American rampart and cannons still guard the site of the Battle of New Orleans in 1815.

images.altText: Setting sun lights up cemetery headstones
images.title: Chalmette National Cemetery at Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Established during the Civil War, Chalmette National Cemetery's 14,000+ headstones pay tribute to those buried there.

images.altText: Visitor center exhibit titled "Crossroads of Cultures"
images.title: French Quarter Visitor Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Hundreds of years of history and thousands of people from all over the world have created New Orleans' distinctive cultural mix.

images.altText: Model of an early Acadian home sits in a glass case
images.title: Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Bringing skills and traditions from Nova Scotia, the Acadian exiles in Louisiana found a new home and a new name---Cajuns.

images.altText: Center exhibit with glass display cases and photos
images.title: Prairie Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: The Acadians (Cajuns) who settled Louisiana's Cajun prairies were cowboys, farmers, and ranchers.

images.altText: Exhibit case full of musical instruments
images.title: Wetlands Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Acadian (Cajun) music began in cabins and dancehalls and has become famous worldwide.

properties.fullName: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve

entranceFees.description: The park does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: To reach the visitor center from the east, follow US Route 15 to MD Route 77 and go west about 3 miles.  The visitor center is on the right side of the road.  From the west, take I 70 to MD 66 at exit 35.  Turn left onto MD 66 north and travel about 5 miles, passing through the roundabout.  Turn right onto MD 64 and drive 1 mile.  Turn right onto MD 77.  Drive on MD 77 about 7.5 miles.  The visitor center is on the left.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summer (June-Aug) average temperature is between 61 and 81 degrees Fahrenheit.

Fall (Sep-Nov) average temperature is between 45 and 64 degrees Fahrenheit.  Fall foliage is at its peak in mid-October

Winter (Dec-Feb) average temperature is between 24 and 41 degrees Fahrenheit.  Winter snowfall is between 5-12" per month.

Spring (March-May) average temperature is between 41 and 63 degrees Fahrenheit.

Average precipitation is approximately 4 inches per month.  

(Source: usclimatedata.com)
properties.name: Catoctin Mountain
properties.description: President Franklin D. Roosevelt created programs to give people a chance to rebuild their lives from the Great Depression. The Works Progress Administration and the Civilian Conservation Corps gave this land a second opportunity and through re-growth, a new role as a recreation area.

images.altText: Rock formation with mountains in the background
images.title: Chimney Rock Vista
images.caption: A challenging hike leads to Chimney Rock, the most popular vista in the park.

images.altText: A woman and girl hike along a tree-lined trail.
images.title: Hikers on a Trail
images.caption: Hiking on one of the many wooded trails is a popular activity.

images.altText: A log cabin in the woods
images.title: Historic Camp Misty Mount
images.caption: Visitors can stay overnight in one of the historic Misty Mount cabins.

images.altText: A stone and wood building with plants and flowers in front
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: First time visitors should begin their park experience at the visitor center.

entranceFees.description: Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and its occupants.
entranceFees.title: Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits a private, non-commercial motorcycle and its riders.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car. This pass is typically used for bicyclists, and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: Per Person

properties.directionsInfo: The entrance to Natural Bridges is at the end of UT 275, which is roughly 35 miles west of Blanding, Utah, on UT 95. Driving time from Blanding is roughly 45 minutes.

entrancePasses.description: Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Arches and Canyonlands national parks, and Natural Bridges National Monument. Pass is valid for one year through the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Southeast Utah Parks Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Natural Bridges is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
properties.name: Natural Bridges
properties.description: Three majestic natural bridges invite you to ponder the power of water in a landscape usually defined by its absence. View them from an overlook, or hit the trails and experience their grandeur from below. Declared a National Monument in 1908, the bridges are named "Kachina," "Owachomo" and "Sipapu" in honor of the ancestral Puebloans who once made this place their home.

images.altText: a natural bridge at night with the Milky Way arcing overhead
images.title: Dark Skies at Owachomo Bridge
images.caption: Natural Bridges National Monument was designated the world's first International Dark Sky Park in 2007

images.altText: Sipapu Bridge with a blue sky and clouds overhead
images.title: Sipapu Bridge
images.caption: Sipapu Bridge is one of the three massive bridges at the monument.

images.altText: a stone structure below a rock alcove
images.title: Horse Collar Ruin
images.caption: Horsecollar Ruins are located near Sipapu Bridge

images.altText: a hiker standing below a massive natural bridge
images.title: Hiker at Kachina Bridge
images.caption: Hiking trails link the three natural bridges at the monument.

images.altText: a broad natural bridge with clouds in the sky
images.title: Owachomo Bridge
images.caption: Owachomo Bridge is one of the three natural bridges at the monument.

addresses.line2: Approximately 45 minutes' drive west of Blanding, Utah

properties.directionsInfo: Gettysburg National Military Park is located in Adams County, Pennsylvania. The museum and visitor center is located at 1195 Baltimore Pike (Route 97) with a back entrance from the Taneytown Road (State Rt. 134). From North or South, follow US 15 to Gettysburg and watch for signs to direct you to the National Park Service Museum and Visitor Center. From East or West, drive into Gettysburg on US Rt. 30, turn South on Baltimore Street (Rt. 97), and follow signs to the entrance of the visitor center.
properties.weatherInfo: http://www.wunderground.com/cgi-bin/findweather/hdfForecast?query=17325
properties.name: Gettysburg
properties.description: The Battle of Gettysburg was a turning point in the Civil War, the Union victory that ended General Robert E. Lee's second and most ambitious invasion of the North. Often referred to as the "High Water Mark of the Rebellion", Gettysburg was the Civil War's bloodiest battle and was also the inspiration for President Abraham Lincoln's immortal "Gettysburg Address".

properties.name: Eisenhower
properties.description: Eisenhower National Historic Site preserves the farm of General and 34th President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Adjacent to the Gettysburg battlefield, the farm served the president and first lady as a weekend retreat and as a meeting place for world leaders. With its peaceful setting and view of South Mountain, it was a respite from Washington, DC, and a backdrop for efforts to reduce Cold War tensions.

images.altText: The Eisenhower home with Ike's putting green in the foreground
images.title: Eisenhower home
images.caption: President Eisenhower was an avid golfer and had a putting green added to the backyard.

properties.directionsInfo:
From Boise: take I-84 East to exit 216 (Declo); go south on Highway 77 to Conner Creek Junction; turn right (west) on Highway 77 Spur to Almo. The visitor center and the park entrance are south of the post office and businesses.
From Pocatello: take I-86 West to I-84 West to exit 216 and proceed as above.
From Salt Lake City: take I-84 west to exit 245 (Sublette), turn left and go west to Malta. From Malta take Highway 77. Take Highway 77 Spur to Almo.
properties.weatherInfo: City of Rocks is located in south-central Idaho within the northern edge of the Basin and Range geologic province. Outdoor recreation can be pleasant from April through October. Summers are generally dry with 10 to 15 inches of precipitation in winter and spring. Summer temperatures range widely with night time lows occasionally approaching freezing and midday highs nearing 100° F; however, the typical range of low and high temperature is 45-85. Thunderstorms are common in the summer months (June - August)
properties.name: City Of Rocks
properties.description: Emigrants of the California Trail describe the rocks here in vivid detail as "a city of tall spires,” “steeple rocks," and "the silent city." Today, this backcountry byway attracts rock climbers, campers, hikers, hunters, and those with the spirit of adventure. There's inspirational scenery, exceptional opportunities for geologic study, and remnants of the Old West awaiting your discovery.

images.altText: Granite monoliths stand silently, reaching toward a summer sky
images.title: City of Rocks National Reserve
images.caption: Campsites are nestled here in the Elephant Rock Basin

images.altText: A climber ascend a granite spire with snowy mountains in the distance
images.title: City of Rocks Climber on granite formation called The Anteater
images.caption: Over half of the 100,000 annual visitors to City of Rocks come to experience climbing

images.altText: A granite arch is displayed on the horizon
images.title: Window Arch at City of Rocks
images.caption: Forces of nature sculpt unexpected features in granite such as Window Arch

images.altText: Golden aspens mixed with pinyon and juniper blanket this sweeping view of City of Rocks
images.title: Grand Autumn View of City of Rocks
images.caption: City of Rocks offers sweeping vistas and awe-inspiring scenery

images.altText: Replica emigrant wagons rest unhitched at sunrise

images.altText: Emigrant signature written with axle-grease on granite
images.title: Emigrant Signatures at City of Rocks
images.caption: California-bound emigrants painted their signature on Register Rock in 1850

entranceFees.description: Entry to Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park is free.  Some services, such as a hiking permit for the Chilkoot Trail or camping have associated fees.
entranceFees.title: Entry Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Park headquarters and visitor center are located at 2nd and Broadway in Skagway, Alaska. 

To get to Skagway by car: you can access the park via the Alaska Marine Highway or the South Klondike Highway. By plane: you can fly into the Skagway Airport. By water: You can visit the park by cruise ship, tour boat, or ferry. The park visitor center is less than half a mile from all docks.
properties.weatherInfo: Skagway has a highly variable climate with frequent rain and high winds.  Average temperatures May through September range from 47 F to 60 F.  Average temperatures October through April range from 28 F to 38 F.
properties.name: Klondike Gold Rush
properties.description: Headlines screamed "Gold!" The dream of a better life catapulted thousands of people to Alaska and the Yukon Territory. Their journey shaped them, and changed the people they encountered and the north forever. Today, the park remembers the trails, boomtowns, and stories of the Klondike Gold Rush.

images.altText: People standing around a ranger in front of a building.
images.title: Walking Tour
images.caption: Enjoy a free historic walking tour with a ranger.

images.altText: Colorful buildings
images.title: Skagway Historic District
images.caption: Explore history with the restored buildings at Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park

images.altText: View from a mountain pass down a valley
images.title: The Chilkoot Trail
images.caption: Each summer thousands of people hike along the "worlds longest museum"

images.altText: Group of people gathered around a log cabin with a ranger
images.title: Captain William Moore Cabin
images.caption: The first building in Skagway was built in 1887, ten years before the Klondike gold rush.

images.altText: Aerial view of town in a valley with cruise ships in port
images.title: Gateway to the gold rush
images.caption: The historic district in Skagway, Alaska is one of three units of the park in Alaska.

properties.weatherInfo:
Spring daytime temperatures in the 70's can be followed by a snow storm with wet heavy snow and daytime temperatures in the 40's.
Summer s dry with June usually being the hottest month of the year. Days in July, August and September often end with thunderstorms that can drop heavy localized rain and are often accompanied by lightning.
Autumn weather is usually sunny with turquoise blue skies and warm (but not hot) days and cool nights.
Winter average snowfall 25". Snow and ice can close trails and roads.
properties.name: Bandelier
properties.description: Bandelier National Monument protects over 33,000 acres of rugged but beautiful canyon and mesa country as well as evidence of a human presence here going back over 11,000 years.  Petroglyphs, dwellings carved into the soft rock cliffs, and standing masonry walls pay tribute to the early days of a culture that still survives in the surrounding communities.

properties.directionsInfo: From Boston take I-95 north to Augusta, Maine, then Route 3 east to Ellsworth, and on to Mount Desert Island. For an alternate route, continue on I-95 north to Bangor, Maine, then take Route 1A east to Ellsworth. In Ellsworth, take Route 3 to Mount Desert Island.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for 12 months from purchase date. This pass provides access to Acadia National Park only. This pass admits the pass holder and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Acadia Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Located on Mount Desert Island in Maine, Acadia experiences all four seasons. Summer temperatures range from 45-90F (7-30C). Fall temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C). Typically the first frost is in mid-October and first snowfall begins in November and can continue through April with an average accumulation of 73 inches (185 cm). Winter temperatures range from 14-35F (-10 - 2C). Spring temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C).
properties.name: Acadia
properties.description: Acadia National Park protects the natural beauty of the highest rocky headlands along the Atlantic coastline of the United States, an abundance of habitats, and a rich cultural heritage. At 3.5 million visits a year, it's one of the top 10 most-visited national parks in the United States. Visitors enjoy 27 miles of historic motor roads, 158 miles of hiking trails, and 45 miles of carriage roads.

images.altText: Large puffy clouds dot a brilliant blue sky as wave crash against the rocky coastline of Acadia.
images.title: Acadia's rocky coastline
images.caption: Millions of people come to Acadia for our distinctive rocky coastline.

images.altText: A brilliant sunset filled with hues of blue, red, orange, magenta, and purple highlight the sky.
images.title: Sunset atop Cadillac Mountain
images.caption: As the tallest point on the eastern seaboard Cadillac Mountain provides fantastic viewpoints.

images.altText: Two hikers ascend a sheer cliff trail by way of historic iron rung ladders.
images.title: Climbing The Precipice
images.caption: Whether it's a stroll along Ocean Path or a difficult ascent up The Precipice, there are hiking trails for everyone!

images.altText: A man peers into a telescope as the Milky Way lights up the night sky.
images.title: Starviewing
images.caption: With dark skies, Acadia is a fantastic place to come see the stars.

images.altText: Hiking tracks carved through three feet of snow wind through a heavy snow-laden forest.
images.title: Heavy snow-laden trees
images.caption: During the colder months snows transform our landscape into a winter wonderland.

entranceFees.description: To enter the park there is no fee.
entranceFees.title: There is no entrance fee at Amistad National Recreation Area

properties.weatherInfo:
Weather in Southwest Texas can change in a matter of minutes. It is best to check the local weather report. 
Amistad National Recreation Area usually has hot summers and mild winters.
properties.name: Amistad
properties.description: An oasis in the desert, Amistad National Recreation Area consists of the US portion of the International Amistad Reservoir. Amistad, whose name comes from the Spanish word meaning friendship, is best known for excellent water-based recreation, camping, hiking, rock art viewing, and its rich cultural history. Amistad is also home to a wide variety of plant and animal life above and below the water.

images.altText: Amistad National Recreation Area
images.title: View of Amistad National Recreation Area from The Diablo East Nature Trail
images.caption: Blue skies and blue waters are common at Amistad National Recreation Area

images.altText: Under the HWY 90 Bridge
images.title: Under the HWY 90 Bridge
images.caption: A view of the Amistad Reservoir and the HWY 90 Bridge from Governors Landing.

images.altText: A view of the peaceful shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.title: The shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: A peaceful view of the shores along Amistad National Recreation Area

images.altText: Sunset over Amistad National Recreation Area
images.title: Sunset over Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: The ever chainging and beautiful sunsets in Southwest Texas are one of the many things visitor enjoy while at Amistad National Recreation Area.

images.altText: Limestone shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.title: Limestone shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: Limestone is visible along the shoreline of Amistad National Recreation Area.

properties.directionsInfo: There are two entrances to Assateague Island National Seashore. Assateague's north entrance is at the end of Route 611, eight miles south of Ocean City, MD. The south entrance is at the end of Route 175, two miles east of Chincoteague, VA. There is no vehicle access between the two entrances on Assateague Island. Vehicles must return to the mainland to access either the north or south entrance.

properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Often windy and cool with lows in the 40's and highs in the 60's.
Summer: Hot and humid with lows in the 60's and highs in the 80's.
Fall: Warm with lows in the 50's and highs in the 70's.
Winter: Damp cold and often windy. Lows in the 20's, highs in the 40's.
properties.name: Assateague Island
properties.description: Want to live on the edge? Visit a place recreated each day by ocean wind and waves. Life on Assateague Island has adapted to an existence on the move. Explore sandy beaches, salt marshes, maritime forests and coastal bays. Rest, relax, recreate and enjoy some time on the edge of the continent.

images.altText: Wild horses on the dunes at Assateague
images.title: Wild Horses on the dunes at Assateague
images.caption: There are few places in the United States where you can view wild horses.Take advantage of the opportunity to view these horses in a natural habitat.

images.altText: Horses grazing in the marsh at the water's edge.
images.title: Wild horses grazing in the salt marshes on Assateague Island
images.caption: Assateague's wild horses can often be found grazing in salt marshes.

images.altText: Tree Swallows migrating along the beach at Assateague
images.title: Tree Swallows Migrating along Assateague
images.caption: Enormous flocks of migrating tree swallows stop and rest on Assateague beaches in the fall.

images.altText: tents and vehicle in the oceanside campground dunes
images.title: Camping at Assateague
images.caption: Tent camping in the Oceanside campground at Assateague is a great way to relax and recreate at the beach.

images.altText: waves on Assateague beach with people fishing in the background
images.title: Waves on Assateague beach
images.caption: Visit the shifting sands at the water's edge where thousands of waves change the beach every day.

entranceFees.description: Big Thicket National Preserve does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

properties.directionsInfo: Big Thicket National Preserve consists of 15 units spread across 7 counties. The visitor center is located approximately 30 miles north of Beaumont, and 8 miles north of Kountze, along US 69/287.
properties.weatherInfo: Big Thicket National Preserve is generally very hot and humid during the spring and summer. Winters are mild. Snow and subfreezing temperatures are uncommon.
properties.name: Big Thicket
properties.description: Life of all types abounds in the Big Thicket. This national preserve protects the incredible diversity of life found where multiple habitats converge in southeast Texas. Hiking trails and waterways meander through nine different ecosystems, from longleaf pine forests to cypress-lined bayous. It is a place of discovery, a place to wander and explore, a place to marvel at the richness of nature.

images.altText: Knobby cypress knees resembling cave stalagmites protrude up from a pool of water.
images.title: Cypress Knees
images.caption: Knobby knees, extensions of the root system, are a distinctive feature of the bald cypress trees.

images.altText: A dense stand of funnel-shaped carnivorous pitcher plants awaiting their next insect meal.
images.title: Pitcher Plants
images.caption: Look for carnivorous pitcher plants in bogs along the Sundew Trail and Pitcher Plant Trail.

images.altText: Three people paddling kayaks along a waterway densely lined with bald cypress trees.
images.title: Kayakers in Cooks Lake
images.caption: Kayaking is a popular way to explore the many waterways in the Big Thicket. Here, kayakers paddle along the Cooks Lake Paddling Trail near Beaumont.

images.altText: The yellow flowers of pitcher plants bloom beneath longleaf pine trees.
images.title: Pitcher Plants and Pines
images.caption: Early April is the best time to see wildflowers blooming in the Big Thicket..

images.altText: A woman and her dog on a metal bridge spanning a creek lined with bald cypress trees.
images.title: Hiker on bridge over Village Creek
images.caption: The view from the bridge over Village Creek is a highlight for hikers on the Kirby Nature Trail.

images.altText: Two rangers standing in front of a log cabin-style visitor center.
images.title: Rangers in front of visitor center
images.caption: The visitor center is open daily from 9 am to 5 pm.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for the park. Pipestem Resort State Park charges a small fee to ride the tram to and from the bottom at the entrance in Pipestem.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

properties.directionsInfo:
Bluestone National Scenic River is most easily accessed via Bluestone State Park and Pipestem Resort State Park. A narrow, graveled park road provides access to the Bluestone Turnpike Trail at the former Lilly town site at the confluence of the Little Bluestone River.

To reach these parks from I-64, take exit 139, then south on Rt. 20. From I-77 take exit 14 to Rt.20 north. Either direction, Bluestone State Park is 15 miles and Pipestem is 22 miles.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summer: Temperatures range from low to mid 60's at night to middle to upper 80's during the daytime hours. 

Winter: Temperatures average from the mid 20's to the mid 40's. Snowfall amount varies, but averages 5" per month Dec. - March.

Spring and Fall: temperatures and rainfall variable. Peak fall foliage is usually mid-October.
properties.name: Bluestone
properties.description: The Bluestone River and the rugged and ancient gorge it has carved is a richly diverse and scenic area of the southern Appalachians. Bluestone National Scenic River is preserved as a living landscape that provides an unspoiled experience for visitors and a haven for a variety of plants and animals. The park protects a 10.5-mile section of the Bluestone River in southern West Virginia.

images.altText: Turnpike Trail
images.title: The Turnpike Trail
images.caption: The ten mile Turnpike Trail parallels the Bluestone, connecting Pipestem Resort State Park and Bluestone State Park.

images.altText: Hiking the Turnpike Trail
images.title: Leading a hike
images.caption: Ranger Richard leads a guided walk on the Turnpike Trail

images.altText: Youngster enjoying the Bluestone
images.title: Enjoying the day
images.caption: A young hiker makes his own connection with Bluestone National Scenic River.

images.altText: Bluestone River
images.title: Bluestone River
images.caption: Bluestone National Scenic River offers a quiet getaway.

images.altText: Ranger giving information to park visitor
images.title: Bluestone Turnpike Trail
images.caption: NPS Ranger Richard Altaire provides an overview of the park map to a visitor to the Bluestone NSR.

properties.weatherInfo: During the summer season visitors should dress in light, comfortable clothing, wear comfortable shoes and use sunscreen. We recommended you carry a bottle of water with you. High temperatures and high humidity create higher risk of heat cramps, heat exhaustion and heatstroke. Most of the Historic site is out-of-doors and although not a great distance from an air-conditioned building, staying properly hydrated will help prevent these illnesses. During the fall visitors should have a light jacket available.
properties.name: Colonial
properties.description: On May 13, 1607, Jamestown was established as the first permanent English settlement in North America. Three cultures came together – European, Virginia Indian and African–to create a new society that would eventually seek independence from Great Britain. On October 19, 1781, American and French troops defeated the British at Yorktown in the last major battle of the American Revolutionary War.

images.altText: Historic Jamestowne Visitor Center
images.title: Historic Jamestowne Visitor Center

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Curecanti. Visitors traveling to East Portal through the Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park entrance must pay $15.00 per vehicle. It covers all persons in a single, private, noncommercial vehicle and is valid for seven calendar days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: U.S. Highway 50 runs the length of Curecanti between Montrose and Gunnison. The recreation area is also accessed from CO Highway 149 and CO Highway 92.
properties.weatherInfo:
Weather can vary greatly throughout the day. Summer daytime temperatures range between 50 to 90F (10 to 32C), nights 40 to 60F (4 to 15C). Winter daytime temperatures range between -20 to +40F (-29 to +4C), nights -30 to +20F (-34 to -7C).

Precipitation is minimal, but afternoon thunderstorms and strong winds are common during the summer. Snow accumulation varies greatly year to year. Layered clothing appropriate for the season is recommended.
properties.name: Curecanti
properties.description: Curecanti National Recreation Area is a series of three reservoirs along the once wild Gunnison River. The reservoirs that make up Curecanti today are a destination for water-based recreation high in the Rocky Mountains. Best known for salmon and trout fishing, Curecanti also offers opportunities for hiking, boating, camping, and bird watching.

images.altText: Dillon Pinnacles, Curecanti National Recreation Area
images.title: Dillon Pinnacles, Curecanti National Recreation Area
images.caption: Dillon Pinnacles, Curecanti National Recreation Area

images.altText: Blue Mesa Reservoir, Curecanti National Recreation Area
images.title: Blue Mesa Reservoir, Curecanti National Recreation Area
images.caption: Blue Mesa Reservoir, Curecanti National Recreation Area

entranceFees.description: Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania is a fee free park
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
The Fredericksburg and Chancellorsville Visitor Center each offer a unique 22-minute film. The films cost $2.00 (free for ages 10 and under, $1.00 for adults 62 and over). 

Tickets can be purchased at the museum store.
entranceFees.title: Visitor Center Films

properties.directionsInfo: Fredericksburg and Spotsylvania National Military Park manages 4 battlefields and multiple historical sites across multiple counties. The park is located approximately 50 miles south of Washington DC. Different battlefields and historical sites are accessible via I-95 and VA Route 3. For directions and physical addresses for each of our sites, please visit the Directions & Transportation section of our website.
properties.weatherInfo: The regional climate is characterized by mild winters and warm, humid summers. The mean annual temperatures is 56 degrees Fahrenheit. The average summer temperature is 75 degrees Fahrenheit. Daytime highs during the summer are in the upper 80s, and nighttime lows are in the lower 60s. Daytime highs in the winter are in the upper 40s, and nighttime lows are in the middle 20s. Precipitation is well distributed throughout the year, with the minimum amount in August and the maximum in February.
properties.name: Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania
properties.description: Fredericksburg, Chancellorsville, Wilderness, and Spotsylvania--this is America's battleground, where the Civil War roared to its bloody climax. No place more vividly reflects the War's tragic cost in all its forms. A town bombarded and looted. Farms large and small ruined. Refugees by the thousands forced into the countryside. More than 85,000 men wounded; 15,000 killed--most in graves unknown.

images.altText: Fog near rolling hills with sun rising in background
images.title: Jackson Flank Attack Site
images.caption: Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania is now characterized by dynamic landscapes as well significant Civil War battles that took place on the same ground

images.altText: Trees with fall colors in front of large brick manor house
images.title: Chatham in the Fall
images.caption: When visiting Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania, be sure to explore our numerous historic structures, such as Chatham Manor pictured here

images.altText: Cannon crew in the process of a firing demonstration
images.title: Cannon Firing Demonstration
images.caption: Check out our Special Events page for information about special tours, lectures, programs, and living history demonstrations

images.altText: Monument in national cemetery illuminated by candles
images.title: Fredericksburg National Cemetery
images.caption: Thousands of visitors join us every year for our Memorial Day Illumination of the National Cemetery

images.altText: Two NPS rangers and a number of visitors hold candles during evening ceremony
images.title: Ranger Programs
images.caption: Get the most out of your battlefield experience by taking a guided ranger program!

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Gauley River National Recreation Area. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Plane
The largest airport is at Charleston, about 65 miles from Summersville. There are also small airports at Summersville and Beckley.

Car
The main entrance to Gauley River National Recreation Area is located off US Route 19 south of Summersville and north of Fayetteville, West Virginia. Turn off US Route 19 onto WV Route 129 toward Summersville Dam. Take the second left after you cross over the dam and follow the signs to Gauley River.

entrancePasses.description: There is no fee to enter Gauley River National Recreation Area, so there is no need for an entrance pass. Enjoy your visit!
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Passes

properties.weatherInfo: Weather in the Appalachian Mountains can be unpredictable and can change quickly. Always be prepared for the possibility of sudden storms. Weather in the mountains is often cooler and wetter than the surrounding area. On average, the warmest month is July. The maximum average precipitation also occurs in July.
properties.name: Gauley River
properties.description: The 25 miles of free-flowing Gauley River and the six miles of the Meadow River pass through scenic gorges and valleys containing a wide variety of natural and cultural features. The Gauley River contains several class V+ rapids, making it one of the most adventurous white water boating rivers in the east.

properties.directionsInfo: Green Springs National Historic Landmark District is privately owned, includes no public facilities, but is visible from public highways. It sits astride Route 15 in Louisa County, Virginia.
properties.weatherInfo: Louisa County, Virginia enjoys a temperate climate with hot, humid summers and cool winters.
properties.name: Green Springs
properties.description: Green Springs National Historic Landmark District in Virginia’s Piedmont encompasses over 14,000 acres. Its landscapes and structures, privately owned today but viewable from public roads, offer a continuum of rural vernacular architecture with minimal alteration. Many of the farmsteads, often dating to the 19th century and connecting to one another visually, are preserved through easements.

All park visitors are required to purchase a recreational use pass upon entering Haleakalā National Park. Passes are non-transferable.

All park visitors are required to purchase a recreational use pass upon entering Haleakalā National Park. Passes are non-transferable.

entranceFees.description: Organized groups that do not qualify for Educational Fee Waivers are charged as follows: $25.00 Non-commercial vehicles with a vehicle capacity of 14 or less. $12.00 per person Non-commercial vehicles with a capacity of 15 or greater. Youth 15 and under are free. Individuals or families with any valid Annual or Lifetime pass may use their pass for entry at the per person rate. Pass and photo ID must be present upon entry.
entranceFees.title: Haleakalā Natonal Park Non-Commercial Organized Groups Fee; Scouts, Rotary, Clubs, Youth Groups, Churches, Reunions

entranceFees.description: This fee is for visitors entering the park on a bicycle or on foot. Entry Fee is valid for 3 days starting from the day of purchase. Please use credit cards for payment of entry fees at the Summit and Kipahulu entrance stations. All park visitors are required to purchase a recreational use pass upon entering Haleakalā National Park. Passes are non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Haleakalā National Park Per Person Entry Fee; includes bicyclists, walk-ins, hikers

properties.directionsInfo:
Located on the island of Maui, Haleakalā National Park extends from the 10,023 foot (3055m) summit of Haleakalā down the southeast flank of the mountain to the Kīpahulu coast near Hana. These two sections of the park are not directly connected by road, but both can be reached from Kahului.
There are no gas stations within the park. The last place to get gas in route to the Summit Area is in the town of Pukalani, and along the Hana Highway before Hana is in the town of is in the town of Paia.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for 12 months from purchase date. Admits the pass holder/s and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle (14 pax capacity or less) to Haleakala National Park, Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park and Pu`uhonua O Hōnaunau National Historical Park. All other National Parks in Hawai‘i are free entry.
entrancePasses.title: Hawai‘i Tri-Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
On any given day, the temperatures in the park can range from a high of 80°F (27°C) in Kīpahulu to a low of 30°F (-1°C) at the summit. In either area clouds and rain can quickly replace warm sunshine.
Weather in the high-elevation summit and wilderness areas of the park is highly unpredictable and changes often. Cool temperatures, intense solar radiation, and rapidly moving clouds are characteristic. On average, the temperature drops about 3°F for every 1,000 foot rise in elevation.
properties.name: Haleakalā
properties.description: This special place vibrates with stories of ancient and modern Hawaiian culture and protects the bond between the land and its people. The park also cares for endangered species, some of which exist nowhere else. Come visit this special place - renew your spirit amid stark volcanic landscapes and sub-tropical rain forest with an unforgettable hike through the backcountry.

entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
There are several different ways to get to Lake Meredith. If you are coming from Amarillo, exit Loop 335 North, then exit Hwy 136 North to Fritch. Headquarters is located at 419 E. Broadway in Fritch. If coming from the North you can take 1913 from the Dumas Highway or 1913 from US 287.

The airport in Amarillo is approximately 35 miles south of Lake Meredith if traveling by air. Rental cars are available.
properties.weatherInfo: The Texas Panhandle experiences a wide variety of weather conditions throughout the year. Winters are cold and windy, and summers are hot and dry. It is usually a good idea to bring a jacket with you because the region gets very windy, even in the summer.
properties.name: Lake Meredith
properties.description: Within the dry and windswept plains of the Texas Panhandle lies a hidden oasis, a welcoming haven where wildlife and humans find respite from the dry grasslands above. Through this plain, the Canadian River has cut dramatic 200-foot canyons, or breaks, where humans have lived for over 13,000 years. Lake Meredith now occupies these hidden coves where early humans once roamed.

images.altText: A boat speeds across Lake Meredith.
images.title: Lake Meredith
images.caption: A boat speeds across Lake Meredith.

images.altText: Wildflowers at Lake Meredith
images.title: Lake Meredith in Bloom
images.caption: Wildflowers bloom along the shores of Lake Meredith.

images.altText: A bench on the Harbor Bay Trail, overlooking Lake Meredith.
images.title: Harbar Bay Trail
images.caption: The Harbor Bay Trail has benches which offer hikers a respite with a view.

images.altText: Picnic shelter at a campsite overlooking Lake Meredith.
images.title: Camp with a View!
images.caption: Fritch Fortress and Sanford-Yake Camprgrounds offer campers beautiful views of the lake.

images.altText: Sanford Dam and Lake Meredith
images.title: Sanford Dam at Lake Meredith
images.caption: Lake Meredith was formed in the Canadian River Valley when the Sanford Dam was constructed.

entranceFees.description:
Located near Cedar Bluff, Alabama, the Canyon Mouth Park area features amenities including a paved parking lot, restrooms with sinks and flush toilets, picnic tables, grills, lots of shade, close to the water, and a brand new playground.

FEES ARE CURRENTLY SUSPENDED

A seven-day pass costs $15 and an annual pass costs $35 and is valid for the calendar year. 

A machine is available at the entrance to Canyon Mouth Park should no park personnel be present in the booth. The machine takes cash only.
entranceFees.title: Canyon Mouth Park picnic area

properties.directionsInfo: GPS Address: 472 AL Hwy 35, Fort Payne, AL 35967. Our address was updated by 911 and some GPS units will send you to an incorrect address. Please use this address for GPS units.

entrancePasses.description:
Give the user unlimited access during operating hours during a calendar year (January - December). Located near Cedar Bluff, Alabama. Instead of paying $15 per vehicle, purchase the pass for a year for $35. Amenities included paved parking lot, restrooms, picnic tables, grills, lots of shade, close to the water, and a playground. 

America the Beautiful passes are also valid at Canyon Mouth Park and will allow access using the fee machine or when park staff are present at the booth.
entrancePasses.title: Canyon Mouth Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The weather in Fort Payne, Alabama is mild. The average temperature in the winter is in the 20's. The average summer temperature is in the high 80's. We receive about 55 inches of rain each year. Snowfall varies, but only lasts a few days per event.
properties.name: Little River Canyon
properties.description: Little River is unique because it flows for most of its length atop Lookout Mountain in northeast Alabama. Forested uplands, waterfalls, canyon rims and bluffs, pools, boulders, and sandstone cliffs offer settings for a variety of recreational activities. Natural resources and cultural heritage come together to tell the story of the Preserve, a special place in the Southern Appalachians.

properties.weatherInfo: Weather in the Appalachian Mountains can be unpredictable and can change quickly. Always be prepared for the possibility of sudden storms. Weather in the mountains is often cooler and wetter than the surrounding area. On average, the warmest month is July. The maximum average precipitation also occurs in July.
properties.name: New River Gorge
properties.description: A rugged, whitewater river flowing northward through deep canyons, the New River is among the oldest rivers on the continent. The park encompasses over 70,000 acres of land along the New River, is rich in cultural and natural history, and offers an abundance of scenic and recreational opportunities.

properties.directionsInfo:
From Interstate 77, Exit 5
At Exit 5 turn onto SC Hwy 48 East/Bluff Road. Following the brown and white "Congaree National Park" directional signs, travel approximately 8 miles on and then take a slight right onto Old Bluff Road. Follow Old Bluff Road for 4.5 miles to the park entrance sign, which will be on the right. Proceed one mile to the Harry Hampton Visitor Center. Parking lots will be on the right.
properties.weatherInfo: Check the forecast before getting on the road. Conditions can change rapidly within the park. Flooding can happen with little or no warning, so make sure to check water levels for Cedar Creek and the Congaree River.
properties.name: Congaree
properties.description: Astonishing biodiversity exists in Congaree National Park, the largest intact expanse of old growth bottomland hardwood forest remaining in the southeastern United States. Waters from the Congaree and Wateree Rivers sweep through the floodplain, carrying nutrients and sediments that nourish and rejuvenate this ecosystem and support the growth of national and state champion trees.

images.altText: View of the Congaree River during the Fall
images.title: Congaree River
images.caption: View of the Congaree River during the Fall

properties.weatherInfo:
Today's Weather: http://www.weather.com/weather/today/l/NPBLCA:13:US

CLIMATE
Weather can vary greatly throughout the day. Summer daytime temperatures range between 55 to 90F (13 to 32C), nights 45 to 60F (7 to 16C). Winter daytime temperatures range between 15 to 40F (-9 to 4C), nights 10 to 20F (-12 to -6C).

Afternoon thunderstorms are common during the summer. Snow accumulation varies greatly year to year. Layered clothing appropriate for the season is recommended.
properties.name: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison
properties.description: Big enough to be overwhelming, still intimate enough to feel the pulse of time, Black Canyon of the Gunnison exposes you to some of the steepest cliffs, oldest rock, and craggiest spires in North America. With two million years to work, the Gunnison River, along with the forces of weathering, has sculpted this vertical wilderness of rock, water, and sky.

images.title: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point
images.caption: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point

properties.directionsInfo: Wupatki and Sunset Crater Volcano National Monuments are connected by loop road FR-545. Visitors can enter the loop road near mile markers 430 (Sunset Crater Volcano) and 444 (Wupatki) on U.S. Highway 89.

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for one year from the month of purchase. At Sunset Crater Volcano and Wupatki National Monuments, it covers entry for all occupants of one private vehicle. At Walnut Canyon National Monument, it covers entry for up to four adults; children ages 15 and younger enter for free.
entrancePasses.title: Flagstaff Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Be prepared for variable and extreme weather conditions. You may expect high winds any time of year, summer temperatures above 100ºF (38ºC), afternoon storms July–September, and occasional snow in winter and early spring. Dress in layers, as Wupatki weather can change quickly at any time of year.
properties.name: Wupatki
properties.description: Nestled between the Painted Desert and ponderosa highlands of northern Arizona, Wupatki is a landscape of legacies. Ancient pueblos dot red-rock outcroppings across miles of prairie. Where food and water seem impossible to find, people built pueblos, raised families, farmed, traded, and thrived. Today, if you linger and listen, earth and artifacts whisper their stories to us still.

images.altText: a large stone pueblo in a desert beneath partly cloudy skies
images.title: Wupatki Pueblo
images.caption: Wupatki, the monument's namesake pueblo, is made up of more than 100 rooms. The trail also features an ancient ball court and natural blowhole.

images.altText: a man and woman walking toward a three-story sandstone tower
images.title: Wukoki Pueblo
images.caption: Wukoki Pueblo is located three miles from the Wupatki Visitor Center.

images.altText: a stone pueblo beneath a dark blue sky
images.title: Lomaki Pueblo
images.caption: Lomaki means "beautiful house" in the Hopi language. The pueblo is located ten miles from the visitor center and is reachable via a short, 0.25-mile trail.

images.altText: stars and the Milky Way galaxy over a desert juniper tree
images.title: Dark Skies over the Desert
images.caption: Wupatki National Monument features exceptionally dark night skies and hosts numerous star parties each year.

images.altText: T-shaped doorways in adjoining pueblo walls beneath a clear sky
images.title: Crack-In-Rock Pueblo
images.caption: Each April and October, park rangers guide visitors into the Wupatki back country on overnight hikes to Crack-In-Rock Pueblo.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee is good for 7 days and can be paid for with cash, check, or credit card. Entrance fee is per vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Lava Beds Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Lava Beds is a truly remote park, in a corner of California most people never visit. Most roads into this area wind through mountains, and along rivers, and travel may take longer than expected. Services are few and far between and winter driving conditions can be encountered anytime between fall and spring.

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass is good for one year at both Lava Beds and Crater Lake.
entrancePasses.title: Lava Beds & Crater Lake Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Park elevations range from 4,000 to 5,700 feet. Cold weather is possible any time of year, and snow has been recorded in all months. Winter day­time highs average 40°F; lows average 20°F. Morning fog is frequent from autumn through spring. Summer daytime highs average 75° to 80°F; lows average 50°F. Occasional thunderstorms occur in summer.
properties.name: Lava Beds
properties.description: Lava Beds National Monument is a land of turmoil, both geological and historical. Over the last half-million years, volcanic eruptions on the Medicine Lake shield volcano have created a rugged landscape dotted with diverse volcanic features. More than 800 caves, Native American rock art sites, historic battlefields and campsites, and a high desert wilderness experience await you!

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

properties.directionsInfo:
Plane
Cleveland Hopkins International Airport and Akron-Canton Regional Airport offer many daily flights to the area. Car rentals are available at both airports.

Bus & Train
Bus stations are located in downtown Cleveland and Akron. The Amtrak station is in downtown Cleveland.

Car
The park is easily accessible by car from all directions. A good place to start your visit is at Boston Mill Visitor Center located at 6947 Riverview Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. (41° 15'45.3" N) (81° 33'37.3" W).
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring's rain and warming temperatures bring new leaves on trees, blooming wildflowers, and visitors anxious get out on the trail. 

Summer temperatures range from 49 to 95 degrees F and can be humid. Dressing in layers is advisable. 

Fall temperatures can range from low 70s during the day to freezing during the night. Fall foliage often peaks in mid-October.

Winter weather conditions can rapidly change, due to the lake effect snow from Lake Erie. Temperatures vary from mid-30s to below zero.
properties.name: Cuyahoga Valley
properties.description: Though a short distance from the urban areas of Cleveland and Akron, Cuyahoga Valley National Park seems worlds away. The park is a refuge for native plants and wildlife, and provides routes of discovery for visitors. The winding Cuyahoga River gives way to deep forests, rolling hills, and open farmlands. Walk or ride the Towpath Trail to follow the historic route of the Ohio & Erie Canal.

images.altText: Scenic train as it pulls into Peninsula Depot.
images.title: Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad in Peninsula
images.caption: Many park visitors ride the scenic excursion trail through the valley or take advantage of the Bike Aboard option to ride one way with their bike.

images.altText: A ray of sunshine streaming through the rock formation along the Ledges Trail.
images.title: Along the Ledges Trail
images.caption: One of Cuyahoga Valley's most popular trails, the Ledges Trail proved glimpses of great color and rock formations throughout the year.

images.altText: A misty sunset over a lone goose at the Beaver Marsh
images.title: Sunset at the Beaver Marsh
images.caption: Anytime of day or night there is some wildlife at the Beaver Marsh to capture your attention.

images.altText: Brandywine Falls the parks 60 ft waterfall.
images.title: Brandywine Falls
images.caption: Brandywine Falls is Among the Most Popular Attractions in Cuyahoga Valley National Park

properties.directionsInfo: To access the park's only entrance road, New Mexico Highway 7, turn north from US Hwy 62/180 at White's City, NM, which is 20 miles (32 km) southwest of Carlsbad, NM and 145 miles (233 km) northeast of El Paso, TX. The entrance road stretches a scenic seven miles (11.3 km) from the park gate at White's City to the visitor center and cavern entrance. The address for the park's visitor center is 727 Carlsbad Caverns Hwy, Carlsbad, NM, 88220, located 27 miles (43 km) from the town of Carlsbad.
properties.weatherInfo: Carlsbad Caverns National Park is located in the Chihuahuan Desert in southeast New Mexico. Summers are hot with temperatures between 90°F (32°C) and low 100s °F (38°C). Windy conditions and mild temperatures are common in early spring (March-May) with frequent rain in early fall (August-September). This part of the country also sees cold temperatures in the winter with occasional snow and icy conditions. Most days, the park is enveloped by a gorgeous blue sky with very few clouds, 278 sunny days a year!
properties.name: Carlsbad Caverns
properties.description: High ancient sea ledges, deep rocky canyons, flowering cactus, and desert wildlife—treasures above the ground in the Chihuahuan Desert. Hidden beneath the surface are more than 119 caves—formed when sulfuric acid dissolved limestone leaving behind caverns of all sizes.

images.altText: Looking up through the mouth of the cave on the Natural Entrance path.
images.title: The Natural Entrance
images.caption: Beautiful view looking back out the Natural Entrance as you descend into the cave.

images.altText: Visitors rest at the formation "Rock of Ages."
images.title: Rock of Ages
images.caption: Part of the Big Room tour, the "Rock of Ages" is a spectacular formation.

images.altText: Visitors gathered in the outdoor amphitheater to experience bat flight.
images.title: A ranger presents a Bat Flight Program to hundreds of visitors.
images.caption: Every summer evening visitors gather in the outdoor amphitheater to watch hundreds of thousands of bats leave on their nightly food forage.

images.altText: Visitors watch as droplets ripple through a cave pool.
images.title: Longfellow's Bathtub
images.caption: A spectacular view from Longfellow's Bathtub, a long cave pool, inside the Big Room.

images.altText: "The Chandelier" is spotlighted in this photo taken inside the Big Room.
images.title: The Big Room inside the cavern.
images.caption: A scenic view of the Big Room, highlighting "the Chandelier" formation clinging to the 250 foot high ceiling.

images.altText: Gorgeous formations inside the Big Room of the cavern.
images.title: Scenic Big Room
images.caption: A grand view of the Big Room, fully decorated with stalagmites and stalactites.

images.altText: A hedgehog cactus in bloom in a rocky garden.
images.title: Life Among Rocks
images.caption: Amid the arid rocky environment, a hedgehog cactus blooms in the spring.

images.altText: Two Jr. Rangers earn their badges.
images.title: New Jr. Rangers
images.caption: Ranger Chris Bramblett kneeling with two new Jr. Rangers, after the children were awarded their badges.

entranceFees.description: Admits one private non-commercial vehicle (capacity 15 or less) and all of its passengers. Valid for 7 days. Organized non-profit groups, (service organizations, scouts, church groups, college/school clubs) are not eligible.
entranceFees.title: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Per motorcycle - Valid for 7 days
entranceFees.title: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Per walk-in pedestrian - valid for 7 days

entranceFees.description: Per bicycle - Valid for 7 days
entranceFees.title: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park - Bicycle

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups entering the park in a bus or vehicle with a capacity of 16 persons or more will be charged $15.00 for each person on board. Exceptions: Anyone who is 15 or younger is exempt from paying an entrance fee. Passes may be used for entry as defined on the back of the pass. In many cases the driver will have been hired for transportation only and is exempt from paying the entrance fee. The total fee charged will not exceed the equivalent commercial fee for that type of vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park - Groups

properties.directionsInfo: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park is located on the island of Hawai‘i. From Hilo: 30 miles southwest on Highway 11 (a 45 minute drive); from Kailua-Kona: 96 miles southeast on Highway 11 (2 to 2 1/2 hour drive), or 125 miles through Waimea and Hilo via highways 19 and 11 (2 1/2 to 3 hours).

entrancePasses.description: An annual tri-park pass allows access for 1 full year from date of first use at Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park, Haleakalā National Park, and Pu‘uhonua o Hōnaunau National Historical Park.
entrancePasses.title: Hawai‘i Tri-Park Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The weather at Kīlauea's summit (4000' elevation) varies daily and may be rainy and chilly any time of the year. Temperature varies by elevation. At the summit of the volcano, temperatures may be 12 to 15 degrees cooler than at sea level. The coastal plain at the end of Chain of Craters Road, where lava crossed the road in 2003, is often hot, dry, and windy with the possibility of passing showers.
properties.name: Hawai'i Volcanoes
properties.description: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park protects some of the most unique geological, biological, and cultural landscapes in the world. Extending from sea level to 13,677 feet, the park encompasses the summits of two of the world's most active volcanoes - Kīlauea and Mauna Loa.

images.altText: Steam from the Steaming Bluff

images.caption: The Steaming Bluff is near the Steam Vents area. Rain water seeps down to hot earth and returns as steam.

images.altText: Sulphur Banks
images.title: Sulphur Banks
images.caption: Walk the boardwalk along the Sulphur Banks. The smell may be an irritant to some.

images.altText: Hikers on the Kīlauea Iki Trail

images.caption: A very popular hike is the Kīlauea Iki Trail. It's a 4 mile loop trail along the crater rim and across the crater floor.
