entranceFees.description: All services and programs are free.
entranceFees.title: Alibates Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Alibates Flint Quarries is located approximately 35 miles north of Amarillo, Texas. From I-40 in Amarillo, take Lakeside exit north towards Lake Meredith National Recreation Area. Exit on TX 136 north towards Borger. After about 30 miles, turn west from TX 136 onto Cas Johnson Road. Park Service signs will be visible. Proceed approximately 3 miles to "Y" intersection and bear to right. Go northwest approximately 2 miles to the Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument Visitor Center.

entrancePasses.description: We charge no entrance fee and do not require an entrance pass.
entrancePasses.title: Monument Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The Texas Panhandle experiences a wide variety of weather conditions throughout the year. Winters are cold and windy, and summers are hot and dry. It is usually a good idea to bring a jacket with you if you are planning on hiking to the quarries with a ranger because the mesa gets very windy, even in the summer.
properties.name: Alibates Flint Quarries
properties.description: 13,000 years ago this site was already well-known by mammoth hunters as a place to get the best stone for their tools. Centuries passed but the colorful flint found right here in the Texas panhandle never lost its value and usefulness. Visit and gain a sense of how integral this site was to the survival, commerce and culture of the High Plains.

images.altText: Turtle Petroglyph at Antelope Creek Village Site
images.title: Turtle Petroglyph
images.caption: Turtle Petroglyph at Antelope Creek Village Site

images.altText: Looking down from the nearby mesa onto the gardens and Alibates Visitor Center.
images.title: Alibates Visitor Center
images.caption: The gardens and Alibates Visitor Center host activities and ranger-led programs throughout the year.

images.altText: Colorful chunks of Alibates Flint.
images.title: Alibates Flint
images.caption: Used for at least 13,000 years, Alibates Flint was the choice of many tribes for their stone tools, spearpoints and arrowheads.

images.altText: Stair steps up the Alibates Flint Quarries Trail.
images.title: Alibates Flint Quarries Trail
images.caption: Take a hike up the Quarries Trail to learn about this important stone.

images.altText: A snowy mesa, as seen from the Alibates Visitor Center.
images.title: Snowy Alibates
images.caption: Every season hold special beauty at Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument.

properties.directionsInfo:
Canaveral National Seashore is located along Florida's East coast in both Volusia & Brevard counties. To access Apollo Beach, take I-95 to exit 249, then go east until it turns into A1A. Follow A1A south to the park entrance. 

To access Playalinda Beach, take I-95 to exit 220. Go east through Titusville on Garden Street, continue east and follow the signs.

entrancePasses.description: Park-specific pass. Admits pass holder and all persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle to Canaveral National Seashore. Valid for 12 months from when the pass is purchased.
entrancePasses.title: Canaveral National Seashore Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Summer:  Hot & humid (Temperatures average in the 90's)

Winter months:  Temperatures in the 40-70 degree range, with a "cold spells" where temps down to the low to mid-30's).

Hurricane Season: June 1st through November 30th  (most activity normally occurs in August or September)
properties.name: Canaveral
properties.description: Since ancient times, this barrier island has provided sanctuary to both people and wildlife. Many threatened and endangered species find refuge here, including sea turtles who nest on its shores. Like first natives and early settlers, you too can find tranquility. Stroll down a wooded trail. Reflect on a pristine undeveloped shoreline - the way things used to be.

images.altText: Image of Playalinda beach
images.title: Playalinda Beach
images.caption: Each year millions of visitors discover the pristine beauty of Canaveral National Seashore.

images.altText: Image of mosquito lagoon viewed from one of Playalinda's vistas
images.title: Mosquito Lagoon
images.caption: Discover the pristine beauty of Canaveral National Seashore

images.altText: Image of mosquito lagoon viewed from restored main house at Seminole Rest
images.title: Seminole Rest
images.caption: Just one of the views available to park visitors who visit to Canaveral's historic Seminole Rest site.

images.altText: Image of trail at Seminole Rest
images.title: Trail at Seminole Rest
images.caption: Visit Seminole Rest to discover that Canaveral National Seashore has much more to offer than just a fun day at the beach...

images.altText: Image of Visitor Center at Apollo Beach
images.title: Canaveral National Seashore Visitor Center
images.caption: While you're here, be sure to stop by our visitor center at Apollo Beach; see the exhibits, meet some of the staff, and browse the souvenir shop.

images.caption: Get an up close view of a rocket launch!

entranceFees.description: None
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Buffalo National River is a long, narrow park that is crossed by three main highways. 

Highways 7, 43, and 62/65 are the main roads out of Harrison, Arkansas that will take you to the Buffalo River, depending on which part of the park you wish to visit.

GPS systems are not reliable in this area so please call ahead for directions or pick up a map of the area beforehand.

entrancePasses.description: None
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Summer in the Ozarks can be very hot and humid. Please check the weather forecast prior to your arrival and plan accordingly. The weather the rest of the year has the potential to be wet and cool or dry and warm. Please pay special attention to river levels and the rain forecast when planning a trip on the river. River levels can rise dramatically in a short period of time so please be aware of conditions.
properties.name: Buffalo
properties.description: Established in 1972, Buffalo National River flows freely for 135 miles and is one of the few remaining undammed rivers in the lower 48 states. Once you arrive, prepare to journey from running rapids to quiet pools while surrounded by massive bluffs as you cruise through the Ozark Mountains down to the White River.

images.altText: A large bluff shelter near Buffalo Point.
images.title: Indian Rockhouse
images.caption: Every year thousands of people hike to the Indian Rockhouse to admire this large bluff shelter.

images.altText: Kayakers floating towards Skull Rock near Buffalo Point.
images.title: Skull Rock
images.caption: A peaceful day on the Buffalo River as kayakers approach Skull Rock and Buffalo Point.

images.altText: Camping at Steel Creek
images.title: Steel Creek Campground
images.caption: Camping along the Buffalo River is a wonderful way to enjoy the park.

images.altText: Floaters on the river.
images.title: Floating the Buffalo
images.caption: Canoeing and kayaking the river is a wonderful way to spend a day at the Buffalo.

images.altText: Historic homestead built by the Collier Family.
images.title: Sod Collier Homestead
images.caption: Many historic structures are scattered along the Buffalo River reminding us of the hardworking settlers that once called this river valley home.

images.altText: Fisherman with smallmouth bass.
images.title: Smallmouth Bass Fishing
images.caption: Fishing for smallmouth bass is a popular activity on the Buffalo River.

emailAddresses.description: Primary email contact for Mammoth Cave National Park visitor information

entranceFees.description: Entry to Mammoth Cave National Park and its surface features is free of charge. There is, however, a charge to tour the cave. Cave tour prices vary.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Visit the Rotunda, one of the largest rooms in the cave and explore a vast canyon passageway. Learn about prehistoric Native American explorers, saltpeter mining operations, and basic cave geology. This is a short introductory tour to Mammoth Cave.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Passage Tour - Adult Ticket

entranceFees.description: Visit the Rotunda, one of the largest rooms in the cave and explore a vast canyon passageway. Learn about prehistoric Native American explorers, saltpeter mining operations, and basic cave geology. This is a short introductory tour to Mammoth Cave.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Passage Tour - Youth Ticket

entranceFees.description: Visit the Rotunda, one of the largest rooms in the cave and explore a vast canyon passageway. Learn about prehistoric Native American explorers, saltpeter mining operations, and basic cave geology. This is a short introductory tour to Mammoth Cave.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Passage Tour - Senior Pass or Access Pass holder

entranceFees.description: The Frozen Niagara Entrance provides easy access to this decorative area of the cave. Walk through a fairyland of formations to learn how dripstone is formed. An optional 49 step staircase takes visitors under the Frozen Niagara formation to the Drapery Room. This easy trip is ideal for people who want a short introduction to Mammoth Cave. A ten-minute bus ride to and from the entrance is included.
entranceFees.title: Frozen Niagara Tour - Adult Ticket

entranceFees.description: The Frozen Niagara Entrance provides easy access to this decorative area of the cave. Walk through a fairyland of formations to learn how dripstone is formed. An optional 49 step staircase takes visitors under the Frozen Niagara formation to the Drapery Room. This easy trip is ideal for people who want a short introduction to Mammoth Cave. A ten minute bus ride to and from the entrance is included.
entranceFees.title: Frozen Niagara Tour - Youth Ticket

entranceFees.description: The Frozen Niagara Entrance provides easy access to this decorative area of the cave. Walk through a fairyland of formations to learn how dripstone is formed. A ten minute bus ride to and from the entrance is included.

entranceFees.description: Visit one of the largest rooms in the cave and explore a vast canyon passageway. Learn about prehistoric explorers, saltpeter mining, early owners and basic cave geology on this self-guiding tour. Rangers are on hand along this short introductory tour.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Cave Discovery Tour - Adult Ticket

entranceFees.description: Visit one of the largest rooms in the cave and explore a vast canyon passageway. Learn about prehistoric explorers, saltpeter mining, early owners and basic cave geology on this self-guiding tour. Rangers are on hand along this short introductory tour.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Cave Discovery Tour - Youth Ticket

entranceFees.description: Visit one of the largest rooms in the cave and explore a vast canyon passageway. Learn about prehistoric explorers, saltpeter mining, early owners and basic cave geology on this self-guiding tour. Rangers are on hand along this short introductory tour.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Cave Discovery Tour - Senior Pass or Access Pass holder

entranceFees.description: Feel the same excitement that intrigued our earliest explorers and visitors. Leave initial large passages behind to descend into deeper levels. Cross over Bottomless Pit, squeeze through Fat Man's Misery, clamber up Mammoth Dome tower to return to the Historic Entrance.
entranceFees.title: Historic Tour - Adult Ticket

entranceFees.description: Feel the same excitement that intrigued our earliest explorers and visitors. Leave initial large passages behind to descend into deeper levels. Cross over Bottomless Pit, squeeze through Fat Man's Misery, clamber up Mammoth Dome tower to return to the Historic Entrance.
entranceFees.title: Historic Tour - Youth Ticket

entranceFees.description: Feel the same excitement that intrigued our earliest explorers and visitors. Leave initial large passages behind to descend into deeper levels. Cross over Bottomless Pit, squeeze through Fat Man's Misery, clamber up Mammoth Dome tower to return to the Historic Entrance.

entranceFees.description: Wind down through deep pits and high domes via a 280 step staircase. Vertical cave gives way to large canyons and underground hill climbs.  Visit the Frozen Niagara formation, then pass through one of the caves most decorative dripstone areas. A ten-minute bus ride to and from the entrances is included.
entranceFees.title: Domes and Dripstones Tour - Adult Ticket

entranceFees.description: Wind down through deep pits and high domes via a 280 step staircase. Vertical cave gives way to large canyons and underground hill climbs.  Visit the Frozen Niagara formation, then pass through one of the caves most decorative dripstone areas. A ten-minute bus ride to and from the entrances is included.

entranceFees.description: Wind down through deep pits and high domes via a 280 step staircase. Vertical cave gives way to large canyons and underground hill climbs.  Visit the Frozen Niagara formation, then pass through one of the caves most decorative dripstone areas. A ten-minute bus ride to and from the entrances is included.

entranceFees.description: This physically demanding trip gives you an excellent perspective of the size and complexity of the Mammoth Cave system. Learn of the interwoven natural and cultural history of the cave as you journey  through some of the cave’s most dramatic passages.
entranceFees.title: Grand Avenue Tour - Adult Ticket

The flickering flame and rustic trails in this area make it seem as if time stands still in the cave.

Learn of early photography and challenges with cave lighting. Still or video cameras may be used, with flash. Pass through Thanksgiving Hall, Shower Bath Springs, Drapery Room, Onyx Colonnade, and Rainbow Dome.

Gaze upward in the Star Chamber as a traditional illusion is recreated. Follow your guide into mystical Gothic Avenue. Retrace your steps and exit the cave to Kentucky’s nocturnal landscape.

Unlock the secrets of how cave life survives. Discover a new world as you hike, crawl and belly-slide through the cave. (Children 8-12 years only)

Be prepared for free-climbing, lengthy crawls, wet areas, and tight openings. Good physical condition is essential.  Participants must be 16 years of age.  Any youth ages 16 - 17 must be accompanied by an adult 18 or over.

entranceFees.description: Located ¼ mile from the park Visitor Center, this campground includes 105 sites. Each site features paved parking, a picnic table, and a fire ring. The campground has restrooms, fresh water, a dump station, garbage dumpsters, and a recycling station.  There are no hookups for electricity or water. No Refunds. Reservations are recommended. Check-in time is 12 noon, and check-out time is 11am. A maximum of 8 persons is permitted at each  site, and campers may stay a maximum of 14 days in a calendar year.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Cave Campground - Regular Site

entranceFees.description: Located ¼ mile from the park Visitor Center, this campground includes 105 sites. Each site features paved parking, a picnic table, and a fire ring. The campground has restrooms, fresh water, a dump station, garbage dumpsters, and a recycling station.  There are no hookups for electricity or water. No Refunds. Reservations are recommended. Check-in time is 12 noon, and check-out time is 11am. A maximum of 8 persons is permitted at each  site, and campers may stay a maximum of 14 days in a calendar year.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Cave Campground - Regular Site - Senior/Access Pass

entranceFees.description: Mammoth Cave Campground offers 4 sites to accommodate groups, with a limit of 16 campers per site.  Each site has paved parking, picnic tables, and a fire ring. No discount is offered on group camping.  Check-in time is 12 noon, and check-out time is 11am. No refunds. Reservations are recommended.
entranceFees.title: Mammoth Cave Campground - Group Site

entranceFees.description: Located 6 miles from the Visitor Center and 3 miles north of the Green River Ferry, this campground has 7 sites; 3 of these are primitive group sites with a limit of 24 persons/site.  All Maple Springs campsites have multiple picnic tables and fire rings. Chemical toilets, garbage dumpsters, and fresh water are available. No discounts for group camping. No refunds. Reservations are required. Maple Springs Campground check-in time is 12 noon and check-out time is 11am.
entranceFees.title: Maple Springs Group Campground - Group Site

entranceFees.description: Located 6 miles from the Visitor Center and 3 miles north of the Green River Ferry, this campground has 7 sites; 4 of these are designated horse camp sites with hitching posts and trailer parking, limited to 8 horses/site. Sites #1 and #2 have water and electric hookups. All Maple Springs sites have picnic tables and fire rings. Chemical toilets, garbage dumpsters, and fresh water available. No discounts for group camping. No refunds. Reservations required. Campground check-in is noon and check-out is 11am.
entranceFees.title: Maple Springs Group Campground - Horseback Site - Hookups

entranceFees.description: Located 6 miles from the Visitor Center and 3 miles north of the Green River Ferry, this campground has 7 sites; 4 of these are designated horse camp sites with hitching posts and trailer parking, limited to 8 horses/site. Sites #3 and #4 are primitive (no hookups). All Maple Springs sites have picnic tables and fire rings. Chemical toilets, garbage dumpsters, and fresh water available. No discounts for group camping. No refunds. Reservations required. Campground check-in is noon and check-out is 11am.
entranceFees.title: Maple Springs Group Campground - Horseback Site - Primitive

entranceFees.description: Located 15 miles from the park Visitor Center on the south bank of the Green River, this campground includes 12 sites. Each site has a picnic table and a fire ring. The campground has two chemical toilets, fresh water, and an adjacent picnic shelter. This campground is not suitable for large trailers or RVs. No refunds. Campsites are available on a first-come, first-served basis.
entranceFees.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Regular Site

entranceFees.description: Located 15 miles from the park Visitor Center on the south bank of the Green River, this campground includes 12 sites. Each site has a picnic table and a fire ring. Campsites are available on a first-come, first-served basis. Fee is per night/per site.
entranceFees.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Regular Site - Senior/Access Pass

entranceFees.description: Located near the park Visitor Center, the picnic area has an open picnic shelter available by reservation. The picnic area also has fire grates, restrooms, fresh water, and a garbage dumpster. The picnic shelter features ten picnic tables, and a working fireplace. Availability is limited; call for information. No Refunds. Cost is per day.
entranceFees.title: Open Picnic Shelter - Reservation

entranceFees.description: Located near the park Visitor Center, the picnic area has an enclosed picnic shelter available by reservation. The picnic area also has fire grates, restrooms, fresh water, and a garbage dumpster. The picnic shelter features ten picnic tables. Availability is limited; call for information. No Refunds. Cost is per day.
entranceFees.title: Enclosed Picnic Shelter - Reservation

entranceFees.description: Utilizing the Elevator Entrance, this tour emerges near the historic underground cafeteria known as Snowball Room. Continuing through historic Cleaveland Avenue, this tour passes through areas of the cave highly decorated with historic signatures and sparkling geological formations. This tour is ideal for people who wish to see the cave and are looking for a tour with no stairs.

properties.directionsInfo:
DO NOT FOLLOW YOUR GPS!

From the North: Take Interstate 65 to Exit 53 (Cave City Exit). Turn right onto KY-70. Follow 70/255 as it becomes the Mammoth Cave Parkway in the park. Follow the Mammoth Cave Parkway to the Visitor Center.

From the South: Take Interstate 65 to Exit 48 (Park City Exit). Turn left onto KY-255 and follow 255 as it becomes the Park City Road into the park. Follow Park City Road until it joins the Mammoth Cave Parkway; turn left. Follow the Mammoth Cave Parkway to the Visitor Center.
properties.weatherInfo: Kentucky has a moderate climate with warm, yet moist conditions. Summers average in the high 80s; winters average in the low 40s. Southern Kentucky, where Mammoth Cave is located, receives the highest average precipitation for the state, about 50 inches per year, mostly in spring. Winter can bring mild to moderate snow and ice. Storms happen year-round, and can include tornadoes and flooding in low-lying areas, but severe weather is infrequent. The temperature deep in the cave is a constant 54°F (12°C).
properties.name: Mammoth Cave
properties.description: Mammoth Cave National Park preserves not only the longest known cave system on earth (400+ miles), but also 53,000 acres of beautiful forest.  With nearly a dozen miles of cave trail below ground, and a surface boasting nearly 70 miles of nature trail, 13 backcountry campsites, three campgrounds, and over 20 miles of navigable river to explore and enjoy, it really is two worlds in one

images.altText: A ranger explains the cave to visitors in the vast expanse of the passage called Broadway.
images.title: Broadway in Mammoth Cave
images.caption: A ranger explains Mammoth Cave in the vast passage known as Broadway. Rotunda, one of the cave's largest rooms, is just ahead.

images.altText: Dripstone formations create a panoply of textures in the Frozen Niagara section of Mammoth Cave
images.title: Mammoth Cave - Dripstone Wall
images.caption: Dripstone formations create a panoply of textures in the Frozen Niagara section of Mammoth Cave as slowly dripping water redeposits dissolved limestone over the course of centuries. Image is a panoramic composite.

images.altText: A girl peers wonderingly into the shadows of Mammoth Cave.
images.title: Wonder in Mammoth Cave
images.caption: Mammoth Cave's shadows have beckoned the explorer deep within its visitors for geneerations, asking the question "Where does that lead? What lies in the dark places?" The questions remain as compelling today as they did for the first explorers.

images.altText: A kayaker paddles up the languid waters of the Green River in Mammoth Cave National Park.
images.title: Green River in Mammoth Cave National Park
images.caption: More than 30 miles of the Green and Nolin Rivers course through Mammoth Cave NP, representing one of the most biologically diverse river systems in the Eastern United States. Their languid waters are a magnet for canoeist, kayakers and anglers.

images.altText: A layer of fog hangs over a small group gathered to enter Mammoth Cave on a summer day.
images.title: Fog at Mammoth Cave Entrance
images.caption: A layer of mist hangs over a small tour group gathered at the Historic Entrance of Mammoth Cave on a summer day - it both delights the skin and fogs spectacles, and gives a sense that one is on the threshold of another world.

images.altText: Frances Benjamin Johnston and her photographic expedition enter Mammoth Cave in 1892.
images.title: Frances Benjamin Johnston Enters Mammoth Cave in 1892
images.caption: Frances Benjamin Johnston and her photographic expedition enter the Historic Entrance of Mammoth Cave, 1892.

Car

Plane

properties.weatherInfo: Whiskeytown NRA is in a Mediterranean climate, which means hot, dry summers followed by cool, wet winters. Summer temperatures often reach the upper 90's to lower 100 degrees Fahrenheit, as well as the occasional thunderstorm. Winter brings snow to the upper elevations (only occasionally down to the lake level of 1,200'), and rain and ice.
properties.name: Whiskeytown
properties.description: Whiskeytown Lake’s crystal-clear water is perhaps the most recognized feature of the park. However, water-based recreation is only a part of what the 42,000-acre Whiskeytown National Recreation Area (NRA) has to offer. Visit waterfalls, hike through rugged mountains, explore California Gold Rush history, and observe post-fire ecology in action. Your national park is calling...

Possession of passes or the ages of the passengers does not affect the price charged.

properties.directionsInfo:
Driving
Westbound on Highway I-70 towards Grand Junction, Exit 31 (Horizon Drive).
Follow signs through Grand Junction to the east entrance. The visitor center and campground are 19 miles from the east entrance.

Eastbound on Highway I-70 take Exit 19 (Fruita). Turn south on Highway 340 to the west entrance, which is approximately three miles from Fruita. The visitor center and campground are four miles up from the west entrance.

entrancePasses.description: Covers entrance fees for any two passholders and accompanying passengers in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle at Colorado National Monument. This pass can be purchased at either entrance to Colorado National Monument. Good for one year from purchase. This pass does not cover camping fees. Non-transferable and non-refundable.
entrancePasses.title: Colorado National Monument Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Spring - Daytime high temperatures 70-85 F (21-30 C), nighttime low temperature 30-50 F (-1 - +10 C).
Summer - Daytime high temperatures can reach 100 F (38 C), afternoon thunderstorms common.
Fall - Similar to spring temperatures, sudden changes in weather common. Snow can occur in October.
Winter - Daytime highs vary from 10 - 45 F (-12 - +7 C). Snow common, patches of snow and ice stay around most of the winter.
properties.name: Colorado
properties.description: Colorado National Monument preserves one of the grand landscapes of the American West. But this treasure is much more than a monument. Towering monoliths exist within a vast plateau and canyon panorama. You can experience sheer-walled, red rock canyons along the twists and turns of Rim Rock Drive, where you may spy bighorn sheep and soaring eagles.

properties.directionsInfo: Pinnacles National Park is accessible through highway 101 for the West entrance, and highway 25 for the East entrance. From highway 101 you must pass through the City of Soledad to find highway 146 which will lead to West side of Pinnacles. To enter East Pinnacles you must find highway 25 through the City of Hollister coming from the North, and King City through Bitter Water Road (G-13) when coming from the South.

properties.weatherInfo: Pinnacles National Park has a Mediterranean climate with hot and dry summers, and mild winters with moderate precipitation. The park is several miles inland from the Pacific Ocean. A wider variation in seasonal temperatures can be expected in the local area. On July or August day, daytime temperatures over 100° F are not uncommon, but a bright sunny day can turn into a very cold night.
properties.name: Pinnacles
properties.description: Some 23 million years ago multiple volcanoes erupted, flowed, and slid to form what would become Pinnacles National Park. What remains is a unique landscape. Travelers journey through chaparral, oak woodlands, and canyon bottoms. Hikers enter rare talus caves and emerge to towering rock spires teeming with life: prairie and peregrine falcons, golden eagles, and the inspiring California condor.

images.altText: Boulders in the Balconies Cave.
images.title: Balconies Caves
images.caption: Balconies Cliffs as seen from the inside of the Balconies Caves

images.altText: Light falling on tree
images.title: Tree
images.caption: Light illuminates a tree on a rainy day, seen from the Resurrection Wall.

images.altText: A Tarantula walking
images.title: Tarantula
images.caption: A Tarantula crawls in the wild.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for the lakeshore, however, there are various user fees. Check the website for more information.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Apostle Islands National Lakeshore features several points of interest. Learn more about how to get to the park on the park website.
properties.weatherInfo:
Lake Superior is renowned for its cold temperatures, rough seas, fog, and sudden squalls. Boaters and paddlers should monitor marine weather forecasts and be constantly alert to changing conditions.

Average daytime high temperatures range from 60 degrees Fahrenheit in May, to the upper 80s in mid-summer, to the mid-60s in September. Average lows vary from 40 degrees in May, to the upper 50s in mid-summer, to 50 degrees in September. Average water temperatures in May and June are only in the 40s.
properties.name: Apostle Islands
properties.description: Imagine that moment, being in that perfect spot as the sun rises, and everything comes into focus. A rocky shoreline suddenly reflects the world around you. Waiting for you among the water, land, forests, and history is that moment. How will the islands inspire you?

images.altText: The Long Island Light.
images.title: Long Island Lightstation
images.caption: The Long Island Light.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Big Cypress National Preserve
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Big Cypress is located along the Tamiami Trail East and I-75 in southern Florida.  The preserve can be accessed by driving from Miami and Naples. The preserves two visitor centers are located along Tamiami Trail East.
properties.weatherInfo:
Big Cypress National Preserve experiences two predominant seasons- wet and dry.

RAINY SEASON
(May through October)
While visiting during this season you may find daily afternoon thunderstorms, high humidity, temperatures in the mid - to - high 80s and a multitude of mosquitoes. 

DRY SEASON
(November through April)
Falling water levels within the Big Cypress make this a pleasant time to hike, camp, and watch wildlife.

For more information visit http://www.nps.gov/bicy/planyourvisit/weather.htm
properties.name: Big Cypress
properties.description: The freshwaters of the Big Cypress Swamp, essential to the health of the neighboring Everglades, support the rich marine estuaries along Florida's southwest coast. Protecting over 729,000 acres of this vast swamp, Big Cypress National Preserve contains a mixture of tropical and temperate plant communities that are home to a diversity of wildlife, including the elusive Florida panther.

images.altText: a Florida Panther sits in a tree
images.title: Florida Panther
images.caption: The Florida Panther is one of the most iconic animals of Big Cypress

images.altText: Two Alligators rest on a river bank
images.title: Alligators of Big Cypress
images.caption: Two Alligators rest on a river bank

images.altText: two visitors in a canoe go through mangrove tunnels on the Turner River
images.title: Canoeing through mangrove tunnels
images.caption: Canoeing is one of the many activities you can enjoy in Big Cypress

images.altText: A prairie foreground with tall pine trees in the background. A large blue sky with white cloud
images.title: Prairies and Pine Lands in Big Cypress
images.caption: large open expanses of prairie bordered by pine lands create stunning landscapes

images.altText: palm trees emerge out of the fog in an orange sunrise
images.title: Sunrise in Big Cypress
images.caption: palm trees emerge out of the fog as an orange sunrise dots the landscape

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Big South Fork NRRA.
entranceFees.title: Big South Fork Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Please use the following link to learn more about how to get here from various locations.
properties.weatherInfo: The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.
properties.name: Big South Fork
properties.description: Encompassing 125,000 acres of the Cumberland Plateau, Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area protects the free-flowing Big South Fork of the Cumberland River and its tributaries. The area boasts miles of scenic gorges and sandstone bluffs, is rich with natural and historic features and has been developed to provide visitors with a wide range of outdoor recreational activities.

images.altText: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.title: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.caption: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall

properties.fullName: Big South Fork National River & Recreation Area

properties.directionsInfo:
Bighorn Canyon has two districts that are separated by a three hour drive.  

To get to the North District at Fort Smith, MT from Billings,take Interstate 90 south to Hardin, MT. Turn at exit 495 onto State Highway 313 to St. Xavier and then to Fort Smith, Montana.

To get to the South District at Lovell, WY from Billings, MT, take Interstate 90 west. Turn at exit 434 at Laurel, MT. Turn onto US 310 East/US 212 South. Turn at US 310 East to Lovell. The visitor center is on the east side of Lovell.
properties.weatherInfo:
North District: Semi-arid, receiving 18 to 20 inches of rain annually.
South District: High-desert, receiving 6 to 10 inches of rain annually.
Summer temperatures: Highs in the 80s (F) and 90s (F), lows in the 50s (F) and 60s (F). Summer temperatures can peak over 100 degrees.
Winter temperatures: Range in the 20s and 30s with low temperatures averaging the 10s (F) and 20s (F). During the winter the thermometer can drop below 0 (F) with extreme wind chill factors.
properties.name: Bighorn Canyon
properties.description: The vast, wild landscape of Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area offers visitors unparalleled opportunities to immerse themselves in the natural world, and experience the wonders of this extraordinary place. With over 120,000 acres, one can find an astounding diversity in ecosystems, wildlife, and more than 10,000 years of human history to explore.

images.altText: Summer view of the Yellowtail Dam from the Ok-A-Beh road.
images.title: Yellowtail Dam
images.caption: Summer view of the Yellowtail Dam from the Ok-A-Beh road.

images.altText: spring cactus with yellow flowers
images.title: Spring Cactus
images.caption: Spring Cactus

images.altText: Kayaks at Barry's Landing
images.title: Kayaks at Barry's Landing
images.caption: Kayaks at Barry's Landing ready to go.

images.title: Bighorn Sheep Overlooking the Canyon
images.caption: Bighorn Sheep Overlooking the Canyon

images.title: Devil Canyon Overlook from Sullivan's Knob Trail
images.caption: Devil Canyon Overlook from Sullivan's Knob Trail

images.altText: smooth water just south of Barry's Landing

images.caption: Horseshoe Bend from the Sykes Mountain

Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area South District Visitor Center

entranceFees.description: Driving the parkway is free.
entranceFees.title: No entrance fee

properties.directionsInfo: The parkway is a 469-mile-long scenic road connecting Shenandoah National Park in Virginia to Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina. Numerous federal and state highways provide access to the parkway. Milepost markers are positioned every mile along the parkway, starting at 0 in Virginia and ending at 469 in North Carolina. We suggest using a map to identify the area you want to visit, as GPS directions often do not incorporate the parkway's milepost system.
properties.weatherInfo: The weather on the parkway can vary widely along its 469-mile route. Precipitation is possible any time of the year. Winter can be cold and snowy, especially at the higher elevations. Spring and fall can have large temperature swings, from near freezing to over 80 degrees Fahrenheit. Summers are hot in the lower elevations, but the highest elevations remain cooler. Summertime thunderstorms are common, so be prepared for weather changes.
properties.name: Blue Ridge
properties.description: A Blue Ridge Parkway experience is unlike any other: a slow-paced and relaxing drive revealing stunning long-range vistas and close-up views of the rugged mountains and pastoral landscapes of the Appalachian Highlands. The Parkway meanders for 469 miles, protecting a diversity of plants and animals, and providing opportunities for enjoying all that makes this region of the country so special.

images.altText: Black Bear Cub
images.title: Black Bear Club
images.caption: Black bears are among the many mammals found across the Blue Ridge Parkway.

images.altText: Fall at Linn Cove Viaduct
images.title: Linn Cove Viaduct
images.caption: Linn Cove Viaduct, located in the North Carolina Highlands district, is one of the most iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.altText: Summer colors at Mabry Mill
images.title: Mabry Mill
images.caption: Located in Virginia's Plateau district, picturesque Mabry Mill is one of the most iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.altText: Mountain vista and clouds on the Blue Ridge Parkway
images.title: Mountain vista
images.caption: Beautiful mountain in North Carolina draw visitors from around the world to the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.altText: water cascading into Linville Falls plunge basin
images.title: Linville Falls
images.caption: The Linville Gorge offers visitors the opportunity to learn about fascinating geology and view magnificent waterfalls.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for the park.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
The recommended route to the park is from Highway 191 in Chinle then turning east on Route 7. The park entrance and Visitor Center is about 3 miles from Highway 191.

An alternative is entering the park on the East side via Route 64. There are 3 overlooks to stop at along Route 64 before getting to the Visitor Center.

Travel on Route 7 from the East is NOT RECOMMENDED since the road is unpaved and unmaintained between Sawmill and the Spider Rock turnoff.
properties.weatherInfo: Canyon de Chelly is located at 5,500 feet.  Spring is cool and windy; highs from 50 to 70; lows of 35 degrees.  Expect dust storms and canyon flooding. Summer is hot and dry; highs from 85 to 100; lows of 51 degrees.  Drink plenty of water outdoors. Fall is warm and often wet; highs from 60 to 80; lows of 40 degrees.  Expect lightning, thunderstorms, and flash floods. Winter is cold and breezy; highs from 40 to 60; lows of 18 degrees. Expect 1-4 inches of snow and freezing nighttime temperatures.
properties.name: Canyon de Chelly
properties.description: For nearly 5,000 years, people have lived in these canyons - longer than anyone has lived uninterrupted anywhere on the Colorado Plateau.  In the place called Tsegi, their homes and images tell us their stories. Today, Navajo families make their homes, raise livestock, and farm the lands in the canyons. A place like no other, the park and Navajo Nation work together to manage the land's resources.

images.altText: Farm in the canyon
images.title: Canyon Farm
images.caption: Navajo families continue to live and farm in the canyon they call Tsegi

images.altText: Hiking in the canyon
images.title: Canyon Hike
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy a free ranger led hike into the canyon

images.altText: View of Spider Rock from the overlook
images.title: Spider Rock
images.caption: Her home on top of Spider Rock, Spider Woman taught the Navajo people how to weave

images.altText: View of the canyon from the White House Trail
images.title: Canyon View
images.caption: The Navajo people call the canyon Tsegi meaning "within the rocks"

images.altText: View of White House Ruin
images.title: White House
images.caption: Ancient Puebloans built villages like White House that offered opportunities for trade, ceremony, and social gatherings.

properties.directionsInfo: Much of the year, the park's North Entrance is closed to cars. The North Entrance Road closes for the season on November 1 (or earlier if there is significant snowfall) and tends to open in early June.  The park’s South Entrance is open year round. Winter travelers from Roseburg will need to take Route 138 east to Route 230 south to Route 62 east to the park's west entrance. Winter travels from Bend will take Route 97 south to Route 62 north and west to the park's south entrance.

entrancePasses.description: Valid at Crater Lake National Park and Lava Beds National Monument only, the Crater Lake annual pass is good for one year from the issue month. It admits the pass owner and accompanying passengers in a single, private, noncommercial vehicle or pass owner and three persons when entry is by other means.
entrancePasses.title: Crater Lake Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Summers at Crater Lake are short but sunny. July, August, and September are your best bets for warm, dry weather. In May, June, and October, sunny days alternate with periods of rain and snow. Winters at Crater Lake are long and snowy. Storms from the Pacific Ocean dump an annual average of 43 feet (13 meters) of snow at Park Headquarters. The park's tremendous snowfall is a result of its position at the crest of the Cascade Mountains.
properties.name: Crater Lake
properties.description: Crater Lake inspires awe. Native Americans witnessed its formation 7,700 years ago, when a violent eruption triggered the collapse of a tall peak. Scientists marvel at its purity: fed by rain and snow, it’s the deepest lake in the USA and one of the most pristine on earth. Artists, photographers, and sightseers gaze in wonder at its blue water and stunning setting atop the Cascade Mountain Range.

images.caption: Looking at Crater Lake and Wizard Island from Discovery Point

entranceFees.title: Dinosaur Entrance Fee - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo:
Dinosaur National Monument is located on the Colorado and Utah border with a parts of the monument in both states. Dinosaur fossils are not visible in the Colorado portion of the monument - only on the Utah side.

The Quarry Visitor Center and Exhibit Hall (where you see the dinosaur fossils) are located approximately 7 miles north of Jensen, Utah.

entrancePasses.description:
Valid for 12 months from purchase date.
Admits the pass holder/s and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle(14 passenger capacity or less) to Dinosaur National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Dinosaur Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Dinosaur's climate is semiarid with temperatures averaging between 0°F to 30°F in January and 50°F to 100°F in July. Extreme winter low temperatures may reach -40°F and summer highs can top 110°F.  Elevations within the park vary between 4,700 and 9,000 feet. Winter snow may be heavy at higher elevations while only light to moderate snow is found at lower elevations. Summer thunderstorms may cause heavy downpours and localized flooding, but fail to dampen parched soils less than a mile away.
properties.name: Dinosaur
properties.description: Dinosaurs once roamed here. Their fantastic remains are still visible embedded in the rocks. Today, the mountains, desert and untamed rivers flowing in deep canyons, support an array of life. Petroglyphs hint at earlier cultures. Later, homesteaders and outlaws found refuge here. Whether your passion is science, adventure, history or scenery, Dinosaur offers much to explore.

images.altText: the fossilized skull of camarasaurus dinosaur
images.title: Camarasaurus Skull
images.caption: Over 1500 fossilized bones of various dinosaurs are still embedded in the cliff face including a skull and several neck vertebrae of a camarasaurus

images.altText: the rocky pinnacle of Steamboat Rock rises over the Green River
images.title: Steamboat Rock and the Green River in Echo Park
images.caption: Steamboat Rock rises above the Green River in Echo Park

images.altText: Fremont rock art at McKee Springs
images.title: McKee Springs Petroglyphs
images.caption: The Fremont people left petroglyphs on many of the rock cliffs within Dinosaur National Monument including those at McKee Springs

images.altText: view of a river flowing through a deep canyon
images.title: Mitten Park from Harpers Corner
images.caption: Hikers arriving at the end of the Harpers Corner Trail are rewarded with a view of the Mitten Park Fault, Green River and the Yampa River Canyons

images.altText: the star filled sky above a tent
images.title: Night Sky over Tent
images.caption: Dinosaur's dark skies provides dramatic views of the Milky Way Galaxy

entranceFees.description: The 3 state parks (Fort Ebey, Fort Casey, and Ebey's Landing - all located within the Reserve boundaries) require the Washington State Park Discover Pass.
entranceFees.title: Fort Ebey State Park

entranceFees.description: Ebey's Reserve is open to the public year-round with no admittance fee.
entranceFees.title: General Entrance

entranceFees.description: The 3 state parks (Fort Ebey, Fort Casey, and Ebey's Landing - all located within the Reserve boundaries) require the Washington State Park Discover Pass.
entranceFees.title: Fort Casey State Park

entranceFees.description: The 3 state parks (Fort Ebey, Fort Casey, and Ebey's Landing - all located within the Reserve boundaries) require the Washington State Park Discover Pass.
entranceFees.title: Ebey's Landing State Park

properties.directionsInfo: Ebey's Landing National Historical Reserve is on Whidbey Island in the Puget Sound. The island is easily accessible from the mainland by vehicle via Washington State Route 20 from Burlington and aboard the Washington State Ferries from either Mukilteo or Port Townsend.
properties.weatherInfo: Fall and Winter often bring blustery and rainy weather, and while winter storm watching might be fun from the many beaches within the Reserve, it's important to watch for high waves and logs coming ashore. Always dress appropriately for the weather, which can change suddenly from warm to chilly very quickly.
properties.name: Ebey's Landing
properties.description: This stunning landscape at the gateway to Puget Sound, with its rich farmland and promising seaport, lured the earliest American pioneers north of the Columbia River to Ebey’s Landing. Today Ebey’s Landing National Historical Reserve preserves the historical, agricultural and cultural traditions of both Native and Euro-American – while offering spectacular opportunities for recreation.

images.altText: View from the Bluff Overlook
images.title: View from the Bluff Overlook
images.caption: The Bluff Overlook on the Bluff Trail offers spectacular views of the Straight of Juan de Fuca

images.altText: Sunrise over Admiralty Bay
images.title: Sunrise over Admiralty Bay
images.caption: Admiralty Bay in Fort Casey State Park offers spectacular views of Mt Rainier and the Olympic Mountains.

images.altText: Mt Baker and the historic Smith Barn
images.title: Mt Baker and the historic Smith Barn
images.caption: The views from the prairie overlook tell a story of farming and community that stretches back for centuries.

images.altText: Sunrise over the prairie.
images.title: Sunrise Over a Prairie Farm
images.caption: Ebey's Landing National Historical Reserve exists to preserve a working rural farm community.

images.altText: Historic Ferry House
images.title: Historic Ferry House
images.caption: The Ferry House sits in the heart of the Reserve, a testament to the community that calls this place home.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter El Malpais National Monument.
entranceFees.title: El Malpais National Monument Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Take exit 85 of I-40 in Grants, New Mexico. After you exit, head south on Santa Fe Ave, and continue straight over the freeway overpass. Take a left at the entrance sign for El Malpais Visitor Center. Continue 300 yards until you reach the parking lot.
properties.weatherInfo: As a general rule, daily temperatures swing roughly 30 degrees (F) from night lows to afternoon highs. Summer is sunny and hot with monsoon rain storms with average high of 80 (F), while Winter is cool, sunny, with potential snow storms and an average high of 45 (F). Spring and Fall are generally dry, with the occasional storm rain and/or snow storm.
properties.name: El Malpais
properties.description: The richly diverse volcanic landscape of El Malpais offers solitude, recreation, and discovery. Explore cinder cones, lava tube caves, sandstone bluffs, and hiking trails. Wildlife abounds in the open grasslands and forests. While some may see a desolate environment, people have been adapting to and living in this extraordinary terrain for generations. Come discover the land of fire and ice!

images.altText: Summer at Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.title: Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.caption: A vast expanse of lava fields as seen from Sandstone Bluffs Overlook

images.altText: Snow on the El Calderon Trail
images.title: Snowy Landscape
images.caption: Winter exploration allows one to discover the quiet beauty of El Malpais

images.altText: Summer view from El Calderon cinder cone
images.title: View from El Calderon
images.caption: A hike to the top of El Calderon cinder cone offers one a view of the entire monument.

images.altText: Hiking in Summer
images.title: Wildflowers on the El Calderon Trail
images.caption: Enjoy a stroll along the El Calderon Trail to view beautiful wildflowers in summer.

images.altText: Lava Tube caving at El Malpais
images.title: Lava Tube Cave
images.caption: Explore lava tube caving at El Malpais National Monument

The entrance fee is good for 7 consecutive days starting from the day of purchase. Individuals 16 years old and younger, are admitted free of charge.

properties.directionsInfo:
Directions to Ernest Coe Visitor Center
40001 State Road 9336, Homestead, FL 33034

Visitors coming from the Miami area and points north should take the Florida Turnpike (Route 821) south until it ends merging with U.S. 1 at Florida City. Turn right at the first traffic light onto Palm Drive (State Road 9336/SW 344th St.) and follow the signs to the park.

Visitors driving north from the Florida Keys should turn left on Palm Drive in Florida City and follow the signs to the park.

entrancePasses.description: The Annual Pass for the Everglades National Park is valid for 12 months starting from the day of purchase and is good for unlimited visits to the park during this period. These passes can be purchased at the Homestead and Shark Valley entrance stations or the Gulf Coast and Flamingo Visitor Centers. You can also purchase the senior park pass or pass for entry into all national parks at these locations.
entrancePasses.title: Everglades National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The climate in Florida is known to be mild and sunny.The average annual temperatures for South Florida and the Keys range from 74° to 77°F (23° to 25°C). There are two seasons at the Everglades National Park: the wet season and the dry season. The wet season runs from Mid-May to November and the dry season runs from December to mid-May.
properties.name: Everglades
properties.description:
Everglades National Park protects an unparalleled landscape that provides important habitat for numerous rare and endangered species like the manatee,  American crocodile, and the elusive Florida panther.

An international treasure as well -  a World Heritage Site, International Biosphere Reserve, a Wetland of International Importance, and a specially protected area under the Cartagena Treaty.

images.altText: Two canoes at Nine Mile Pond during sunset.
images.title: Nine Mile Pond
images.caption: A meeting ground of marsh and mangrove environments. You may see alligators, wading birds, turtles, and fish.

images.altText: An American Alligator high walks the Anhinga Trail.
images.title: American Alligator
images.caption: An American Alligator high walks the Anhinga Trail.

images.altText: Two visitors bike along the road in Shark Valley.
images.title: Shark Valley Tram and Bicycle Road
images.caption: Biking is a great way to experience the quiet beauty of the Everglades.

images.altText: An aerial view of the landscape transition from Sawgrass to Florida Bay.
images.title: Transition from Sawgrass to Florida Bay
images.caption: An aerial view of the landscape transition from Sawgrass to Florida Bay.

images.altText: Three tents are put up along the Long Pine Key campsite.
images.title: Camping at Long Pine Key
images.caption: Long Pine Key Campground is open seasonally from November through May. It is located seven miles (11 km) from the main entrance, just off the main road.
