entranceFees.description: Admits one individual when entering on foot or bicycle. Individuals 15 years of age and younger are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: 1-7 Day Individual Entrance

entranceFees.description: Admits one single private vessel. If a Senior Pass is presented at time of purchase, the boat entrance fee is $15.00 and good for 1-7 Days.
entranceFees.title: 1-7 Day Boating Entrance

entranceFees.description: Admits one single private vessel on the same trailer as a vessel paying full entry fees
entranceFees.title: 1-7 Day Boating Entrance additional vessel

properties.directionsInfo: There are multiple districts in Glen Canyon very far away from each other. Make sure you know which district you are going to before you begin travelling here.

entrancePasses.description: Allows unlimited entry to Glen Canyon for 12 months from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Allows unlimited entry to Glen Canyon for one vessel for one calendar year. If a Senior Pass is presented at time of purchase, the annual vessel sticker fee is $25.
entrancePasses.title: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area Annual Vessel Sticker

properties.weatherInfo: The weather in Glen Canyon National Recreation Area is usually typical for the high deserts. Summers are extremely hot with little, if any, shade. Winters are moderately cold with night time lows often below freezing. Spring weather is highly variable and unpredictable with extended periods of winds. Fall weather is usually nice and mild, a great time to beat the heat (and the crowds!).
properties.name: Glen Canyon
properties.description: Encompassing over 1.25 million acres, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area offers unparalleled opportunities for water-based & backcountry recreation. The recreation area stretches for hundreds of miles from Lees Ferry in Arizona to the Orange Cliffs of southern Utah, encompassing scenic vistas, geologic wonders, and a vast panorama of human history.

images.altText: Woman raises her arms while standing in front of a sandstone butte
images.title: Enjoy Lake Powell
images.caption: Spending time on Lake Powell near Tower Butte can make anyone excited.

images.altText: Green river winds through high cliffs.
images.title: Horseshoe Bend
images.caption: The Colorado River makes a 270 degree turn at Horseshoe Bend. Watch your step at the 1000 foot drop!

images.altText: A concrete dam plugs high canyon walls. Buildings and wires on the sides.
images.title: Glen Canyon Dam
images.caption: Glen Canyon Dam is the country's second largest gravity arch dam. Take a tour from the Carl Hayden Visitor Center.

images.altText: Three kayaks on the lake.
images.title: So Many Ways to Find Your Park
images.caption: If motorized recreation isn't your thing, take a kayak and paddle through the high side canyons of Lake Powell.

images.altText: Log cabin and fences with a wooden wagon.
images.title: Lonely Dell Ranch at Lees Ferry Historic District
images.caption: Glen Canyon isn't just houseboats and wakeboards. Come down to Lees Ferry Historic District to relive pioneer times when crossing the river was a major undertaking.

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit.
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Vehicle Permit

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial motorcycle and its passenger(s).
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Motorcycle Permit

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual when entering by foot, bicycle, park shuttle bus, Grand Canyon Railway and private rafting trip. Individuals 15 years old and younger are admitted free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Individual Permit

properties.directionsInfo:
South Rim: Open all year, is located 60 miles north of Williams, Arizona (via route 64 from Interstate 40) and 80 miles northwest of Flagstaff (via route 180). Grand Canyon lies entirely within the state of Arizona.

North Rim: Now closed for the winter - opens May 15, 2020, for the season. North Rim is located 30 miles south of Jacob Lake on Highway 67; the actual rim of the canyon is an additional 14 miles south. Jacob Lake, AZ is located in northern Arizona on Highway 89A, not far from the Utah border.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for twelve months from the date of purchase, for unlimited visits to Grand Canyon National Park. It admits the purchaser and any accompanying persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the purchaser and accompanying immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (train, shuttle, bicycle, and foot).
entrancePasses.title: Grand Canyon National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: This weather varies with cold winters and mild pleasant summers, moderate humidity, and considerable diurnal temperature changes at the higher elevations, with hot and drier summers at the bottom of the Grand Canyon along with cool damp winters. Summer thunderstorms and winter snowfall adds to the weather variety in this region.
properties.name: Grand Canyon
properties.description:
Unique combinations of geologic color and erosional forms decorate a canyon that is 277 river miles (446km) long, up to 18 miles (29km) wide, and a mile (1.6km) deep. Grand Canyon overwhelms our senses through its immense size.

The park is CLOSED due to public health concerns (COVID-19) All visitor facilities, trails, and roads, including Highway 64 are closed until further notice.

images.altText: The canyon glows orange as people visit Mather Point, a rock outcropping that juts into Grand Canyon
images.title: Grand Canyon Mather Point Sunset on the South Rim
images.caption: People come from all over the world to view Grand Canyon's sunset

images.altText: The Cape Royal viewpoint curves into the distance and closer rock formations jut into the canyon.
images.title: Grand Canyon National Park: View from Cape Royal on the North Rim
images.caption: A popular outdoor site for weddings and receptions, Cape Royal Amphitheater is located 23 miles (37 km) from the North Rim developed area.

images.altText: The Desert View Watchtower looms 70 feet into the air over a vast and dramatic view of the canyon.
images.title: Grand Canyon National Park: Desert View Watchtower (South Rim)
images.caption: The Watchtower is located at Desert View, the eastern-most developed area on the South Rim of Grand Canyon National Park.

images.altText: Tall canyon walls frame the wide Colorado river weaving back and forth.
images.title: Looking down the Colorado River from Nankoweap at river mile 53
images.caption: A view down the Colorado river from Nankoweap in Marble canyon.

entranceFees.description: Great Smoky Mountains National Park does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Great Smoky Mountains National Park straddles the borders of the states of Tennessee and North Carolina. The three main entrances to the park are in the Gatlinburg, TN; Townsend, TN; and Cherokee, NC.
properties.weatherInfo: Elevations in the park range from approximately 875 feet to 6,643 feet and the topography can drastically affect local weather. Temperatures can vary 10-20 degrees Fahrenheit from mountain base to top, and clear skies lower down do not guarantee equally pleasant weather at higher elevations. Visit http://www.nps.gov/grsm/planyourvisit/weather.htm for seasonal weather information and links to local forecasts.
properties.name: Great Smoky Mountains
properties.description: Ridge upon ridge of forest straddles the border between North Carolina and Tennessee in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. World renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and the quality of its remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture, this is America's most visited national park.

images.altText: A thick layer of frost covers the fields, trees, and mountains in Cades Cove.
images.title: Frosty Morning in Cades Cove
images.caption: Wintertime brings a quiet beauty to the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.altText: Wisps of fog hang over the forests in the mountains.
images.title: "Smoke" Rising From the Mountains
images.caption: The park gets its name from mists that often rise like smoke from the mountains.

images.altText: Tombstones stand in front of a white, wooden church on a foggy morning.
images.title: A Foggy Morning at Cades Cove Methodist Church
images.caption: Historic buildings such as churches, gristmills, barns, and homes allow visitors to get a feel for life in the mountains before the national park was created.

images.altText: Rhododendron bushes line the banks of a stream filled with large boulders.
images.title: The Waters of Roaring Fork Below Grotto Falls
images.caption: Abundant rainfall means lush forests and beautiful stream scenes in the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.altText: A hillside in the forest covered with white trillium flowers
images.title: The "Wildflower National Park"
images.caption: Wildflowers, such as these white trillium, can be found blooming from February through November in the park.

images.altText: Bright gold and red leaves shine through the fog in a forest.
images.title: Fall Colors Near Newfound Gap
images.caption: Fall leaf season is one of the busiest times of year in the park.

images.altText: Gold and red fall colors fill the valleys while snow coats the mountain tops.
images.title: Fall Meets Winter
images.caption: In spring and fall, weather in the foothills can be pleasant, while snow and cold rule on the mountain tops.

properties.Name: Illinois & Michigan Canal National Heritage Corridor

entranceFees.description:
The daily entrance fee is  $7 per person. It is charged to enter or remain within the park per calendar day (it includes the day you arrive and the day you depart the park). Pay this fee after your transportation reservations have been confirmed. 

All Federal Recreation Passes (Annual, Senior, Access, Military) are honored. Entrance fees will be waived for the pass holder and up to 3 adults traveling with the pass holder.

Children ages 15 and under are exempt from paying entrance fees.
entranceFees.title: Isle Royale Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Isle Royale National Park headquarters is located in Houghton, MI.  Visit the Houghton page on the Isle Royale National Park website for additional information and a map on how to access the visitor center.

entrancePasses.description: Valid from April 16 - October 31 of the year indicated. Covers the entrance fee ($7 per person per day) for the person whose signature appears on the pass and up to 3 adults (aged 16 and up) traveling with the pass holder. Non-refundable and non-transferable. Can be obtained in-person from the Houghton, Rock Harbor, or Windigo Visitor Centers or online at www.pay.gov, search Isle Royale Season Pass and click on "Continue to Form."
entrancePasses.title: Isle Royale Season Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Isle Royale National Park is a remote island wilderness in the middle of Lake Superior.  Weather influences traveling to and from the island, as well as your trip once you arrive.  For the most up-to-date weather information, call (906) 482-0984 or email isro_parkinfo@nps.gov prior to your trip.
properties.name: Isle Royale
properties.description: Explore a rugged, isolated island, far from the sights and sounds of civilization. Surrounded by Lake Superior, Isle Royale offers unparalleled solitude and adventures for backpackers, hikers, boaters, kayakers, canoeists and scuba divers. Here, amid stunning scenic beauty, you'll find opportunities for reflection and discovery, and make memories that last a lifetime.

images.altText: Aerial View of Belle Harbor
images.title: Aerial View of Belle Harbor
images.caption: One of the best ways to view Isle Royale's land and water is from the air.

images.altText: Young bull moose browsing for food
images.title: Bull Moose
images.caption: Moose are one of the few mammal species who have journeyed to the island.

images.altText: Aerial view of Rock of Ages Lighthouse
images.title: Rock of Ages Lighthouse
images.caption: Rock of Ages is one of four lighthouses at Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: Ice floes float in a harbor
images.title: Winter Ice Floes
images.caption: Isle Royale National Park is closed in winter, with the exception of a few visiting researchers.

images.altText: Diverse colored Aurora Borealis in the night sky
images.title: Aurora Borealis Over Isle Royale National Park
images.caption: Isle Royale National Park's dark skies make it an excellent location to enjoy nighttime phenomenon, like the Aurora Borealis.

entranceFees.description: A week long boat long pass is valid for seven, consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Boat Launch Week Permit

entranceFees.description: The annual boat launch permit is good from the time of purchase through the calendar year.
entranceFees.title: Boat Launch Annual Pass

entranceFees.description: The In-Season Camping Fee is current from May 1st - September 30th.
entranceFees.title: In-Season Camping Fee

entranceFees.description: The Off-Season Camping Fee is from October 1st - April 30th.
entranceFees.title: Off-Season Camping Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From Spokane

Take I-90 West
At Exit 277, merge onto US-2 toward Davenport/Fairchild AFB/Spokane Airport
Just past Wilbur, turn right onto WA-21
Stay left onto Highway 174
Turn right onto WA-155
Stay on WA-155 past Grand Coulee Dam and into the town of Coulee Dam
Cross the Columbia River and continue on WA-155
Turn right onto Crest Drive and follow up the hill.
The Headquarters Office is located on the left

entrancePasses.description: This pass allows unlimited boat launches from all National Park Service boat launches at Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area. Good for the calendar year. This pass is not eligible for the 50% discount available with America the Beautiful Senior and Access passes.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Boat Launch Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Lake Roosevelt is generally a cool or cold place from fall through spring with overcast skies. In the summer, the skies clear and present warm to hot days.
properties.name: Lake Roosevelt
properties.description: In 1941 the Grand Coulee Dam was built on the Columbia River as part of the Columbia River Basin project, creating a 130-mile long lake. Named for President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area provides opportunities for boating, fishing, swimming, camping, canoeing, hunting and visiting historic Fort Spokane and St. Paul's Mission.

images.altText: Looking down Lake Roosevelt with clear skies and treed shorelines.
images.title: Lake Roosevelt 1
images.caption: Looking down Lake Roosevelt with clear skies and treed shorelines.

images.altText: People canoeing down Lake Roosevelt on a day with blue skies.
images.title: Lake Roosevelt 2
images.caption: Visitors enjoying canoeing around the Hawk Creek area.

images.altText: A glow is coming over the horizon and bringing first light to Lake Roosevelt and Crescent Bay Lake.
images.title: Lake Roosevelt 3
images.caption: The glow of first light is hitting Lake Roosevelt and Crescent Bay Lake.

images.altText: Snow falls over a small peninsula with its clear reflection over the waters.
images.title: Lake Roosevelt 4
images.caption: Snow falls over a small peninsula with its clear reflection over the waters.

images.altText: A draw down of the reservoir reveals extended beaches.
images.title: Lake Roosevelt 5
images.caption: A draw down of the reservoir reveals extended beaches.

phoneNumbers.description: This is the general phone line at the Mississippi River Visitor Center. Please leave a voicemail if we miss your call and expect a return call within 1 day, often sooner.

emailAddresses.description: This is the e-mail address for all Park-related questions. This account is checked daily with responses sent out within two days.

entranceFees.description: We do not charge any fees for entrance, parking, or Ranger programs. However, some of our partner sites do and those specific sites should be contacted for more information about their fees. See http://www.nps.gov/miss/planyourvisit/placestogo.htm for contact information.
entranceFees.title: Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Limited metered street parking is available on nearby streets near our headquarters. Several parking ramps are available nearby including the Kellogg Square parking ramp.

Visitor Centers are located in the lobby of the Science Museum of Minnesota (120 Kellogg Blvd East, St. Paul, MN) and at the Upper St. Anthony Lock and Dam (1 Portland Ave, Minneapolis, MN).
properties.weatherInfo: Minnesota has a continental climate characterized by cold winters and warm summers. Spring brings moderate temperatures and low humidity. Summer days may reach temperatures of more than 100°F (38°C), but are usually pleasant with temperatures in the low to mid-80°F (25-30°C). Autumn brings dry, warm days, cool nights and gorgeous fall colors. Winter daytime highs are around 25°F (-3°C). Rarely, winter daytime high temperatures may not get above -10°F (-23°C), sometimes with strong winds.
properties.name: Mississippi
properties.description: In the middle of a bustling urban setting, this 72 mile river park offers quiet stretches for fishing, boating and canoeing, birdwatching, bicycling, and hiking. And there are plenty of visitor centers and trails that highlight the fascinating human history of the Mississippi River. This a great place to start your exploration of this important river.

images.altText: A park ranger guides a boat past historical buildings.
images.title: Boating on the Mississippi River
images.caption: Our park rangers often use boats, bikes, and hikes to help visitors understand the historical and cultural significance of our park.

images.altText: Large canoes and crews paddle down the river amidst autumnal color.
images.title: Voyageur Canoes
images.caption: The park often uses big, safe Voyageur canoes in our programs.

images.altText: A large canoe filled with paddlers on the river surrounded by autumnal color.
images.title: Modern day Voyageurs Paddle the Mississippi River
images.caption: A Voyageur canoe makes headway up a river while surrounded by autumnal color.

images.altText: A large, long-necked, long-legged bird wades in the river.
images.title: Great Egret Fishes the Mississippi River
images.caption: Wildlife is a common sight along the river.

images.altText: Large trees are widely spaced in a grassland.
images.title: Savanna at Coldwater Spring
images.caption: Visitors can glimpse the past in the Coldwater Spring savanna restoration.

images.altText: Gray clouds over flowers growing on sand dunes.
images.title: Storms over Grey Cloud Dunes
images.caption: Storm clouds begin gathering over Grey Cloud Dunes Scientific and Natural Area

images.altText: A canoeist reaches out and holds a large, yellow flower.
images.title: Canoeing through Lotus Blossoms
images.caption: Lotus beds bloom in the backwaters of the Mississippi National River and Recreation Area and provide canoeists an unexpected visual treat.

images.altText: Water tumbles down layers of rock with an old stone spring house in the background.
images.title: Water Source for a Fort
images.caption: The Spring House at Coldwater Spring provided water to Historic Fort Snelling and the Upper Post.

images.altText: A canoeist paddles through a water channel between islands.
images.title: Canoeing the Vermillion River Backwaters
images.caption: The Vermillion River Bottoms are a tangle of waterways where the river meets the Mississippi River.

images.altText: Gulls stand on a floating log while a canoe passes in the background.
images.title: Canoeing Past Gulls
images.caption: Canoeists find a wide variety of wildlife in the backwaters of the Mississippi River.

images.altText: A large, long-necked, long-legged bird flies overhead carrying a branch.
images.title: Building a Nest
images.caption: Blue herons are a common sight on the Mississippi River and its backwaters.

images.altText: White clouds streak the blue sky over a river flanked by sandy shorelines and green trees.
images.title: Clouds Over the Mississippi River
images.caption: The upper stretch of the Mississippi River in the Mississippi National River and Recreation Area is often referred to as the "Prairie River" due to its gentle banks. Further downstream is the Mississippi River gorge and below that is the floodplain river

properties.fullName: Mississippi National River and Recreation Area

entranceFees.description: Grants unlimited entry for one vehicle and passengers for seven consecutive days. Vehicle must be private, noncommercial, and with a seating capacity of 15 or less.
entranceFees.title: Mount Rainier Single Vehicle Fee

entranceFees.description: Walk-up or single bicycle fee. Grants unlimited entry for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Mount Rainier "Per Person" Fee

entranceFees.description: Grants unlimited entry for one motorcycle and passenger for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Mount Rainier Motorcycle Fee

entranceFees.description: Fee per site, nightly, for camping in Cougar Rock, Ohanapecosh, and White River campgrounds. Learn more about camping at Mount Rainier at https://www.nps.gov/mora/planyourvisit/campgrounds.htm
entranceFees.title: Mount Rainier Campground Fee

entranceFees.description: Fee for group sites, nightly, in Cougar Rock and Ohanapecosh campgrounds. Group sites accommodate 25 to 40 people depending on site. There are no group sites in White River Campground. For more information about camping at Mount Rainier: https://www.nps.gov/mora/planyourvisit/campgrounds.htm
entranceFees.title: Mount Rainier Campground Fee - Groups

properties.directionsInfo: Mount Rainier National Park is located in west-central Washington state. Several major cities in Washington- Seattle, Tacoma, and Yakima- and Portland, Oregon, are within 200 miles of the park. For GPS to Nisqually Entrance use: 39000 State Route 706 E, Ashford, WA 98304.

entrancePasses.description: Grants unlimited entry for one year to pass owner and passengers in the same car.
entrancePasses.title: Mount Rainier Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Weather patterns at Mount Rainier are strongly influenced by the Pacific Ocean and elevation. The climate is generally cool and rainy, with summer highs in the 60s and 70s. While July and August are the sunniest months of the year, rain is very likely in spring, fall, and winter. Visitors should be aware that mountain weather is very changeable. In the higher elevations, like Paradise, winter can last from November to May with many feet of snow on the ground.
properties.name: Mount Rainier
properties.description: Ascending to 14,410 feet above sea level, Mount Rainier stands as an icon in the Washington landscape. An active volcano, Mount Rainier is the most glaciated peak in the contiguous U.S.A., spawning five major rivers. Subalpine wildflower meadows ring the icy volcano while ancient forest cloaks Mount Rainier’s lower slopes. Wildlife abounds in the park’s ecosystems. A lifetime of discovery awaits.

images.altText: Sunset paints the glaciers of Mount Rainier in pink and gold.
images.title: Mount Rainier at sunset
images.caption: Every scenic overlook shows a different side of Mount Rainier. Viewed from Gobblers Knob Lookout at sunset, the glaciers covering the mountain turn pink and gold.

images.altText: Purple lupine and white bistort bloom in a meadow alongside a sign for the Wonderland Trail.
images.title: Wildflower Meadow Along the Wonderland Trail
images.caption: Both the Wonderland Trail and subalpine meadows encircle Mount Rainier. Summertime blooms splatter the hillsides with color.

images.altText: Towering cedars and douglas-firs reach skyward while a beam of sun breaks through the canopy.
images.title: Giants of the Old-Growth Forest
images.caption: With some of the few remaining old-growth forests in the Cascade Mountains, Mount Rainier National Park protects native plants great and small in places like the Grove of the Patriarchs.

images.altText: A hoary marmot with white frosted fur rests on a rock beside white flowers in a meadow.
images.title: Marmot in Morning Dew
images.caption: From small amphibians and hoary marmots to the black bears and elk, many animals call the wild places of Mount Rainier home.

images.altText: The historic National Park Inn covered in a foot of snow.
images.title: National Park Inn in Winter
images.caption: For thousands of years, people have traveled up to, over, and around Mount Rainier. Today the park strives to preserve this history while providing a chance for new generations to find their own adventures.

images.altText: Two children hike on trail through wildflower meadow with Mount Rainier above them.
images.title: Kids Hiking Through Wildflower Meadow
images.caption: Enjoying the outdoors through recreation is a big part of many visitors' experiences.

images.altText: Climber on glacier steps downward with icy crags in background.
images.title: Climbing Mount Rainier
images.caption: Summiting Mount Rainier involves climbing a volcano, scaling glaciers, dealing with high elevations and much more. Almost 10,000 people a year attempt to summit.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter the Natchez Trace Parkway. Visitors can enter the Parkway, free of charge, from dozens of county, state, and U.S. roads in Mississippi, Alabama, and Tennessee. Please refer to the Parkway Map for places to access the Parkway. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: No entrance fee

properties.directionsInfo: Directions to the Natchez Trace Parkway vary greatly depending on what part of the tri-state Parkway you are trying to reach. There are more than 50 roads that access the Parkway in Tennessee, Alabama, and Mississippi. For specific questions concerning how to get to a certain portion of the Parkway, please call the Visitor Center at 1-800-305-7417.
properties.weatherInfo: Mississippi, Alabama, and most of Tennessee are classified as humid subtropical climates. The weather ranges from mild winters to hot summers. Average high temperatures reach into the high 80's in summer, and into the high 40's in winter. Thunderstorms are common in Mississippi, especially in the southern part of the state, and from June through November, the state is occasionally affected by hurricanes moving north from the Gulf of Mexico. Check local forecasts to plan your trip.
properties.name: Natchez Trace
properties.description: The Natchez Trace Parkway is a 444-mile recreational road and scenic drive through three states. It roughly follows the "Old Natchez Trace" a historic travel corridor used by American Indians, "Kaintucks," European settlers, slave traders, soldiers, and future presidents. Today, people can enjoy not only a scenic drive but also hiking, biking, horseback riding, and camping along the parkway.

images.altText: Meriwether Lewis Monument on a summer day
images.title: Meriwether Lewis Monument (milepost 385.9) on the Natchez Trace Parkway
images.caption: Built in 1848, this monument commemorates the life of Meriwether Lewis of the Lewis & Clark Corps of Discovery. Lewis died near the monument while traveling the Natchez Trace in 1809. Though questions exist, most historians believe Lewis died of suicide.

images.altText: View of the Double Arch Bridge from Birdsong Hollow
images.title: Double Arch Bridge over Birdsong Hollow (milepost 438) on the Natchez Trace Parkway
images.caption: The elegant Double Arch Bridge won the Presidential Award for Design Excellence in 1995. It spans Birdsong Hollow and Tennessee Highway 96. To see it from below, take the TN 96 exit and stop at the pulloff before you get to the highway.

images.altText: Mount Locust Historic House
images.title: Mount Locust Historic House (milepost 15.5) on the Natchez Trace Parkway
images.caption: Mount Locust served as a family home and as a stand, or inn, for Natchez Trace travelers. Built around 1780, the home and grounds are open for visitors during operating hours.

images.altText: A foggy section of the Old Trace in autumn
images.title: Old Trace (milepost 221.4) on the Natchez Trace Parkway
images.caption: The "Old Trace," the historic trail commemorated by the Natchez Trace Parkway today, still survives in segments. The Old Trace was the main road through the Old Southwest, connecting Natchez to Nashville by going through Chickasaw and Choctaw lands.

images.altText: A slightly curvy section of the Natchez Trace Parkway in Early Fall
images.title: Natchez Trace Parkway in Early Fall
images.caption: The Natchez Trace Parkway commemorates a historic travel route that helped build the young United States. The Parkway 444 miles, with plenty of stops to allow you to explore some of the history or enjoy the scenery along the way.

entranceFees.description: North Cascades National Park Complex does not charge entrance fees.
entranceFees.title: North Cascades National Park Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Access to North Cascades National Park and Ross Lake National Recreation Area is from the State Route 20 corridor. SR 20 (North Cascades Highway) connects with Interstate 5 (Exit 230) at Burlington. From the east, the highway intersects with US 97 at Okanogan and with SR 153 at Twisp. The State Department of Transportation closes a portion of the road between Ross Dam Trailhead and Lone Fir Campground in winter. The Lake Chelan National Recreation Area (Stehekin) is accessible by ferry or plane from Chelan.

entrancePasses.description: North Cascades National Park Complex does not sell entrance passes because no entry fee is required to enjoy the park.
entrancePasses.title: North Cascades National Park Complex Entrance Passes

properties.weatherInfo: The best weather for visiting the North Cascades generally occurs between mid-June and late-September. Summer daytime temperatures average in the 70's F. Snow is off most trails by mid-July. Autumn and Spring are popular for color and wildlife. Storms are common: always be prepared for a few days of rain and wind. The east side of the Cascade Mountains (Lake Chelan National Recreation Area) is drier and warmer in the summer than the west side. Summer temperatures at Stehekin reach the 90's F.
properties.name: North Cascades
properties.description: Less than three hours from Seattle, an alpine landscape beckons. Discover communities of life adapted to moisture in the west and recurring fire in the east. Explore jagged peaks crowned by more than 300 glaciers. Listen to cascading waters in forested valleys. Witness a landscape sensitive to the Earth's changing climate. Help steward the ecological heart of the Cascades.

images.altText: boats on the water with mountains and trees surrounding
images.title: Stehekin - Looking down Lake Chelan
images.caption: Stehekin sits at the top of Lake Chelan, welcoming visitors to take a life at a slower pace.

images.altText: Tents set up in a wooded area.
images.title: Camping on Ross Lake
images.caption: Grab your tent, your sleeping bag, and adventurous soul and camp along Ross Lake.

images.altText: Trees surround the frame with glacier and mountains in the background
images.title: Pelton Basin from Cascade Pass
images.caption: Let the wow factor exceed your expectations while hiking Cascade Pass.

images.altText: Person with backpacking and climbing gear hikes on a trail.
images.title: Backpack the North Cascades
images.caption: Explore the trails and backcountry camping and climbing in a landscape over 9,000 feet of vertical relief.

images.altText: Jagged mountain peaks give way to glaciers.
images.title: Jagged Mountain Peaks
images.caption: Explore jagged peaks crowned by more than 300 glaciers as you traverse the landscape.

entranceFees.description: Valid for seven consecutive days. Applies to private, non-commercial vehicles (15 passenger capacity or less). The pass covers all vehicle occupants.
entranceFees.title: Olympic Entrance Fee - Vehicle (Non-Commercial)

entranceFees.description: Valid for seven consecutive days. Fee admits one individual on a private, non-commercial motorcycle.
entranceFees.title: Olympic Entrance Fee - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Valid for seven consecutive days. This fee admits one person without a vehicle, including hikers, bicyclists, and pedestrians. Individuals fifteen years or younger are admitted free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Olympic Entrance Fee - Per Person and Bicyclists

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced or sold for leisure recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provisions of the service.
entranceFees.title: Olympic Entrance Fee - Commercial Van (7-15 seats)

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced or sold for leisure recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provisions of the service.
entranceFees.title: Olympic Entrance Fee - Commercial Minibus (16-25 seats)

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced or sold for leisure recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provisions of the service.
entranceFees.title: Olympic Entrance Fee - Commercial Motor-coach (26 seats or more)

entranceFees.description: Applies to organized groups such as Scouts, Rotary, Youth Groups, Churches, Clubs and Reunions etc. Youth 15 and under are admitted free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Olympic Entrance Fee - Non-Commercial Organized Group Vehicles 15 seats or less

properties.directionsInfo:
You can reach Olympic National Park via the I-5 corridor or by any one of the quieter state roadways. Once you arrive on the Olympic Peninsula connect to Hwy 101 to reach any destinations in and around Olympic National Park.
From Olympia: take I-5 to Hwy 101
From Tacoma: take State Route 16 to Bremerton; take State Route 3 north from Bremerton to State Route 104.
From Washington/Oregon Coast connect to Hwy 101 in Aberdeen.

entrancePasses.description: The Olympic National Park Annual Pass costs $55 and is good for entry into the park for one year from the month of purchase. Passes can be purchased at Olympic National Park visitor centers and entrance stations.
entrancePasses.title: Olympic National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Summers tend to be fair and warm, with high temperatures between 65 and 75 degrees F. July, August and September are the driest months, with heavier precipitation during the rest of the year. While winters are mild at lower elevation, snowfall can be heavy in the mountains. It is common for different weather conditions to exist within the park at the same time.  At any time of year, visitors should come prepared for a variety of conditions.
properties.name: Olympic
properties.description: With its incredible range of precipitation and elevation, diversity is the hallmark of Olympic National Park. Encompassing nearly a million acres, the park protects a vast wilderness, thousands of years of human history, and several distinctly different ecosystems, including glacier-capped mountains, old-growth temperate rain forests, and over 70 miles of wild coastline. Come explore!

images.altText: Large trees and ferns
images.title: Olympic Forest
images.caption: Large trees and ferns inhabit the temperate forests of Olympic.

images.altText: Hikers sit and watch the sun set behind snow-capped mountains.
images.title: Mountain Sunset
images.caption: Backpackers stop to enjoy a spectacular sunset in Olympic's high country.

images.altText: A herd of elk crossing a river.
images.title: Roosevelt Elk
images.caption: A herd of Roosevelt Elk cross a river in Olympic.

images.altText: Fresh snow atop the Olympic Mountains.
images.title: Hurricane Ridge
images.caption: A fresh layer of snow covers Hurricane Ridge in the Olympic Mountains.

images.altText: Orange sea stars on a rocky coast.
images.title: Tide Pools of the Olympic Coast
images.caption: Ocher sea stars rest on the rocks during a low tide on one of Olympic's beaches.

phoneNumbers.description:
Through winter, the Information Office is open 8:00 am–4:30 pm Mon–Fri.
Recorded Trail Ridge Road status: (970) 586-1222.

entranceFees.description: Valid for date of purchase. Covers single, non-commercial vehicle with capacity of less than 16 passengers. Purchase online.
entranceFees.title: 1-Day Pass - Automobile

entranceFees.title: 7-Day Pass - Per Person

entranceFees.title: 7-Day Pass - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Valid for date of purchase. Covers one motorcycle.
entranceFees.title: 1-Day Pass - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Valid for date of purchase. Applies to walk-ins, bicycles, and non-commercial groups.
entranceFees.title: 1-Day Pass - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo: Driving from the east: from I-25, take US Hwy 34 or 36. Driving from the west: from I-70, take US Hwy 40 to Granby to US Hwy 34 to Grand Lake. From mid-October until late May, Trail Ridge Road between Estes Park and Grand Lake is closed to vehicles, so driving between the two takes ~4 hours. The closest airport is Denver International (DIA). There is no public transportation between nearby cities and the park.

entrancePasses.description: Unlimited entry for one year from date of purchase. Purchase online.
entrancePasses.title: Rocky Mountain National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Winter (Dec–Mar): cold weather, deep snow at higher elevations, and seasonal closures of facilities and roads. Spring (April–May): unpredictable weather, with a mix of warm sunny days and cool days with heavy snow and rain. Many trails are still snow-covered. Trail Ridge Road opens in late May. Summer (Jun–Aug): warmer weather, thunderstorms, and wildflowers. Most park roads and facilities are open. Fall (Sep–Nov): crisp air, blue skies, fall colors, and the elk rut. Trail Ridge Road closes mid-October.
properties.name: Rocky Mountain
properties.description: Rocky Mountain National Park’s 415 square miles encompass and protect spectacular mountain environments. Enjoy Trail Ridge Road – which crests at over 12,000 feet including many overlooks to experience the subalpine and alpine worlds – along with over 300 miles of hiking trails, wildflowers, wildlife, starry nights, and fun times. In a world of superlatives, Rocky is on top!

images.altText: Longs Peak, covered in snow, against dark moody clouds.
images.title: Longs Peak
images.caption: Longs Peak towers above Rocky Mountain National Park.

images.altText: Yellow flowers bloom on tundra slopes with mountains in the background.
images.title: Summer on the Tundra
images.caption: Old Man of the Mountain bloom on Rocky's alpine tundra.

images.altText: Road sweeps across open tundra with mountains in background.
images.title: Trail Ridge Road
images.caption: Trail Ridge Road, the highest continuous paved road in the United States, let's visitors experience Rocky's alpine tundra.

images.altText: A herd of elk stand in a meadow.
images.title: Elk in Moraine Park
images.caption: In the fall, Rocky's elk gather together in groups for the mating season.

images.altText: The moon sets below mountain peaks at sunrise.
images.title: Horseshoe Park
images.caption: While the moon sets, the sun rises at Horseshoe Park, one of Rocky's beautiful meadows.

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle or RV and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit.
entranceFees.title: Saguaro National Park Vehicle Weekly Pass

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual when entering by foot or bicycle. Individuals 15 years or younger are admitted free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Saguaro National Park Individual Weekly Pass

entranceFees.description: Admits one motorcycle and its riders.
entranceFees.title: Saguaro National Park Motorcycle Weekly Pass

properties.directionsInfo: Saguaro National Park has two districts separated by the city of Tucson.  We do not recommend using mobile mapping applications to search for either district.  Instead, please click the link to the directions page, determine which district you plan to visit, and enter that physical address into the mobile application.

entrancePasses.description:
Valid for 12 months from the date of purchase, for unlimited visits to Saguaro National Park, in Tucson, Arizona.   May be purchased at either district or online from www.nps.gov/sagu/payfee.htm.

Admits purchaser and any accompanying persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or pass holder and three persons (16 & older) where per person entrance fees are charged. This passport covers entrance fees only and is not refundable and/or transferable.
entrancePasses.title: Saguaro National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Winter Season
With daytime temperature from the low 50's to the high 70's

Summer Season 
As we get deeper into the summer season, temperatures will range from mid-90's to low 110's. This is a great time to experience the desert as the day breaks or in the late of the day as the sun disappears behind the surrounding mountain ranges. During the late spring and summer months Saguaro National Park only offers interpretive programs on an intermittent basis.
properties.name: Saguaro
properties.description: Tucson, Arizona is home to the nation's largest cacti. The giant saguaro is the universal symbol of the American west. These majestic plants, found only in a small portion of the United States, are protected by Saguaro National Park, to the east and west of the modern city of Tucson. Here you have a chance to see these enormous cacti, silhouetted by the beauty of a magnificent desert sunset.

images.altText: A flowering fishhook pincushion cactus
images.title: Flowering Fishhook Pincushion Cactus
images.caption: Wildflower season at Saguaro National Park is at it's peak in the month of MArch. The Pincushion cactus, however, blooms April through August.

images.altText: Two coyote pups captured on a wilderness camera
images.title: Coyote Pups
images.caption: Saguaro National Park has a vast variety of wildlife, and with the help of wilderness cameras, can be photographed to help with studies and for visitors to learn about animals only seen by chance.

images.altText: Lightning strike captured on camera with saguaros in the background
images.title: Saguaro National Park Lighting Storm
images.caption: Saguaro deaths are usually attributed to natural weather conditions and other natural phenomena. Specifically, lightning strikes have been known to strike saguaros due to the large amount of water stored within their fleshy tissue.

images.altText: Rare Sight of snow in Saguaro National Park East Visitor Center (Rincon Mountain District)
images.title: Weather at Saguaro National Park
images.caption: Saguaro National Park summers can be extremely hot with temperatures exceeding 105 degrees F, lows averaging 72 degrees F.  Winters are mild warm days averaging 65 degrees F and cool nights averaging 40 degrees F. Snowfall is extremely rare in the area.

images.altText: A group of Phrynosoma solare, or regal horned lizards.
images.title: Group of Regal Horned Lizards
images.caption: Regal horned lizards are one of many reptiles in the park, who have adapted to living in the harsh desert environment. Information on how different species survive can be found on the park's website, visitor center, or through our many programs offered.

entranceFees.description: Free entrance to national park visitor centers. Free entrance to national park facilities and lands. There may be charges to enter state, county, and private lands within the boundaries of the Riverway.
entranceFees.title: St. Croix National Scenic Riverway

properties.directionsInfo: The St. Croix National Scenic Riverway stretches for over 200 miles in northwest Wisconsin and east-central Minnesota. The Namekagon River flows entirely in Wisconsin while the St. Croix River serves as a border between the two states for much of its length. With many different access points there are numerous opportunities for day trips as well as multi-day paddling adventures. Visitor centers are located on the Namekagon River in Trego, Wisconsin, and on the St. Croix River in St. Croix Falls, Wisconsin.
properties.weatherInfo: Access to the Riverway is year-round. Early spring temperatures can reach into the 40's resulting in high, fast, and cold water from melting snow and ice. Summers are warm and humid. Severe weather can be experienced anytime from mid-spring through late summer. Fall colors begin in late September with high temperatures averaging in the 60's. Winter can set in early with high temperatures in the teens, lows falling below zero, and occasional heavy snow. The rivers can begin to freeze over by early December.
properties.name: Saint Croix
properties.description: Grab your paddle and your longing for adventure and head to the St. Croix and Namekagon rivers! Together they form the St. Croix National Scenic Riverway, offering over 200 miles of clean water that glides and rushes through a forested landscape. Paddle, boat, fish, and camp among this wild and scenic beauty. Hiking and historic towns also beckon, if you can bear to leave the cool water.

images.altText: A man holds a large fish while sitting in a boat near a forested shore.
images.title: Fishing the St. Croix River
images.caption: The fishing is spectacular on the St. Croix and Namekagon rivers.

images.altText: A woman paddles a kayak past cliffs on a forested river.
images.title: Kayaking on the St. Croix River
images.caption: Paddling is an excellent way to experience the St. Croix National Scenic Riverway.

images.altText: A fast river flows over large rocks in a forested landscape.
images.title: Fast Water on the St. Croix River.
images.caption: There are opportunities to paddle stretches of fast and slow water on the Riverway.

images.altText: A man stands next to a river watching a sunset.
images.title: Evening on the St. Croix River.
images.caption: Watch scenic sunsets from shoreline campsites.

images.altText: Kayakers pass impressive cliffs.
images.title: The St. Croix Dalles
images.caption: The scenic Dalles of the St. Croix River provide dramatic backdrops for paddlers.

entranceFees.description:
This fee covers unlimited entry for one vehicle and passengers for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase.

Vehicles must be private, noncommercial, and with a seating capacity of 15 or less.
entranceFees.title: Shenandoah Entrance Fee - Single Vehicle

entranceFees.description: The fee for walk-up or bicycling visitors, when 16 years of age or older (children under 16 are admitted for free). Includes entering the Park by all means other than a private, non-commercial vehicle. A family traveling together shall pay no more than the vehicle fee.
entranceFees.title: Shenandoah Entrance Fee - Individual Person

entranceFees.description: Covers entry for one motorcycle and one passenger for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Shenandoah Entrance Fee - Single Motorcycle

entranceFees.title: Shenandoah Entrance Fee - Commercial Tour (1-6 Passengers)

entranceFees.description: The entry fees are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry 7 or more passengers, regardless of the actual number of passengers.

entranceFees.title: Shenandoah Entrance Fee - Commercial Tour (16-25 Passengers)

entranceFees.title: Shenandoah Entrance Fee - Commercial Tour (26+ Passengers)

properties.directionsInfo: Shenandoah National Park is located in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia, west of Washington, D.C. It stretches 105 miles and has four entrances: Front Royal (northern entrance), Thornton Gap, Swift Run Gap, and Rockfish Gap (southern entrance to Shenandoah and the northern entrance to the Blue Ridge Parkway). The physical address listed is to the administrative offices, not the park itself. GPS can be unreliable for navigating to the park.

entrancePasses.description: Provides unlimited entry for one year to the pass owner and passengers in the same vehicle. At "per-person" fee areas this pass covers the pass holder and three adults, not to exceed 4 adults total. Children under 16 are admitted free.
entrancePasses.title: Shenandoah Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Shenandoah experiences four distinct seasons. Best known for its fall foliage, the park is also spectacular in spring when the wildflowers and trees are in full bloom. Summer brings lush greens and relief from the hot valleys. The park's elevation encourages as much as a 10 degree temperature difference. In winter, this means that when surrounding lowlands are experiencing rain, the the park can be blanketed in snow and ice. It's always a good idea to be prepared for varying weather.
properties.name: Shenandoah
properties.description: Just 75 miles from the bustle of Washington, D.C., Shenandoah National Park is your escape to recreation and re-creation. Cascading waterfalls, spectacular vistas, quiet wooded hollows—take a hike, meander along Skyline Drive, or picnic with the family. 200,000 acres of protected lands are haven to deer, songbirds, the night sky…and you. Plan a Shenandoah escape today!

images.altText: A man stands on a rocky outcrop overlooking the receding mountains.
images.title: Adventure Awaits
images.caption: There are over 60 peaks with an elevation over 3,000 feet in Shenandoah.

images.altText: A man stands with his back facing us, looking at a waterfall.
images.title: Wonderful Waterfalls
images.caption: Dark Hollow Falls, at 70 feet, is our most visited waterfall.

images.altText: A close up shot of a Red-Bellied Woodpecker with a blurry teal background.
images.title: Red-Bellied Woodpecker
images.caption: There are over 200 species of bird that call Shenandoah "home."

images.altText: A road surrounded by fall foliage turns a curve around a small waterfall.
images.title: Driving on Skyline Drive
images.caption: There are 105 miles to explore on Skyline Drive.

images.altText: Looking up at a poplar stand canopy, which is turning yellow in fall.
images.title: Find Yourself in Nature
images.caption: This poplar stand at mile 8 is a popular stop for visitors entering from the north entrance.

entranceFees.description: We are a free park.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

properties.directionsInfo: The beautiful expanse of the Timucuan Preserve is located within the city limits of Jacksonville, Florida.  The Preserve can be accessed from major roads and highways in and around Jacksonville. Directions to individual park sites such as Kingsley Plantation, American Beach and the Ribault Column can be found on our website.  Our main visitor center is located at Fort Caroline, about 14 miles northeast of downtown.
properties.weatherInfo: We have mild winters and hot summers.  In the winter average highs are in the 60's, lows in the 40's.  The summer temperatures reach up into the 90's.
properties.name: Timucuan
properties.description:
Visit one of the last unspoiled coastal wetlands on the Atlantic Coast. Discover 6,000 years of human history and experience the beauty of salt marshes, coastal dunes, and hardwood hammocks.

The Timucuan Preserve includes Fort Caroline and Kingsley Plantation.

images.altText: slave cabins made of tabby with wooden roofs
images.title: Kingsley Plantation Slave Quarters
images.caption: The tabby cabins at Kingsley Plantation were the homes of many enslaved people.

images.altText: sand dune and blue sky
images.title: Nana dune at American Beach
images.caption: The sand dune at American Beach is a protected part of the Timucuan Preserve.

images.altText: fort gate
images.title: Fort Caroline
images.caption: The fort exhibit at Fort Caroline teaches visitors of the failed French colony in Florida.

images.altText: park bench alongside a trail
images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Area
images.caption: The Theodore Roosevelt Area trails provide a getaway from the urban hustle within the city of Jacksonville.

images.altText: A baby fox pops it's head from a burrow
images.title: Baby Fox
images.caption: The Timucuan Preserve hosts wondrous biodiversity.

entranceFees.description: This is a entrance fee for all persons traveling in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van). The permit is non-transferable. Visitors can enter the park at any time, if the entrance station is not staffed, a self-registration area is available for purchasing a 7-day park permit.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee by car - 7 day permit

entranceFees.description: This is a per person entrance fee for a visitor traveling on foot, bicycle, or for individuals traveling together in a vehicle as a non-commercial, organized group. The permit is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee by single entry

entranceFees.description: This is a per motorcycle entrance fee. The permit is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee by motorcycle

properties.directionsInfo:
Glacier National Park is located in the northwest corner of Montana along the spine of the Rocky Mountains.
By Car you can access Glacier via Highway 2, which runs along the southern boundary of the park. You can reach the east side of the park via Highway 89.

The nearest airports are in Kalispell and Great Falls, Montana

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for one year from the month of entry and admits the purchaser and passengers in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the pass holder and his/her immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (foot, bicycle) into the park. It is nontransferable, nonrefundable, and does not cover camping fees.
entrancePasses.title: Glacier National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Glacier's weather is highly variable and can be extreme. Expect warm sunny summer days and in the winter the temperatures can fall well below freezing. Glacier's geography, straddling the Continental Divide, sets the stage for clashes of two very different climates. Warm, wet Pacific air moves in from the west, and cold dry Arctic air from the northeast. They meet at the Divide.
properties.name: Glacier
properties.description: Come and experience Glacier's pristine forests, alpine meadows, rugged mountains, and spectacular lakes. With over 700 miles of trails, Glacier is a hiker's paradise for adventurous visitors seeking wilderness and solitude. Relive the days of old through historic chalets, lodges, and the famous Going-to-the-Sun Road. Explore Glacier National Park and discover what awaits you.

images.altText: View of Logan Pass and the Continental Divide from the summit of Mt. Oberlin
images.title: Logan Pass from Mt. Oberlin
images.caption: View of Logan Pass and the Continental Divide from the summit of Mt. Oberlin

images.altText: View of St. Mary Lake from Wild Goose Island Overlook
images.title: St. Mary Lake and Wild Goose Island
images.caption: View of St. Mary Lake from Wild Goose Island Overlook

images.altText: View of the mountains behind Lake McDonald at sunset
images.title: Lake McDonald at Sunset
images.caption: Sunset on the mountains at the head of Lake McDonald

images.altText: Bowman Lake
images.title: Bowman Lake
images.caption: View of Bowman Lake in the northwest corner of the park

images.altText: Looking down into the lobby of the Lake McDonald Lodge from the balcony
images.title: Lobby of the Lake McDonald Lodge
images.caption: Lobby of the historic Lake McDonald Lodge

entranceFees.title: Park Entrance Pass

properties.directionsInfo:
From the south (Detroit or Chicago areas) :Take US-31, US-131, US-27 to M-115 & M-37, I-75 and M-72 North to Traverse City, then west on M-72 to the Village of Empire. You will see the visitor center as you enter Empire on your right.
You may also get to Empire from the south via US-31 to Ludington and then north to Manistee. You can follow either US-31 or M-22 from north of Manistee.

From the north (Michigan's Upper Peninsula), take I-75 to Grayling and follow M-72 to Traverse City or take US-31 south

entrancePasses.description:
Admits pass holder and all passengers in a noncommercial vehicle. Valid for one year from month of purchase.

Valid for 12 months from month of issue.
When purchased at an Automated Pay Station, please exchange the receipt for the Annual Park Pass card at any staffed fee collection station.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Park Entrance Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Tenperatures usually range from 40 F to 70 F. Rain is common.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from from 50 F to 83 F. Rain and sun are equally common. On very sunny days, be prepared with plenty of water--heat exhaustion is common, especially when hiking on the dunes.

Fall: Temperatures range from 40 F to 70 F. Fall foliage is at its peak around mid September. 

Winter: Temperatures range from 15 F to 40 F. Snow is common and is on the ground for most of the winter. Dress in warm layers.
properties.name: Sleeping Bear Dunes
properties.description: Miles of sand beach, bluffs that tower 450’ above Lake Michigan, lush forests, clear inland lakes, unique flora and fauna make up the natural world of Sleeping Bear Dunes. High dunes afford spectacular views across the lake. An island lighthouse, US Life-Saving Service stations, coastal villages, and picturesque farmsteads reflect the park’s rich maritime, agricultural, and recreational history.

images.altText: Snowy white clouds brush the top of a sand dune
images.title: Summer clouds over a sand dune
images.caption: Sand and sky meet on the dunes.

images.altText: Looking through across deep blue-green water toward Sleeping Bear point from atop Empire Bluff.
images.title: View from Empire Bluff
images.caption: This view of Sleeping Bear Point is a major reason visitors hike to the top of Empire Bluff.

images.altText: A man is sillouetted against the winter sun setting in the lake.
images.title: Winter sunset
images.caption: Enjoying a winter sunset from a frozen sand perch.

images.altText: Many beachgoers enjoy the river and lake.
images.title: A perfect beach day at Platte River Point
images.caption: Bright-colored umbrellas, bathing suits and floats make a festive day at the beach

images.altText: A bright sun begins to set into Lake Michigan
images.title: Lake Michigan overlook sun
images.caption: Sunset viewing is a favorite activity--especially from the Lake Michigan overlook.

images.altText: A kayaker in a red kayak floats down the Platte River surrounded by fall-colored trees.
images.title: A fall paddle down the river
images.caption: A quiet paddle through fall splendor.

images.altText: Deep shadows are being thrown by the snowshoers ready to start their hike
images.title: Snowshoe hike at Treat Farm
images.caption: Snowshoers enjoy the sunshine as they explore the Treat Farm in winter

images.altText: The Milky Way lighting up the night sky with a pink glow along the horizon
images.title: Milky Way, lightning, and ground fog
images.caption: The night sky--nothing better; the Milky Way reaches across the sky

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for the park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
The Obed Wild & Scenic River Visitor Center is located at 208 North Maiden Street in downtown Wartburg, Tennessee.

Please use the link for more information.
properties.weatherInfo:
The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. 

Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.
properties.name: Obed
properties.description: The Obed Wild and Scenic River looks much the same today as it did when the first white settlers strolled its banks in the late 1700s. While meagerly populated due to poor farming soil, the river was a hospitable fishing and hunting area for trappers and pioneers. Today, the Obed stretches along the Cumberland Plateau and offers visitors a variety of outdoor recreational opportunities.

images.altText: Obed in Fall
images.title: Obed WSR in Fall
images.caption: Obed in Fall

entranceFees.description: Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore is open year-round, 24 hours day. There is no entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Pictured Rocks Entrance Fee = $0

properties.directionsInfo: Pictured Rocks NL is located on the south shore of Lake Superior in Michigan's Upper Peninsula, between the towns of Munising (west) and Grand Marais (east). Access the west side of the park via Michigan highways M-28 and M-94 to Munising. State highway M-77 leads to Grand Marais on the east side. Alger County Road H-58 runs parallel and through the park, providing access to spur roads that lead to scenic overlooks, trailheads, campgrounds, beaches, etc. Many roads are closed in winter due to snow.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are pleasant with the average highs in June, July, and August in the 70s°F, and lows in the low 50s°F. The coldest months are December through March with average highs of 25°F to 32°F, and average lows in the teens.

Annual precipitation averages 31 inches; average annual snowfall ranges from 140 to 160 inches. Snow generally covers the ground from late November through late April.
properties.name: Pictured Rocks
properties.description: Sandstone cliffs, beaches, sand dunes, waterfalls, inland lakes, deep forest, and wild shoreline beckon you to visit Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. The power of Lake Superior shapes the park's coastal features and affects every ecosystem, creating a unique landscape to explore. Hiking, camping, sightseeing, and four-season outdoor opportunities abound.

images.altText: Mineral stained cliff wall along Lake Superior shoreline.
images.title: Pictured Rocks Colorful Cliff Wall
images.caption: The park is named for the colorful cliff walls along Lake Superior shoreline.

images.altText: Miner's Castle rock formation along the Lake Superior shoreline.
images.title: Miner's Castle
images.caption: View the Miner's Castle rock formation from the adjacent cliffs or from a boat.

images.altText: The Grand Sable Dunes rise up 300 feet from Lake Superior.
images.title: Grand Sable Dunes
images.caption: The Grand Sable Dunes rise up 300 feet from Lake Superior.

images.altText: Au Sable Lighthouse and light keeper's quarters
images.title: Au Sable Light Station
images.caption: Au Sable Lighthouse and light keeper's quarters

images.altText: High volume of water flowing at Miners Falls
images.title: Miners Falls
images.caption: Water flowing over Miners Falls

images.altText: Backcountry camping at Benchmark site showing tent surrounded by ferns and trees.
images.title: Backcountry Camping - Benchmark Site
images.caption: Backpacking and camping are a popular activities.

images.altText: Shallow creek narrowing through the forest.
images.title: Beaver Basin Wilderness
images.caption: Shallow creek in the Beaver Basin Wilderness

images.altText: Kayakers near Lovers Leap rock arch formation
images.title: Kayaking Along the Pictured Rocks Cliffs
images.caption: Kayakers near Lovers Leap

images.altText: Ice climber on a curtain of ice along the Pictured Rocks Escarpment
images.title: Ice Climbing
images.caption: Ice climbing is a popular winter activity.

images.altText: Three sections of cliffs sticking out into Lake Superior like the bows of battleships.
images.title: Battleship Row
images.caption: 15 miles of carved and colorful cliffs along the Lake Superior shoreine.

images.altText: Mineral stained cliffs and collapsed rock arch along Lake Superior
images.title: Pictured Rocks Cliffs along the Chapel / Mosquito Loop
images.caption: Springtime along the Chapel / Mosquito hiking loop

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee at Ozark National Scenic Riverways.
entranceFees.title: Park entrance fee

properties.directionsInfo: The Headquarters for Ozark National Scenic Riverways is located at 404 Watercress Drive in Van Buren, Missouri.  It's located at the corner of Watercress Drive and Main Street, across the street from the Van Buren Public School complex.
properties.weatherInfo: Ozark National Scenic Riverways is located in southeastern Missouri.  Summer temperatures generally range from 75-100 degrees with high humidity.  Winter temperatures generally range from 0-50 degrees with periods of intermittent freezing and snow.
properties.name: Ozark
properties.description: Ozark National Scenic Riverways is the first national park area to protect a river system. The Current and Jacks Fork Rivers are two of the finest floating rivers you'll find anywhere. Spring-fed, cold and clear they are a delight to canoe, swim, boat or fish. Besides these two famous rivers, the park is home to hundreds of freshwater springs, caves, trails and historic sites such as Alley Mill.

images.altText: Alley Spring in the winter.
images.title: Alley Spring in the winter
images.caption: Alley Spring Roller Mill is a popular destination year round.

images.altText: Big Spring near Van Buren, Missouri
images.title: Big Spring
images.caption: Big Spring produces more than 250 million gallons of water per day.

images.altText: Prairie Hollow Gorge
images.title: Prairie Hollow Gorge
images.caption: Prairie Hollow Gorge is located near the Two Rivers junction, off State Route V.

images.altText: Current River near Pulltite
images.title: Current River near Pulltite
images.caption: The clear water of the Current River is perfect for floating.

images.altText: Rocky Falls
images.title: Rocky Falls
images.caption: Rocky Falls is a popular picnic area and swimming hole located near the center of Ozark National Scenic Riverways.

images.altText: Round Spring
images.title: Round Spring
images.caption: Round Spring maintains a deep blue hue, like many of the other Ozark springs.

phoneNumbers.description: This is the primary phone number for the Malaquite Visitor Center at Padre Island National Seashore.

emailAddresses.description: This is the primary park e-mail address for visitors to ask questions and get information about the park.

entranceFees.description: This fee provides entrance into the park for one private, standard passenger vehicle for one day (not overnight). It covers all occupants of the vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Padre Island Vehicle 1 Day Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: This fee provides entrance into the park for one pedestrian or one bicycle for up to 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Padre Island Bicycle/Pedestrian Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: This fee provides for use of the Bird Island Basin area within Padre Island National Seashore for one day. It covers all occupants of one private, standard passenger vehicle. Bird Island Basin provides access to the Laguna Madre and has a boat ramp, windsurfing and kayaking area, and camping area. Please note this fee is in addition to the park entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Bird Island Basin Use Fee

entranceFees.description: This fee provides entrance into the park for one private, standard passenger vehicle for up to 7 days. It covers all occupants of the vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Padre Island Vehicle 7 Day Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The National Seashore is located on North Padre Island, southeast of the city of Corpus Christi, Texas. Visitors to the area should head east through Corpus Christi on Highway 358. After crossing the JFK Causeway onto Padre Island, Highway 358 changes to Park Road 22. Continue about 10 miles south on Park Road 22 to reach the park entrance.

entrancePasses.description: This pass entitles one private, standard passenger vehicle and its occupants to enter the park for one calendar year from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Padre Island Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: This pass entitles one private, standard passenger vehicle and its occupants to enter the Bird Island Basin area of Padre Island National Seashore for one calendar year from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Bird Island Basin Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Padre Island has long, hot summers and short, mild winters. Summers are very humid. Winter can bring strong cold fronts and gale force winds. Most rain falls near the beginning and end of hurricane season (June-October). Average seasonal temperatures (Fahrenheit) are: Spring - high 70s-80s, low 50s-60s; Summer - high mid-90s, low 70s; Fall - high 70s-80s, low 50s-60s; Winter - high 50s-70s, low 30s-40s. Year-round, average wind speed ranges from 5-25 miles per hour. Relative humidity seldom drops below 70%.
properties.name: Padre Island
properties.description: Padre Island National Seashore separates the Gulf of Mexico from the Laguna Madre, one of a few hypersaline lagoons in the world.  The park protects 70 miles of coastline, dunes, prairies, and wind tidal flats teeming with life.  It is a safe nesting ground for the Kemp’s ridley sea turtle and a haven for over 380 bird species.  It also has a rich history, including the Spanish shipwrecks of 1554.

images.altText: A small boy plays at the water's edge on Padre Island
images.title: A boy at play on scenic Padre Island
images.caption: Over 60 miles of beach offers beautiful scenery and fun for the whole family.

images.altText: Tiny Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings crawl on the beach of Padre Island.
images.title: Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings
images.caption: Thousands of visitors come to the park each summer to watch newborn Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings get released into the Gulf of Mexico.

images.altText: A black skimmer flies by, slicing the surf with its lower bill to catch food.
images.title: Black Skimmer
images.caption: Over 380 bird species have been found at the park, making it a top destination for birders from around the world.

images.altText: A tent is set up close to the beach on Padre Island.
images.title: Camping on Padre Island
images.caption: Camping in a tent or RV is one of the most popular activities on Padre Island.

images.altText: A beautiful and colorful sunrise over the Gulf of Mexico on Padre Island.
images.title: Sunrise over the Gulf of Mexico on Padre Island
images.caption: Breathtaking sunrises, remote beaches, and dark night skies make Padre Island a top vacation destination.

images.altText: A woman drives a boat up to the ramp at Bird Island Basin.
images.title: Bird Island Basin Boat Ramp
images.caption: Bird Island Basin offers access to the Laguna Madre for boating, fishing, windsurfing, kayaking, and camping.

images.altText: A man in waders fishes in the surf along the Mansfield Channel jetties.
images.title: Fishing at Mansfield Channel
images.caption: Surf fishing is a great way to enjoy the outdoors at Padre Island National Seashore.

images.altText: Large seashells in front of the turquoise blue waters of the Gulf of mexico
images.title: Big Shell Beach at Padre Island National Seashore
images.caption: Padre Island National Seashore has over 70 miles of undeveloped coastline with ample beachcombing opportunities.

entranceFees.description: Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all its occupants.
entranceFees.title: Private Vehicle Fee

entranceFees.description: Admits a private, non-commercial motorcycle and its riders.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle Fee

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car. Typically used for bicyclists, hikers, and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free.

properties.directionsInfo:
Arches National Park is located in southeast Utah, five miles north of Moab on US 191.

From Moab, Utah, drive five miles north on Main Street/US 191. Turn right at the stoplight.

From Interstate 70, take exit 182 (Crescent Junction), then drive south 28 miles on US 191. Turn left at the stoplight.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year through the month of purchase. Admits one (1) private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Arches and Canyonlands national parks, and Natural Bridges National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Southeast Utah Parks Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Arches is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
properties.name: Arches
properties.description: Visit Arches to discover a landscape of contrasting colors, land forms and textures unlike any other in the world. The park has over 2,000 natural stone arches, in addition to hundreds of soaring pinnacles, massive fins and giant balanced rocks. This red-rock wonderland will amaze you with its formations, refresh you with its trails, and inspire you with its sunsets.

images.altText: a stone monolith reflected in standing water
images.title: The Organ with Potholes
images.caption: The Organ rock formation is reflected in one of many natural potholes.

images.altText: a broad, red arch with rock pinnacles in the background
images.title: Double O Arch
images.caption: Double O Arch is one of many large arches in the Devils Garden area

images.altText: a stone arch
images.title: Delicate Arch
images.caption: Delicate Arch is perhaps the most famous natural arch in the world.

images.altText: the Milky Way arcs above silhouetted stone pinnacles
images.title: Milky Way over the Garden of Eden
images.caption: Arches offers some excellent night sky viewing.

images.altText: two hikers descend a broad wash with tall rock walls on either side.
images.title: Park Avenue Trail
images.caption: The Park Avenue trail is one of many hiking trails at Arches, ranging from easy to strenuous.

addresses.line1: 5 Miles north of Moab, Utah, on US 191

entranceFees.description: No entrance fees associated with this park.  Camping amenity fees are separate fees.
entranceFees.title: Voyageurs Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Voyageurs National Park is located in Northern Minnesota. The park shares its northern boundary with Canada and lies just west of the Boundary Water Canoe Area Wilderness. The park visitor centers are accessible by car but in order to truly experience the park, one must leave their vehicle behind and access the park by boat.

entrancePasses.description: No park specific entrance pass associated with this park.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Pass

properties.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in Voyageur country.  The air is temperate during June, July, and August when periods of fine, mild weather prevail.  The frost-free season averages 120 days from June to mid-September.  The average ice-out date is May 3 but varies year to year.  Annual precipitation (rain and snow) averages 25-28 inches in the park and snowfall ranges from 55-70 inches, but is highly variable.  The first measurable snowfall occurs in late October and the last in late April or early May.
properties.name: Voyageurs
properties.description: Voyageurs is a maze of interconnected water highways. Plan ahead before coming to this water-based park by bringing your own watercraft, reserving a watercraft, or taking a park ranger boat tour.

images.altText: Northern Lights over Voyageurs National Park waters
images.title: Northern Lights
images.caption: Experience the Aurora Borealis at Voyageurs National Park

images.altText: overlooking a lake
images.title: Perry Lake
images.caption: For peace and quiet explore the backcountry of the Kabetogama Peninsula

images.altText: rock cliffs along the lake
images.title: Anderson Bay
images.caption: Explore the unique geology of Voyageurs National Park and see our story unfold.

images.altText: orange, yellow, and green colors are showing in the fall foliage
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: The mix of hardwood and conifers create inspiring scenic views especially in the fall.

images.altText: a trail through the wood
images.title: Hike a trail
images.caption: Get outside and get hiking on one of our many trails.
