properties.directionsInfo:
Theodore Roosevelt National Park is located in the Badlands of western North Dakota. 
There are three units to the park. The South Unit entrance is in the town of Medora, ND off of Interstate 94 exits 24 and 27. The North Unit entrance is on Highway 85 approximately 14 miles south of Watford City, ND. The remote Elkhorn Ranch Unit sits roughly in the middle of the North and South Units and is accessed via gravel roads. Consult park staff for directions to the Elkhorn Ranch Unit.

entrancePasses.description: Entrance to all units of Theodore Roosevelt National Park for one year from month of purchase. Admits pass holder and passengers in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the pass holder and his/her immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (foot, bicycle, etc.).
entrancePasses.title: Theodore Roosevelt National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: In winter, some or all park roads may be closed due to snow.
properties.name: Theodore Roosevelt
properties.description: When Theodore Roosevelt came to Dakota Territory to hunt bison in 1883, he was a skinny, young, spectacled dude from New York. He could not have imagined how his adventure in this remote and unfamiliar place would forever alter the course of the nation. The rugged landscape and strenuous life that TR experienced here would help shape a conservation policy that we still benefit from today.

images.altText: the Little Missouri River under blue skies
images.title: A View from the Maah Daah Hey Trail
images.caption: The Maah Daah Hey Trail follows the Little Missouri River for several miles before it enters the Theodore Roosevelt Wilderness.

images.altText: A colorfully striped butte in the foreground overlooks a dark green badlands landscape
images.title: River Bend Overlook, North Unit
images.caption: The River Bend Overlook offers one of the most popular views in the park's North Unit.

images.altText: a green prairie hilltop overlooks the badlands, shrouded in shadows
images.title: Sunset on Buck Hill
images.caption: A short climb to the top of Buck Hill in the park's South Unit rewards hikers with a sweeping panorama and a fantastic place to watch the sun rise or set.

images.altText: A muddy river bank lined with cottonwood trees and steep buttes
images.title: Ekblom Trail
images.caption: The Ekblom Trail is the gateway to the Theodore Roosevelt Wilderness. All you have to do is make it across the river!

images.credit: NPS Photo / Roland and Lisa Honeyman
images.altText: a string of bison are silhouetted against the backdrop of hazy blue and yellow badlands
images.title: Bison Trail
images.caption: Bison roam the badlands from top to bottom, surprising visitors with their agility and ability to cross even the most rugged terrain.

images.altText: two bull bison collide heads in a dusty battle for dominance
images.title: Raise a Ruckus
images.caption: In the summer, bull bison wage furious battles over the right to breed.

images.credit: NPS Photo / Rolan and Lisa Honeyman
images.altText: A bugling bull elk and his harem of cows stand on the edge of a butte as the sunlight fades
images.title: Fall Bugle
images.caption: The ghostly bugles of bull elk can be heard wafting through the badlands in the fall.

images.altText: the swirling, dusty looking milky way runs vertically though a starry night sky
images.title: Milky Way
images.caption: Though light pollution in the area is increasing, the night sky over Theodore Roosevelt National Park remains beautiful and inspiring.

images.altText: a strange looking sand and rock formation stands in a prairie of brown grass
images.title: Hoodoos
images.caption: Theodore Roosevelt described the badlands as "so fantastically broken in form and so bizarre in color as to seem hardly properly to belong to this earth."

images.altText: The rising sun casts light on Roosevelt's snow-covered cabin.
images.title: Maltese Cross Cabin
images.caption: Imagine waking up on a crisp winter morning in Roosevelt's Maltese Cross Cabin. It is no wonder that his heart was captured by the romance of life in the West.

properties.directionsInfo: The Kris Eggle Visitor Center is located on Highway 85, approximately 25 miles south of Why, AZ.
properties.weatherInfo: Summer months are hot, with temperatures exceeding 100F.  Winter months are milder, with temperatures in the 70s, with overnight lows in the 40s.
properties.name: Organ Pipe Cactus
properties.description: Look closely. Look again. The sights and sounds of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, an International Biosphere Reserve, reveal a thriving community of plants and animals. Human stories echo throughout this desert preserve, chronicling thousands of years of desert living. A scenic drive, wilderness hike or a night of camping will expose you to a living desert that thrives.

images.altText: sun setting on a green organ pipe cactus
images.title: Organ Pipe Cactus
images.caption: Experience the only place in the US where the Organ Pipe Cactus naturally grows

images.altText: View through the valley, flanked by Ajo Mountains
images.title: Scenic view through the Ajo Mountains
images.caption: Capture amazing views from the scenic drives

images.altText: a green desert environment with cholla cactus glowing in the light
images.title: Cholla Cactus in the Light
images.caption: Experience the rich assemblage of cacti at Organ Pipe Cactus.

images.altText: Jagged Bates Mountains with shadows and clouds
images.title: View of the Bates Mountains
images.caption: Watch sun and shadow interplay across the jagged mountains

images.altText: Yellow poppies on the green desert floor with cacti in the background
images.title: Desert Wildflowers
images.caption: The desert awakens in the Spring with vibrant wildflowers

entranceFees.description:
This fee covers entrance to the park for 7 days. If you are arriving via seaplane or ferry the travel ticket includes entrance fee to Dry Tortugas National Park and Fort Jefferson. If you hold a National Parks Pass, show your pass at check-in and the entrance fee will be deducted from your transportation cost.

If you are arriving via private boat or private seaplane fees are collected through a self-service fee area on the main dock at Garden Key. Cash or check only.
entranceFees.title: Dry Tortugas Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Dry Tortugas National Park is one of the most remote parks in the National Park System. Located approximately 70 miles west of Key West it is accessible only by a daily concession ferry, private boats, charter boats, or seaplane.
properties.weatherInfo: The climate in the Dry Tortugas is subtropical, which basically means that it has warm and tropical weather in the range of 60°F to 90°F. The two main seasons are the winter stormy season from December through March which is windier and sees rougher seas, and the summertime tropical storm season from June through November where there is a higher chance of isolated storms. During the summers it is hot and humid. During the winter the temperature is milder and drier.
properties.name: Dry Tortugas
properties.description: Almost 70 miles (113 km) west of Key West lies the remote Dry Tortugas National Park. This 100-square mile park is mostly open water with seven small islands.  Accessible only by boat or seaplane, the park is known the world over as the home of magnificent Fort Jefferson, picturesque blue waters, superlative coral reefs and marine life, and the vast assortment of bird life that frequents the area.

images.altText: Park visitors enjoy a sunset on the moat wall.
images.title: Sunset at Fort Jefferson
images.caption: Sunsets at the Dry Tortugas are breathtaking. Visitors who choose to camp over night can view the sun set at Fort Jefferson.

images.altText: A view of Fort Jefferson from the moat all.
images.title: Fort Jefferson
images.caption: ort Jefferson is a massive but unfinished coastal fortress. It is the largest masonry structure in the Americas, and is composed of over 16 million bricks.

images.altText: A boat passes in front of Loggerhead Key during sunset.
images.title: Loggerhead Key
images.caption: The largest island in the Dry Tortugas, Loggerhead Key is a site of shipwrecks, a significant lighthouse installation, and where the historic Carnegie Laboratory for Marine Ecology once stood. Named for its abundance of loggerhead sea turtles, Loggerhead

images.altText: A view inside Fort Jefferson.
images.title: Inside Fort Jefferson
images.caption: Garden Key is the second largest island in the Dry Tortugas, about 14 acres in size, and has had the most human impact. Located on Garden Key is historic Fort Jefferson, one of the nation’s largest 19th century forts and a central cultural feature of Dry

images.altText: A few of the stars at night with a view of Fort Jefferson.
images.title: Night sky at the Dry Tortugas
images.caption: The Dry Tortugas is so remote that night sky viewing is possible.

images.altText: Two divers dive the Windjammer Wreck
images.title: Diving at the Dry Tortugas
images.caption: The Dry Tortugas has over 300 sunken ships. One of the most accessible is the Winjammer Wreck which can be dove or snorkeled.

images.altText: An aerial view of the Dry Tortugas
images.title: Aerial view of the Dry Tortugas
images.caption: The Dry Tortugas is made up of seven islands.

properties.directionsInfo: White Sands National Park is located off of US Highway 70 between the cities of Las Cruces and Alamogordo. The monument is about 15 miles west of Alamogordo and 52 miles east of Las Cruces.

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for the card holder and three other adults within the same vehicle. Pass is good for one year from month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: White Sands Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Temperatures at White Sands vary greatly throughout the year. Summer time temperatures can be very hot. Winters are mild with cool evenings. Spring time is the windy season. Fall is very enjoyable with mild daytime and night time temperatures.
properties.name: White Sands
properties.description: Rising from the heart of the Tularosa Basin is one of the world's great natural wonders - the glistening white sands of New Mexico. Great wave-like dunes of gypsum sand have engulfed 275 square miles of desert, creating the world's largest gypsum dunefield. White Sands National Park preserves a major portion of this unique dunefield, along with the plants and animals that live here.

images.altText: Aerial of white sand dunes.
images.title: Aerial of Dunefield
images.caption: The dunes at White Sands cover 275 square miles of the Tularosa Basin.

images.altText: Close up view of ripples on a dune.
images.title: Ripples
images.caption: The wind shapes and moves the dunes as a whole but gives each individual dune the texture of ripples.

images.altText: Dunes colored orange by sunset.
images.title: Sunset Colored Dunes
images.caption: Sunsets are one of the most popular times to visit White Sands. Visitors can experience sunset every day of the year.

images.altText: Cottonwood trees with orange leaves.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: Fall is a wonderful time to visit as most of our plants with leaves change beautiful colors.

images.altText: Grey shadows on dunes.
images.title: Shaded Dunes
images.caption: As the sun changes its angle through the sky it allows shadow to roll across the dunes.

phoneNumbers.description: Phones are answered and messages returned as soon as possible as staffing allows.

properties.directionsInfo:
From the North:
Take I-15 south to UT-20 (exit 95). Travel east on UT-20 to US-89. Follow US-89 south to UT-12. Travel east on UT-12 to UT-63. Take UT-63 south to Bryce Canyon National Park.

From the South through Zion National Park:
Take I-15 north to UT-9 (exit 16). Follow UT-9 east through Zion National Park to US-89. Travel north on US-89 to UT-12. Go east on UT-12 to UT-63. Take UT-63 south to Bryce Canyon National Park.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for twelve months from the date of purchase, for unlimited visits to Bryce Canyon National Park. It admits the purchaser and any accompanying persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the purchaser and accompanying immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (shuttle, bicycle, and foot). This pass covers entrance fees only and is not refundable and/or transferable.

properties.weatherInfo: Due of its high elevation climate, weather at Bryce Canyon through autumn, winter, and spring can be highly variable. From October to May temperatures fall below freezing nearly every night. The park typically experiences its coldest and snowiest periods from December through February. Spring storms in March and April can still produce heavy snowfall that may impact travel in the region. Summer highs are typically in the 70s-80s F and afternoon thunderstorms are common in July and August.
properties.name: Bryce Canyon
properties.description: Hoodoos (irregular columns of rock) exist on every continent, but here is the largest concentration found anywhere on Earth. Situated along a high plateau at the top of the Grand Staircase, the park's high elevations include numerous life communities, fantastic dark skies, and geological wonders that defy description.

images.credit: NPS Photo / Brian B. Roanhorse February 24, 2015
images.altText: Bryce Canyon Visitor Center Toll booths in winter.
images.title: Bryce Canyon Visitor Center Toll Booths
images.caption: Opening the gates at Bryce Canyon National Park under snow.

images.credit: NPS Photo / Brian B. Roanhorse February 28, 2015

images.caption: Trail to Queens Garden is exceptional any day of the year.

images.caption: Orange is the new look at Bryce.

entranceFees.title: Yellowstone (motorcycle or snowmobile)

entranceFees.description: Good for entry into Yellowstone National Park for seven days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Yellowstone (individual on foot, bicycle, etc.)

properties.directionsInfo: Yellowstone National Park covers nearly 3,500 square miles in the northwest corner of Wyoming (3% of the park is in Montana and 1% is in Idaho). Yellowstone has five entrance stations, and several are closed to regular vehicles during winter. It takes many hours to drive between these entrances, so be sure to check the status of roads at the entrance you intend to use while planning your trip and before you arrive.

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance into Yellowstone National Park for one year (valid through the month of purchase). On a snowmobile, this pass admits the signer(s). When traveling by snowcoach or shuttle, this pass admits a signer and up to three additional persons (16 and older) for a total of four people.
entrancePasses.title: Yellowstone National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Yellowstone's weather can vary quite a bit, even in a single day. In the summer, daytime highs can exceed 70°F (25°C), only to drop 20 or more degrees when a thunderstorm rolls through. It can snow during any month of the year, and winter lows frequently drop below 0°F (-18°C), especially at night. Bring a range of clothing options, including a warm jacket and rain gear, even in the summer.
properties.name: Yellowstone
properties.description: On March 1, 1872, Yellowstone became the first national park for all to enjoy the unique hydrothermal wonders. Today, millions of people come here each year to camp, hike, and enjoy the majesty of the park.

images.altText: A crowd in front of a geyser

images.caption: Did you know that you can visit Old Faithful in the winter? You need to take a snowcoach or snowmobile!

images.altText: Visitors walk in front of brightly colored landscape.

images.caption: The vibrant colors of Palette Springs are formed by "thermophiles" -- heat-loving organisms.

images.altText: Two bighorn sheep

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to enter the Niobrara NSR. However, because the NPS does not own the land along the river, individual sites and private landowners may charge a fee.
entranceFees.title: Niobrara NSR Entrance Fees

entranceFees.description: Smith Falls State Park, within the boundaries of the Niobrara NSR, charges a day use fee (per carload). Those with a Nebraska State Park Pass are not charged the day use fee. Individuals with out-of-state license plates will be charged slightly more. Federal passes are not valid for this entry fee. NOTE: no fee is charged for those visiting the waterfall from the river.
entranceFees.title: Smith Falls State Park day use fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Most visitors start their trip in the city of Valentine, Nebraska. Valentine is 76 miles south of I-90 (Murdo, SD Exit) on Hwy 83; or 130 miles north of I-80 (North Platte, NE Exit) on Hwy 83.

The nearest major airports are in Rapid City, SD (220 miles); Denver, CO (391 miles); and Omaha, NE (300 miles).
properties.weatherInfo:
Summer (June-August): highs - low 80s to low 100s; lows - 50s to 60s, with occasional thunderstorms and associated strong winds. Moderate dry winds are common in the summer. 8.3" is average summer rainfall.

Spring (April/May) and Fall (September/October) have cooler temperatures: average highs 60-70s, average lows 30-40s with 7.3" average rain/snowfall.
properties.name: Niobrara
properties.description: The 76 miles of the Niobrara National Scenic River winds through dramatic bluffs, incredible wildlife diversity, gorgeous waterfalls, world-class fossil resources, and plenty of floating fun for the whole family. Less than 1/4 of one percent of US rivers are designated under the National Wild & Scenic Rivers System. Come discover why this prairie river has earned this honor.

images.altText: Two people in one canoe paddle along the bluffs of the Niobrara NSR.
images.title: Canoeing the Niobrara NSR
images.caption: The Niobrara is a peaceful place to paddle during the week.

images.altText: A beautiful, if short, waterfall empties into the side of the Niobrara NSR.
images.title: Berry Falls along the Niobrara NSR.
images.caption: Berry Falls is one of over 200 waterfalls that visitors may see along the Niobrara National Scenic River's bluffs.

images.altText: A view from a canoe, with the photographer's feet resting on the bow, of the Niobrara NSR.
images.title: Relaxing canoeing on the Niobrara NSR
images.caption: Much of the Niobrara National Scenic River is easy paddling, suitable for novice canoers.

images.altText: A paddler in a canoe goes through Class II Rapids on the Niobrara NSR.
images.title: Egelhoffs Rapids on the Niobrara NSR
images.caption: An experienced canoer takes on the Class II Egelhoffs Rapids along the Niobrara National Scenic River.

images.altText: Yellows, oranges, and greens dominate the fall colors along the Niobrara NSR.
images.title: Fall colors along the Niobrara NSR
images.caption: Autumn is a perfect time to enjoy the beauty of the Niobrara National Scenic River, from the river or the banks.

images.altText: A man takes a photo of a meandering river from an overlook.
images.title: Taking photos along the Niobrara NSR
images.caption: Parts of the river are shallow and meandering, making beautiful backdrops for people to take photographs.

images.altText: Many people on tubes float down the Niobrara.
images.title: Tubers congregate at Smith Falls State Park
images.caption: On Saturdays, the Niobrara National Scenic River is a great place to meet hundreds of other tubers.

properties.directionsInfo: Grand Teton National Park is located in northwestern Wyoming north of the town of Jackson, Wyoming and south of Yellowstone National Park.

entrancePasses.description: Pass is valid for one year through the month of purchase. Park Annual Pass provides entrance to pass holder and accompanying passengers in a single private non-commercial vehicle to Grand Teton National Park. Purchase your pass at one of Grand Teton's park entrances and permits desks at the Craig Thomas Discovery and Visitor Center and the Colter Bay Visitor Center.
entrancePasses.title: Grand Teton Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Jackson Hole has long, cold winters; snow and frost are possible any month. 
mid-April, May & June - Mild days and cool nights alternate with rain and snow.
July & August - Warm days and cool nights prevail, with afternoon thundershowers common.
September, October & November - Sunny days and cold nights alternate with rain and occasional snowstorms.
December to mid-April - Between storms the days are sunny and nights are frigid. Snow blankets the mountains and valley.
properties.name: Grand Teton
properties.description: Rising above a scene rich with extraordinary wildlife, pristine lakes, and alpine terrain, the Teton Range stands as a monument to the people who fought to protect it. These are mountains of the imagination. Mountains that led to the creation of Grand Teton National Park where you can explore over two hundred miles of trails, float the Snake River, and enjoy the serenity of this remarkable place.

images.altText: Backpackers in North Fork Cascade Canyon, Grand Teton behind
images.title: North Fork Cascade Canyon
images.caption: Backpackers in North Fork Cascade Canyon approaching Paintbrush Divide.

images.altText: Winter sunrise on snow-covered Teton Range
images.title: Winter Sunrise on the Teton Range
images.caption: Winter sunrise on snow-covered Teton Range

images.altText: Grizzly bear running through dry grass with shrubs behind
images.title: Grizzly Bear
images.caption: Grizzly bears are found throughout Grand Teton National Park

images.altText: Lake Solitude with the high Teton Peaks beyond during summer
images.title: Lake Solitude with the Cathedral Group
images.caption: Lake Solitude is a favorite hiking destination in the park.

images.altText: Oxbow Bend on the Snake River during fall with golden aspens and Mount Moran in the background.
images.title: Oxbow Bend and Mount Moran
images.caption: Mount Moran at Oxbow Bend is a classic autumn view.

images.altText: Mother in pink shirt, child in orange shirt, the Snake River below and the Teton Range beyond.
images.title: Visitors at the Snake River Overlook
images.caption: The Snake River Overlook is a where Ansel Adams took his iconic image of the Teton Range.

images.altText: Historic Moulton Barn with visitors and the Teton Range beyond.
images.title: John Moulton Barn at Mormon Row
images.caption: Two Moulton brothers built adjacent icon barns on Mormon Row. John's barn is pictured. T.A., his brother, built a barn just to the south.

images.altText: American Pika perched on a granite boulder
images.title: American Pika (Ochotona princeps)
images.caption: American Pika live in rockfall areas.

images.altText: Bull moose with large antlers walking through fall grasses
images.title: Moose
images.caption: In the fall, bull moose antlers have lost their velvet readying for the rut.

images.altText: beaver pond at Schwabacher landing reflecting the Teton Range in early summer
images.title: Schwabacher Landing
images.caption: The beaver ponds near Schwabacher Landing can produce beautiful reflections of the Teton Range.

images.altText: two people paddling a green canoe on String Lake with the Teton Range above
images.title: String Lake Canoes
images.caption: Canoeing on String Lake is a popular way to enjoy the scenery.

images.altText: yellow arrowleaf balsamroot blooms with Teewinot Peak towering beyond
images.title: Arrowleaf Balsamroot
images.caption: Arrowleaf Balsamroot is a bright splash of color during early summer.

properties.directionsInfo: Road conditions can be rough or impassable. Please call in advance for updates.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summer highs are typically in the 80's to mid-90's. Thunderstorms can produce heavy localized downpours and sudden dramatic drops in temperatures.

Winter temperatures will drop to well below freezing most nights. If you plan to camp in the winter, prepare for nighttime temperatures in the teens or lower.

Spring and Fall are great times to visit with more moderate temperatures, but unexpected storms can change things dramatically. Monitor local weather forecasts.
properties.name: Chaco Culture
properties.description: Today the massive buildings of the Ancestral Puebloan people still testify to the organizational and engineering abilities not seen anywhere else in the American Southwest. For a deeper contact with the canyon that was central to thousands of people between 850 and 1250 A.D., come and explore Chaco through guided tours, hiking & biking trails, evening campfire talks, and night sky programs.

images.altText: Black on White Bowls
images.title: Red Mesa Black on White Bowls
images.caption: Many of the things discovered at Chaco came from other places. These bowls came from the Red Mesa area. Red Mesa Black on White was produced from about A.D. 875 to 1040. Due to the lack of adequate resources, very few pots were produced in Chaco Canyon.

images.altText: Pueblo Bonito with Cliff Face
images.title: Pueblo Bonito with Cliff Face
images.caption: Pueblo Bonito is the most famous Chacoan great house. Constructed between 850 and 1150, Pueblo Bonito had almost 700 rooms, 32 kivas, and 3 great kivas.

images.altText: Gallup Black on White Pitchers
images.title: Gallup Black on White Pitchers
images.caption: These pitchers are another form of pottery that was created elsewhere and then brought to Chaco canyon. This particular style was manufactured from A.D. 1030 to 1150.

images.altText: Night Sky Above Fajada Butte
images.title: Night Sky Above Fajada Butte
images.caption: In 2013 Chaco Culture NHP was designated an International Dark Sky Park. The park has night sky and sunrise programs throughout the year.

images.altText: Black and White Photo of Una Vida Great House
images.title: Una Vida
images.caption: Una Vida is one of Chaco's largely un-excavated great houses. It's location provides great views of the canyon floor while being a short walk from a striking rock art panel.

properties.directionsInfo:
Badlands National Park is located 75 miles east of Rapid City, South Dakota.

Physical Addresses for GPS*

Park Headquarters: 25216 Ben Reifel Road, Interior, SD 57750.
Northeast Entrance (I-90, Exit 131): 21020 SD Hwy 240, Interior, SD 57750.
Pinnacles Entrance (I-90, Exit 110): 24240 Hwy 240, Wall, SD 57790.
Interior Entrance: 20640 SD Hwy 377, Interior, SD 57750.

entrancePasses.description: This pass admits a single, private, non commercial vehicle and its occupants into the park. This pass does not include camping or give any type of discount at stores inside the park. Valid for one year from month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Badlands National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The Badlands weather is variable and unpredictable with temperature extremes ranging from 116° F to -40° F. Summers are hot and dry with occasional violent thunderstorms. Hailstorms and occasional tornadoes can descend on the Badlands with sudden fury. Winters are typically cold with 12 to 24 inches of total snowfall.
properties.name: Badlands
properties.description: The rugged beauty of the Badlands draws visitors from around the world. These striking geologic deposits contain one of the world’s richest fossil beds. Ancient mammals such as the rhino, horse, and saber-toothed cat once roamed here. The park’s 244,000 acres protect an expanse of mixed-grass prairie where bison, bighorn sheep, prairie dogs, and black-footed ferrets live today.

images.altText: Badlands formations are very rugged and often have sharp peaks.

images.caption: Badlands formations are very rugged and often have sharp peaks.

Organized groups such as Scouts, Clubs, Youth Groups, Churches, Reunions, etc. that do not qualify for an Academic Fee Waiver are charged as follows: 
$35.00 Non-commercial vehicles with a vehicle capacity of 15 or less.
$20.00 per person Non-commercial vehicles with a capacity of 16 or greater. Fees will not exceed the commercial fee for the same-sized vehicle. Youth 15 and under are free. Individuals or families with any valid Annual or Lifetime pass may use their pass for entry at the per person rate.

properties.directionsInfo: Zion National Park is located on State Route 9 in Springdale, Utah.

entrancePasses.description: $80. Valid for 12 months from from purchase date. This pass provides access to, and use of, Federal recreation sites that charge an Entrance or Standard Amenity Fee*. The pass admits the pass holder/s and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle at per vehicle fee areas.

This is a free pass for active duty military personnel (Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines and Coast Guard) and their dependents. In order to qualify for the Annual Pass for Military, the military member must present a valid Department of Defense (CAC Card)

This pass admits the holder and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle at per vehicle fee areas and pass holder + 3 adults at per person fee areas.

properties.weatherInfo:
Zion is known for a wide range of weather conditions. Temperatures vary with changes in elevation and day/night temperatures may differ by over 30°F.

In summer, temperatures in Zion National Park often exceed 100°F/38°C. Zion experiences monsoons from mid-July into September that results in an increased risk of flash floods. Always be aware of the threat of storms and lightning and be prepared for a wide range of weather conditions. Winters are generally mild.
properties.name: Zion
properties.description: Follow the paths where ancient native people and pioneers walked. Gaze up at massive sandstone cliffs of cream, pink, and red that soar into a brilliant blue sky. Experience wilderness in a narrow slot canyon. Zion’s unique array of plants and animals will enchant you as you absorb the rich history of the past and enjoy the excitement of present day adventures.

images.altText: Zion Canyon Visitor Center
images.title: Zion Canyon Visitor Center
images.caption: The Zion Canyon Visitor Center sits under the watchful gaze of the Watchman

images.altText: Temples and Towers of the Virgin

images.altText: Mountain of the Sun

images.caption: The Zion Narrows is a challenging wilderness experience.

images.altText: Kolob Arch
images.title: Kolob Arch
images.caption: Deep in Zion's Wilderness sits Kolob Arch, one of the largest free-standing arches in the world.

properties.directionsInfo:
Mesa Verde National Park is in Southwestern Colorado. The park entrance is along Highway 160, between the towns of of Cortez and Mancos, Colorado. (10 miles east of Cortez; 9 miles west of Mancos; and about 35 miles west of Durango, Colorado.)

Once you enter the park, the first view of a cliff dwelling is 21 miles (approximately 45 minutes) along a steep, narrow, and winding road.

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass provides entrance into Mesa Verde National Park for a year, beginning from the date of sale. It covers the entrance fee for the pass holder and anyone in his/her vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Mesa Verde Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Spring: Temps range from 40 F to 70 F, but snowstorms can occur as late as May. 

Summer: Temps can reach well into the 90s F. Thunderstorms are common in July and August. Be prepared to bring and DRINK plenty of water.

Fall: Temps can range from 50 F to 75 F. Snowstorms can occur as early as October. 

Winter: Temps can range from the teens to low 30s F. Icy roads are common. Snow tires, all-wheel drive, or chains, may be required. Be prepared with water, snacks, and layers of warm clothing.
properties.name: Mesa Verde
properties.description: Mesa Verde National Park was established in 1906 to preserve and interpret the archeological heritage of the Ancestral Pueblo people who made it their home for over 700 years, from 600 to 1300 CE. Today, the park protects nearly 5,000 known archeological sites, including 600 cliff dwellings. These sites are some of the most notable and best preserved in the United States.

entranceFees.description: Great Basin National Park has no entrance fees.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

properties.directionsInfo: From the East or West: From U.S. Highway 6 & 50, turn south on Nevada State Highway 487 and travel 5 miles to Baker, NV. In Baker turn west on Highway 488 and travel 5 miles to the park. From the South (Utah): Travel north on Utah State Highway 21 through Milford, UT and Garrison, UT, Highway 487. Turn west on Highway 488 in Baker and travel 5 miles to the park. From the South (Nevada): Travel north on U.S. Highway 93. No public transportation is available to, or in, Great Basin National Park.
properties.weatherInfo: There is almost an 8,000 ft (2,400 m) difference in elevation between Wheeler Peak and the valley floor. Weather conditions in the park vary with elevation. In late spring and early summer, days in the valley may be hot, yet the snow pack may not have melted in the higher elevations. The Great Basin is a desert, with low relative humidity and sharp drops in temperature at night. In the summer, fierce afternoon thunderstorms are common. It can snow any time of the year at high elevations.
properties.name: Great Basin
properties.description: From the 13,063-foot summit of Wheeler Peak, to the sage-covered foothills, Great Basin National Park is a place to sample the stunning diversity of the larger Great Basin region. Come and partake of the solitude of the wilderness, walk among ancient bristlecone pines, bask in the darkest of night skies, and explore mysterious subterranean passages. There's a whole lot more than just desert here!

images.altText: Viewers gaze at stars and planets through telescope
images.title: Star Gazers
images.caption: Star Gazers view the Galaxy.

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-70: Take exit 149, then take UT-24 west toward Hanksville; continue for 43.8 miles (70.5 km). Turn right to continue on UT-24 west and continue for 37.3 miles (60 km). 

From I-15: take exit 188 then US-50 east toward Scipio. Left on UT-50; continuing 0.7 miles (1.1 km). Turn right onto US-50 east; continue for 24.4 miles (39.3 km). Turn right onto UT-260 south and continue 4.2 miles (6.8 km), then right on UT-24 for 71.3 miles. 

UT-12: North on highway 12 to Torrey, UT. Right onto UT-24.

entrancePasses.description: This pass covers the entrance fees to Capitol Reef National Park of the pass holder and occupants of a single, private non-commercial vehicle. It is valid for 365 days from the date of purchase. For information about other passes available see https://www.nps.gov/care/planyourvisit/fees.htm.
entrancePasses.title: Capitol Reef Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Weather is posted daily; check at the park visitor center for weather updates. Do not enter into narrow canyons if there is a threat of rain or if rain has been falling in the area.
properties.name: Capitol Reef
properties.description: Located in south-central Utah in the heart of red rock country, Capitol Reef National Park is a hidden treasure filled with cliffs, canyons, domes, and bridges in the Waterpocket Fold, a geologic monocline (a wrinkle on the earth) extending almost 100 miles.

images.altText: Wingate Sandstone cliffs behind historic barn and farmhouse
images.title: Gifford House and Pendleton Barn
images.caption: Windgate sandstone towers above historic Fruita farms and homes

images.altText: A hiker stands beside Hickman Bridge, a natural sandstone bridge
images.title: Hickman Bridge
images.caption: Hickman Bridge, a natural sandstone bridge, is a popular hike in the park.

images.altText: Exposed layers of rock in the Waterpocket fold
images.title: Strike Valley
images.caption: The Strike Valley shows colorful layers in the Waterpocket fold.

images.altText: Cliffs known as "The Castle" tower above the Capitol Reef Visitor Center
images.title: Capitol Reef Visitor Center with "The Castle"
images.caption: The Capitol Reef Visitor Center sits below cliffs known as "The Castle".

images.altText: Fruit tree with peaches in front of red sandstone cliffs
images.title: Capitol Reef Peach Orchard
images.caption: The Capitol Reef Orchards, planted in the pioneer era, remain a popular place for visitors today.

properties.directionsInfo: Canyonlands National Park is cut into three districts by the Green and Colorado rivers. Island in the Sky district, in the north of the park, is the closest district to Moab, UT. In about 40 minutes, you can reach Island in the Sky via UT 313. The Needles district is in the southeast corner of Canyonlands. The Needles is about an hour's drive from Monticello, UT via UT 211. The Maze district, in the west of the park, is the most remote and challenging. You can reach The Maze via unpaved roads from UT 24.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year through the month of purchase. Admits one (1) private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Arches and Canyonlands national parks, and Natural Bridges National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Southeast Utah Parks Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Canyonlands is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
properties.name: Canyonlands
properties.description: Canyonlands invites you to explore a wilderness of countless canyons and fantastically formed buttes carved by the Colorado River and its tributaries. Rivers divide the park into four districts: Island in the Sky, The Needles, The Maze, and the rivers themselves. These areas share a primitive desert atmosphere, but each offers different opportunities for sightseeing and adventure.

images.altText: a rugged canyon
images.title: The Maze
images.caption: The Maze is the most remote district of the park. Visiting requires four-wheel drive, self-reliance, and extra time.

images.altText: a broad stone arch with rock pinnacles in the distance
images.title: Mesa Arch
images.caption: Mesa Arch, at Island in the Sky, is a great spot for photographers.

images.altText: shallow pools with a double rainbow in the background
images.title: Pothole Point
images.caption: Pothole Point Trail

images.altText: a long gravel road with cyclists on it
images.title: White Rim Road
images.caption: The White Rim Road at Island in the Sky is a popular road for mountain bikers.

images.altText: pinnacles of horizontally striped sandstone
images.title: The Needles in Chesler Park
images.caption: The Needles, pinnacles of Cedar Mesa Sandstone, are visible in many parts of the Needles District, including this view in Chesler Park.

images.altText: a person rowing a dory on the Colorado River
images.title: Boating on the Colorado River
images.caption: Boating the Colorado and Green rivers is a popular activity at Canyonlands (permit required).

properties.directionsInfo: To access the main park area, including the Dunes Parking Lot, Visitor Center, and Pinyon Flats Campground, take US 160 to CO 150 from the south, or CO 17 to Lane 6 to CO 150 from the west. The national park is at the north end of CO 150.

entrancePasses.description: Covers one family's entrance for 12 months from time of purchase. Valid for two adults with signatures plus others in vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Great Sand Dunes Annual Family Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Temperatures are relatively cool all year, thanks to the park and preserve's high elevation. Conditions are most often calm, but winds can arise, especially in spring and during storm fronts.  Daytime temperatures feel warmer here year round due to intense high-altitude sunlight, and a scorching mid-day summer sand surface. Plan to explore the dunes morning or evening during summer. Nights are cool in summer, and frigid in winter. Visit the Great Sand Dunes website for the most accurate weather forecasts.
properties.name: Great Sand Dunes
properties.description: Open all day and night year round, the tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, conifer and aspen forests, alpine lakes, and tundra. Experience a starry sky on moonless nights, or a surreal walk on the dunes under bright full moonlight.

images.altText: View of Dunes and Sangre de Cristo Mountains from Park Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: From Interstate 5 (Redding), take Hwy 44 - 48 miles east to the junction of Hwy 89. Follow Hwy 89 south 1 mile to the north entrance of the park. From Interstate 5 (Red Bluff) take Hwy 36 E - 51 miles east to the junction of Hwy 89. Follow Hwy 89 north 6 miles to south entrance of the park.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year from month of purchase at Lassen Volcanic National Park and Whiskeytown National Recreation Area. Passes may be purchased as park entrance stations mid-May through October.
entrancePasses.title: Lassen Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Weather at Lassen can vary dramatically throughout the year.

Average January temperatures are a high of 40.4 °F (4.7 °C) and a low of 20.8 °F (-6.2 °C). Average July temperatures are a high of 88.4 °F and a low of 49.8 °F. Temperatures reach 90 °F or higher on an average of 36.9 days, and drop to 32 ° or lower on an average of 164 days days annually.
properties.name: Lassen Volcanic
properties.description: Lassen Volcanic National Park is home to steaming fumaroles, meadows freckled with wildflowers, clear mountain lakes, and numerous volcanoes. Jagged peaks tell the story of its eruptive past while hot water continues to shape the land. Lassen Volcanic offers opportunities to discover the wonder and mysteries of volcanoes and hot water for visitors willing to explore the undiscovered.

images.altText: A frozen lake below snow-covered trees and peak
images.title: Winter at Manzanita Lake
images.caption: With over 30 feet of snowfall annually, Lassen provides numerous opportunities for winter recreation.

images.altText: Golden grasses edge a pond reflecting a snow-dusted peak
images.title: Hat Creek
images.caption: Lassen Volcanic's rugged volcanic landscape is softened by numerous meadows, lakes, and creeks.

images.altText: A boardwalk passes through a colorful, steaming hydrothermal basin.
images.title: Bumpass Hell
images.caption: A 3-mile round-trip trail leads to Bumpass Hell, the largest of the park's hydrothermal areas.

images.altText: Two hikers sit on a mountain top with a view of multiple peaks, dotted with patches of snow
images.title: Brokeoff Panorama
images.caption: Over 150 miles of trails let you choose your adventure.

images.altText: A volcanic peak rises above a tree-lined, deep blue lake.
images.title: Deep Blue
images.caption: Lassen Peak stands out boldly between the bright blue sky and the sapphire hue of Lake Helen.

images.altText: A fisherman casts a line from a boat below a snow-dotted volcanic peak.
images.title: A Fisherman's Paradise
images.caption: Manzanita Lake offers spectacular catch-and-release fishing in the shadow of volcanoes.

images.altText: An ash cloud rises above a volcano with an early 19th century vehicle at the forefront.
images.title: Lassen Peak Eruption
images.caption: A large, explosive eruption of Lassen Peak brought national attention and set the stage for the establishment of Lassen Peak.

properties.directionsInfo: Gulf Islands National Seashore is a place of myriad riches - blue-green, sparkling waters, magnificent white beaches, and fertile coastal marshes.  Its 13 areas include historic forts, shaded picnic areas, trails, and campgrounds.  From Cat Island, Mississippi, it stretches eastward 160 miles tot he Okaloosa Area east of For Walton Beach, Florida.

entrancePasses.description: Covers all areas in Gulf Islands National Seashore charging an entrance fee until the end of the month one year after purchase. This pass can be purchased at the Fort Pickens Entrance Station, Perdido Key Entrance Station, and Davis Bayou Campground.
entrancePasses.title: Gulf Islands National Seashore Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Weather along the northern coast of the Gulf of Mexico can change quickly. During the winter temperatures range from 40-70 degrees fahrenheit, rain is less common than other seasons. Snow and freezing temperatures are not common. During the summer temperatures range from 70-100+ degrees fahrenheit. Rain is common during the summer with many thunderstorms. Hurricanes impact the area during the tropical storm season between June and November. Tornadoes can impact the area during the Spring and Fall.
properties.name: Gulf Islands
properties.description: What is it that entices people to the sea?  Poet John Masefield wrote, “I must go down to the seas again, for the call of the running tide is a wild call and a clear call that may not be denied.”  Millions of visitors are drawn to the islands in the northern Gulf of Mexico for the white sandy beaches, the aquamarine waters, a boat ride, a camping spot, a tour of an old fort, or a place to fish.

images.altText: A beach umbrella shades a chair as blue-green waves crash against a white sand beach.
images.title: Beach Scene
images.caption: A beach umbrella shades a chair as blue-green waves crash against a white sand beach.

images.altText: A room full of exhibits and displays about natural and cultural resources.
images.title: Fort Pickens Museum
images.caption: Visit the Fort Pickens Museum and learn more about the national seashore's awesome stories and resources.

images.altText: Two kayakers paddle toward the camera.
images.title: Kayaking at Gulf Islands National Seashore
images.caption: Experience the park from the water and see what makes Gulf Islands National Seashore so special.

images.altText: A brick fort stands on the edge of a white sand beach.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts is one of the four forts built in 1800s preserved by Gulf Islands National Seashore.

images.altText: A recently hatched turtle makes its way to the water from the beach.
images.title: Sea Turtles
images.caption: Gulf Islands National Seashore biologist study sea turtle to protect them and their habitats.

Estimated Project Time: January 2nd through May 9th, 2020. For more information on this project and subsequent road closures please visit https://www.nps.gov/pefo/planyourvisit/road-closures.htm

properties.weatherInfo: Petrified Forest National Park is a semi-arid grassland. Temperatures range from above 100° F (38° C) to well below freezing. About 10 inches (25.4 cm) of moisture comes during infrequent snow in the winter and often dramatic summer thunder-storms. Animals and plants are adapted to extremes in temperature and moisture. You should be ready too. Check out the forecast before you arrive and plan accordingly.
properties.name: Petrified Forest
properties.description: Did you know that Petrified Forest is more spectacular than ever? While the park has all the wonders known for a century, there are many new adventures and discoveries to share. There are backcountry hikes into areas never open before such as Red Basin and little known areas like the Martha's Butte. There are new exhibits that bring the stories to life. Come rediscover Petrified Forest!

properties.directionsInfo: The Dante Fascell Visitor Center may be reached from the Florida Turnpike by taking Exit 6 (Speedway Boulevard). Turn left from exit ramp and continue south to SW 328th Street (North Canal Drive). Turn left on 328th Street and continue for four miles to the end of the road. The park entrance is on the left just before the entrance to Homestead Bayfront Marina.

entrancePasses.description: No entrance fees.
entrancePasses.title: No entrance fees.

properties.weatherInfo: The park is situated in a subtropical climate, which ensures sunshine year-round. Winters are normally dry and mild, with occasional fronts bringing wind and little rain. Summer brings hot and humid weather with scattered thunderstorms in the afternoons. The average temperature in January is 68 degrees Fahrenheit and 82 in July. The average rainfall for the area is 2.17 inches in January and 3.95 inches in July. June to November is hurricane season.
properties.name: Biscayne
properties.description: Within sight of downtown Miami, yet worlds away, Biscayne protects a rare combination of aquamarine waters, emerald islands, and fish-bejeweled coral reefs. Here too is evidence of 10,000 years of human history, from pirates and shipwrecks to pineapple farmers and presidents. Outdoors enthusiasts can boat, snorkel, camp, watch wildlife…or simply relax in a rocking chair gazing out over the bay.

images.altText: Downtown Miami in background.
images.title: Boca Chita Key
images.caption: Boca Chita Key is the park's most popular island destination.

images.altText: The coral reefs are located mostly on the Eastern side of the park.
images.title: Coral Reef
images.caption: Biscayne National Park is 95% water.

images.altText: Green sea turtle
images.title: Green sea turtle
images.caption: Loggerhead, Green and Hawksbill turtles are all commonly observed in park waters.

images.altText: Aerial view of Totten Key.
images.title: Totten Key
images.caption: Biscayne National Park includes the northernmost Florida Keys.

images.altText: snorkeling is an easy-to-learn skill
images.title: Snorkeling
images.caption: Experience the park's shallow reefs up close and personal by snorkeling with some of the park's most colorful wildlife.

entranceFees.description:
An entrance fee of $10 per person (16 years of age and older) is required; entrance fees/passes permit 1-7 consecutive days of use in this national park..

Holders of the Annual, Senior, Military, 4th grade and Access Pass can bring in 3 adults free of charge under their pass. Any pass must be displayed in a vehicle while in the national park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Guadalupe Mountains National Park is located on the north side of US Hwy 62/180. 
If you are traveling east from El Paso, TX, we are 110 miles East of the city. Follow US Hwy 62/180 North to the Pine Springs Visitor Center. 
If you are traveling from Van Horn, TX, you will travel north on US 54 and make a left hand turn at the junction of US 62/180 to arrive at the park.
If you are traveling west from Carlsbad, NM, you will travel on US Hwy 62/180 South and cross into Texas. Follow signs to the park.

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for entrance into Guadalupe Mountains National Park for one year from the month of purchase. The pass admits up to four adults in a private vehicle and is non-transferable; visitors under 16 years of age are free. You can purchase this pass at the Pine Springs Visitor Center.
entrancePasses.title: Guadalupe Mountains National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Weather in the Guadalupe Mountains can change in an instant. In the Spring and Summer, average temperatures vary with highs between 70F-80F+ with evening lows in the 40F-60F range. The Fall and Winter bring milder temperatures with highs in between 50F-60F with evening lows in the 30F-50F range.
properties.name: Guadalupe Mountains
properties.description: Guadalupe Mountains National Park protects the world's most extensive Permian fossil reef, the four highest peaks in Texas, an environmentally diverse collection of flora and fauna, and the stories of lives shaped through conflict, cooperation and survival. Come experience mountains and canyons, desert and dunes, night skies and spectacular vistas within a place unlike any other within the NPS.

images.altText: El Capitan with blooming claret cup cacti
images.title: El Capitan
images.caption: Blossoming claret cup cacti add a splash of color to the Chihuahuan desert.

images.altText: Fall colors in Devil's Hall
images.title: Devil's Hall Fall Colors
images.caption: Changing maple trees line the Devil's Hall trail during the fall months.

images.altText: Pratt Cabin in McKittrick Canyon
images.title: Pratt Cabin
images.caption: Pratt Cabin is nestled in McKittrick Canyon with abundant trees and

images.altText: the slat flats become flooded during monsoon months after large rain events.
images.title: Flooded Salt Flats
images.caption: After the monsoon storms, the salt flats will often become flooded creating a seasonal lake.

images.altText: wildflowers blossom along The Bowl trail
images.title: The Bowl wildflowers
images.caption: During the spring months, wildflowers are a common sight along The Bowl trail.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to drive through or hike in the park. Enjoy!
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Half price for children 6-16 and for Senior (Golden Age)/Access pass holders. Children 5 and under are free.
entranceFees.title: Garden of Eden Cave Tour Fee

entranceFees.description: Half price for children 6-16 and for Senior (Golden Age)/Access pass holders. Children 5 and under are free.
entranceFees.title: Natural Entrance Cave Tour Fee

entranceFees.description: Half price for children 6-16 and for Senior (Golden Age)/Access pass holders. Children 5 and under are free.
entranceFees.title: Fairgrounds Cave Tour Fee

entranceFees.description:
Half price for children 8*-16 and for Senior (Golden Age)/Access pass holders. Reservations strongly recommended.

*Minimum age for Candlelight Tour is 8 years old.
entranceFees.title: Candlelight Cave Tour Fee

entranceFees.description: Half price Senior (Golden Age)/Access pass holders. Minimum age is 17. Reservations are required.
entranceFees.title: Wild Cave Tour Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Wind Cave National Park is located in South Dakota about 11 miles north of Hot Springs, or about 22 miles south of Custer, on US Highway 385. The park Visitor Center, where all cave tours begin, is approximately 1/2 mile west of the highway.
properties.weatherInfo:
Spring:  Highs range from 50 - 70 F with highly variable weather. Spring is the park's wettest season.

Summer:  Warm and generally dry with highs in the 80s F. Thunderstorms are common and can produce large hail and severe lightning. 

Fall:  Generally dry with warm days and cool nights. Highs in the 50s - 60s F. Lows below freezing are common.

Winter: Highs in the upper 30s F with lows in the 10s F. Snowfall averages 30 inches annually, periodically closing park roads.
properties.name: Wind Cave
properties.description: Bison, elk, and other wildlife roam the rolling prairie grasslands and forested hillsides of one of America's oldest national parks. Below the remnant island of intact prairie sits Wind Cave, one of the longest and most complex caves in the world. Named for barometric winds at its entrance, this maze of passages is home to boxwork, a unique formation rarely found elsewhere.

images.altText: a bison cow and calf on the prairie
images.title: Bison cow and calf
images.caption: Several hundred bison roam the rolling prairie of Wind Cave National Park.

images.altText: rolling hills of forest and prairie landscape
images.title: Rankin Ridge view
images.caption: Wind Cave National Park from Rankin Ridge, the park's highest point.

images.altText: criss-cross-patterned calcite fins of the cave feature boxwork
images.title: Boxwork
images.caption: Delicate fins of boxwork, a rare cave feature, in Elk's Room, Wind Cave.

images.altText: a caver with pads and helmet crawling in the cave
images.title: Wind Cave explorer
images.caption: Each summer, the Wild Cave Tour offers the chance to get up close and personal with Wind Cave.

images.altText: two prairie dogs watch from their burrow
images.title: Prairie Dogs
images.caption: Prairie dog sightings are common throughout the park's prairies.

entranceFees.description: None. there is no fee
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Free

properties.directionsInfo: Alagnak Wild River is located in a remote part of the Alaska Peninsula, about 290 miles southwest of Anchorage. Access is by boat or small floatplane.
properties.weatherInfo: Located between the stormy north Pacific Ocean and the even stormier Bering Sea, the Alagnak Wild River is often a battleground between weather systems. When you visit, be prepared to encounter all types of weather.  On average, wet and cool conditions predominate in spring, summer, and fall. Winters are drier and colder.
properties.name: Alagnak
properties.description: The headwaters of Alagnak Wild River lie within the rugged Aleutian Range of neighboring Katmai National Park and Preserve. Meandering west towards Bristol Bay and the Bering Sea, the Alagnak traverses the beautiful Alaska Peninsula, providing an unparalleled opportunity to experience the unique wilderness, wildlife, and cultural heritage of southwest Alaska.

images.altText: underwater photo of salmon swimming in river
images.title: salmon in Alagnak River
images.caption: Each summer, hundreds of thousands of salmon return to the Alagnak watershed to spawn.

images.altText: inflatable rafts on the edge of a river
images.title: Rafts along the river
images.caption: Rafting is a popular way to experience the river.

images.altText: aerial view of braided Alagnak River
images.title: Alagnak Wild River
images.caption: Alagnak River's lower reaches are extremely braided.

entranceFees.description: This fee includes all occupants of a private, non-commercial vehicle and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Per Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Fee applicable to one motorcycle; valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Fee applicable to one individual walking in or bicycling in and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Individual

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups with a vehicle capacity of 15 or less pay a per vehicle fee.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial groups with vehicle capacity 15 or less

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups with a vehicle capacity of 16 or more pay a $12.00 per person fee. Children 15 and younger are free. Annual and lifetime passes may be used.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial groups with vehicle capacity of 16 or more

entranceFees.description: $12 per client; passes may not be used. Business is required to obtain commercial use authorization. Bus tours, 25 person capacity or greater, $200 (commercial use authorization not required).
entranceFees.title: Commercial Group Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Several highways lead to Big Bend National Park: TX 118 from Alpine to Study Butte or FM 170 from Presidio to Study Butte (then 26 miles east to park headquarters) or US 90 or US 385 to Marathon (then 70 miles south to park headquarters). 

Distances between towns and services are considerable. Be sure you have plenty of gas, oil, food, and water for your trip.

entrancePasses.description: The Big Bend Annual Pass covers entrance fees to Big Bend National Park. Pass is available at Big Bend National Park entrance stations or the Panther Junction Visitor Center. Pass is non-transferable.
entrancePasses.title: Big Bend Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Variable
-- February through April the park abounds with pleasant and comfortable temperatures.
-- May through August is hot and can also be stormy. Temperatures regularly reach well over 100 degrees in the lower elevations and along the Rio Grande.
-- September through January temperatures are cooler; the weather can quickly turn cold at any time during these months.
properties.name: Big Bend
properties.description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and diversity of species is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...

images.altText: An ocotillo grows in the foreground and a pastel desert with bright green shrubs in the background
images.title: Desert Vista
images.caption: Desert Vista from Dorgan House

images.altText: Adult javelina, or collared peccary, and two young javelinas forage in a rocky area.
images.title: Javelina and Young
images.caption: A female javelina, or collared peccary, and her young, often called reds because of the color of their hair when very young.

images.altText: View of a river snaking through a desert landscape.
images.title: River Vista
images.caption: View of the Rio Grande River in Big Bend National Park.

images.altText: Two lane road disappears into the horizon in a desert landscape.
images.title: Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive
images.caption: Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive in Big Bend National Park

images.altText: Bright red claret cup cactus flowers bloom with a mountainous desert landscape in the background.
images.title: South Rim Vista
images.caption: South Rim Vista and Claret Cup Cactus

entranceFees.description: This per-vehicle fee covers all occupants of your vehicle for seven consecutive days and provides entrance into the NPS Monument.
entranceFees.title: NPS Monument Entrance Fee - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This per-person fee provides entrance into the NPS Monument for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: NPS Monument Entrance Fee - Per Person / bicycle or foot

entranceFees.description: When the Loop Drive is closed by snow access is available by snowshoe, ski or foot only. There is no entrance fee during this time period.
entranceFees.title: Winter Recreation Access

entranceFees.description: This motorcycle fee provides entrance into the NPS Monument for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: NPS Monument Entrance Fee - Motorcycle

properties.directionsInfo: Visitor Center and Loop Drive are located 18 miles southwest of Arco, Idaho on U.S. Highway 20/26/93, 24 miles northeast of Carey, Idaho on U.S. Highway 20/26/93, 84 miles from Idaho Falls, and 90 miles from Twin Falls. Physical address is 1266 Craters Loop Road(Lat/Long: 43° 27.711'N/113° 33.7) Access to the main visitor use area is via a paved highway. Unpaved roads provide additional access to the BLM monument and NPS Preserve but should only be utilized by four wheel drive and high clearance vehicles.

entrancePasses.description: This pass covers the entrance fees of the pass holder and up to three fellow travelers. It is valid for 365 days from date of purchase. Available in spring 2016.
entrancePasses.title: Craters Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Weather at Craters of the Moon is characterized by hot summers and cold winters. In February, average snow depth ranges from 26 inches at the north end of the monument to just 2 inches at the south end. Intense summer sun bakes the black lava, generating surface temperatures of 170 degrees Fahrenheit and air temperatures in the 90s. Drying winds are a daily occurence, especially in the afternoon, and may reach 15 to 30 miles per hour.
properties.name: Craters Of The Moon
properties.description: Craters of the Moon is a vast ocean of lava flows with scattered islands of cinder cones and sagebrush. We invite you to explore this "weird and scenic landscape" where yesterday's volcanic events are likely to continue tomorrow...

images.altText: moon behind volcanic cones
images.title: Volcanic Cones and Moon
images.caption: Craters of the Moon is out of this world!

images.altText: visitor exploring lava tube cave
images.title: Indian Tunnel
images.caption: The lava tube caves are fun to explore.

images.altText: hikers climbing a volcanic cone
images.title: Spatter Cone
images.caption: Craters of the Moon is famous for its well preserved spatter cones.

images.altText: Students follow a Ranger on a snowshoe walk.
images.title: Snowshoe Walk
images.caption: Craters of the Moon is a winter wonderland that is great for cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.

images.altText: Park Ranger in cave with visitors
images.title: Ranger Guided Walk
images.caption: A wide variety of Ranger guided activities are offered through out the year.

images.altText: Snowhoeing and crosscountry skiers
images.title: Winter Wonderland
images.caption: Snowhoeing and crosscountry skiers enjoy a winter wonderland.

addresses.line1: Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve
Craters of the Moon National Monument

properties.fullName: Craters Of The Moon National Monument & Preserve

entranceFees.description: This permit allows all persons traveling with the permit holder in one single private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) to leave and re-enter the park as many times as they wish during the 7-day period from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Death Valley Entrance Fee - per vehicle

entranceFees.description: This permit allows a single individual traveling on foot, motorcycle, or bicycle to leave and re-enter the park as many times as they wish during the 7-day period from the date of purchase. If the motorcycle or bicycle has more than one rider, each rider is charged the $10 fee.
entranceFees.title: Death Valley Entrance Fee - per individual

properties.directionsInfo:
The main road transecting Death Valley National Park from east to west is California Highway 190.
On the east in Nevada, U.S. Route 95 parallels the park from north to south with connecting highways at Scotty's Junction (State Route 267), Beatty (State Route 374), and Lathrop Wells (State Route 373).

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance to Death Valley for 12 months from the date of purchase
entrancePasses.title: Death Valley Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
AUTUMN arrives in late October, with warm but pleasant temperatures and generally clear skies.
WINTER has cool days, chilly nights and rarely, rainstorms. With snow capping the high peaks and low angled winter light, this season is especially beautiful for exploring the valley.
SPRINGTIME is the most popular time to visit Death Valley. Besides warm and sunny days, the possibility of spring wildflowers is a big attraction.
SUMMER starts early in Death Valley. By May the valley is too hot for most visitors
properties.name: Death Valley
properties.description: In this below-sea-level basin, steady drought and record summer heat make Death Valley a land of extremes. Yet, each extreme has a striking contrast. Towering peaks are frosted with winter snow. Rare rainstorms bring vast fields of wildflowers. Lush oases harbor tiny fish and refuge for wildlife and humans. Despite its morbid name, a great diversity of life survives in Death Valley.

images.altText: Morning light on the badlands below Zabriskie Point.
images.title: Zabriskie Point
images.caption: Zabriskie Point is a popular place to view sunrise over the badlands.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees to drive the scenic roads or highways in our three state parks and national park.
entranceFees.title: Redwood National Park and State Parks Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Day use fee. To be paid at the California State Park entrance kiosk at the southern end of Gold Bluffs Beach. State and federal passes will be honored.
entranceFees.title: Gold Bluffs Beach / Fern Canyon - Day Use & Vehicle Fees

entranceFees.description: Day use fee for vehicles parked next to the Smith River. State and federal passes will be honored.
entranceFees.title: Jedediah Smith Campground - Day Use & Vehicle Fees

properties.directionsInfo:
Redwood National and State Parks is located in northernmost coastal California - almost on the Oregon border. The parks are about 60-miles long, with four visitor centers from north to south.

We are a six to seven-hour drive (325 miles) north of San Francisco, a six-hour drive (330 miles) south of Portland, OR and a four-hour drive (170 miles) west of Redding, CA.
properties.weatherInfo:
Visitors should be prepared for cooler and damp weather. Dress in layers and expect to get wet.
Year-round temperatures along California's redwood coast: mid-40s°F (7°C) to mid-60s°F (18°C). 

Summer can be foggy, with highs occasionally reaching low 70s°F (20°C). 
Winters are cooler with considerable rain. October through April averages 60-80 inches of rain over the region.
properties.name: Redwood
properties.description: Most people know Redwood as home to the tallest trees on Earth. The parks also protect vast prairies, oak woodlands, wild river-ways, and nearly 40-miles of rugged coastline.  For thousands of years people have lived in this verdant landscape.  Together, the National Park Service and California State Parks are managing and restoring these lands for the inspiration, enjoyment, and education of all.

images.altText: Two visitors looking at tidepools.
images.title: Tide pooling at Enderts Beach

images.altText: Visitors chatting with a ranger above a river mouth.
images.title: Ranger Program at Klamath River Overlook
images.caption: Coastal overlooks provide amazing places to whale watch.. and more.

images.altText: Redwood trees line a narrow dirt road.
images.title: Howland Hill Road
images.caption: With a small car, you can expericne close-up Redwoods along a century old, narrow road.

images.altText: Visitors pose with one of the widest Redwood trees.
images.title: "Big Tree" wayside.
images.caption: For those short of time, the "Big Tree" offers easy access for all to a very photogenic tree.

images.altText: Rocks, rockpools and waves
images.title: Incoming Tide at  Redwood National Park
images.caption: 40 miles of coastline are part of Redwood National Park

images.altText: Five young women read the park map.
images.title: Visitors Plan Their Redwood Trip
images.caption: A great redwood trip starts with good trip planning.

images.altText: A ranger helps a father and son learn about being a junior ranger.
images.title: A New Junior Ranger
images.caption: Becming a junior ranger at Redwoods is fun and educational for the whole family.

images.altText: Three people stand on a walkway in the trees. It is foggy.
images.title: Visitors on walkway to Lady Bird Johnson Grove
images.caption: Visitors to the Lady Bird Johnson Grove cross a road using a walkway.

images.altText: Two adults and child look upwards into a forest
images.title: Family Enjoys the Redwoods
images.caption: Millions of people visit the park to enjoy the forests.

images.altText: Two adults talk with a park ranger under foggy trees
images.title: Ranger and Visitors in the Redwoods
images.caption: Park rangers help visitor learn about and safely enjoy the Redwoods.

images.altText: Two adults and a child stand next to a tree while a ranger nearby opens his arms wide.
images.title: How wide is that Redwood?
images.caption: The height and size of redwood trees can be hard to measure.

images.altText: Three adults stand and look curiously toward the tree tops
images.title: How Tall is that Redwood?
images.caption: From the forest floor we can only see about a third of any old redwood tree.

images.altText: Four adults stand on a trail surrounded by redwood trees
images.title: Having fun under the redwoods
images.caption: Taking a walk on the trail through redwood groves is great fun

images.altText: A tree stump is covered with plants.
images.title: Nurse Log
images.caption: A fallen redwood tree will be on the forest floor for centuries providing habitat for a new generation of plants and animals.

images.altText: View from forest floor looking straight up. Ferns as seen close up and redwood trunks meet.
images.title: Fish-eye view of Redwood canopy
images.caption: The redwood forest is a complicated and beautiful series of habitats.

images.altText: A small waterfall cascades past different trees
images.title: Trillium Falls
images.caption: The Trillium Falls trail is a popular, easy and family friendly walk.

images.altText: A trail meanders into a  grove of tall trees. A family is seen  at the far end of the trail.
images.title: A family walks in Stout Grove
images.caption: Redwood forests are wonderful places to walk, relax and look up.

images.altText: Fog surrounds tall redwoods on a trail. A park ranger stands in the distance.
images.title: Redwood Ranger in the mist
images.caption: Park Rangers help tell the stories and meanings of the park to visitors.

images.altText: A footbridge with people crosses a road on a foggy day
images.title: Footbridge to Lady Bird Johnson Grove
images.caption: Summer fog is frequent in the redwoods

images.altText: Waves run-up on a beach, and sea stack rocks are seen in the distance.
images.title: Coastline at Redwood National Park
images.caption: 40 miles of protected coastline are part of Redwood National and State Parks

entranceFees.description: With the exception of the entrance fee for Muir Woods National Monument and the cost of the ferry to visit Alcatraz Island, there is no fee to visit lands of Golden Gate National Recreation Area.
entranceFees.title: Visiting Golden Gate is free except for Alcatraz Island and Muir Woods National Monument.

properties.directionsInfo:
Golden Gate National Recreation Area has many sites that span over 60 miles of mostly coastal areas north and south of San Francisco. Park areas can be reached by Highways 1, 101 and 280 from the north and south San Francisco Bay Area, and by Highway 80 from the East Bay. 

To access park headquarters at Fort Mason, please use the entrance at Franklin and Bay Streets in San Francisco.
properties.weatherInfo: Winter is characterized by sporadic rain and cool weather punctuated by brilliant sunshine. In winter the grass greens. Trees and flowers dormant through winter start blooming in late February or early March and last until May or June. By July, summer fog predominates in most coastal areas of the park. Grasses and plants have now turned to the golden brown and muted grays characteristic of California summer and fall.  September and October skies are clear and sunshine is abundant everywhere in the park.
properties.name: Golden Gate
properties.description: Experience a park so rich it supports 19 distinct ecosystems with over 2,000 plant and animal species. Go for a hike, enjoy a vista, have a picnic or learn about the centuries of overlapping history from California’s indigenous cultures, Spanish colonialism, the Mexican Republic, US military expansion and the growth of San Francisco. All of this and more awaits you, so get out and find your park.

images.altText: Mori Point view north with yellow an blue flowers, the blue-green Pacific Ocean and Mt. Tamalpais.
images.title: Spring Flowers at Mori Point
images.caption: View north from Mori Point showing abundant spring flowers and Mt. Tamalpais in the background.

images.altText: View over the Pacific from Bolinas Ridge; Stinson Beach, Bolinas Lagoon and head in mid-ground.
images.title: Stinson Beach from Bolinas Ridge
images.caption: Bolinas Ridge offers outstanding panaramas of the Pacific Coast, here including Stinson Beach and Lagoon.

images.altText: Orange Golden Gate Bridge with waves crashing in foreground and storm clouds behind.
images.title: Storm over the Golden Gate
images.caption: The Golden Gate Bridge is an iconic attraction year-round.

images.altText: View south with family on road in foreground and Rodeo Beach and cove in front of Point Bonita.
images.title: Marin Headlands and Rodeo Beach
images.caption: Trails in the Marin Headlands offer a fun and spectacular hiking experience for all.

images.altText: Row of red brick barracks with white-columned porches where infantry soldiers lived.
images.title: Montgomery Street Barracks, Presidio of San Francisco
images.caption: The Presidio offers an outdoor museum of military architecture over the centuries.

images.altText: White buildings with red roofs at Crissy Field with blue bay and Golden Gate Bridge and fog behind.
images.title: Morning Fog at Crissy Field
images.caption: Visiting Crissy Field is an ever changing experience as the fog comes in and dissipates.

images.altText: Closeup shot of Alcatraz Island showing lighthouse and prison with yellow flowers on slope in front.
images.title: Alcatraz Island from Crissy Field
images.caption: Visitors can learn about the complex layered history of Alcatraz Island.
