properties.directionsInfo:
You can drive to Yosemite all year and enter via Highways 41, 140, and 120 from the west. Tioga Pass Entrance (via Highway 120 from the east) is closed from around November through late May or June. Hetch Hetchy is open all year but may close intermittently due to snow.

Please note that GPS units do not always provide accurate directions to or within Yosemite.

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance to Yosemite for 12 months from the date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Yosemite Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance and standard amenity fees for national parks and other federal fee areas, valid for 12 months from date of purchase. This replaces the National Parks Pass and Golden Eagle Pass.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful—National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Lifetime or annual admission and discount pass for US citizens or permanent residents who are age 62 or older. An annual version of this pass, valid for 12 months, costs $20.
entrancePasses.title: Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description: Lifetime admission and discount pass for US citizens or permanent residents with permanent disabilities.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance and standard amenity fees for all active US military personnel and their dependents, valid for 12 months from date of issuance. (For active duty military personnel and dependents with proper identification (CAC Card or DD Form 1173).)
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass for US Military

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance fees for 4th grade students for 2018–2019 school year.
entrancePasses.title: Annual 4th Grade Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Yosemite National Park covers nearly 1,200 square miles (3,100 square km) in the Sierra Nevada, with elevations ranging from about 2,000 feet (600 m) to 13,000 ft (4,000 m). Yosemite receives 95% of its precipitation between October and May (and over 75% between November and March). Most of Yosemite is blanketed in snow from about November through May. (Yosemite Valley can be rainy or snowy in any given winter storm.)
properties.name: Yosemite
properties.description:
Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra.

First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.

images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.
images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.caption: Cathedral Peak is one of the most recognizable peaks in the Yosemite Wilderness.

images.altText: A rainbow over a mountain in the distance.
images.title: Rainbow over Half Dome
images.caption: A hike up to Sentinel Dome rewards people with great views of the landscape around them.

images.altText: Mountains reflecting in water
images.title: Glen Aulin
images.caption: Glen Auilin is one of five High Sierra Camps, located in the Yosemite high country.

images.altText: Mountains surrounding a lake.
images.title: Tenaya Lake at Sunset
images.caption: Tenaya Lake is a favorite place to stop along the Tioga Road in summer.

images.altText: Glaciated valley with vertical cliffs.
images.title: Yosemite Valley from Tunnel View
images.caption: Tunnel View is perhaps one of the most photographed views in the park.

images.altText: Two tall waterfalls flowing down snow covered granite walls.
images.title: Yosemite Falls on a Winter Morning
images.caption: Yosemite Falls will sometimes only trickle at the end of summer, but wet winters can rejuvenate the flow.

images.altText: A waterfall flowing down a granite cliff.
images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.caption: The walk to Lower Yosemite Fall is a popular and easy hike.

images.altText: Granite dome with trace amounts of snow.
images.title: Half Dome
images.caption: Half Dome is one of the most recognizable granitic formations in the world.

images.altText: Massive cliff of El Capitan reflected in the Merced River
images.title: El Capitan
images.caption: El Capitan rises over 3,000 feet above the floor of Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: Cluster of tall trees with cloudy sky.
images.title: Giant Sequoia Trees in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
images.caption: Yosemite National Park's massive giant sequoias (Sequoiadendron giganteum) live in three groves in the park. The most famous of these is the Mariposa Grove, which contains about 500 mature giant sequoias.

images.altText: Very tall sequoia trees in a sequoia grove.
images.title: Giant Sequoia Tree
images.caption: Giant Sequoia trees are the largest living things (by volume) on the planet. Though not the tallest trees, one feels miniature in their presence..

entranceFees.description: Entrance to the park (visitor center and all trailheads) is free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
There are multiple trailheads around the park, so there is not one main entrance.
You can begin your visit at the visitor center, located off Mulholland Highway in Calabasas.
The Santa Monica Mountains are traversed by the 405 Freeway on the east side; crowned by the 101 Freeway on the north and west side; and Highway 1, the Pacific Coast Highway (PCH), on the southern ocean border.
properties.weatherInfo: Summers are hot and dry while winters are cool and wet.
properties.name: Santa Monica Mountains
properties.description: Hidden in plain sight from Los Angeles, the Santa Monica Mountains offer easy access to surprisingly wild places. Experience the famous beaches of Malibu or explore more than 500 miles of trails. The park abounds with historical and cultural sites, from old movie ranches to Native American centers. What will you and your family discover?

images.altText: Clouds between the mountains
images.title: Mountains
images.caption: Clouds between the mountains

images.altText: A large balanced rock with mountain ridges fading into the horizon.
images.title: Balanced Roack
images.caption: Hike to Balanced Rock along the Mishe Mokwa Trail, located near Circle X

images.altText: Looking up from within a traditional Chumash wood structure.
images.title: Chumash 'ap
images.caption: Visit the Satwiwa Native American Indian Cultural Center to stand under a traditional Chumash 'ap and walk through a native plant garden.

images.altText: A field of orange wildflowers with mountains in the background.
images.title: Native Wildflowers
images.caption: California poppy, Eschscholzia californica

images.altText: Man on a horse with a horse and carriage and building in the background.
images.title: Filming in the Santa Monica Mountains
images.caption: Getting ready to start filming for Booneville Redemption at Paramount Ranch's Western Town!

properties.fullName: Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area

phoneNumbers.description: This number will initially be answered by an automated attendant, from which one can opt to access a name directory, listen to recorded information about the park (i.e., directions to the park; visitor center hours of operation; weather forecast; fire danger information; shuttle bus system status; wildlife updates; ranger-led programs; seasonal events; etc.), or speak with a ranger. Please note that if you are calling between 4:30 pm and 10 am, park staff may not be available to answer your call.

emailAddresses.description: Please browse through this website (the Plan Your Visit section is very useful) and check out the Frequently Asked Questions before submitting your message. We receive a lot of emails requesting information that is available through our website. If you cannot find answers to your questions by browsing through our website, please feel free to send us an email. We will respond to emails in the order they are received. Due to the high volume of email, response to your message may take more than a week.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit Point Reyes National Seashore.
entranceFees.title: Point Reyes National Seashore Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Point Reyes is located along the west coast of California approximately 30 miles (50 km) north of San Francisco. Travelers may approach the park from the winding scenic Highway 1, either from the north or the south. Visitors can also reach the park via Sir Francis Drake Boulevard or the Point Reyes/Petaluma Road.
properties.weatherInfo: The moderating influence of the Pacific Ocean creates a climate with no great extremes of heat or cold. Any season can bring interesting weather during your visit to Point Reyes National Seashore. Come prepared!
properties.name: Point Reyes
properties.description: From its thunderous ocean breakers crashing against rocky headlands and expansive sand beaches to its open grasslands, brushy hillsides, and forested ridges, Point Reyes offers visitors over 1500 species of plants and animals to discover. Home to several cultures over thousands of years, the Seashore preserves a tapestry of stories and interactions of people. Point Reyes awaits your exploration.

images.altText: Point Reyes Lighthouse
images.title: Point Reyes Lighthouse
images.caption: Point Reyes Lighthouse

images.altText: Herd of Tule Elk on Tomales Point
images.title: Herd of Tule Elk on Tomales Point
images.caption: Herd of Tule Elk on Tomales Point.

images.altText: Hikers and horse riders on Bear Valley Trail.
images.title: Hikers and horse riders on Bear Valley Trail
images.caption: Hikers and horse riders on Bear Valley Trail.

images.altText: Pelican Lake
images.title: Pelican Lake
images.caption: Pelican Lake

images.altText: Photo taken at sunset looking south from Tomales Point with a large granite boulder on the left.
images.title: Sunset on Tomales Point
images.caption: Sunset on Tomales Point.

entranceFees.description: 7-day vehicle permit, admitting the passengers of a single, non-commercial vehicle on the day of purchase and for the next six days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: 7-day entrance permit, per motorcycle.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: 7-day entrance fee, per person on foot or bike.
entranceFees.title: Individual Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Per-person fee charged to non-commercial groups entering in a vehicle with a capacity of 16 passengers or more.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial Groups - Per Person

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-10, take exit 117 for CA Hwy 62 toward 29 Palms/Yucca Valley. This will allow you to access the West Entrance, the North Entrance, Black Rock, and Indian Cove.

Take exit 168 off I-10 to come in at the park's South Entrance.

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for 12 months from the month of purchase. It covers the entrance fee to Joshua Tree National Park for the pass signee and accompanying passengers entering in a single, non-commercial vehicle. Joshua Tree Annual Passes are available at park entrance stations and visitor centers.
entrancePasses.title: Joshua Tree National Park Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Days are typically clear with less than 25% humidity. Temperatures are most comfortable in the spring and fall, with an average highs around 85°F (29°C) and average lows around 50°F (10°C) respectively. Winter brings cooler days, around 60°F (15°C), and freezing nights. It occasionally snows at higher elevations. Summers are hot, over 100°F (38°C) during the day and not cooling much below 75°F (24°C) at night.
properties.name: Joshua Tree
properties.description: Two distinct desert ecosystems, the Mojave and the Colorado, come together in Joshua Tree National Park. A fascinating variety of plants and animals make their homes in a land sculpted by strong winds and occasional torrents of rain. Dark night skies, a rich cultural history, and surreal geologic features add to the wonder of this vast wilderness in southern California. Come explore for yourself.

images.altText: hiker looks over Hidden Valley
images.title: Hidden Valley Hiker
images.caption: Scrambling to the top of boulders in Joshua Tree can get you a great view.

images.altText: a fiery sky behind the silhouette of a Joshua tree
images.title: Joshua Tree Sunset
images.caption: The wide-open desert of Joshua Tree National Park makes for stunning sunsets.

images.altText: an historic wood house seen through the missing windshield of an old, rusty vehicle
images.title: Historic Keys Ranch
images.caption: The historic Keys Ranch can be visited only on a ranger-guided tour.

images.altText: night scene showing stars of the Milky Way over a sign saying "Entering Joshua Tree National Park"
images.title: Stars Over the Park Entrance
images.caption: Enjoy some of the darkest night skies in Southern California.

images.altText: a little girl smiles while wearing a Jr. Ranger hat and badge
images.title: Joshua Tree Junior Ranger
images.caption: Kids of all ages can take part in Joshua Tree National Park's Junior Ranger program.

images.altText: people climbing on boulders are silhouetted against a colorful sunset sky
images.title: Jumbo Rocks at Sunset
images.caption: Jumbo Rocks Campground is a fun place to explore the park's bouldered landscape.

images.altText: Joshua trees grow on a flat plain with boulder outcrops and mountains in the distance
images.title: Lost Horse Valley
images.caption: Take in views of the park's iconic Joshua trees and rock outcrops in Lost Horse Valley.

entranceFees.description: Mojave National Preserve does not charge a fee to enter the park
entranceFees.title: Mojave Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Note: There is no fuel inside the Preserve. Please fill up with gas BEFORE you enter.

Park headquarters in Barstow, California is 60 miles from the Preserve, and offers maps, a bookstore and information. Our main visitor center, Kelso Depot, is located inside the Preserve, 95 miles north of Barstow, and 90 miles south of Las Vegas, at the intersection of Kelso-Cima and Kelbaker Roads.

entrancePasses.description: Mojave does not charge a fee to enter the park
entrancePasses.title: Mojave Park Pass

properties.weatherInfo: Mojave Desert experiences change with the seasons. In winter, freezing temperatures and strong winds can be expected, with rain and snow in the mountains. With enough moisture, spring wildflowers may carpet the desert floor with vivid colors. Summers are hot, and temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit are typical. In summer, adventurers head for the higher elevations such as Mid-Hills and the New York Mountains. The cooler temperatures of fall mark hunting season.
properties.name: Mojave
properties.description: Singing sand dunes, cinder cone volcanoes, Largest Joshua tree forest, and carpets of spring wildflowers are all found within this 1.6-million-acre park. A visit to its canyons, mountains, and mesas will reveal long-abandoned mines, homesteads, and rock-walled military outposts. Located between Los Angeles and Las Vegas, Mojave provides serenity and solitude from major metropolitan areas.

images.altText: Spring wildflowers carpeting the desert floor
images.title: A desert road surrounded by spring wildflowers
images.caption: Many people visit Mojave in the spring season to view stunning wildflower displays.

images.altText: A lonely desert trail leads to tall sand dunes
images.title: Hiking Opportunities Abound
images.caption: Mojave has endless options for hikers. Kelso Sand Dunes are a popular trail in cooler months.

images.altText: A desert tortoise rest in the shade of a bush near some hikers
images.title: Desert Wildlife
images.caption: Mojave has a great diversity of wildlife. In spring and fall, the elusive desert tortoise can be seen foraging food.

images.altText: A man standing on a mountain peak in front of a wide desert landscape
images.title: Stunning Vistas
images.caption: Mojave is a hiker's paradise. With no less than 9 named mountain ranges int he park, there's no shortage of amazing views to be had.

images.altText: A Joshua tree seen though the window of an old miner's cabin
images.title: Rich Human History
images.caption: Visitors can still hear the echos of history here. Evidence of days long past still persist in Mojave. Native American petroglyphs, long-abandoned mines, and cattle ranches still dot the landscape.

entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling in a single vehicle for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument. You can purchase this pass in advance at www.yourpassnow.com.
entranceFees.title: Vehicle Pass

entranceFees.description: This entry fee is for a single person traveling on foot or by bicycle. It is valid for 1-7 days in Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Individual Entry Pass

entranceFees.description: Groups traveling in a bus or vehicle with a capacity of 16 persons or more are charged per person. People 15 years old or younger, drivers hired for transportation only, or anyone with a pass that may be used for park entry is exempt from paying the entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Non-Commercial Group

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of one or more people traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. This fee is based on the seating capacity of the vehicle and not the actual number of passengers. Passenger ages or entrance passes do not affect the price. The charge for vehicles with a seating capacity of 1-6 passengers is $25 plus $10 per person.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Group, 1-6 Passenger Capacity

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 7-15 people.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Group, 7-15 Passenger Capacity

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 16-25 people.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Group, 16-25 Passenger Capacity

entranceFees.description: This entrance fee is for commercial tours of vehicles with a seating capacity of 26 or more people.
entranceFees.title: Commercial group, 26+ Passenger Capacity

entranceFees.description: This pass is valid for 1-7 days and includes everyone traveling on a motorcycle, scooter, or similar motorized vehicle for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument. You can purchase this pass in advance at www.yourpassnow.com.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle Pass

properties.directionsInfo:
Two highways enter the parks. Hwy 180 from Fresno leads east to Kings Canyon National Park, then continues 30 miles east to Cedar Grove. Hwy 198 from Visalia leads east to Sequoia National Park via Three Rivers. Inside the parks, Highway 198 becomes the Generals Highway, which connects 198 to 180. 

Vehicles over 22-feet long should enter the parks via Highway 180.

In winter, the Generals Highway between the parks often closes. Chains may be required on park roads.

No roads cross these parks east to west.

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks and Hume Lake Ranger District of Sequoia National Forest/Giant Sequoia National Monument for one year from the month of purchase. The pass admits all passengers in a private vehicle and is non-transferable. You can purchase this pass in advance at www.yourpassnow.com.
entrancePasses.title: Sequoia & Kings Canyon Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Because of the extreme elevation range in these parks, weather conditions vary widely between areas. 

In summer, the sequoia groves have comfortable temperatures and the foothills are hot and dry. Snow lingers on high-mountain passes well into summer.

In fall, some areas close or reduce their hours. Winter brings snow to sequoia groves and rain to the foothills. Be prepared for tire chain requirements. 

Spring is a great time to hike in the foothills and snow begins to melt at higher elevations.
properties.name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon
properties.description: In response to guidance from the Tulare County Department of Public Health and for the health and safety of our visitors, employees, volunteers, and partners, Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks are temporarily closed until further notice. The National Park Service is working servicewide with federal, state, and local authorities to closely monitor the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.altText: A deep canyon with a forested floor and steep granite cliffs
images.title: Kings Canyon
images.caption: The Glaciers carved the Kings Canyon's steep granite cliffs, leaving a wide U-shaped valley.

images.altText: A steep granite slope leads from forest to a bare alpine landscape
images.title: The Tablelands
images.caption: Just above Lodgepole Valley, the trail to the Watchtower offers views above the treeline.

images.altText: A guardrail encircles people along a narrow walkway with wide views
images.title: Moro Rock
images.caption: A historic stairway leads to the top of Moro Rock, offering views from foothills to peaks

images.altText: A giant sequoia's reddish bark contrasts with the snow around it
images.title: Giant Sequoia in Winter
images.caption: For those who don't mind icy roads, winter offers stunning views of sequoias in snow.

images.altText: A rustic building is surrounded by giant sequoias
images.title: Giant Forest Museum
images.caption: Giant Forest Museum offers exhibits, park information, and a bookstore.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit the Channel Islands National Park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: While the mainland visitor center in Ventura is readily accessible by car or public transportation, the islands are only accessible by park concessionaire boats and planes or private boat. Advanced planning is highly recommended.
properties.weatherInfo: In general, the islands have a Mediterranean climate year-round. Temperatures are relatively stable, with highs averaging in the mid-60s (°F) and lows in the low-50s. However, there are seasonal differences that visitors should take into consideration when visiting the park. In addition, visitors also should be aware that ocean and weather conditions vary considerably from day-to-day and island-to-island. For more information visit: http://www.nps.gov/chis/planyourvisit/weather.htm
properties.name: Channel Islands
properties.description: Channel Islands National Park encompasses five remarkable islands and their ocean environment, preserving and protecting a wealth of natural and cultural resources. Isolation over thousands of years has created unique animals, plants, and archeological resources found nowhere else on Earth and helped preserve a place where visitors can experience coastal southern California as it once was.

images.altText: Steep, rugged ocean cliffs extending in an island chain.
images.title: Inspiration Point by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Inspiration Point, Anacapa Island: One of the most spectacular views in the park can be found from Inspiration Point. Looking to the west, one may see Middle and West Anacapa, with Santa Cruz Island in the distance.

images.altText: Yellow flowers in foreground extending out along a rocky coastline to a natural arch.
images.title: Arch Point by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Arch Point, Santa Barbara Island: With winter rains, the coreopsis emerges from summer's dormancy with light green foliage and bright yellow daisy-like flowers

images.altText: Pine tree high on a ridge overlooking a bay with blue water and white sand beach.
images.title: Torrey Pines by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Torrey Pines, Santa Rosa Island: Torrey pines occur naturally in only two locations throughout the world--on the cool, fog drenched northeastern slopes of Bechers Bay and just north of San Diego.

images.altText: Brown seals and sea lions on white sand beach with blue water and partly cloudy sky.
images.title: Point Bennet by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Point Bennet, San Miguel Island: One of the greatest concentrations of wildlife in the world occurs on San Miguel with over 100,000 pinnipeds gathering to breed, pup, and rest.

images.altText: Rust and grey colored fox in green grass.
images.title: Island Fox by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Island Fox, Santa Cruz Island: Thousands of years of isolation in a unique island environment has resulted in the development of the endemic island fox, a dwarf form of the mainland gray fox.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Aniakchak National Monument and Preserve
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Located on the Alaska Peninsula, 450 miles southwest of Anchorage, Aniakchak National Monument and Preserve is inaccessible by road. Notoriously bad weather makes access to Aniakchak unpredictable. Drop-offs and/or pick-ups may be significantly delayed.
properties.weatherInfo: When you visit, be prepared to encounter all types of weather. On average, wet and cool conditions predominate in spring, summer, and fall. Strong winds can delay the departure and arrival of boats and floatplanes.
properties.name: Aniakchak
properties.description: Given its remote location and challenging weather conditions, Aniakchak is one of the most wild and least visited places in the National Park System. This landscape is a vibrant reminder of Alaska's location in the volcanically active "Ring of Fire," as it is home to an impressive six mile (10 km) wide, 2,500 ft (762 m) deep caldera formed during a massive volcanic eruption 3,500 years ago.

images.altText: A lone raft floats the Aniakchak Wild River as it flows through the "Gates"
images.title: Floating the Gates of Aniakchak
images.caption: A lone raft floats the Aniakchak Wild River as it flows through the "Gates"

images.altText: Aerial shot of Aniakchak Caldera
images.title: Aniakchak Caldera
images.caption: Aerial shot of Aniakchak Caldera

images.altText: Black Nose, Aniakchak Caldera
images.title: Black Nose, Aniakchak Caldera
images.caption: Black Nose, Aniakchak Caldera

images.altText: Maar Lake, Aniakchak Caldera
images.title: Maar Lake, Aniakchak Caldera
images.caption: Maar Lake, Aniakchak Caldera

images.altText: The Gates of Aniakchak
images.title: The Gates of Aniakchak
images.caption: The Gates of Aniakchak

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter the preserve.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance

properties.directionsInfo:
The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located in Nome, AK. Nome, AK is not on the road system and may be reached via a commercial flight. The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located about a mile from Nome Airport. 

Bering Land Bridge National Preserve is located in the northern portion of the Seward Peninsula. There are no roads or trails into the parklands. Logistics on how to reach Bering Land Bridge is based on an individual’s resources and abilities.
properties.weatherInfo: Weather in the Seward Peninsula is generally characterized by long freezing winters and short, cool summers. Coastal areas typically have mild weather, while the interior has greater seasonal variation in temperature and precipitation.
properties.name: Bering Land Bridge
properties.description: Bering Land Bridge National Preserve lies at the continental crossroads that greatly influenced the distribution of life in the Western Hemisphere during the Pleistocene Epoch. It is a vital landscape for indigenous communities who depend on the land just as their ancestors did for many generations. It is a wild and ecologically healthy landscape unlike any other.

images.altText: Flock of shore birds taking flight
images.title: Flock of shore birds
images.caption: Flock of shore birds taking flight

images.altText: A hiker is seen in the distance as autumn colors dominate the tundra landscape.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: Autumn hike at Bering Land Bridge

images.altText: Three wet muskox stand in a line.
images.title: Wet Muskox
images.caption: Three wet muskox.

images.altText: Rolling sand dunes with sparse vegetation with full moon rising above.
images.title: Coastal Moon Rise
images.caption: Coastal moon rise

entranceFees.description: There is no fee required to visit Cape Krusenstern National Monument
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: Cape Krusenstern National Monument lies within a remote area of northwest Alaska and is bordered by the Arctic Ocean and Chukchi Sea.  Visitors generally access the monument via the regional hub in Kotzebue. Commercial airlines provide daily service from Anchorage to Kotzebue. Chartered flights with licensed air taxi services, booked in advance, can take backcountry travelers to remote destinations within the monument.
properties.weatherInfo: Snow, rain, and freezing temperatures can occur any time of the year. Always travel with good quality rain gear and warm layers. Be especially careful to stay dry. Hypothermia can set in on a windy, wet day, even when it doesn't feel that cold.
properties.name: Cape Krusenstern
properties.description: North of the Arctic Circle, the monument forms 70 miles of shoreline on the Chukchi Sea.  More than 114 beach ridges provide evidence of human use for 5,000 years.  The Inupiat continue to use the area today.  Vast wetlands provide habitat for shorebirds from as far away as South America.  Hikers and boaters can see carpets of wildflowers among shrubs containing wisps of qiviut from muskoxen.

images.altText: muskox standing on the tundra
images.title: Muskox and Geese
images.caption: Muskox and Greater White-fronted Geese on vegetated beach ridges in front of the Igichuk Hills.

images.altText: moon over snow covered hills
images.title: Winter Moon
images.caption: January light and a bright moon at 2 pm over the Igichuk Hills in Cape Krusenstern National Monument.

images.altText: aerial view of beach ridges
images.title: Beach Ridges on the Shore of Cape Krusenstern
images.caption: Beach ridges created by years of wave action during storms can be seen as parallel lines in the fall vegetation covering the old gravel. People have lived and traveled on this beach to hunt sea mammals for 5000 years.

images.altText: fish hanging on rack
images.title: Fish on a Drying Rack
images.caption: Pike (left right) and trout (middle) dry on a rack at a subsistence camp. The slash marks allow more air to circulate and dry the meat more quickly.

images.altText: archaeologist digging
images.title: Old House Uncovered
images.caption: A University of Washington archeology crew conducts research on an old semi-subterranean house along the beach ridges of Cape Krusenstern. Old house timbers are slowly revealed about 4 feet down

phoneNumbers.description: A ranger is available 9 am—4 pm daily (except on major holidays). If you get to the voicemail, please leave a message and we'll call you back as soon as we finish with the previous caller.

entranceFees.description:
Youth age 15 years or younger are free. 

For people age 16 or older: This fee provides the visitor a 7-day entrance permit. It is charged year-round.
entranceFees.title: Denali Entrance Fee—Per Person

properties.directionsInfo:
You can drive to Denali from Anchorage or Fairbanks, along Highway 3, which is known as the "George Parks Highway." Fairbanks is about 2 hours north, while Anchorage is 5 hours south of the Denali entrance. 

You can also reach Denali from either city via the Alaska Railroad, which is operated by the State of Alaska. A small private airstrip is also available near the park entrance for individuals wishing to fly their own small craft to the park.

entrancePasses.description:
This pass is valid for a year from the month of purchase (e.g., purchasing it in May of one year means it is valid until the end of May the following year).

The pass covers the cardholder plus up to three fellow-travelers. Up to two names can be written on the pass, meaning it can be used by either cardholder.
entrancePasses.title: Denali Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo:
Summer is typically cool and wet, with highs typically in the upper 50s to low 60s, and lows in the 40s. On occasion, summer highs reach the low 80s, though this is rare. Snow can fall any month of the year, so be prepared for chilly weather even in summer.

Fall colors emerge on the alpine tundra in August and in the low valleys in early September. Winter generally starts in mid-September, with temps often getting down to -40 by January. Spring is a short season in April / May, with highs above freezing.
properties.name: Denali
properties.description: Denali is six million acres of wild land, bisected by one ribbon of road. Travelers along it see the relatively low-elevation taiga forest give way to high alpine tundra and snowy mountains, culminating in North America's tallest peak, 20,310' Denali. Wild animals large and small roam unfenced lands, living as they have for ages. Solitude, tranquility and wilderness await.

images.altText: snowy mountains reflected in a pond
images.title: Denali and Reflection Pond
images.caption: Denali is the highest mountain in North America

images.altText: a vast white mountain looming over a brown landscape
images.title: View from Stony Overlook
images.caption: Many bus trips into Denali pause at Stony Overlook, which features a great view of Denali when skies are clear

images.altText: a white colored sheep standing on a mountainside overlooking a green valley
images.title: Dall Sheep
images.caption: Congress originally created Denali National Park (called Mount McKinley National Park, at the time) to protect wildlife, particularly Dall sheep

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Gates of the Arctic.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Gates of the Arctic is a wilderness park, with no roads or trails into the park lands, so visitors must fly or hike into the park. Access begins in Fairbanks, Alaska & there are several small airlines that provide daily flights into the communities of Bettles and Anaktuvuk Pass, and Coldfoot. Most visitors access the park by air taxi or hike in from the Dalton Highway or from the village of Anaktuvuk Pass. River crossings are necessary from both locations.
properties.weatherInfo: The climate of Gates of the Arctic National Park & Preserve is generally classified as arctic and sub-arctic, with exceptionally cold winters, relatively mild summers, low annual precipitation, and generally high winds. The weather is influenced by many different systems, and can change rapidly.
properties.name: Gates Of The Arctic
properties.description: This vast landscape does not contain any roads or trails. Visitors discover intact ecosystems where people have lived with the land for thousands of years. Wild rivers meander through glacier-carved valleys, caribou migrate along age-old trails, endless summer light fades into aurora-lit night skies of winter. It remains virtually unchanged except by the forces of nature.

images.altText: Alpenglow on the granite cliffs of mountains
images.title: Arrigetch Peaks
images.caption: A spring alpenglow brightens the granite walls of the Arrigetch Peaks

images.altText: Aerial view of the Alatna River as it winds through a valley
images.title: Alatna River
images.caption: Aerial view of the Alatna River as it winds through a valley

images.altText: A hiker crosses a stream with mountains in the background
images.title: Entering Oolah Valley
images.caption: A hiker crosses a stream and enters Oolah Valley.

images.altText: Handful of blueberries
images.title: Blueberries
images.caption: Pausing to pick blueberries can result in a handful of delicious snacks.

images.altText: Two hikers climb up a mountain pass
images.title: Hikers crossing a mountain pass
images.caption: Hikers choose river valleys as corridors when hiking over mountain passes.

properties.fullName: Gates Of The Arctic National Park & Preserve

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to enter Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve lies west of Juneau, Alaska, and can only be reached by plane or boat. The only road in the area merely connects the small town of Gustavus and its airfield to park headquarters at Bartlett Cove (10 miles). Alaska Airlines provides daily jet service from Juneau to Gustavus  in the summer months. Year-round scheduled air service is also provided by a variety of small air taxis and charters. The Alaska Marine Highway ferries also provide regular service from Juneau.
properties.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures average 50° to 60° F (10° to 15° C). Rain is the norm in lush southeast Alaska. It is best to be prepared to enjoy the park in any kind of weather, especially rain. Suggested clothing includes waterproof boots, rain gear, a hat, gloves, wool or pile layers or a warm coat. Good rain gear is essential here. April, May and June are usually the driest months of the year. September and October tend to be the wettest.
properties.name: Glacier Bay
properties.description: Covering 3.3 million acres of rugged mountains, dynamic glaciers, temperate rainforest, wild coastlines and deep sheltered fjords, Glacier Bay National Park is a highlight of Alaska's Inside Passage and part of a 25-million acre World Heritage Site—one of the world’s largest international protected areas. From sea to summit, Glacier Bay offers limitless opportunities for adventure and inspiration.

images.altText: Icebergs, calved from tidewater glaciers are a common sight in Glacier Bay National Park.
images.title: Iceberg on the shore
images.caption: Icebergs, calved from tidewater glaciers are a common sight in Glacier Bay National Park.

images.altText: Pan ice in Tarr Inlet
images.title: Pan ice in Tarr Inlet
images.caption: Glacier Bay offers a rare glimpse into the Ice Age

images.altText: Beachcombing Brown Bear
images.title: Beachcombing Brown Bear
images.caption: Brown bears frequently forage along the shoreline of Glacier Bay

images.altText: Sheltered waters of Glacier Bay
images.title: Sheltered waters of Glacier Bay
images.caption: Glacier Bay is a paradise for wilderness aficionados.

images.altText: Cruising Glacier Bay
images.title: Cruising Glacier Bay
images.caption: Passengers line the deck to enjoy the icy scene at Margerie Glacier

images.altText: Camping in the Glacier Bay backcountry
images.title: Camping in the Glacier Bay backcountry
images.caption: Glacier Bay provides endless possibilities for wilderness camping.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Katmai.
entranceFees.title: Katmai National Park and Preserve

properties.directionsInfo: Katmai National Park & Preserve is located on the northern Alaska Peninsula, northwest of Kodiak Island and southwest of Homer, Alaska. The park’s headquarters is in King Salmon, about 290 air miles southwest of Anchorage. Unlike most national parks in the United States, Katmai is almost exclusively accessed by plane or boat.

entrancePasses.description: No entrance passes are necessary to enter Katmai.
entrancePasses.title: None

properties.weatherInfo: Located between the stormy north Pacific Ocean and the even stormier Bering Sea, the Katmai region is often a battleground between weather systems. When you visit, be prepared to encounter all types of weather.  On average, wet and cool conditions predominate in spring, summer, and fall. Winters are drier and colder.
properties.name: Katmai
properties.description:
A landscape is alive underneath our feet, filled with creatures that remind us what it is to be wild.

Katmai was established in 1918 to protect the volcanically devastated region surrounding Novarupta and the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes. Today, Katmai National Park and Preserve also protects 9,000 years of human history and important habitat for salmon and thousands of brown bears.

images.altText: salmon jumping at waterfall
images.title: Salmon jumping at Brooks Falls
images.caption: Each year, 200,000 to 400,000 sockeye salmon jump Brooks Falls.

images.altText: Bear standing at the edge of a waterfall while a salmon is leaping towards it.
images.title: Bear catching jumping salmon
images.caption: In July, brown bears often stand on the lip of Brooks Falls to try to catch leaping salmon.

images.altText: Three bears walk near a sleeping bear
images.title: Bear family walks near sleeping bear
images.caption: Salmon streams in Katmai attract high numbers of brown bears.

images.altText: lake inside of an ash and glacier covered volcano
images.title: Mount Katmai caldera
images.caption: Mount Katmai's summit collapsed during the 1912 Novarupta-Katmai eruption. Today, the caldera is filled with a deep lake.

images.altText: meadow in foreground and snow capped volcanoes on the horizon
images.title: sedge meadows and volcanoes at Hallo
images.caption: Glacially clad volcanoes loom over the sedge meadows of Hallo Bay

entranceFees.description: No entrance fees are charged at Kenai Fjords National Park
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
Kenai Fjords National Park is located just outside the town of Seward in south-central Alaska, 126 miles south of Anchorage. Even though the park is often inaccessible during the winter months, Seward is accessible year-round via the Seward Highway, a National Scenic Byway.

Follow the Seward Highway (AK-1) south from Anchorage. It will become AK-9 around mile 35 (87 miles from Anchorage) with AK-1 heading to Homer and Kenai. Continue on AK-9 to Seward.
properties.weatherInfo:
The weather  Kenai Fjords is difficult to predict and can change rapidly. The area generally enjoys a relatively temperate maritime climate, primarily due to the influence of the Japanese current that flows through the Gulf of Alaska.

Summer daytime temperatures range from the mid 40s to the low 70s (Fahrenheit). Overcast and cool rainy days are frequent. Winter temperatures can range from the low 30s to -20.
properties.name: Kenai Fjords
properties.description: At the edge of the Kenai Peninsula lies a land where the ice age lingers. Nearly 40 glaciers flow from the Harding Icefield, Kenai Fjords' crowning feature. Wildlife thrives in icy waters and lush forests around this vast expanse of ice. Sugpiaq people relied on these resources to nurture a life entwined with the sea. Today, shrinking glaciers bear witness to the effects of our changing climate.

images.altText: aerial image of Bear Glacier
images.title: Bear Glacier Aerial
images.caption: Bear Glacier is the largest of nearly 40 glaciers that flow from the Harding Icefield.

images.altText: kayakers in front of a tidewater glacier
images.title: Aialik Bay Kayakers
images.caption: Kayakers enjoy the spectacular scenery in the fjords in Aialik Bay.

images.altText: a humpback whale breaches
images.title: Humpback Whale Breach
images.caption: A humpback whale breaches in Kenai Fjords National Park

images.altText: aerial view of Bear Glacier from Harding Icefield
images.title: Above Bear Glacier
images.caption: Flightseeing over the Harding Icefield provides amazing opportunities to view glaciers, like Bear Glacier, from a different perspective.

images.altText: visitors at accessible overlook of Exit Glacier and Exit Creek.
images.title: Exit Glacier View
images.caption: A stroll to Glacier View provides a nice overlook of Exit Glacier as part of a 1 mile accessible walk.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit Kobuk Valley National Park
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

properties.directionsInfo: Kobuk Valley National Park is very remote. There are no roads to provide access, so planes take care of most transportation needs.  Commercial airlines provide service from Anchorage to Kotzebue, or from Fairbanks to Bettles. Once in Kotzebue or Bettles, you must fly to the park with authorized air taxis.
properties.weatherInfo: Snow, rain, and freezing temperatures can occur any time of the year. Always travel with good quality rain gear and warm layers. Be especially careful to stay dry. Hypothermia can set in on a windy, wet day, even when it doesn't feel that cold.
properties.name: Kobuk Valley
properties.description: Caribou, sand dunes, the Kobuk River, Onion Portage - just some of the facets of Kobuk Valley National Park. Half a million caribou migrate through, their tracks crisscrossing sculpted dunes. The Kobuk River is an ancient and current path for people and wildlife. For 9000 years, people came to Onion Portage to harvest caribou as they swam the river. Even today, that rich tradition continues.

images.altText: sun setting on sand dunes
images.title: Kobuk Sand Dunes
images.caption: The setting sun casts shadows of black spruce on the dunes and colors the water of Ahnewetut Creek a deep blue. Sunlight on sand dunes and creek in shadow.

images.altText: aerial view of snow capped mountains
images.title: Mountains as Far as the Eye Can See
images.caption: The peaks of the Baird Mountains stretch far into the distance and are so remote that many of them have not been named. An aerial view on a clear fall day is a breathtaking sight.

images.altText: Caribou bone sitting in the sand
images.title: Left Behind
images.caption: Caribou migrate across the Great Kobuk Sand Dunes, heading north in the summer and south in the fall. Some survive and some don't, which is a sad reality of life

images.altText: Single caribou with antlers in velvet
images.title: Lone Rangifer tarandus
images.caption: A single caribou captured by a photographer on its fall migration south across Kobuk Valley National Park. Several hundred throusand in the Western Arctic Caribou Herd are doing the same thing.

images.altText: pink flower growing in sand
images.title: Kobuk Locoweed
images.caption: Oxytropis kobukensis (aka Kobuk Locoweed) is a member of the pea family and adds a splash of pink to the sand dunes. The blossoms have that typical pea/ bean flower shape that many gardeners know.

entranceFees.description:
You do not need to pay fees, make reservations, or obtain permits from the National Park Service for any recreational activities in the park including backpacking, camping, river running, bear viewing, or visiting Dick Proenneke's cabin.

Information regarding hunting and fishing license requirements, voluntary backcountry registration forms, and the permits commercial film crews or scientists conducting research and collecting items need to obtain are available on the Permits & Reservations page.
entranceFees.title: Lake Clark Entrance and User Fees

properties.directionsInfo: Lake Clark is located on the Alaska Peninsula southwest of Anchorage and north of Katmai National Park. It is not on the road system; therefore, in order to get here you must travel either via plane or by boat. A one to two-hour flight from Anchorage, Kenai, or Homer will provide access to most points within Lake Clark. Fixed-wing aircraft are allowed to land on all suitable lakes, rivers, beaches, gravel bars, and open ground in both the park and preserve unless the area is closed or otherwise restricted.

entrancePasses.description: No entrance passes are necessary to enter Lake Clark National Park and Preserve.
entrancePasses.title: None

properties.weatherInfo: Lake Clark has two distinct climate areas: the coast and the interior. The coast is wetter and experiences milder temperatures. The interior gets half to one fourth as much precipitation, but temperatures are hotter in summer and colder in winter.  Frost and snow can occur any time parkwide, but are most common from September to early June. Lakes here typically begins freezing in November and melting in April. Ice conditions dictate whether planes need floats or skis to land on lakes.
properties.name: Lake Clark
properties.description: Lake Clark National Park and Preserve is a land of stunning beauty. Volcanoes steam, salmon run, bears forage, and craggy mountains reflect in shimmering turquoise lakes. Here, too, local people and culture still depend on the land and water. Venture into the park to become part of the wilderness.

images.altText: Underwater photo of one sockeye salmon in spawning colors with bright red body and green head.
images.title: Sockeye Salmon
images.caption: Lake Clark National Park and Preserve protects critical spawning and rearing habitat at the headwaters of the world’s most productive sockeye salmon fishery.

images.altText: Forest of spruce trees blanketed in snow and fog.
images.title: Boreal Forest
images.caption: Boreal forests encircle the earth's northern latitudes like an emerald necklace. Lake Clark's forest, which covers more than 440 thousand acres or 11% of the park,  is dominated by white spruce mixed with black spruce and birch.

images.altText: photo of large alpine glacier
images.title: Tanaina Glacier
images.caption: Perenial snow and glacial ice covers ~1,250 square miles, or 20% of Lake Clark National Park and Preserve.

images.altText: Photo of blue sky with fluffy white clouds reflect in calm lake with mountains in the background.
images.title: Lake Clark
images.caption: The park's namesake lake is the largest lake by volume in the National Park Service.

images.altText: Photo of a stratovolcano flanked with glaciers towering over a river valley.
images.title: Redoubt Volcano
images.caption: Lake Clark is a land of fire and ice. Active volcanism and retreating glaciers created and continue to shape the peaks, moraines, and river systems in the Chigmit and Neacola Mountains.

images.altText: Photo of a one story log cabin, cache, forest, and American flag reflecting in a calm, blue lake.
images.title: Richard L. Proenneke National Historic Site
images.caption: The park protects and interprets the Richard L. Proenneke National Historic Site and trail complex as a symbol of the national wilderness movement and a source of inspiration and solace sought out by visitors from throughout the world.

images.altText: Waterfall surrounded by forest in fall foiliage and mountains in the background.
images.title: Tanalian Falls
images.caption: The park protects thousands of waterfalls including Tanalian Falls, which is a popular day hike destination from the town of Port Alsworth.

images.altText: Photo of a river delta flowing into tidal flats surrounded by green salt marshes and mountains.
images.title: West Glacier Creek
images.caption: Estuaries where rivers meet the sea provide a mosaic of rich habitats along the Cook Inlet Coast that support high numbers of bears and other wildlife.

images.altText: A colorful sky, an island with spruce trees, and mountains in the background reflect in a calm lake
images.title: Telaquana Lake
images.caption: A number of glacier fed lakes pepper the western boundary of the Chigmit and Neacola mountains like a string of spectacular turquoise gems.

images.altText: Photo of an alpine valley with fuchsia-colored flowers surrounded by tall mountains.
images.title: Wilderness
images.caption: Lake Clark National Park and Preserve manages over 2 million acres of designated Wilderness and another 2 million acres of undeveloped, wild landscapes, providing visitors with superlative opportunities for solitude, challenge, and self-reliance.

images.altText: two brown bear cubs playing in the sedges
images.title: Two cubs playing at Silver Salmon Creek
images.caption: Bear viewing is a popular activity along the Cook Inlet Coast.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to visit Noatak National Preserve
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

properties.directionsInfo:
Noatak National Preserve is a very remote area. There are no roads that provide access. 

Commercial airlines provide service from Anchorage to Kotzebue or Fairbanks to Bettles. Once in Kotzebue or Bettles, you must fly to the preserve with various air taxi operators. There are scheduled flights to villages and chartered flights to remote park areas. Summer access may include motorized/non-motorized watercraft, aircraft, or by foot.
properties.weatherInfo: Snow, rain, and freezing temperatures can occur any time of the year. Always travel with good quality rain gear and warm layers. Be especially careful to stay dry. Hypothermia can set in on a windy, wet day, even when it doesn't feel that cold.
properties.name: Noatak
properties.description: As one of North America's largest mountain-ringed river basins with an intact ecosystem, the Noatak River environs features some of the Arctic's finest arrays of plants and animals. The river is classified as a national wild and scenic river, and offers stunning wilderness float-trip opportunities - from deep in the Brooks Range to the tidewater of the Chukchi Sea.

images.altText: green northern lights
images.title: Nightime Extravaganza
images.caption: A huge spray of northern lights is reflected in a tiny sliver of water in the Noatak River. This image was captured in early September at 2:30 in the morning.

images.altText: Light and shadows on mountains
images.title: Golden Hour
images.caption: The famous golden hour near sunset on Copter Peak gives depth to the mountains and neon hues to the tundra.

images.altText: mountain refection on calm lake
images.title: Mirror Image
images.caption: The Delong Mountains are flawlessly reflected in the clear, clean water of Desperation Lake in the northern part of Noatak National Preserve.

images.altText: bear walking along river
images.title: Grizzly on the Noatak River
images.caption: The profile of this grizzly on the Noatak River shows a nice example of the hump of muscle between it's shoulders. That muscle makes grizzlies good diggers.

images.altText: small plane taking off
images.title: Scout Leaving Kelly Bar
images.caption: A National Park Service plane takes off from the Kelly Bar landing site at the confluence of the Kelly River and Noatak River

entranceFees.description: Fee free park
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The administrative building and main park visitor center are located along the Richardson Highway (Hwy 4), which is a paved state highway that runs through Copper Center, AK. The buildings are 8 miles south of the Glenn Highway and Richardson Highway intersection near Glennallen, Alaska.  This is approximately 200 miles east of Anchorage, AK and 250 miles south of Fairbanks, AK.
properties.weatherInfo: Varies widely depending on location in park and time of year.  Visit http://www.nps.gov/wrst/planyourvisit/weather.htm for detailed information.
properties.name: Wrangell - St Elias
properties.description: Wrangell St. Elias is a vast national park that rises from the ocean all the way up to 18,008 ft. At 13.2 million acres, the park is the same size as Yellowstone National Park, Yosemite National Park, and Switzerland combined! Within this wild landscape, people continue to live off the land as they have done for centuries. This rugged, beautiful land is filled with opportunities for adventure.

images.altText: Two backpackers sitting in an alpine meadow with snowy mountains in the background
images.title: Backpackers in Mentasta Mountains
images.caption: Wrangell-St. Elias National Park is a backpacker's paradise.  A variety of routes take you into beautiful country, including the Mentasta Mountains.

images.altText: Glaciers loom over the ocean with large snowy mountains rising into blue skies
images.title: Icy Bay with Mt. St. Elias
images.caption: Wrangell-St. Elias National Park contains a diversity of natural features.  Landscapes unique to the North American continent are common here.

images.altText: Historic, large, red buildings with mountains in the background
images.title: Kennecott Mill Town
images.caption: Kennecott Mines National Historic Landmark is found within Wrangell-St. Elias National Park.  This early 1900's copper mining operation overcame numerous challenges and found success in the heart of the Alaskan wilderness.

images.altText: A large glacier with stripes of different colored rock nestled in between barren mountain slopes.
images.title: Logan Glacier
images.caption: Wrangell-St. Elias National Park contains the greatest concentration of glaciers in North America.  More than 3000 glaciers covering over three million acres of land are found in the park.

images.altText: Four large snow covered mountains rise above dense forest into blue skies.
images.title: Wrangell Mountains
images.caption: The Wrangell Mountains dominate the view of the northern half of the park.   This range lies entirely within the park and reaches 16,390 ft (4,996 m) in height.

properties.fullName: Wrangell - St Elias National Park & Preserve

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: Although there is no direct highway connection to Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve, visitors are able to access the preserve by either air travel from Fairbanks, or water or air travel from two small towns on the road system(Eagle and Circle), near the preserve boundaries.
properties.weatherInfo: The area that Yukon-Charley Rivers encompasses is generally classified as sub-arctic, with exceptionally cold winters, relatively warm summers, low annual precipitation, and generally high winds.
properties.name: Yukon - Charley Rivers
properties.description: Located in Interior Alaska, Yukon-Charley Rivers offers exploration in a largely untouched landscape. Whether you float the mighty Yukon River or paddle the Charley River's whitewater, your memories will last a lifetime. Geology, cultural history, gold rush remnants, wildlife, and vast scenery will be a part of your experience. But, the strongest element will be solitude. Your adventure awaits.

images.altText: Aerial view of the Yukon River showing fall colors
images.title: Aerial view of the Yukon River
images.caption: The Yukon River is a vast body of water that has carved its path into the landscape over millions of years.

images.altText: Historic Coal Creek Dredge
images.title: Coal Creek Dredge
images.caption: The historic Coal Creek Dredge sits nonoperational at its original site, near Slaven's Roadhouse

images.altText: Eagle Visitor Center in front of Eagle Bluff
images.title: Eagle Visitor Center
images.caption: The Eagle Visitor Center sits atop a small bluff overlooking the Yukon River.

entranceFees.description: The Appalachian National Scenic Trail (NST) does not charge an entrance fee for use of the trail on Appalachian NST land.
entranceFees.title: Appalachian National Scenic Trail Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: There are many points of access along the Appalachian Trail, whether it is by car, train, bus or plane. For more detailed directions, please refer to the "Directions" section of our park webpage.
properties.weatherInfo: It is your responsibility to be prepared for all weather conditions, including extreme and unexpected weather changes year-round. As the trail runs from Georgia to Maine there will be different weather conditions depending on your location. For weather along specific sections of the trail and at specific shelters, please refer to: http://www.atweather.org/
properties.name: Appalachian
properties.description: The Appalachian Trail is a 2,180+ mile long public footpath that traverses the scenic, wooded, pastoral, wild, and culturally resonant lands of the Appalachian Mountains. Conceived in 1921, built by private citizens, and completed in 1937, today the trail is managed by the National Park Service, US Forest Service, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, numerous state agencies and thousands of volunteers.

images.altText: Silhouette of a man with backpack standing on McAfee Knob at sunset with mountains in the distance.
images.title: McAfee Knob
images.caption: McAfee Knob is one of the most popular locations along the A.T. to take photographs.

images.altText: The Appalachian Trail runs across a mountain ridge line with views to the horizon of mountain range.
images.title: Appalachian Trail
images.caption: Crossing into thirteen states, hikers experience a variety of scenery along the way.

images.altText: A white blaze marks a tree in the foreground, with a man and child walking away on the wooded trail.
images.title: The Infamous White Blaze of the A.T.
images.caption: The white blaze marks the Appalachian Trail as a way for hikers to identify the route.

images.credit: Photo Credit: Maine Appalachian Trail Club
images.altText: A volunteer is carrying a split log while walking across a wooden footbridge in the woods.
images.title: Volunteer on the A.T.
images.caption: The Appalachian Trail is maintained largely by volunteers.

images.altText: A snowy winter view from the A.T. overlooking snowy mountains and clouds in the distance.
images.title: Winter on the A.T.
images.caption: Hikers can experience many seasons along the A.T. all year round. It is important to be prepared.

entranceFees.description: No Fee Required
entranceFees.title: No Fee Required

properties.directionsInfo:
From Baltimore and Points North:
Take the Baltimore-Washington Parkway south to US Route 50 west (which becomes New York Avenue). Take New York Avenue to Massachusetts Avenue and continue west. Turn right onto 13th Street. Go one block and turn left onto 'N' Street. Go another block and turn right onto Vermont Avenue. 1318 is one half block up the street on the left. Street parking is limited and restricted. Please read the street signs carefully.

entrancePasses.description: No Pass Required
entrancePasses.title: No Pass Required

properties.weatherInfo:
Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30 to 50 F. There is occasional snow.

Spring: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Rain is common.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70 to 90 F. Humidity is usually high. Be prepared and drink plenty of water. There is a water fountain in the visitor center.

Fall: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Humidity can remain high in the earlier part of the season.
properties.name: Mary McLeod Bethune Council House
properties.description: Mary McLeod Bethune achieved her greatest recognition at the Washington, DC townhouse that is now this National Historic Site. The Council House was the first headquarters of the National Council of Negro Women (NCNW) and was Bethune’s last home in Washington, DC. From here, Bethune and the NCNW spearheaded strategies and developed programs that advanced the interests of African American women.

images.altText: MAMC
images.title: Mary McLeod Bethune Council House National Historic Site
images.caption: Bethune Council House in Spring time full bloom!

addresses.line1: Mary McLeod Bethune Council House National Historic Site

properties.fullName: Mary McLeod Bethune Council House National Historic Site

entranceFees.description: National Capital Parks-East is located in Anacostia Park, which is fee free.
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

properties.directionsInfo:
DC295 South to the Exit for I-694/I-395/Capitol Hill then a left Exit 4B to 11th St SE/MLK Jr Ave.  Turn Left at light onto 11st/MLK JR. **

I-295 North to Exit 4B to 11th St SE/MLK Jr Ave.  Turn Right at the light.  **

From downtown DC: I-395 to I-695/SW Freeway, take Exit 1C 11th St SE. Turn Right onto 11th St **

** At the  light turn Right onto Good Hope Road.  At the Stop Sign turn Left.  Turn Left at the next road way.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit, high humidity, and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. 
Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. 
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
properties.name: National Capital Parks-East
properties.description: Welcome to National Capital Parks-East. We invite you to journey to parks Beyond the Capital of Washington, D.C.  National Capital Parks-East is 13 park sites, parkways and statuary covering more than 8,000 acres of historic, cultural, and recreational parklands from Capitol Hill to the nearby Maryland suburbs

images.altText: The red barns and outbuildings at Oxon Hill Farm
images.title: Oxon Cove Park
images.caption: The Barnyard at Oxon Hill Farm

images.altText: Photo of the outside of the Mary McLeod Bethune Council House
images.title: Mary McLeod Bethune National Historic Site
images.caption: Mary McLeod Bethune Council House in Washington D.C.

images.altText: Cars driving on the Baltimore0Washington Parkway
images.title: Baltimore-Washington Parkway
images.caption: Baltimore-Washington Parkway is managed by National Capital Park-East

images.altText: Image of a three red and white water lilies.
images.title: Kenilworth Aquatic Gardens
images.caption: Water lilies that can be found at Kenilworth Aquatic Gardens

images.altText: Photo of Cedar Hill, home of Frederick Douglass
images.title: Frederick Douglass National Historic Site
images.caption: Cedar Hill, Frederick Douglass' Washington D.C. home.

images.altText: Image of Still Creek running through the trees at Greenbelt Park.
images.title: Greenbelt Park
images.caption: Still Creek at Greenbelt Park

images.altText: Hundreds of audience member watching the Summer Theater program at Fort Dupont.
images.title: Fort Dupont
images.caption: Summer Theater is an annual event at Fort Dupont Park.

images.altText: A photo of the Urban Tree House.  The tree house is a wooden outline of the United States.
images.title: Anacostia Park
images.caption: The tree house is a wooden outline of the United States.  Used as an outdoor classroom.

images.altText: Photo of the parade ground inside the historic fort.
images.title: Fort Washington Park
images.caption: Fort Washington's parade ground facing the main entrance.

images.altText: Photo of Accokeek Creek Site, as the fog rises in the early morning.
images.title: Piscataway Park
images.caption: Accokeek Creek Site is a part of Piscataway Park.  The boardwalk takes you over the wetlands.

entranceFees.description: f=Fee Free
entranceFees.title: Fort DuPont Park

properties.directionsInfo:
No physical address. Best address to use is as follows;
3600 F Street SE Washington D.C.

entrancePasses.description: No passes required.
entrancePasses.title: Fort DuPont Park

properties.name: Fort Dupont Park
properties.description: Welcome to Fort Dupont Park in Washington DC! At 376-acres, the wooded park was once home to earthen fort built to protect the capital during the Civil War. Today, visitors can see the fort's earthworks and escape to the great outdoors. Activities include picnics, nature walks, biking, gardening, environmental education, music, and ranger-led programs.

images.altText: Fort during fall hike
images.title: Fort DuPont Park
images.caption: FODU

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Visitors can reserve tickets for guided tours of the historic house.
entranceFees.title: House Tour Reservation

properties.directionsInfo: The site can be reached by car, public transportation, or on foot. See the directions page of the website for more detailed information.
properties.weatherInfo:
Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30 to 50 F. There is occasional snow.

Spring: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Rain is common.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70 to 90 F. Humidity is usually high. Be prepared and drink plenty of water. There is a water fountain in the visitor center.

Fall: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Humidity can remain high in the earlier part of the season.
properties.name: Frederick Douglass
properties.description: Frederick Douglass spent his life fighting for justice and equality. Born into slavery in 1818, he escaped as a young man and became a leading voice in the abolitionist movement. People everywhere still find inspiration today in his tireless struggle, brilliant words, and inclusive vision of humanity. Douglass's legacy is preserved here at Cedar Hill, where he lived his last 17 years.

images.altText: Visitors take photos in front of a historic house
images.title: Cedar Hill
images.caption: Rangers guide daily tours of the historic house at scheduled times.

images.altText: A tiny stone cabin surrounded by fall foliage
images.title: The Growlery
images.caption: Frederick Douglass retreated to this stone cabin to read, write, and think in seclusion.

images.altText: View of downtown Washington, D.C., including the Washington Monument and U.S. Capitol
images.title: View of Washington, D.C.
images.caption: Frederick Douglass's view from Cedar Hill continues to impress visitors today.

images.altText: A plaster bust of Frederick Douglass
images.title: Bust of Frederick Douglass
images.caption: Hundreds of original objects, such as this bust, furnish the historic house.

entranceFees.description:
Great Falls Park Vehicle Permit ($10)
Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit. Is NOT valid for entrance into the C &O Canal National Historic Park.

Great Falls Park Individual Permit ($5)
Admits one individual when entering by foot, bicycle, or equestrian. Individuals 15 years old and younger are admitted free of charge. Is NOT valid for entrance into the C &O Canal National Historic Park
entranceFees.title: Great Falls Park, VA

properties.directionsInfo:
Directions to Parkway Headquarters
From the south, take the George Washington Memorial Parkway north. Just past the CIA exit turn right into the parking lot for the US Park Police and parkway headquarters. Go through the chain link fence and take an immediate right. Follow the road down to a stop sign and turn right into the parking lot for the headquarters building.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers on the parkway are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning.
Winters on the parkway are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. Please be alert for snowplows and icy spots on roadways.
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
properties.name: George Washington
properties.description: The George Washington Memorial Parkway was designed for recreational driving. It links sites that commemorate important episodes in American history and preserve habitat for local wildlife. The parkway and its associated trails provide a scenic place to play and rest in the busy Washington, DC metropolitan area.

images.altText: A view of the Parkway
images.title: George Washington Memorial Parkway
images.caption: A beautiful drive

entranceFees.description: Oxon Cove Park & Oxon Hill Farm does not have an admission fee. All programs are free and open to the public unless otherwise indicated.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

properties.directionsInfo: While our mailing address is on Oxon Hill Road, the parking lot entrance to the park is on Bald Eagle Road.  Bald Eagle Road can be accessed from the Capital Beltway (I-495/I-95), as well as Indian Head Highway (MD-210) and Oxon Hill Road (MD-414).  For detailed directions, please visit our website at http://www.nps.gov/oxhi/planyourvisit/directions.htm
properties.weatherInfo:
Make sure that you wear appropriate shoes and clothing. Closed-toe shoes are recommended, sneakers or comfortable boots are best. Dress for the season, light clothes in summer, layers in spring and fall, and warm coats in winter.

Cooler days are often the best days to visit Oxon Hill Farm if you’re interested in seeing farm animals or wildlife out and about. There are still lots of things to see and do on hotter days, just make sure to keep hydrated and take frequent breaks.
properties.name: Oxon Cove  Park & Oxon Hill Farm
properties.description: The diverse history of Maryland and our national heritage can be experienced at Oxon Cove Park. Through hands-on programs and other activities, you can experience farm life and how its changed over time.  Explore how the park evolved from a plantation home during the War of 1812, to a hospital farm, to the park you can visit today.

properties.directionsInfo: The National Colonial Farm:  From the Capital Beltway (I495/95) from southbound take Exit 3, to MD210 South/Indian Head Highway.  Travel approximately 9 miles, at the traffic light by B&J Carryout turn right on Livingston Road (please note that Livingston Road crosses MD210 several times)  Drive one block and turn right on Biddle Road.  At the stop sign, turn left on Bryan Point Road and follow about 3.5 miles.  National Colonial Farm will be on the right.

properties.name: Piscataway
properties.description: Piscataway Park is home to bald eagles, beavers, deer, foxes, ospreys, and many other species. To complement the surroundings, the park has, in addition to a public fishing pier and two boardwalks over fresh water tidal wetlands, a variety of nature trails, meadows, and woodland areas. The Park is also home to National Colonial Farm.

properties.directionsInfo:
Off I-95 South
Take Exit 23 Route 201 Kenilworth Avenue South(toward Bladensburg). (this will be a left). Drive on Kenilworth Avenue (Route 201). Once crossing over I-95, you will see sign for Route 193 Greenbelt Road. Veer right to Take Route 193 East.
Take a left on Greenbelt Road .
(Greenbelt Road is Route 193 and is an overpass over Route 201) 
The park entrance is a quarter mile on the right hand side.
properties.weatherInfo:
The Washington, D.C. area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. 
Spring: During these months of transition, the weather can alternate from warm, humid air coming from the south to cold, dry air coming from the northwest. Be prepared for changing conditions.
Summer: The warmest months are June, July, and August, with average highs in the 80s (~31 ?) combined with high humidity. 
Fall: Expect a drop in temperature and humidity in September

Greenbelt Park is located in suburban Greenbelt, Maryland.

Greenbelt Park has a 174 site campground, nine miles of trails and three picnic areas.

entranceFees.title: President's Park

properties.directionsInfo: The White House is located in downtown Washington, DC, directly north of the Washington Monument. The park boundaries are between 17th and 15th Streets NW on the east and west and between Constitution Ave NW and H St NW on the north and south. The nearest Metro stations are Farragut North/South, McPherson Square, and Federal Triangle. The park visitor center is located at 15th St. & Pennsylvania Ave.
properties.weatherInfo:
The Washington, DC, area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. Precipitation averages 2-4” monthly, year-round. 

The warmest months are June, July, and August, with average highs in the 80s (~31) combined with high humidity.  Temperatures often climb into the 90s (~34).
The coldest months are December, January, and February, with average temperatures in the 30s (~3), though lows may dip into the single digits on occasion.
properties.name: President's Park (White House)
properties.description: Every president except George Washington has called the White House and its surrounding grounds his place of work, rest, and solitude. Recognizable around the world, the White House stands as a symbol of democracy. The White House and its park grounds serve not only as the seat of the executive branch of government of the United States of America, but also as an iconic place for civil discourse.

images.altText: The White House and South Lawn.
images.title: White House - Truman Balcony
images.caption: The White House and South Lawn

images.altText: Andrew Jackson Statue and view of North Side of the White House
images.title: Andrew Jackson Statue and North Side of the White House

images.altText: National Christmas Christmas Tree with the view of the south side of the White House.
images.title: National Christmas Tree Lighting Ceremony 2015
images.caption: Trombone Shorty performs at the National Christmas Tree Ceremony in 2015.

images.altText: White House model and exhibit cases inside the visitor center
images.title: White House Visitor Center
images.caption: You can take a virtual tour inside the White House as well as view items on display from the White House collection in the visitor center.

emailAddresses.description: Email contact for the Superintendent: nace_superintendent@nps.gov

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to the park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo: The park is located in North East Washington D.C. south of route 50 and Baltimore Washington Parkway. The park is also within the D.C. Kenilworth community and the Anacostia river runs along the park boundary. Interstate 295 runs parallel to the park.
properties.weatherInfo:
June-September expect warm and humid weather. Average high temperatures are in the 80s, though often in the low 90s. On humid days, showers and thunderstorms often build in the late afternoon. July and August are the warmest months.

The coldest month is January, with average daytime highs in the low 40s and overnight lows in the upper 20s.
properties.name: Kenilworth Park & Aquatic Gardens
properties.description: In an age old dance wind, water, and land combine here.  Sparkling in the sun on a breezy day, this natural area of Anacostia Park has origins in a 1926 act of Congress to preserve the forests, water quality, and recreation value of the waterways of Washington, DC.  The park reflects the policies that affect rivers and wetlands.  Come, join the dance.

images.altText: Pink lotus flower blooms in a pond.
images.title: Lotus pond bloom
images.caption: Lotus flowers bloom in many ponds during the hot humid summer months.

images.altText: Aquatic ponds during the fall with trees displaying orange and yellow colors.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: As the seasons change, so do the colors around the ponds which can be seen as reflections on the water.

images.altText: Turtles basking in the sun.
images.title: Hanging around
images.caption: As the temperatures warm up during spring and summer months many reptiles including turtles can be seen basking in the sun on logs, tree stumps or the banks of the ponds.

images.altText: A woman taking a photo of lotus flowers
images.title: Capturing Moments
images.caption: The summer blooms in and around the ponds attract many photographers and artist from around the world.

images.altText: Great Blue Heron in flight over the ponds during the fall.
images.title: Flight in Fall
images.caption: The wetlands and marsh habitat many shore birds and they can be seen wading in and around the ponds for food.
