properties.directionsInfo:
Ample parking for hiking, biking and visiting the Nature Center is located at 5200 Glover Rd, NW. Administrative offices are located at 3545 Williamsburg Lane, NW.
Rock Creek Park is a large urban park stretching from the Maryland - DC border to the Potomac River. Rock  Creek Park also administers 99 separate neighborhood small sites. A large network of public roads provide access to all points administered by Rock Creek Park.

properties.weatherInfo:
Weather in D.C. is often erratic
Spring: Pleasant, Avg. High: 67° Avg. Low: 44.3°, Avg. Precipitation: 12.1”
Summer: Hot & Humid, Avg. High: 87°, Avg. Low: 66°, Avg. Precipitation: 12.7”, July is the hottest month
Fall: Pleasant, Avg. High: 69°, Avg. Low: 48.3°, Avg. Precipitation: 11.6”
Winter: Mild, Avg. High: 45°, Avg. Low: 27.3°, Avg. Precipitation: 9.3”, Avg. Snowfall: 15.4”
January is coolest month
Hurricanes may impact D.C. in late summer and fall
Light droughts are not uncommon in summer
properties.name: Rock Creek
properties.description: Rock Creek Park is truly a gem in our nation's capital. This 1,754 acre city park was officially authorized in 1890, making it the third national park to be designated by the federal government. It offers visitors the opportunity to escape the bustle of the city and find a peaceful refuge, recreation, fresh air, majestic trees, wild animals, and thousands of years of human history.

properties.directionsInfo: Pennsylvania Avenue National Historic Site is part of National Mall and Memorial Parks. The avenue is among the world's more famous streets and is known the world over as the heart of the Nation's Capital, extending through the corridors of Federal power and influence. "America's Main Street" visually connects, yet separates, the White House from the U.S. Capitol and the U.S. Supreme Court buildings.

properties.weatherInfo:
Washington DC gets to see all four seasons. Humidity will make the temps feel hotter in summer and colder in winter.

Spring (March - May) Temp: Average high is 65.5 degrees with a low of 46.5 degrees

Summer (June - August) Temp: Average high is 86 degrees with a low of 68.5 degrees

Fall (September - November) Temp: Average high is 68 degrees with a low of 51.5 degrees

Winter (December - February) Temp: Average high is 45 degrees with a low of 30 degrees

(Source: www.usclimatedata.com)

Parking
Because of limited parking availability, public transportation is recommended. Street parking is available on Constitution Ave. during posted hours.

Bicycle
Sidewalks and paved paths are open to bicycles in the park. Please walk your bicycle across the footbridge to Signers Island.

Public Transportation
Constitution Gardens is approximately 1 mile from three Metro stops: Foggy Bottom, Farragut West

properties.name: Constitution Gardens
properties.description: Officially established in 1965, National Mall and Memorial Parks actually protects some of the older parkland in the National Park System. Areas within this premier park provide visitors with ample opportunities to commemorate presidential legacies; honor the courage and sacrifice of war veterans; and celebrate the United States commitment to freedom and equality.

properties.name: Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial
properties.description: These words by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt ushered the United States into World War II and defined what it is to be an American. Stop by this secluded memorial and begin to understand the Roosevelt legacy.

images.altText: Picture of FDR in a wheel chair within his memorial
images.title: Franklin Delano Roosevelt
images.caption: From Adversity to Presidency

entranceFees.description: There are no fees for the park.
entranceFees.title: Harmony Hall

properties.directionsInfo: From the Capital Beltway (I495/95) take Exit 3 to MD 210 South/Indian Head Highway, travel approximately 4 miles to Fort Washington Road, turn right.  At the traffic light, Livingston Road, turn right.  The Harmony Hall Regional Center will be on your left.  That is where you will need to park.  After parking, when facing Livingston Road, go to your left and the park entrance is the next driveway.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. 
Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. 
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly..
properties.name: Harmony Hall
properties.description: The 18th century Harmony Hall mansion is located on a 62.5-acre open pasture land estate along the Potomac River.  This estate was purchased by the National Park Service in 1966, to preserve southern Maryland cultural heritage. Surrounded by a rich landscape, it offers visitors many chances to connect with Colonial History. The park also home to the remains of the Want Water House and canal.

images.altText: Photo Harmony Hall Mansion
images.title: Harmony Hall Mansion
images.caption: East elevation of Harmony Hall Mansion

images.altText: Photo of Harmony Hall taken in 1938
images.title: Historic Harmony Hall
images.caption: Historic image of Harmony Hall, circa 1938.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees associated with the park.
entranceFees.title: Fort Foote Park

properties.directionsInfo:
From the Beltway (I495/I95), take Exit 3, Indian Head Highway south (MD210/Indian Head Highway) and drive for approximately 3.5 miles to Old Fort Road. Turn right for 1 mile to Fort Foote Road S, turn left. Follow the winding road through the residential area to entrance sight on the left for the fort.

If driving north on MD210/Indian Head Highway turn left onto the 2nd Old Fort Road you come to (Old Fort Rd cross 210 twice).  There will be a McDonald's on your left at the correct traffic light.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning.
Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. 
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
properties.name: Fort Foote
properties.description: Fort Foote was constructed in 1863  atop Rozier's Bluff to strengthen the ring of fortifications that encircled Washington, D.C. Two of the Guns that protected Washington are still there along with the remains of the fort's earthworks.

images.caption: 15-inch Rodman Cannon

images.altText: Drawing of Fort Foote Park, depicting the fort in 1865.
images.title: Drawing of Fort Foote
images.caption: Drawing of fort in 1865.

properties.directionsInfo: Anacostia Park is located in South East Washington DC running parallel to the Anacostia river. The park can be accessed from the South Capitol bridge over the Anacostia river across from the Nationals baseball stadium. You could also enter from Pennsylvania avenue over the Anacostia river as well.

entrancePasses.description: There are no entrance passes for this park.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Passes

properties.weatherInfo: Spring brings mild temperatures and a light breeze along with springtime flower blooms. Summer can be hot and humid. Fall cools down and changing of the seasons brings changing of the colors in leaves. Winter gets cold and temperatures may drop below freezing.
properties.name: Anacostia
properties.description:
Welcome to Anacostia Park, your neighborhood national park in the heart of Washington, DC!
Enjoy exercise along the river trail or relax by the water, Anacostia Park is a breath of fresh air and a space to unwind amid a bustling city.

images.altText: Aerial view of Anacostia Drive and the playground
images.title: Anacostia Drive
images.caption: Anacostia Drive and the Anacostia river Trail run along side the Anacostia river. Views of the Navy Yard and Nats. Stadium can be seen as across the river.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to the Baltimore Washington Parkway
entranceFees.title: Entrance fee

properties.directionsInfo: This 29-mile highway connects Baltimore, MD and Washington, D.C
properties.weatherInfo:
The Washington, D.C. area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy.
Spring: During these months of transition, the weather can alternate from warm, humid air coming from the south to cold, dry air coming from the northwest. Be prepared for changing conditions.
Summer: The warmest months are June, July, and August, with average highs in the 80s (~31 ?) combined with high humidity. Temperatures often climb into the 90s (~34?).
properties.name: Baltimore-Washington
properties.description: This 29-mile highway connects Baltimore, MD and Washington, D.C. The parkway has carried visitors to and from the capital city since 1954.

images.caption: Millions enjoy the scenic entryway to the Nation's Capital

entranceFees.description: Pass is for one private, non-commercial vehicle — passenger cars, pickup trucks, RVs and vans — and is valid at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and the Great Falls Virginia side of the Potomac River.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Vehicle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Pass is for one person 16 years of age or older — entering on foot or by bicycle — and is valid at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and the Great Falls Virginia side of the Potomac River.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Bicycle or On-Foot Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Pass is for one motorcycle and is valid at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and the Great Falls Virginia side of the Potomac River.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Motorcycle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants. Fee does not include an additional charge of $10 per person.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Commercial Tour Entrance Fee (1-6 passengers)

entranceFees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Commercial Tour Entrance Fee (7-25 passengers)

entranceFees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Commercial Tour Entrance Fee (26+ passengers)

properties.directionsInfo: There are many access point along the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park. There is no main entrance. Please visit our directions page to determine how to get to your closest access point.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one full year from the month of purchase. Permits access to Great Falls Park, Virginia and the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. The annual pass allows entrance for the pass holder and additional passengers in a single private non-commercial vehicle, or pass holder plus three adults when entering on foot or bicycle.
entrancePasses.title: Great Falls Annual Pass

properties.weatherInfo: The Washington, DC, area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. Precipitation averages 2-4” monthly, year-round. The climate gradually gets cooler and wetter further west along the canal where the elevation is higher.
properties.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal
properties.description: Preserving America's early transportation history, the C&O Canal began as a dream of passage to Western wealth. Operating for nearly 100 years the canal was a lifeline for communities along the Potomac River as coal, lumber, and agricultural products floated down the waterway to market. Today it endures as a pathway for discovering historical, natural, and recreational treasures.

images.altText: Park sign in front of the historic Bowles House
images.title: Hancock Visitor Center (Bowles House)
images.caption: One of seven Park visitor centers, the Bowles House sits along an empty canal bed in Hancock.

images.altText: Fog over the Potomac River alongside the Canal towpath.
images.title: Big Slackwater
images.caption: Big Slackwater is a 3 mile stretch where canal boats entered the Potomac River to travel above Dam 4.

images.altText: A whitewashed lockhouse sits above a stone lock with wooden crib.
images.title: Lockhouse 16 along the Canal
images.caption: Lockhouse 16 sits atop a stone outcropping above the lock.

images.altText: A single bike rider on the towpath next to the widewater section of the canal.
images.title: Bike rider along the towpath
images.caption: The towpath offers a serene bike riding experience.

images.altText: The rushing river cascades over the rocks of the Potomac
images.title: Great Falls of the Potomac
images.caption: The area of Great Falls is one of the reasons for the C&O Canal needed to be built for boat traffic.

images.altText: A replica double decker canal boat is being pulled upstream by mules.
images.title: Charles F. Mercer Replica Canal Boat
images.caption: Mule-drawn canal boat rides are offered at Great Falls Tavern, April through October.

properties.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park

Fort Washington no longer has an entrance fee.  

There is still a reservation fee for the Reserved Picnic Areas, www.recreation.gov
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance Fee

properties.directionsInfo:
From I-95/495 take exit 3, Indian Head Highway South/MD 210. Travel about 4 miles to Fort Washington Road, turn right. The park is located at the end of the road.

From Waldorf, MD: MD228 to Indian Head Highway/MD210 North. Turn left onto Old Fort Road. Continue to end of road, at the stop sign turn left onto Fort Washington Road, continue to park entrance.
properties.weatherInfo:
Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning.
Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. 
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
properties.name: Fort Washington
properties.description: Built to defend the river approach to  Washington, DC, Fort Washington has stood as silent sentry for over 200 years. As technologies advanced so did Fort Washington, from the brick and stone of the 19th century to the concrete and steel of the 20th century.  Joining the National Park Service in 1946, the park continues to protect the Potomac River.

images.altText: Picnic Area at Fort Washington Park
images.title: Picnic Area A at Fort Washington Park
images.caption: Picnic Area A is one of the areas available to reserve.

images.altText: Fort Washington Volunteers firing a cannon

images.caption: Fort Washington Guard fires one of the park's cannons.  Demonstrations are presented during the summer months April-October.
